On 15 April 2020, a lynch mob killed two suspected thieves in Buhayo village (Kisoro district), after they were caught stealing potatoes from a garden. One person has been arrested in connection with the killings. [size=no report]

On 15 April 2020, a vigilante mob attacked a private security guard in Kigogwa (Wakiso district), after the guard shot and wounded a former employee of the place he was stationed at (in an inter-personal dispute). The security guarded was seriously wounded, and taken to hospital. [size=no report]

On 16 April 2020, vendors and business owners in Hoima town (Hoima district) rioted following attempts by UPDF and police to enforce coronavirus lockdown measures, which would prevent the traders from operating. 22 vendors were arrested. [size=at least 22]

As reported on 16 April 2020, a number of violent cattle raids attributed to Karamajong raiders were reported in unspecified parts of Katakwi district over the previous two week period, which included abductions, shootings and incidents of sexual violence (presumed to be against women). The source does not mention whether there were fatalities.

column8: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 17 April 2020, suspected Jie raiders clashed with LDU paramilitaries at unspecified areas near Kaabong town and in Kaabong West subcounty (Kaabong district). The paramilitaries ""repulsed"" the raiders; the source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.

On 17 April 2020, Karamajong raiders armed with bows attempted to raid cattle from Lachua East, Leladwong and Locum in Paimol subcounty (Agogo district), wounding six farmers. The attackers do not appear to have stolen any cattle.

On 18 April 2020, a police officer shot a boda boda driver in the legs in the area of Kamonkoli (Budaka district), with the driver later dying at Mbale hospital. The driver did not stop for the officer, who was enforcing travel restrictions relating to coronavirus lockdown measures. The officer has been detained.

On 18 April 2020, police attempting to arrest a UPDF officer in connection with a criminal offence were attacked by a mob of residents at Lagile parish (Pader district). Police opened fire on the crowd, wounding three, one of whom died of their injuries later that day. The suspect escaped. [size=at least three]

On 19 April 2020, an unspecified group destroyed property and crops at a disputed area of land in Kichwamba subcounty (Kabarole district), evicting residents of the land in spite of a moratorium on land evictions during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

column9: PP: People Power; Government of Uganda (1986-); Prisoners (Uganda)
column17: On 19 April 2020, police arrested Francis Zaake MP of the People Power movement in Mityana (Mityana district) after he distributed coronavirus food relief. The MP is reported to have been tortured in police custody (in at least two locations), with one report suggesting he had been blinded after an unknown substance was sprayed into his eyes during detention. A court has ordered that police take the MP to hospital.
On 20 April 2020, residents of Namungoona (Kampala) demonstrated, calling for the government to distribute coronavirus relief food. Police arrested two demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 20 April 2020, a police officer and the Amuru district RDC's driver allegedly beat and robbed two charcoal traders at an unspecified location in Amuru district, before detaining them for three days in Amuru town. The charcoal dealers claim that they were abused on suspicion of recording an illegal transaction with the RDC, involving a bribe to release merchandise. The RDC is disputing the claim.

On 20 April 2020, market vendors demonstrated at the RDC's office in Mbarara town (Mbarara district), in opposition to the ongoing closure of their market, which has been shut due to coronavirus lockdown measures. [size=no report]

On 22 April 2020, over twenty residents (including boda boda drivers) demonstrated at the LC1 chairperson's office in Kasese town (Kasese district), calling for the government to distribute food relief. The group comprises poor and disabled groups, who have been unable to obtain food due to coronavirus lockdown measures. [size=over twenty]

Around 22 April 2020 (week of), UPDF clashed with suspected Karamajong cattle raiders at an unspecified location in Orom subcounty (Kitgum district), killing two. A civilian was also wounded by the raiders, though it is unclear if this was in the same raid or another raid in Orom. Note that deserters from Local Defence Unit paramilitary forces have also been implicated in recent raiding activities in the area.

On 22 April 2020, two mothers and their eleven children camped outside the RDC office in Luwero (Luwero district) in protest at the lack of food and income engendered by the coronavirus lockdown measures. The protest lasted for two days, before the demonstrators were given food, and left the office. [size=13]

On 23 April 2020, supporters of the RDC for Jinja demonstrated in Jinja town (Jinja district) upon hearing news that he had been arrested in connection with a murder case. Police dispersed the supporters with tear gas. [size=no report]

On 25 April 2020, supporters of the RDC for Jinja demonstrated at the courthouse in Jinja town (Jinja district), calling for his release after he had been arrested in connection with a murder case. The demonstrators broke into the (empty) courthouse. [size=no report]

On 26 April 2020, an elderly man was beheaded and dismembered by a group of eight armed men at Ongedo village in Palaro subcounty (Gulu district), in violence which is related to a land dispute. The disputant (who had been arrested with three others) was wounded during the attack. [size=8]

On 28 April 2020, 20 youths demonstrated at the RDC's office in Luwero (Luwero district), after loosing their income due to coronavirus lockdown measures. Police arrested 2, and the remaining demonstrators fled. [size=20]

On 1 May 2020, dozens of youth attempted to kill a murder suspect (and potentially the suspect's family) in Bugembe (Jinja district), torching his house. Police and UPDF intervened and dispersed the lynch mob with tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air), and rescued the suspect and his family. [size=dozens]
On 2 May 2020, a lynch mob attacked a suspected thief in Kakiri (Wakiso district), beating him and cutting off his leg. Police intervened to rescue the victim. [size=no report]

Around 3 May 2020, police arrested an elderly man who was drinking with others in breach of the coronavirus curfew in Kabafukuzi village in Nabingoola subcounty (Mubende district). The police allegedly tortured the man whilst in in their custody, and he died as a result of the torture. Two police have been arrested.

On 4 May 2020, a lynch mob (comprising market vendors) threatened to kill a UPDF soldier attempting to solicit bribes at Mututumba market in Masafu sub-county (Busia district). Police fired shots to disperse the mob (shots presumed to be have been fired into the air) and rescued the soldier. [size=no report]

On 4 May 2020, residents of Kasese district (including widows) demonstrated at the RDC's office in Kasese town (Kasese district), calling for food relief. The protesters claimed that food relief (distributed under coronavirus lockdown measures) was not reaching them, and was instead being sent to those who were less in need. [size=no report]
On 4 May 2020, UPDF and Karamajong fighters clashed at an unspecified area of Kaabong district, with one UPDF soldier killed. The raiders then stole an unspecified number of cattle.

On 5 May 2020, two Acholi clan militias (the Palaro and Lukwor) armed with hand weapons clashed in Omunyjubi in Binya parish (Omoro district), as part of a land dispute in which Lukwor clansmen invaded the Palaro area. 4 were injured.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: Around 6 May 2020 (week of), LDU paramilitaries beat and extorted a civilian in Gulu town (Gulu district), ostensibly under coronavirus lockdown measures. Various abuses have been reported by the paramilitaries in different divisions of the town, though without dates being provided.
On 8 May 2020, suspected Lango raiders from South Sudan attacked Lotuku village in Madi Opei subcounty (Lamwo district), wounding two, and stole a small number of cows.

On 8 May 2020, suspected Karamajong militiamen killed a doctor (who worked for an international NGO) at Turutuko in Napak district in the tri-border area between Abim, Napak, and Kotido districts. There is no further information.

On 8 May 2020, UPDF soldiers killed a civilian in Kyeigombe (Bushenyi district), ostensibly whilst enforcing coronavirus lockdown measures. The soldiers were also reported to have gang raped a woman. Authorities appear to have arrested four soldiers, whilst others have fled the area.
On 9 May 2020, unknown attackers wounded three at Oluba village in Ongako sub-county (Omoro district), in what is reported to be a land dispute. There is no further information.

On 10 May 2020, over 100 families camped outside the house of Betty Aol Ocan (the Leader of the Opposition) in Gulu (Gulu district), in protest at the lack of food that has been provided under coronavirus relief measures. [size=over 100]
On 10 May 2020, youth attacked and killed a health worker at or near Olwiyo village in Alero sub-county (Nwoya district), in what is reported to have been a land dispute. Five have been arrested.

column8: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 10 May 2020, LDU paramilitaries shot dead a man and seriously wounded another in Kapkwata (Kween district), whilst enforcing the coronavirus lockdown. Officials claim that the LDU soldiers attempted to break up a crowd of men who were drinking at the house of the deceased, and that the man (several men, according to one source) drew a machete on the LDUs, whilst throwing stones at them. One LDU has been arrested. [size=at least several]

column7: Lobi Clan Militia (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column9: Palaa Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: On 11 May 2020, members of the Pukwong and Lobi clans of the Acholi attacked the Palaa Acholi clan at an unspecified location in Padibe East subcounty (Lamwo district), torching 18 dwellings, killing animals and looting property. The attack is reported to be related to a land dispute.
On 11 May 2020, over 80 health workers protested against a lack of pay owed to them at Kuluva hospital (Arua district), and announced they were on strike. [size=over 80]
On 11 May 2020, boda boda and taxi drivers protested at the office of the RDC in Wakiso town (Wakiso district), decrying the lack of food provided under coronavirus relief measures. [size=no report]

On 12 May 2020, unknown attackers wounded a man at the Patic area of Atyak (Zombo district), before torching 15 dwellings. Over 600 were displaced in the attack. The attack is linked to a land dispute; the suspects are reported to have fled to the DRC.

On 13 May 2020, a police officer fired at a boda boda driver in Jinja (Jinja district), after the driver refused to stop for the officer, who was enforcing the coronavirus lockdown in the area. A female market vendor who was travelling on the motorbike was hit, and died of her injuries two days later.

Around 13 May 2020 (week of), Karamajong raiders attacked Okameta village on the Napak side of the Napak-Katakwi border. The attackers burned dwellings and stole livestock, displacing over 250 Teso residents (some to Ongongja subcounty in Katakwi). The source notes that several Bokora elites have been arrested on suspicion of masterminding the attack, in order to re-take the land they had previously sold to its current residents.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 13 May 2020, LDU paramilitaries and police threatened to shoot a food vendor in Wantoni (Mukono district), for selling food during the coronavirus lockdown. A headteacher intervened to rescue the food vendor, but was shot dead by authorities.

column9: Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda); Pukwong Clan Group (Uganda); Lobi Clan Group (Uganda)
column17: On 14 May 2020, members of the Palaa clan of the Acholi (armed with basic weapons) attacked the Pukwong and Lobi clans of the Acholi at an unspecified location(s) of Padibe East subcounty (Lamwo district), seriously wounding five, and torching around 150 dwellings. The attack is in retaliation for an attack three days prior, which is said to be connected to a land dispute.

On 14 May 2020, residents of Mukono district (including women, who are prominent in the source) blocked a vehicle carrying a local official at Wantoni (Mukono district) in protest at not receiving food under coronavirus relief measures. Police and LDUs arrived and allowed the official to complete his journey, though do not appear to have intervened directly. [size=no report]

column7: Lobi Clan Militia (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: On 15 May 2020, Acholi clans (assumed Palaa, Lobi and Pukwong) staged a series of raids against each other in Padibe East subcounty (Lamwo district), torching 70 of each others dwellings. The attacks follow violence on 14 and 11 May, in fighting reportedly linked to a land dispute.

On 15 May 2020, over 60 HIV positive residents of Gulu town (Gulu district) protested at the house of a local official in the town, decrying the lack of food provided under coronavirus relief measures. [size=more than 60]
On 15 May 2020, UPDF and Karamajong fighters clashed at an unspecified area of Nadunget sub-county (Moroto district), killing two Karamajong. There is no further information.

On 17 May 2020, police shot and wounded a civilian in the stomach, after they attempted to disperse youth playing football in violation of coronavirus lockdown measures at Omi village in Aroi sub-county (Arua district). Police claim that the victim attempted to grab a weapon from them.

On 18 May 2020, protesters - including a prominent feminist critic of the President - gathered in Kampala to contest abuses by state security organs during the coronavirus lockdown and a lack of food being distributed to the public. Police forcefully arrested five (including the prominent critic). [size=at least five]

On 18 May 2020, unspecified security operatives (presumed to be police) shot a Muslim cleric twice in the leg at Masaka town (Masaka district), amid a spate of arrests against Muslim clerics in the town. The whereabouts of the victim are unknown.

On 18 May 2020, members of the Alur group clashed with armed Acholi at Obira village in Todura parish (Nwoya district), as part of a long-running land dispute. Gunshots were fired (though it appears that nobody was wounded), and three dwellings torched.

On 19 May 2020, police arrested and severely beat 16 civilians (including members of a construction company) at Rwigwe parish in Nyakabande subcounty (Kisoro district), for organising a football match in break of coronavirus lockdown measures.
On 19 May 2020, an unknown group from Zombo district attacked a police post at Otheko (Zombo district), torching the station buildings after earlier sending a letter demanding guns from the police.

On 20 May 2020, residents of Tegwana parish Gulu town (Gulu district) attacked a team appointed by the government who were distributing food under coronavirus relief measures. The source implies the attackers had not received food. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
column17: Around 20 May 2020 (week of), suspected Karamajong fighters attacked a UWA outpost at Moru Alokwamgat in Panyangara subcounty (Kotido district). The attackers were able to steal a small amount of weaponry and ammunition. The source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.
On 20 May 2020, police attacked four journalists in Fort Portal (Kabarole district), ostensibly for breaching coronavirus lockdown measures.

column16: Acholi Times; West Nile Web; URN (Uganda); Red Pepper (Uganda)
column17: On 21 May 2020, men in military uniform (presumed to be UPDF) engaged with members Alur ethnic group at Obira (Nwoya district), killing four Alur and wounding at least 5 (one sources says dozens). Conflicting accounts of the events - which are linked to a long-running land dispute - suggest either that forces connected to a local UPDF general attacked civilians they accused of trespassing (and burned dwellings and looted from the victims), or that around 80 Alur militiamen armed with basic weapons attacked the soldiers, leading to a firefight.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Fisheries Protection Unit
column17: On 21 May 2020, FPU soldiers shot and wounded a fishmonger riding a motorcycle in Labori sub-county (Serere district), after he refused to stop for an inspection.

On 21 May 2020, unknown raiders abducted three civilians and stole 15 head of cattle at one or more of the locations of Oforo, Atoro and Kampala landing site in Amuru subcounty (Amuru district). Around 1,000 have been displaced between this event and another on 25 May.

On 21 May 2020, Karamajong raiders attacked the police post at Kangole (Napak district), resulting in a thirty minute gun battle. There is no clear motive for the attack, and the source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.

column7: Pajong Clan Militia (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Militia (Uganda)
column9: Pajong Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: Around 24 May 2020, members of the Palwo Acholi clan operating in conjunction with are described as ""disgruntled"" members of the Pajong clan attacked Pajong clan civilians in the Alima Lagot area (Kitgum district), wounding 21. The attack is linked to a land dispute between the clans.

On 25 May 2020, unknown raiders attacked one or more of the locations of Oforo, Atoro and Kampala landing site in Amuru subcounty (Amuru district), stealing 25 head of cattle. Around 1,000 have been displaced between this event and another on 21 May.
On 26 May 2020, a lynch mob killed a man in Pumuzika in Budongo subcounty (Masindi district), on the suspicion that he was involved in the poisoning of a neighbour. [size=no report]

On 26 May 2020, over 200 boda boda drivers protested at District HQ in Kabale (Kabale district), calling for the government to provide them with food following the reduction of their income due to coronavirus lockdown measures. [size=over two hundred]
On 26 May 2020, UPDF clashed with Karamajong raiders rustling cattle at an unspecified location in Kotido district, killing three Karamajong, and retrieving 70 head of cattle.

column6: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
column17: Around 27 May 2020 (as reported), UWA park rangers shot and wounded two farmers in the Moyok area of Mount Elgon National Park in or near Kwayiny subcounty (Kween district). Officials have claimed that a mob was approaching, forcing the rangers to flee and to fire their weapons in the air, with the bullets hitting both men. Residents have disputed this version of events, saying the two men were fired upon when they approached the rangers to secure the release of animals that had earlier been impounded.

column9: Women (Uganda); Jaka Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: On 27 May 2020, members of the Kal clan of the Acholi raided Abuturu village in Lalogi subcounty (Omoro district), torching dwellings belonging to the Jaka clan. A pregnant woman was also assaulted, cattle stolen, and dozens displaced. The attack is linked to a land dispute between the clans.
Around 27 May 2020 (as reported), a Burundian man was killed by a lynch mob at Katiema village in the area of Kijunjubwa (Masindi district), after he was found with two stolen goats. [size=no report]
Around 27 May 2020 (week of), Jie cattle raiders clashed with UPDF at Nargengepak (Kaabong district). One Jie raider was killed.

On 27 May 2020, at least 14 individuals attacked a joint UPDF and police team enforcing the coronavirus curfew measures at Gala Trading Centre in the area of Gala (Kayankwanzi district), wounding one soldier. The police fired at the crowd, killing one. Another body was found the following day, although the deceased was said to have died from natural causes. 12 others were arrested. [size=at least 14]

column7: Vigilante Group (Uganda); Okadameri Clan Group (Uganda); Lango Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: On 28 May 2020, a mob from the Okadameri Lango clan attacked the house of an accused murderer and his village of Amunomia pii in Chegere subcounty (Apac district), in retaliation for the murder of one of their kin. The attackers torched buildings (rendering 50 homeless), destroyed property, and displaced an unspecified number. Police intervened, though it was not reported if they engaged in the use of force. [size=no report]
Around 28 May 2020 (as reported), a soldier was witnessed kicking a civilian in the head in Gulu (Gulu district), ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures.

On 28 May 2020, journalists protested at the office of the Resident District Commissioner in Kabale (Kabale district), against harassment by authorities under the pretext of coronavirus lockdown measures. [size=no report]
Around 30 May 2020, a communal militia from Paimol county killed a Karamajong raider at Ananga (near Lachua) in Paimol county (Agago district).

column9: Palwo Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda); Women (Uganda)
column17: Around 30 May 2020 (as reported), six women and five children from the Palwo Acholi clan were rescued from their Pajong clan captors at an unspecified location near Alima Lagot (Kitgum district), where they had been abducted and held captive for an unspecified time. The women had been beaten whilst in captivity. The attack is linked to a land dispute between the clans.

column9: Pajong Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda); Farmers (Uganda)
column17: On 30 May 2020, a farmer belonging to the Pajong Acholi clan was killed by members of the Palwo clan armed with hand weapons and bows at Odongloo village in the Alima Lagot area (Kitgum district). The attack is linked to a land dispute.

column16: Daily Monitor (Uganda); Radio Tamazuj; Eye Radio (South Sudan)
column17: On 30 May 2020, UPDF intercepted a small group of South Sudanese soldiers (including one police officer) who had been reported to be harassing Ugandan civilians at Maru in Goboro parish (Yumbe district). Uganda authorities stated that they were fired upon by the South Sudanese and returned fire, killing three (with a fourth dying of injuries after several days). The bodies of the deceased were handed to South Sudanese authorities.

On 1 June 2020, over 200 Alur demonstrators marched towards Pakwach from Nwoya district, in protest at abuses inflicted upon Alur residents of the area by security forces in a violent land dispute. The demonstrators were stopped before they crossed Pakwach bridge between Nwoya and Pakwach districts by police and UPDF. [size=over 200]

column7: Taxi Drivers (Uganda); Government of Uganda (1986-); FDC: Forum for Democratic Change
column17: On 1 June 2020, hundreds of demonstrators (including boda boda drivers) gathered in Gulu town (Gulu district) to denounce increasing coronavirus cases, which the demonstrators were attributing to truck drivers. Some of the demonstrators burned tires on the main road leading to the South Sudanese border. Police arrested several ringleaders, including two MPs (affiliated with the FDC). [size=hundreds]

On 2 June 2020, over 200 workers from the water facility at Katosi (Mukono district) demonstrated upon discovering that parts of their salaries had been withheld, and without explanation. Police persuaded the protesters to leave (but did not intervene directly), after assuring the demonstrators they would investigate that the matter with the managers of the plant. [size=over 200]

Around 2 June 2020, raiders from Karamajong were intercepted by a vigilante militia (comprising farmers armed with bows) in the Kokil area of Paimol sub-county (Agogo district), with two Karamajong killed by the militia.
On 2 June 2020, UPDF ambushed Kenyan Turkana raiders at an unspecified location in Kamion sub-county (Kaabong district), killing 4 and wounding several others.

column9: Palwo Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: On 5 June 2020, members of the Pajong Acholi clan attacked the Palwo clan village of Latuturu (Kitgum county), torching around 43 huts and destroying food stores and crops. The attack is linked to a land dispute between the clans; hundreds of residents had already fled the area in anticipation of the attack.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 5 June 2020, LDU paramilitaries began beating residents of Arua town (Arua district) found loitering, ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures. A private security guard, who was among the group being beaten, left the scene and returned with a bow, and shot an LDU officer in the head, seriously wounding him. The guard is at large.

On 8 June 2020, a lynch mob attempted to kill a traditional healer they believed had cursed a village at an unspecified location implied to be close to Bumanya in Kaliro district. Police intervened and fired live rounds to disperse the demonstrators, killing one. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column9: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Anti-Stock Theft Unit
column17: On 8 June 2020, LDU and members of the Police Anti-Stock Theft Unit clashed with Pokot cattle raiders at an unspecified location in Sundet sub-county (Kween district), killing one raider.

On 8 June 2020, UPDF with local militia (presumed to be Acholi) clashed with Karamajong raiders in the area of Mora in Ngora parish Paimol sub-county (Agago district) whilst attempting to recover stolen cattle. It is unclear if there were injuries or fatalities, which are not mentioned in the source. 54 head of cattle were recovered.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 9 June 2020, an LDU paramilitary severely beat a heavily pregnant woman in Arua (Arua district), ostensibly whilst enforcing coronavirus measures.

On 10 June 2020, raiders from Adilang, armed with hand weapons, attacked Kamurono village on the Abim side of the Abim-Adilang district borders, amid what is described as an ethnicized land dispute. The attackers wounded six and torched dozens of houses. A police officer shot and wounded one of the attackers after stones were thrown at the officer.

On 10 June 2020, truck drivers demonstrated in Fort Portal (Kabarole district), denouncing the failure of local authorities to clean drainage ditches at their lorry park, which have filled with stagnant water. [size=no report]
On 11 June 2020, youth (including boda boda drivers) demonstrated in Arua (Arua district) against restrictions placed upon bodas under coronavirus guidelines. [size=no report]

On 12 June 2020, a group attempted to seize land belonging to a farmer in Okwii in Bobbi sub-county (Omoro district), attacking the family of the farmer and destroying their crops and several buildings. The attack is linked to a land dispute.

On 12 June 2020, two groups of South Sudanese refugees (from the Liki and Fatak clans, from an unknown Equatorian ethnic group) clashed in Yoro camp (Arua district), after a relative of a woman from the Fatak clan who became pregnant confronted the man suspected of being the father (from the Liki clan). The family of the father attacked the brother (who died later of his wounds), sparking a fight in the camp. 17 have been arrested. [size=at least 18]
On 13 June 2020, UPDF clashed with Kenyan Turkana pastoralists at Logumasiroi parish in Loyoro sub-county (Kaabong district), leaving one UPDF soldier and one civilian wounded.

On 14 June 2020, police officers were filmed severely beating a shop vendor in Kyaliwajjala (Wakiso district). The vendor had been arrested the previous day for keeping his shop open past the coronavirus curfew, but escaped the police station the same night, before returning to the station on the 14th to collect his phone (which he alleged was stolen by the police officers).

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a group suspected of coming from Kasese district attacked Kisogi village (likely near Rwano in the parish of Kabonero, Bunyangabu district), killing one and wounding three. It is believed that the attackers were avenging a relative of theirs who had been murdered in the area.
On 21 June 2020, protesters demonstrated against the poor ambulance service in Orom sub-county, and an unspecified location within the Orom area (Kitgum district). [size=no report]

column9: Private Security Forces (Uganda); Government of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On 21 June 2020, residents demonstrated in the Kirundamarigga area of Lwanda (Rakai district) against the poor condition of the main road in the area. Upon spotting the RDC of Rakai, demonstrators blocked the road with logs, telling the RDC to use the main road he neglected, and insisted he pay them money. Youth attacked the RDC and his security guard when he refused; he subsequently provided money to the demonstrators. [size=no report]

column9: Labour Group (Uganda); Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On 22 June 2020, demonstrators, led by the FDC party chairman for Buikwe district, protested by banding pots and pans at a market in Lugazi (Buikwe district), as part of a joint People Power and FDC initiative to broadcast levels of hunger in the country and highlight the failure of authorities to provide coronavirus relief food. A mob of market vendors assaulted the demonstrators, wounding three. Two other protesters were arrested by police. [size=at least five]

On 23 June 2020, clashes between Nuer and Lango refugees from South Sudan broke out in Zone 4 Block 6 of Palabek Refugee Camp (Lamwo district), with one Nuer wounded with a bladed weapon. The clash is reported to be linked to contested land that was given to refugees by the local community.

On 23 June 2020, an unknown group threw a petrol bomb at a government vehicle in Nateete (Wakiso), as part of a spate of similar, organised attacks by the group in the Greater Kampala area. One person from the group has so far been arrested.

On 24 June 2020, clashes continued between Nuer and Lango refugees from South Sudan in Palabek Refugee Camp (Lamwo district), leaving 20 wounded (2 seriously) and 1 member of the Lango group dead. 2 people have been arrested for their role in the violence, including the leader of a refugee block.

On 24 June 2020, over 100 protesters marched from Aboko village to Aduku (Kwania district), in opposition to the recent arrest of seven suspects relating to a lynch mob attack in December. Police dispersed the demonstrators with live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air). [size=over 100]

Around 24 June 2020 (week of), an unknown group attacked a government vehicle in Katwe (Kampala) with a hammer, as part of a spate of organised attacks by the group in the Greater Kampala area. The vehicle was damaged, but the driver was unharmed. One person from the group has so far been arrested.

On 24 June 2020, a lay reader was shot dead by a UPDF soldier at Karungibate near Hima (Kasese district) as he was travelling with his wife to their garden on a motorbike. Two soldiers - who were reported to have been enforcing the coronavirus directives - have been arrested. The wife of the deceased has disputed the army's claim that her husband failed to stop for the soldiers, and was herself injured when she fell onto the tarmac.

On 26 June 2020, journalists protested outside of the Radio Wa offices in Lira (Lira district), calling for the director of the station to be removed due to alleged mismanagement and nepotism. [size=no report]

column7: PP: People Power; Taxi Drivers (Uganda); Lawyers (Uganda)
column17: On 26 June 2020, a legal officer with People Power mobilised protesters, including boda boda drivers, at Iganda (Iganda district), to criticise the government for failing to provide food under its coronavirus relief measures, whilst also calling for boda drivers to be permitted to work in the evenings (currently prohibited due to the partial lockdown). Police arrested the People Power mobiliser. [size=no report]

Around 26 June 2020 (as reported), a lynch mob attacked the dwelling of a suspected thief at Kabasombwa village near Lwampanga (Nakasongola district), and stoned him to death as he attempted to escape. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2020, an unknown group threw a petrol bomb at a government vehicle in Busega (Kampala), as part of a spate of similar organised attacks by the group in the Greater Kampala area. One person from the group has so far been arrested.

On 27 June 2020, private security guards, supported by a vigilante mob, attacked a student at Makerere University (Kampala), having mistaken him for a thief. The victim died on 4 July from wounds sustained during the attack. Conflicting (though unconfirmed) reports claim that police officers were also involved, and fired gun shots. 13 suspects have been arrested (3 security guards, 10 youth).

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 27 June 2020, LDU paramilitaries dispersed civilians gathering at Amati Trading Centre (Oyam district), before severely beating an elderly man who was unable to leave, ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures. The victim died of his wounds after arriving at a health centre.

On 28 June 2020, a mob beat a South Sudanese refugee in Lobenga village (Yumbe district), after he was accused of being a thief. The victim died later of his wounds after police ordered the crowd to take the man to hospital. Two people have so far been arrested. [size=no report]

column7: Government of Uganda (1986-); DP: Democratic Party
column17: On 29 June 2020, protesters demonstrated in Munyonyo (Kampala) against the demolition of a local market. Police from the Environment Protection unit arrested a protesting DP MP, who they accused of ""inciting violence"". [size=no report]
On 29 June 2020, dozens of villagers attacked a man who was accused of beating his wife at Ayegero in Atana parish (Apac district), beating the man to death. [size=dozens]

On 29 June 2020, a lynch mob killed a suspected thief in Nyamba village of Kabero subcounty (presumed to be near to Rwimi, Bunyangabu district, based on contextual information in the source), prompting relatives of the deceased to form their own lynch mob, killing two of the initial attackers (one of whom died shortly after the attack), and seriously wounding three. [size=at least 5]
On 30 June 2020, boda boda drivers demonstrated in Bududa town (Bududa district) against violent police behaviour towards them in the context of upholding the coronavirus lockdown. [size=no report]

On 30 June 2020, Karamajong raiders clashed with a self-defence militia (presumed to be Acholi) in Lapetak village of Loliya parish (Kitgum district). The Karamajong shot and killed three (one of whom died shortly after being shot), before fleeing.

On 1 July 2020, male patients under quarantine (as a coronavirus precaution measure) in Masaka hospital (Masaka district) protested against a lack of food and the introduction of new patients with existing ones. The patients banged doors and windows, and were reported to have caused a stampede. [size=no report]

Around 1 July 2020 (as reported), a lynch mob killed a Rwandan man suspected of killing three children the previous day, likely in the area of Butemba sub-county in Kyankwanzi district. [size=no report]

On 1 July 2020, an armed Karamajong group attacked miners at Nakabaat (Moroto district), in an apparent act of retaliation after residents reported them to authorities. 1 was killed and dozens wounded; over 1,000 fled to nearby Nakiloro. The attackers also looted from the miners.

On 2 July 2020, a group of nine men began demolishing nine houses at Makindye (Kampala) during hours of darkness in what appears to be a forced eviction. Police fired upon the men after they refused to stop, killing one, and causing the others to flee.

column9: Bokora Ethnic Militia (Uganda); Jie Ethnic Militia (Uganda)
column17: On 2 July 2020, UPDF soldiers (as well as an unspecified military aircraft) pursued and intercepted around 500 raiders from the Matheniko, Bokora and Jie ethnic groups at the eastern border with between Kaabong district and the Turkana region of Kenya. ""Several"" raiders were reported to have been killed, and two UPDF wounded. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

On 2 July 2020, a Madi militia armed with bows and hand weapons attacked dwellings at or near Ocea (Terego district), as part of a land dispute reignited by the creation of the new Terego district. Three houses were destroyed; a violent clash between youth from Terego and the Madi was averted by authorities. 17 members of Madi militia were arrested.

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: On 3 July 2020, SPLM-IO soldiers were reported to have abused four Ugandan civilians in the Ludara area along the South Sudanese border (Koboko district), with two civilians tortured at their homes at Gidogidonga village (on suspicion of harbouring IO deserters), and two farmers beaten at the edge of the border.

On 3 July 2020, demonstrators blocked a street in Fort Portal (Kabarole district) with rocks, to highlight the failure of the contractor undertaking roadworks to limit dust, coating the area in dust. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of South Sudan (2011-) Tiger Division
column17: Around 5 July 2020 (as reported), seven South Sudanese soldiers (including at least from the Tiger Division) clashed with UPDF patrolling the border in Amuru district near Nimule town, with one UPDF soldier wounded in the leg. The South Sudanese soldiers were reported to have been smuggling narcotics when they encountered the patrol. Two South Sudanese have been arrested, including one civilian.

column9: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit; Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On 6 July 2020, boda boda drivers demonstrated against coronavirus lockdown measures in Busia town (Busia district), burning tires on the roads. Police, UPDF, and LDU paramilitaries fired live rounds and tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]

column6: SPLM-In Opposition: Sudan People's Liberation Movement-In Opposition
column17: Around 6 July 2020 (as reported), SPLM-IO forces were reported to have bombed two houses in Busia village in Nyambiri parish (Koboko). The source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities, and does not provide a motive.
On 7 July 2020, a lynch mob killed a man in Ntaawo (Mukono district). There is no further information. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 7 July 2020, UPDF and LDU paramilitaries beat a woman in Mityana town (Mityana district), ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures. A local government official intervened, prompting the soldiers to beat him, in an event which was recorded and caused widespread outrage. 4 soldiers have been arrested.

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 7 July 2020, an LDU paramilitary beat a civilian with a rifle magazine near Njeru Stock Farm near Bukaya (Buikwe district), ostensibly as part of coronavirus lockdown measures. The victim is in a coma.

On 7 July 2020, unknown attackers entered the barracks at Mubende town (Mubende district), assaulting a UPDF soldier and stealing his weapon. The soldier died several hours later (on 8 July) from injuries sustained.

On 8 July 2020, demonstrators (including market vendors, and a prominent academic activist) protested against the effects of the coronavirus lockdown measures on the income of vendors in Nakasero (Kampala). Police arrested the prominent academic. [size=no report]
On 9 July 2020, a lynch mob attacked a suspected thief in Kiduuka (Kampala), the suspected thief survived the attack. [size=no report]

On 10 July 2020, around 200 FDC supporters gathered for a rally in the Kasokoso neighbourhood of Kampala (Wakiso district). Police fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to have been fired into the air) to disperse the crowds and arrested 3, including the speaker of the FDC, ostensibly as part of coronavirus reinforcement measures. [size=about 200]

On 11 July 2020, more than 50 youths staged a rally in Arua (Arua district) in support of a local businessman seeking to run for political office in the city. Police dispersed the youth. [size=more than 50]

On 11 July 2020, police and UPDF fired tear gas at a crowd on People Power supporters who had assembled in Jinja (Jinja district) upon hearing that Bobi Wine MP was present at a radio station in the city. Youths engaged in running battles with state forces. No demonstration activity was reported at the time. [size=no report]

column9: CNL: National Congress for Liberation; Refugees/IDPs (Burundi)
column17: Around 12 July 2020 (as reported), the body of a Burundian refugee from Kashojwa B Village was found at an unspecified location near Nakivale lake (Isingiro district), having been beaten and strangled by unknown perpetrators. The victim was a member of the CNL: National Congress for Liberation, and prior to that a member of the FNL. The killing is suspected to be linked to his political status.

Around 12 July 2020 (as reported), a Ugandan civilian was abducted by Rwandan soldiers at Mushenyi (Kabale district), with the soldiers (who had crossed the border in pursuit of smugglers) allegedly saying the man was a Rwandan national pretending to be Uganda. The incident follows tension in the border area for the past year, linked to security disputes involving the two countries.

On 13 July 2020, two Acholi clans (the Lamogi Payugu and the Pawel clans) clashed in several villages in the area of Layima village, including the villages of Rec ki Ceke, Atiti, Acwera and Lakang, in what is described as a land dispute. 13 were wounded (3 seriously) in this clash and taken to health centres in Oberabic and Lacor (Amuru district). Homes were destroyed and at least 215 displaced, and livestock and property looted.

On 13 July 2020, a prominent academic and at least two students from Makerere University demonstrated at the parliament building in Kampala, calling for a full investigation into an attack on a student in June (which ultimately killed the student). Police arrested the academic and one of the students. [size=at least three]

On 13 July 2020, a lynch mob attacked two residents of Kihorongwa village close to Lake Bunyonyi in Rubaya subcounty (Kabale district), as part of a land eviction. Police fired tear gas to disperse the mob. [size=no report]

column7: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column9: Kuku Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column16: URN (Uganda); West Nile Web; Eye Radio (South Sudan); Radio Miraya
column17: On 13 July 2020, Nuer and Kuku refugees clashed at Palorinya camp (Moyo district), following a dispute over suspected theft which sparked clashes. Two Nuers were killed by Kukus as they attempted to flee the camp; dozens have been injured and over 100 dwellings were torched in two days of clashes. [size=no report]

On 14 July 2020, hundreds of traders attempted to open their stalls at Kisekka market in Kampala in defiance of coronavirus lockdown measures. Police fired tear gas to disperse the traders, who were reported to have thrown stones at the police. [size=hundreds]
On 14 July 2020, a police officer beat and then shot a man in the toe for not wearing a face mask at Manibe near Arua town (Arua district), ostensibly as part of coronavirus enforcement measures.

Around 14 July 2020 (as reported), two large groups of rival factions of the People Power movement reportedly clashed in Kamwokya (Kampala) during nominations hustings. Police fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to have been fired in the air) to disperse the supporters, on the basis that they were violating coronavirus lockdown measures. [size=large]

column7: Nuer Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column9: Kuku Ethnic Group (South Sudan); Refugees/IDPs (South Sudan)
column16: Radio Miraya; URN (Uganda); Eye Radio (South Sudan); West Nile Web
column17: On 14 July 2020, Nuer and Kuku refugees clashed for a second day at Palorinya camp (Moyo district), following a dispute over suspected theft which sparked clashes the previous day. One Nuer died of injuries sustained either on 13 or 14 July; dozens have been injured and over 100 dwellings were torched in two days of clashes. [size=no report]

On 15 July 2020, two Acholi clans (the Lamogi Payugu and the Pawel clans) clashed in several villages in the area of Layima village, including the villages of Rec ki Ceke, Atiti, Acwera and Lakang, in what is described as a land dispute. 13 were wounded (3 seriously) in this clash and taken to health centres in Oberabic and Lacor (Amuru district). Homes were destroyed and at least 215 displaced, and livestock and property looted.

On 15 July 2020, sugarcane drivers blocked a main road in Busia (Busia district) in protest at the recent ban on Ugandan sugarcane imports by Kenyan authorities. Police dispersed the drivers after three hours. [size=no report]

Around 15 July 2020 (week of), Karamajong fighters clashed with UPDF who were escorting an investor in the mining area of Naput near Nakiloro (Moroto district). One UPDF soldier was killed and one other person injured (implied to be a civilian).

On 17 July 2020, five individuals who had been under quarantine under coronavirus protection measures in Entebbe (Wakiso district) protested against an extension of their quarantine period from 14 days. [size=5]

Around 18 July 2020 (between 16 July - 20 July), UPDF soldiers who had recently been deployed to Lenju in Kigorobya subcounty (Hoima district) were reported to have beaten residents (with the source highlighting women and youth as the primary targets). There is no clear reason for the attacks.

Around 18 July 2020 (as reported), Karamajong and Turkana fighters clashed with UPDF who were dislodging them from a mining camp they had taken over in the Nakabaat area close to Nakiloro (Moroto district). The source does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.

On 18 July 2020, police attempted to break up a Bamasaba ceremony at Namakhele village at Bunabutsale sub-county (Manafwa district) using tear gas and live rounds, for breaching coronavirus lockdown measures. Members of the Bamasaba then attacked the police using bladed weapons, sticks and stones, wounding four police. Two civilians were also wounded in the encounter. [size=no report]

On 20 July 2020, several vendors demonstrated in Jinja (Jinja district), in opposition to street traders operating near the main market. Police used pepper spray against the protesting vendors. [size=several]
On 20 July 2020, UPDF shot dead a suspected Karamajong raider at Kurugwe village in Paimol subcounty (Agago district). The armed raider was believed to be conducted surveillance in the village.

On 21 July 2020, suspected Karamajong raiders abducted a civilian in the Gweng-paleya area of Lakwa in Omia Pachwa subcounty (Agago district), before releasing him the following day. The victim represented disabled people in the area. The motive for the abduction is not clear.

On 21 July 2020, police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse supporters of People Power who were attending party nomination events in Kampala, ostensibly because the supporters were violating coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 22 July 2020, residents of Nakitokolo village in Ntuusi subcounty (Ssembabule district) clashed with a private militia hired by a landlord, who had blocked access to the village. A police officer arrived, and fired to disperse the crowd, killing one resident in the process and wounding one of the private militia. The officer has been arrested. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 22 July 2020, LDU paramilitaries clashed with suspected Karamajong raiders at Lakwa central village in Omia Pachwa subcounty (Agago district). The raiders fled, and no injuries were reported.

Around 22 July 2020 (as reported), four youths from Paicho sub-county started a fire on the Gulu-Kitgum road after their preferred choice of Cwero was bypassed as the new location for the district HQ (event presumed to have taken place at or near Cwero, Gulu district). Police fired live rounds into the air, and arrested the four. [size=4]

On 23 July 2020, police and UPDF fired tear gas at People Power supporters at a local politicians' house in Jinja (Jinja district), where they were discussing ways of mitigating internal tensions, ostensibly because they were breaching coronavirus lockdown measures.

On 23 July 2020, dozens of vendors demonstrated in several shopping arcades in Kampala, in protest at the decision by their landlords to charge them rent despite their shops being closed due to the coronavirus lockdown. Police dispersed traders in at least one area with tear gas. [size=dozens]
On 24 July 2020, taxi drivers demonstrated at the RDC's office in Mityana town (Mityana district), following the decision by the RDC to prevent elections among the labour group. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-) Uganda Wildlife Authority
column17: Around 26 July 2020 (weekend of), Wildlife Authority rangers shot two farmers in Mt. Elgon national park (presumed to be near Taragon village, Kween district), wounding one and killing the other. The Wildlife Authority has admitted to firing at the men, but has claimed they were poachers.

On 26 July 2020, a lynch mob attempted to kill two police officers at Nabbingo (Wakiso district) after they were accused of causing a road accident. A passing vehicle rescued the officers. [size=no report]

On 29 July 2020, Karamajong raiders clashed with UPDF in or near Paimol subcounty of Agago district, 30km from Kuriet village where a small number of cattle had been stolen on 29 July. The report does not mention whether there were injuries or fatalities.

Around 29 July 2020 (as reported), more than 200 residents of several villages in the Butuntumula area barricaded the main highway at Ndibulungi (Luwero district), to demonstrate against pollution caused by a chicken farm operating in the area. [size=more than 200]

On 29 July 2020, vendors demonstrated in Kampala against attempts by landlords to charge vendors for rents incurred during the coronavirus lockdown. Six demonstrators threw stones at police and at a police vehicle, and were subsequently arrested. [size=at least 6]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 3 August 2020, Congolese militiamen abducted 10 Ugandan fishermen close to Rweshama landing site (Rukungiri district). Some reports indicate the abductions are linked to criminal activity, others suggest they are in response to regular arrests of Congolese fishermen by Ugandan authorities.
Around 3 August 2020, a lynch mob killed a man suspected of murdering his niece in Ogolo village in Olwelai parish (Soroti district). [size=no report]

On 4 August 2020, demonstrators blocked a street in Fort Portal (Kabarole district) with rocks and burning tires, to highlight the failure of the contractor undertaking roadworks to limit dust, coating the area in dust. Police attempted to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 8 August 2020, police fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air) at National Unity Platform supporters (the new party led by Bobi Wine MP) in Mbale town (Mbale district), after the supporters gathered at a radio station where Bobi Wine was reported to be. 9 supporters have been arrested; one source indicates the charges related to coronavirus lockdown measures (which prohibit 'illegal gatherings').

On 9 August 2020, hundreds of supporters of a NRM politician rallied in Koboko (Koboko district). The supporters burned car tires to block roads, threw stones at police, and tore down posters of a rival contender. Police fired tear gas at the crowd; around 10 are reported injured (including 4 police) and 10 have been arrested. [size=hundreds]

Around 9 August 2020 (as reported), six relatives of an electrician who died in an accident began a sit-in protest at the offices of the electricity firm in Mukono (Mukono district) which had contracted him, demanding the company take responsibility for the death of the man and his co-worker, after the firm distanced themselves from the event. [size=6]

On 9 August 2020, Bakonzo militia attacked Basongora pastoralists at Kabukero village in Karusandara sub county (Kasese district), as part of a lengthy land dispute. 9 were wounded (3 Bakonzo, 6 Basongora) in the clash.

Around 12 August 2020 (as reported), a lynch mob killed a woman in Addis Ababa village of Dure parish in Latanya sub county (Pader district), after they suspected her of poisoning a man who she was involved in a land dispute with. [size=no report]

Around 12 August 2020 (as reported), two police were reported to have extorted boda boda drivers in Mukono town (Mukono district) whilst enforcing coronavirus lockdown measures, and were also reported to have beaten 7 individuals.

On 13 August 2020, two groups of FDC supporters clashed during primary elections in Jinja (Jinja district), after one candidate claimed victory when his rival failed to show up at the event. Police intervened to separate the groups. [size=no report]
Around 14 August 2020, police rescued three suspected thieves from a lynch mob in Kakiri (Wakiso district). [size=no report]

Around 15 August 2020 (month of), UPDF were reported to have killed a Batwa man who was gathering firewood near Nyamatembe in Kacherere parish in Bufundi subcounty (Rubanda district, coordinates for nearby Mukyibara used at GP2), amid reports of beatings and harassment of dispossessed ethnic Batwa in the area.
Around 15 August 2020, two suspected cattle thieves were killed by a lynch mob in Bugabula village in Kidera sub county (Buyende district). [size=no report]

On 16 August 2020, police (operating under the instructions of the Resident District Commissioner, who was present at the time of the incident) attacked an elderly man with batons and pepper spray at Namisindwa (Namisindwa district), breaking the leg of the man. The officers were supposedly enforcing coronavirus lockdown measures. The RDC has been linked by residents of the area to numerous such abuses.
On 17 August 2020, groups of youth clashed in Busia town (Busia district) amid youth elections, throwing stones at one another. Police dispersed the youth with tear gas. [size=no report]

On 17 August 2020, police fired tear gas at youth who had become agitated during youth elections in Jinja (Jinja district), with youth throwing stones at police in response. Six youth have been arrested. [size=at least 6]

On 18 August 2020, police from the Uganda National Roads Authority fired upon a truck (which had driven past an unclearly marked checkpoint, before being pursued by the officers) near Koranorya (Mbarara district), killing one of the drivers, and wounding a young lecturer (who is also running for a parliamentary seat; note that one source describes him as a university administrator) riding in the truck. The other truck driver fled; police have been dispatched to arrest the officers.

On 18 August 2020, residents of Bugembe (Jinja district) converged on Health Centre IV to protest against the storing of dead bodies in the outpatients department, and calling for a morgue to be built. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, NRM and NUP youths clashed in Kamwokya (Kampala) during youth elections, with the NUP youths accusing security forces of preventing their supporters from voting. Police, Military Police and LDU paramilitaries intervened, before clashes spread to a nearby part of the same area. [size=no report]
On 19 August 2020, residents of Lazebu parish demonstrated in Okavu village (Arua district), in opposition to efforts by the National Forest Authority to evict them from their land. [size=no report]

On 21 August 2020, a female farmer was abducted by cattle raiders (all actors presumed to Karamajong) in the Kangolemuge area of Kadocha parish of Nakapelimoru sub county (Kotido district, approximate coordinates from list of water points used at GP2), with raiders then attacking a kraal in the area the same day. There are conflicting reports regarding the whereabouts of the abductee. The abduction is reported to be linked to attempts by raiders to gather information on the location of unguarded herds of cattle.

On 21 August 2020, two or three civilians were abducted by cattle raiders (all actors presumed to Karamajong) in the Kalomuge area of Nakapelimoru sub county (Kotido district). At least one of the abductees was killed, and one wounded. The abductions are reported to be linked to attempts by raiders to gather information on the location of unguarded herds of cattle.

On 23 August 2020, employees of a hardware business demonstrated (at the behest of the owner of the business) in Mbarara (Mbarara district) after the premises was cordoned off due to unpaid debt. Police arrested two, whilst private security forces fired upon the demonstrators, shattering the glass of nearby vehicles. [size=no report]

On 25 August 2020, South Sudanese cattle raiders attacked an unspecified village in Acholi-inhabited Lupilingi parish (Lamwo district), stealing 17 head of cattle. There are no reports of injuries and/or fatalities.

On 26 August 2020, ""scores"" of supporters of a Democratic Party MP (who was detained earlier that day) blocked roads in Semuto town (Nakaseke district), prompting police and UPDF to fire tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air) at the youths. The youths then threw stones at the security services. [size=scores]

On 26 August 2020, two groups of NRM supporters clashed in Ishaka (Bushenyi district) amid NRM primaries for upcoming parliamentary elections. At least three were wounded in the clashes. [size=at least 3]

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 27 August 2020, UPDF clashed with four South Sudanese raiders (who crossed the border from Ikotos county) at Obere village in Ngacino parish (Lamwo district), killing one.

column7: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column9: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column17: On 29 August 2020, supporters of two rival candidates for NRM primaries clashed at Lugusulu (Sembabule district), wounding an unspecified number. There are reports that candidates are using security forces (presumed to be private rather than state) in clashes throughout the area. [size=no report]

column9: Taxi Drivers (Uganda); NRM: National Resistance Movement
column17: On 29 August 2020, supporters of the incumbent NRM candidate clashed with boda boda riders who supported a rival candidate in Katakwi town (Katakwi district), resulting in three being hospitalized. The clash comes in the context of NRM primary elections. [size=at least 3]

column9: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: On 30 August 2020, two rival groups of NRM supporters clashed (using stones and wooden canes) in Nampirika (Iganga district), with police reportedly intervening in favor of one of the groups. The police have denied allegations of bias, saying that the group they supposedly supported obeyed their order to leave the area. [size=no report]

On 30 August 2020, a large raid (in which 22 separate herds of cattle were stolen) was reported in the Lokopo area of Napak district. The raid is suspected of having been conducted by Turkana and Matheniko raiders. 176 head of cattle have so far been recovered.
On 31 August 2020, supporters of an NRM candidate detained by police demonstrated at the police station at Iganga (Iganga district). Police arrested the demonstrators. [size=no report]

column7: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column9: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column17: On 1 September 2020, supporters of two rival candidates for NRM primaries clashed at an unspecified location in Mawogola West (Sembabule district), wounding three (including one of the candidates). There are reports that candidates are using security forces (presumed to be private rather than state) in clashes throughout the area. [size=at least 3]

On 1 September 2020, an NRM candidate in upcoming NRM internal primaries claimed to have been attacked by supporters of a rival candidate near Ojama (Serere district), after he approached the supporters to enquire as to why they had gathered near his house. The rival candidate has denied the accusations, claiming that his opponent had planned instead to ambush him. [size=no report]

On 1 September 2020, two rival groups of NRM supporters clashed in Ngora town (Ngora district), in the run-up to internal NRM primaries. Police fired live rounds (presumed to have been fired into the air) to disperse the groups. [size=no report]

On 1 September 2020, police fired live rounds at NRM supporters involved in a procession in Kotido town (Kotido district), which seriously wounded a woman, who was shot in both legs. An eyewitness said that police allowed the procession to continue after the supporters agreed to adhere to coronavirus social distancing measures, but shortly after the agreement shots were fired.
On 2 September 2020, about 150 NRM supporters demonstrated in Kyenjojo (Kyenjojo district), after they discovered they were not on the ballot for NRM primaries. [size=about 150]

column7: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column9: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Private Security Forces (Uganda)
column17: Around 3 September 2020 (as reported), supporters of two rival candidates for NRM primaries clashed at an unspecified area in Lwemiyaga sub county (Sembabule district). There are reports that candidates are using security forces (presumed to be private rather than state) in clashes throughout the area. [size=no report]

column9: NRM: National Resistance Movement; Police Forces of Uganda (1986-)
column17: Around 3 September 2020, youth from the Democratic Party and the NRM were reported to have clashed in Entebbe (Wakiso district), with police alleged to have beaten Democratic Party supporters after intervening. [size=no report]

On 3 September 2020, an unknown group attacked a Ugandan MP (of the NRM party) along with his wife and driver at an unspecified location implied to be in the Kabuga area of Kibale county (Kamwenge district), after they were visiting a man who worked for the MP and was also wounded in a similar attack. The MP has accused one of his rivals in the NRM primary elections of masterminding the attack, which is denied by the rival candidate.

On 3 September 2020, police fired upon NRM supporters participating in a procession for an NRM candidate (for upcoming internal primaries) at an unspecified location in Sheema district (presumed to be in Sheema town). Three people were wounded, and a person died when they jumped from the truck they were travelling on. According to reports, the Resident District Commissioner (RDC) and police had gone to disperse the rally, when the group saw the RDC, they tried to attack, accusing him of supporting the opponent. Police fired bullets in the air. [size=no report]

Around 3 September 2020 (as reported), a Catholic priest was abducted and beaten by an unknown group of men from his church in Rutenga parish (Kanungu district). The victim was then robbed, and left outside the police station at Kanungu town. The source suggests the attack is linked to the NRM primaries, with a candidate (who denies involvement) being implicated in the attack.

On 4 September 2020, rival NRM youth engaged in what is described as a 'fracas' at Isingiro town (Isingiro district). A police officer fired at the youth, killing one, who is believed to be a pollster. [size=no report]
On 4 September 2020, UPDF fired upon NRM youth who were reported to have turned violent during primary elections at Rugaaga (Isingiro district), killing one. [size=no report]

column7: Vigilante Group (Uganda); NRM: National Resistance Movement
column17: On 4 September 2020, a lynch mob (presumed to be NRM supporters) killed a man in Rwakakwenda (Isingiro district), after they accused him of attempting to tamper with ballots during NRM primary elections. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, Democratic Party supporters demonstrated at the police station in Entebbe (Wakiso district), after several party officials (including the deputy mayor of Entebbe) were arrested in relation to clashes with NRM supporters that week. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, two rival groups of NRM supporters clashed in Rakai town (Rakai district), amid tensions between two NRM contenders during the internal primaries. At least six were wounded and hospitalized, whilst two have been arrested. [size=at least 8]

On 4 September 2020, NRM youth protested in Lalekan (Kitgum district) during NRM primaries, claiming that electoral fraud had taken place. Police used tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired in the air) to disperse the youth. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, two rival groups of NRM supporters clashed in Apule village near Kapujan (Katakwi district). Police and UPDF fired live rounds to disperse the youth, with stray bullets hitting three people (note that is unclear whether the victims were part of the clashing youth), one of whom was killed. Several security officers have been arrested. [size=no report]

On 4 September 2020, a lynch mob killed a woman who they suspected of killing her husband at Nyamiyaga Parish (Rubanda district). Police have arrested two and confirmed the identity of a third member of the mob. [size=at least 3]

On 4 September 2020, two groups of NRM supporters clashed at a polling station in Nakwa West (Kampala) when one of the candidates in the NRM primaries was accused of recruiting non-NRM youth to fraudulently take part in the vote. [size=no report]

column7: Vigilante Group (Uganda); NRM: National Resistance Movement
column17: On 5 September 2020, an NRM-affiliated professor was attacked by a mob of rival NRM supporters in Sheema (Sheema district) after the professor was seen entering a tallying station carrying declarations of results. Police and UPDF rescued the academic, and confiscated the list of results he was carrying to quell the mob. [size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of Uganda (1986-); Government of Uganda (1986-); NRM: National Resistance Movement
column17: On 5 September 2020, a government minister attempted to enter the central polling station in Bundibugyo (Bundibugyo district) during NRM primaries, prompting supporters of a rival candidate to chase him from the venue. The minister's security detail (presumed to be army) fired live rounds in the air to disperse the youth. NRM youth were also reported to have marched through the town later that day, creating tension as they alleged that vote-rigging was occurring. Police dispersed the youth with live rounds (presumed to be fired in the air). [size=no report]

On 5 September 2020, supporters of a defeated NRM candidate threw stones at police in Rubanda (Rubanda district), after they were evicted from the voting hall for disrupting proceedings after information on voting irregularities emerged. The officers then dispersed the youth. [size=no report]

Around 5 September 2020 (as reported), a defeated NRM candidate and his supporters rioted during the announcement of NRM primary results in Mbale (Mbale district), beating the registrar, and alleging that vote rigging had taken place. [size=no report]

On 5 September 2020, NRM youth rioted in Bugiri (Bugiri district) amid allegations of electoral malpractice during NRM primaries, throwing stones at security forces. Police and UPDF fired tear gas and live rounds to disperse the youth, with a female market vendor being hit by a stray round, and dying of her injuries shortly after. [size=no report]

On 5 September 2020, supporters of an NRM candidate (who lost in primary elections) barricaded the highway at Kyankwanzi town (Kyankwanzi district) with burning logs, to demonstrate against the results of the election. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Rushenyi (Ntungamo district) to demonstrate against the detention of the State Minister for Labour Mwesigwa Rukutana. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, Village Health Team members from around Bududa stormed Bududa District Headquarters in Bududa (Bududa district) to demonstrate against the non-payment of allowances for their mosquito net distributions. [size=no report]

On 7 September 2020, Ugandan police forces and Ugandan military forces blocked demonstrators attempting to access the National Resistance Movement office in Rubanda district. The demonstrators gathered because they felt that the NRM Party win in the election was not legitimate. [size=no report]
On 7 September 2020, junior staff at Ongino Hospital went on strike and demonstrated in front of the hospital in Kumi (Kumi) because of delays in the payment of salaries. [size=no report]

On 8 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators in Hoima (Hoima district), who were demonstrating against the dispersal of a NUP political party meeting earlier that day. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, National Resistance Movement (NRM) party supporters demonstrated the results of the primary elections and cut off traffic on the Kampala-Gulu highway near Wobulenzi Town (Luwero). [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, two armed men from an unidentified armed group broke into the home of a Ugandan government spokesman in Mukono (Mukono district), holding his family in a room while looting the house.

On 10 September 2020, demonstrators camped outside the district headquarters in Butaleja (Butaleja district), after election officials announced an NRM party member as a winner instead of the candidate they voted for. Sources report that the demonstrators also had run-ins with police, but do not describe the nature of the interactions. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, a mob organized and attacked the Rhino Camp (Arua district) after a man told his relatives that refugees from the camp assaulted him. The mob then went to the camp and killed 10 refugees. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, demonstrators engaged in violent demonstrations in the city of Gulu (Gulu district) after discrepancies in the election in which a tallying center recorded 2000 voters but the polling station recorded only 100 registered voters. [size=no report]

Around 11 September 2020 (as reported), dozens of teachers demonstrated outside the Anti Corruption Court in Kololo (Kampala) against the court granting bail to 4 suspects alleged to have embezzled funds that were intended to aid private school teachers who have lost income during coronavirus. [size=dozens]

On 11 September 2020, Ugandan police forces fired tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Nabweru near Maganjo (Nansana Municipality) to demonstrate against not being allowed to vote because they were not in the party register. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, Ugandan police forces fired teargas and live bullets to disperse demonstrators who gathered in the city of Lira (Lira district) to demonstrate against the results of the local election. Demonstrators allegedly started throwing stones at supporters for the winning candidate, while police were accused of beating a bystander and a candidate in the elections. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, youths wielding clubs entered a polling station and assaulted an election officer in Musubiro Village in Lwengo district after arguing with elections officials about opening the polling station. Sources allege the youth proceeded to go to nearby polling stations in the area to intimidate voters that don't support their candidate. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, a mob attacked the Rhino Camp (Arua district) after a man told his relatives that refugees from the camp assaulted him. The mob then went to the camp and killed 8 refugees. [size=no report]

On 13 September 2020, the National Unity Platform (NUP) Women Coordinator was allegedly tortured by Ugandan police forces at an undisclosed location around Jinja for wearing a red beret in public, which is considered official army attire.

Around 14 September 2020 (as reported), Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse voters who reportedly became violent after accusations that one candidate bussed in voters in Soroti (Soroti). [size=no report]
On 14 September 2020, Ugandan police forces opened fire on voters who were fighting at a polling station in Bugiri (Bugiri), injuring 2 women. [size=no report]

On 14 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas and live fire against demonstrators after clashes broke out between supporters of opposing parties at a polling station in Bulindo (Wakiso) after the registrar substituted the register with an exercise book. Fatalities or injuries were not reported. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse demonstrators who gathered in Kamwokya (Kampala) to demonstrate against the failure of the police to apprehend a suspect connected to two shootings in Kampala. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse protesters who gathered in Bugumba (Iganga) to protest a delay in announcing elections results, with at least 1 injury. [size=no report]
Around 15 September 2020 (as reported), demonstrators rioted over allegations that ineligible voters were able to vote in Makindye (Kampala). [size=no report]

On 16 September 2020, Ugandan police forces shot live bullets in the air to disperse the approximately 500 demonstrators who gathered in Rwentobo (Ntungamo) to demonstrate against the electoral commission chairperson's decision to cancel the victor of the race for party flag bearer. The demonstrators were burning tires and throwing stones for around 45 minutes before being dispersed by police. [size=about 500]
Around 16 September 2020 (as reported), Ugandan police forces used tear gas to disperse rioters at two polling stations in Hoima (Hoima). The violence was election related. [size=no report]

Around 16 September 2020 (week of), a lynch mob attempted to kill a man accused of practicing witchcraft at Nankondo village in Lwebitakuli parish (Ssembabule district), burning down his house. Police intervened and fired live rounds into the mob, killing one and wounding two others. The officer has been arrested. [size=at least 3]

Around 16 September 2020 (as reported), Ugandan police forces used live bullets to disperse voters who were turned away from a polling station in Busia (Busia) and then turned violent. [size=no report]

On 17 September 2020, People Power supporters blocked a road at Kamwokya (Kampala) with burning tires, to demonstrate against the failure of the police to apprehend a suspect connected to two shootings in Kampala. Police used tear gas, rubber bullets and live rounds, and arrested at least 20 people. A teenage market vendor (who was not involved in the demonstration) suffered a broken leg when police shot her with a rubber bullet, reportedly after People Power supporters had already been dispersed. [size=at least 20]

On 17 September 2020, Ugandan police forces used tear gas, live bullets, and batons to disperse demonstrators who were burning tires, throwing stones, and stopping traffic in Rwahi Township near Kabale, demonstrating against election results. [size=no report]
On 17 September 2020, Ugandan police forces arrested at least 10 demonstrators in Rubaare Town (Ntungamo) who were gathered to protest the results of the elections. [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, Ugandan police forces fired bullets and used tear gas to disperse protesters who had gathered in multiple locations around Kabale (Kabale), all protesting the defeat of their candidate in the elections. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, supporters of an NRM candidate who failed to secure the party nomination in recent primaries demonstrated against alleged irregularities at Katojo Trading Centre (Kanungu district), barricading the main road with stones and burning tires. Police fired live rounds in the air, and used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. 5 were arrested. [size=at least 5]

Around 21 September 2020 (as reported), local militia attacked three suspected Karamajong raiders who were scouting for cattle at Kamanding in Lolwa parish (Kitgum district, coordinates for nearby Agoromin used at GP2), killing one raider.
On 22 September 2020, unsuccessful candidates in NUP primaries and their supporters demonstrated at the NUP headquarters in Kampala, citing irregularities in the primary elections. [size=no report]

Around 24 September 2020 (as reported), more than 500 farmers demonstrated in Rushenyi (Ntungamo district), calling for a businessman to honor a substantial amount of money owed to the farmers. The businessman has acknowledged his debt to the farmers, but claims they have exaggerated the total amount owed. [size=more than 500]

Around 25 September 2020 (as reported), police arrested two bodyguards of a MP outside a courthouse in Kampala, beating one of the guards and using pepper spray against him, whilst claiming the bodyguards were not authorized to stand outside the building.

On 26 September 2020, suspected Madi militia armed with bows and hand weapons attacked the Acholi-inhabited village of Acholiber in the disputed Apaa area (Adjumani district), displacing an unspecified number to nearby Punudyang.

On 28 September 2020, a lynch mob formed at an unspecified location in Ngoma subcounty (Ntungamo district) to attack suspected cattle thieves, killing one and wounding two others. The surviving pair were then forced to carry the body of the deceased to their home area of Kamwezi. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, hundreds of NRM youths from the far south-west of Uganda marched at an unspecified area of Rubanda East (Rubanda district, coordinates for Rubanda town used at GP2), denouncing the failure of election officials to disclose the outcome of delayed primary elections. [size=hundreds]

On 1 October 2020, NRM youth demonstrated in Hamuhambo in the parish of Rwanyana (Kabale district) to denounce delays in announcing primary results, clashing with police, before UPDF fired tear gas at the crowds, and live rounds into the air. [size=no report]
On 1 October 2020, NRM youth demonstrated in the Muchachi area of Rubanda district to denounce delays in announcing primary results, clashing with police at Muchachi Trading Center. [size=no report]
