On 1 October 2020, groups of rival NRM youths clashed in the areas of Kannunga, Rushese and Kizaano in Lugusulu subcounty (Ssembabule district), in the context of delayed NRM primary elections. There is no further information. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, groups of rival NRM youths clashed at Kiganda in Lwebitakuli subcounty (Ssembabule district), in the context of delayed NRM primary elections. There is no further information. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, police fired live rounds and tear gas to disperse what is described as a syndicate of land grabbers armed with pangas, who had recently encroached on parts of Namanve Central Forest Reserve on the outskirts of Seeta (Mukono district). The report does not indicate that there were any injuries. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, Karamajong raiders attacked the house of the LC1 chairperson of Kurmegi village in Omiya Pahcwa subcounty (Agago district), shooting him in the stomach, and stealing a small number of cattle. LDU paramilitaries were able to take the wounded man to hospital for treatment, and recovered the cattle (as well as army uniforms) from the raiders at nearby Lupuk village.

column7: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: Around 2 October 2020, UPDF and LDU paramilitaries clashed with Karamajong cattle raiders in the area of Omiya Pahcwa (Agago district), killing an unspecified number. Unknown fatalities coded as 3.

Around 3 October 2020 (weekend of), a candidate for the NRM primary elections staged a demonstration with her supporters in Tororo town (Tororo district), to denounce what she described as the deliberate delay in announcing the winner. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 5 October 2020, armed men in LDU paramilitary uniforms (and coded as such) shot and wounded an off-duty traffic police officer and his wife near Nabuin/Nabwin (Nakapiripirit district) as they travelled to Moroto hospital. The officer died of his injuries shortly after. There is no clear motive for the attack. Note that one source links Karamajong militia to the attack.

On 5 October 2020, UPDF soldiers from the Marine Brigade fired upon a group who were siphoning fuel from vehicles belonging to a road construction company in Bukuli village in Biso subcounty (Buliisa district), killing one. The colleagues of the victim fled the scene.

Around 6 October 2020 (as reported), medical students demonstrated at the Gulu College of Health Sciences at Layibi (Gulu district) after the college was not able to accommodate returning students, after having been converted into a coronavirus treatment center. [size=no report]

On 6 October 2020, residents protested at the police station in Mukono town (Mukono district), calling for the release of their relatives who were arrested last week in Namanve nature reserve for suspected land grabbing, citing their undue period of detention without charge. [size=no report]

On 6 October 2020, three private security guards (reported to be operating on the instructions of a local priest) shot and killed a man near Tororo Rock in central Tororo (Tororo district), in what is described as a land dispute. The three guards and the priest have been arrested.

Around 6 October 2020 (as reported), four NUP supporters attacked and seriously assaulted an NRM supporter in a bar on Nkose island (Kalangala district), after the NRM supporter had taken the microphone away from the NUP parliamentary candidate at an event on 4 October. Police have arrested the attackers. [size=four]

On 10 October 2020, supporters (described as being ""huge"" in number) of a candidate defeated in delayed NRM primaries demonstrated against the victorious candidate in Kabale town (Kabale district). Police used teargas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=huge]
On 11 October 2020, NRM youth supporters demonstrated at the party HQ in Kabale town (Kabale district), as they had not received allowances promised to them during campaigning. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, NRM supporters attempted to storm the party HQ in Tororo (Tororo district), after their candidate's victory in primary elections was overturned. Police fired teargas to disperse the youth. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 13 October 2020, police and LDU paramilitaries intercepted funeral mourners in Kamwokya (Kampala), whilst enforcing coronavirus curfew measures. LDU paramilitaries fired at the mourners, killing one.

On 14 October 2020, two rival groups of NRM supporters clashed at an unspecified location in Okore subcounty in Katakwi district, after delayed NRM primary election results were announced. Five were seriously injured, and 18 others arrested. [size=no report]

On 15 October 2020, Democratic Party supporters threw stones at police attempting to disperse them from a rally in Makindye (Kampala), prompting police to fire tear gas and beat DP supporters. A supporter was hit by a tear gas canister, fracturing her arm. 31 people have been arrested. [size=no report]

On 15 October 2020, youth threw stones at police in Kisekka Market in Kampala, after police dispersed an election candidate canvassing support prior to nomination proceedings. Police used teargas against the youth, and arrested 4. [size=no report]

column7: Vigilante Group (Uganda); Kopir Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: Around 15 October 2020, an elderly woman was tortured by youth from the Kopir clan of the Acholi, after their chief accused the lady of practicing witchcraft. The youth then stole food from her house. The event occurred at Wang Lango village in Akobi parish (Kitgum district). The victim was then deposited at a police station, with police saying they intend to prosecute the attackers. [size=no report]

Around 15 October 2020 (as reported), more than 1,000 family members demonstrated in Jinja (Jinja district), calling for the payment of compensation money promised to them to make way for the construction of railway tracks. [size=more than 1,000 families]
On 16 October 2020, NRM and FDC youth clashed in Buwama (Mpigi district), after FDC supporters objected to an illegal rally being held. Police dispersed the youth with tear gas. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, youth supporters of a recently nominated politician clashed with police in Bwaise (Kampala), who used tear and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air). During the unrest, unknown groups were involved in destroying property in shops, with some traders suggesting the politician in question was involved in the destruction. [size=no report]

column6: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
column17: On 17 October 2020, Congolese militiamen abducted 16 Ugandan fishermen near Kaiso landing site (Hoima district). The attackers are demanding a ransom for their release.

On 19 October 2020, 25 vendors burned tires in Tororo town center (Tororo district), in a dispute relating to the collection of rent in a park in the town. Police arrested the demonstrators. [size=25]

column9: Pailyec Clan Group (Uganda); Acholi Ethnic Group (Uganda)
column17: Around 19 October 2020 (as reported), members of the Pamuca Acholi clan (armed with bows and hand weapons) attacked members of the Pailyec clan at Ayilla village in Gurunguru subcounty (Amuru district), torching six dwellings. The attack is said to be in revenge for the murder of a member of the Pamuca clan in July.

Around 20 October 2020 (as reported), members of the Baganda marched in Mityana (Mityana district), to denounce the heavy-handed dispersal of a meeting of elders on 17 October by police. Police used tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air) to disperse the crowds, and arrested 5. One police officer was reported to have been injured in what the source describes as a ""scuffle"". [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, members of the Baganda marched to the residence of the Katikkiro (Prime Minister) of Buganda at Mengo (Kampala), to denounce the heavy-handed dispersal of a meeting of elders on 17 October by police. Police intercepted some of the demonstrators as they were en route to residence at Bulange, arresting an unspecified number. [size=no report]

Around 20 October 2020 (as reported), FDC members marched in Kampala, decrying plans announced by the Ugandan government to build roads in South Sudan and the DRC. Police arrested the demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, more than 50 contractors working for a Chinese-owned construction company protested at the company's office at Ntinda (Kampala), calling for wage arrears to be paid; annual leave to be recognized; and for staff to receive promotions. [size=more than 50]

On 21 October 2020, dozens of boda boda drivers demonstrated in Mbarara (Mbarara district), denouncing the death of a fellow rider in a vehicle accident the previous day. Police used live rounds (presumed to be fired in the air) and tear gas to disperse the crowd. [size=dozens]

On 21 October 2020, a mob of boda boda drivers torched the house of a man who was involved in an a fatal vehicle accident with one of their colleagues the previous day, at Kabala cell (Isingiro district). Police intervened, and rescued the three children of the man. [size=no report]

On 21 October 2020, a lynch mob attacked a transwoman in Soroti town (Soroti district) after a man alerted neighbors upon discovering the lady was transgender. The victim was severely beaten by the mob, though police intervened to prevent further violence. Police then arrested the victim, accusing her of being engaged in thievery. [size=no report]

column7: Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Military Police; Military Forces of Uganda (1986-) Local Defense Unit
column17: On 21 October 2020, police, military police and LDU paramilitaries intercepted a convoy carrying NUP leader Bobi Wine MP at Wandegeya (Kampala). Security forces fired tear gas and live rounds (presumed to be fired into the air) at NUP supporters, and forcibly dragged Bobi Wine out of his vehicle, prompting his security detail to intervene and overpower the security forces, freeing the young politician.
Doctors and nurses of the Abbaseyya Psychiatric Hospital held a demonstration amid rumours that the hospital will be relocated outside Cairo.

According to HRW 23 were killed and 79 injured following Christmas Eve Mass in a Coptic Church when a suicide car bomb explodes outside while people were exiting. The bomb was detonated twenty minutes after midnight. An al Qaeda subsidiary later claimed responsibility. Conflicting report: Africa Research Bulletin reports the number of dead at 21 with 80 injured.

Hundreds of protesters from various opposition groups including the MB demonstrated in the Shubra area of Cairo against a recent bombing at a Christian church and called for the resignation of the Interior Minister. Police were present to control the protest, but no incidents were reported.

On Jan 1, inside the Melawite diocese in Minya, more than 150 Coptic Christians organized a protest in solidarity with the victims of New Year's bombing in Alexandria, denouncing the lack of security. Security Forces interfered to prevent them from marching in the streets. [size=150]

Following a car bomb attack against a church, Coptic Christians, some of whom were armed with knives, rioted and clashed with police who used tear gas to disperse them. During the riots a number of police cars were burned. At least one person was injured by pellet shot.
On Jan 2, a ""large number"" of Christian Copts protested against Alexandria's bombing on New Year. They reportedly marched from Imbaba, Giza, to Maspero Television Building, Cairo. [size=no report]

Coptic Christians held a demonstration at St. Marks Cathedral over the recent bombing of a Christian church in Alexandria. Protesters called for the sacking of the Minister of the Interior and arrest of those responsible. The protesters threw rocks and bottles, injuring ""4 policemen and 38 security force officers"". Egypts top Muslim cleric also had his car hit with stones as he went to see the Coptic Pope.
Egyptian police shot dead an African migrant on its border with Israel on the Sinai Peninsula.
On Jan 2, Christian Copts staged a protest in front of Arcadia's Mall, in Bulaq, Cairo, to denounce the New Year's attack in Alexandria. [size=no report]

On Jan 2, in the evening, close to St George's Church, Bulaq neighbourhood, Cairo, hundreds of Christian Copts demonstrated in solidarity with the victims of Alexandria's bombing. Security Forces surrounded the rioters to prevent them from marching in the streets. Report mentions ""small clashes"" between rioters and Police Forces. [size=hundreds]

Coptic Christians protested against the Alexandria church bombing and denounced public officials. Police officers suffered light wounds when the rioters again threw stones at them. Many motorists cars were also hit with stones.

On Jan 2, government supporters in Alexandria set up a protest in front of the Alexandria ambulance station to denounce the recent bombing. Protesters chanted slogans denouncing terrorism and praising national unity. [size=no report]
On Jan 2, in the afternoon, tens of lawyers held a protest in front of the Lawyers Association's headquarters in Cairo to denounce New Year's bombing in Alexandria. [size=tens]

Coptic Christians, upset following a New Years Eve Mass bombing protest outside the targeted Church, denouncing public officials and puling one minister, a Muslim cleric with stones as he passed by. Police officers suffered light wounds when the rioters again threw stones at them. Many motorists cars were also hit with stones.

On Jan 2, after Sunday Mass, at St George Church in Mansoura, young people from various political movements set up a protest against terrorism, in solidarity with victims of Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve. [size=no report]

On Jan 2, in Izbat Harfush village, Fayyum, in the evening, thousands of people participated in the funeral of a police agent killed by unidentified armed men who tried to steal his weapon. They reportedly staged a protest to demand justice. [size=thousands]

On Jan 2, following a protest on Jan 1, more than 1,000 Christian Copts staged another protest in the evening inside the Melawite diocese in Minya against Alexandria's bombing. The Archdiocese and Security Forces closed the doors of the diocese to prevent protesters from marching in the streets. [size=1,000]
Around 2,000 Coptic Christians demonstrated in Al-Ezziyah against a bombing in Alexandria targeting Christians.

Thousands of protesters, mainly Coptics, clashed with police as they protested against the Alexandria church bombing. 8 protesters were arrersted on charges of assaulting police officers and vandalism. 14 members of the security forces were injured by thrown rocks. They responded with tear gas and batons, injuring at least 10 protesters.

On Jan 3, tens of students and professors from Ain Al Shams University, in Cairo, held a protest in front of Qasr Al-Zaafran campus at the university's campus, in solidarity with the victims of Alexandria's attack on New Year. [size=tens]
On Jan 3, in Al Azhar University, Cairo, Muslim Brotherhood members, students and faculty members held a protest to condemn Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve. [size=no report]
On Jan 3, in Luxor, a hundred of students, professors and employees of the Faculty of Tourism held a protest in the afternoon, condemning Alexandria's attack. [size=hundred]

On Jan 4, in Al Marj, in the evening, more than 5,000 Coptic Christians gathered in front of the Abu Seifen church, in protest against Alexandria's attack on New Year. Security Forces interfered to disperse the protesters. [size=5,000]
On Jan 4, at Beni Suef University, Faculty members and more than 2,000 students set up a protest against terrorism following Alexandria's attack on New Year. [size=approximately 2,000]
On Jan 4, in Cairo, a thousand of Cairo University's faculty members, employees and students marched to protest against Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve. [size=1,000]
On Jan 4, dozens of Nubians staged a protest in front of the State Council in Cairo following land issues. [size=dozens]

On Jan 4, in Cairo, Downtown, 2,000 members of the Syndicate of Cinematographers organized a protest in front of the union headquarters, in Adly Street, in solidarity with the victims of Alexandria's bombing. [size=2,000]

On Jan 4, in the morning, in Al Nozha, more than 500 students of the Abbasid Institute (el Nozha city) organized a sit-in, to protest against the university administration's refusal to let them pass their exams. After 6 hours of sit-in, Police Forces interfered and dispersed the protesters. [size=approximately 500]
Around 500 Coptic Christians protested at Asyut in front of the ruling parties HQ against a church bombing in Alexandria. Some of the protesters threw rocks at the police, but no clashes followed.

On Jan 5, at Al Azhar University, Nasr City, university staff and hundreds of students, among Muslim Brotherhood militants marched against Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve and denounced terrorism. [size=hundreds]

column7: April 6 Youth Movement; Ghad Political Party; National Association for Change; Youth for Freedom and Justice Movement
column17: On Jan 5, in the evening, in Cairo, more than 100 members of various political forces (Ghad Political Party, the National Association for Change, April 6 Youth Movement, and Justice and Freedom Youth Movement) set up a protest in front of the Attorney General's office to demand the release of 8 activists arrested during Shubra's protest the day before. [size=approximately 100]
On Jan 5, hundreds of young Coptic Christians marched from Abadir's Church to Assiut's main roads to protest against the New Year's bombing in Alexandria. [size=hundreds]
On Jan 5, in Assiut, downtown, in Shikouril square, a group of Coptic Christians protested against Alexandria's attack on New Year. They were dispersed by Police Forces. [size=no report]

Sometime prior to Jan 20 (coded as over the preceding month with TP3), in Mansoura, young men who entered the Khadiga School for Girls reportedly beat several students and tried to ""kidnap"" one of them during an exam session.
On Jan 5, in Banha University, students and university staff protested against Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve and denounced terrorism. [size=no report]

On Jan 5, in the morning, in Al Nozha, more than 500 students of the Abbasid Institute organized a sit-in, to protest against the university administration's refusal to let a number of them pass their exams. [size=500]
A suspect arrested during the investigation into the Alexandria church bombing was allegedly tortured to death by police on either Jan.5 or 6
Defusal: Policed find a crude explosive at the bottom of a church staircase. It is disarmed before it is able to detonate.

Dozens of protesters staged a sit-in in front of the Omar Makram Mosque in Tahrir Square to express their solidarity with the victims of the Alexandria church bombing. Many opposition groups participated, including Al Wafd, El-Ghad, NAC, and the April 6 Youth Movement. Police surrounded the protest and would not let people leave for about an hour, which led to some scuffles.

On Jan 6, in Heliopolis, in front of Cleopatra Church, more than 100 members of different political parties held a candlelight, denouncing terrorism and pleading for unity between Muslims and Christians. [size=100]
Tens of protesters gathered in front of the Saad Zaghloul Masouleum in Cairo to demonstrate against the governments response to the Alexandria church bombing and to demand a secular state.

On Jan 7, in Cairo, on Qasr An Nile Bridge, members of National Association for Change, and other political movements, wearing black clothes, staged a silent protest against Alexandria's attack on New Year. [size=no report]

On Jan 7, in Qaroun square, Fayyoum, a group of National Assocation for Change young members, along with other opposition parties held a silent protest march to condemn the recent bombing in in Alexandria. [size=no report]
On Jan 9, in Safaga harbor, 900 boat passengers staged a protest against the lack of travelling boats. [size=900]

On Jan 10-11, in Cairo, Bulaq neighbourhood, a group of lawyers staged a protest after Free Christian Voice and Copts United described a lawyer as one of the perpetrators of Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve. (coded as 2 events) [size=no report]

After an off-duty policeman killed a Coptic Christian and wounded at least 4 others on a train in the area, Copts protested outside the hospital where the injured were taken and threw stones at police.
An off-duty policeman boarded a train and opened fire on some Christians, killing 1 and wounding at least 4 others.

On Jan 10-11, in Cairo, Bulaq neighbourhood, a group of lawyers staged a protest after Free Christian Voice and Copts United described a lawyer as one of the perpetrators of Alexandria's attack on New Year's Eve. (coded as 2 events) [size=no report]
On Jan 11, in Cairo, at the Chamber of Commerce, at least 200 members of the Domestic Wealth Division staged a sit-in to protest against the judge's decision to close 50 butcher shops. [size=200]

Coptic Christians protested inside the Ezbet Gaafar Church in Al-Fashn town in Beni Suef against a decision by the cities administration to demolish the churches dome. Police were present but did not engage with the demonstrators.
Following the shooting of a Christian by a police officer a group of 500 Coptics gather on ""Egypts main highway"" and begin throwing stones at cars in protest.
On Jan 14, militants of the Kifaya Movement gathered in front of the Tunisian Ambassy, in Cairo, in support of popular protests in Tunisia. [size=no report]

column7: April 6 Youth Movement; FFPC: Free Front for Peaceful Change
column17: Security forces dispersed a protest held in downtown Cairo over the allegedly torturing to death of a suspect in the Alexandria church bombing investigation. The protest was organized by Youth for Justice and Freedom, the April 6 Youth Movement, Free Front for Peaceful Change, and a number of smaller groups near the Qasr El-Nil Bridge. They were prevented from reaching the bridge and so marched to the Lawyers Syndicate, where they were intercepted and dispersed. Most of the protesters were arrested.
On Jan 15, dozens of people, among which Salafists, were arrested by Police Forces in Behera governorate following the New Year's bombing in Alexandria.

On Jan 16, in Nasr City, inside the Ministry of Education, 150 employees from the Ministry of Education staged a protest to demand the resignation of Dr Badr, Education Minister. They were protesting against the Minister's decision to ""arbitrarily"" transfer a number of workers to other governorates. Another report mentions that 1,000 employees took part in the protest [size=150]

On Jan 16, ten militants from April 6 Youth Movement staged a protest in front of Ain Shams University after two students, also militants of April 6 Youth Movement were prevented to pass their exams, despite a judicial decision allowing them to do so. [size=10]

column7: Kifaya Movement; April 6 Youth Movement; Al-Karama Party; FFPC: Free Front for Peaceful Change
column17: On Jan 16, in the Abdeen area of Cairo, dozens of members of various political parties set up a protest in front of the Journalists Syndicate in support of popular protests in Tunisia. [size=dozens]
On Jan 16, in Cairo, in front of Cairo Economic Court, a ""large"" number of people protested following the Court's decision to seize and sell their lands. [size=no report]

Between Jan 16-18, in Giza, in front of the Ministry of Agriculture, a group of Desert Research Centre workers staged a protest to demand the payment of their salaries. (coded as 3 events) [size=no report]

column7: Youth for Freedom and Justice Movement; FFPC: Free Front for Peaceful Change
column17: On Jan 17, in front of the Prosecutor General's Office, tens of members of the Youth Movement for Freedom and Justice and FFPC militants set up a demonstration against the government. One of them reportedly set himself on fire. [size=tens]

Between Jan 16-18, in Giza, in front of the Ministry of Agriculture, a group of Desert Research Centre workers staged a protest to demand the payment of their salaries. (coded as 3 events) [size=no report]

On Jan 17, close to Baltim, 1,000 inhabitants from Al Shorfa village protested against the establishment of a new administrative unit in the neighbouring Al Wahhabi village, claiming that Al Shorfa, more populated, should take its place. Protesters were dispersed by Police Forces. [size=1,000]
On Jan 18,in front of Abdeen Court, a group of lawyers protested against the Court President's decision to transform the lawyers' breakroom into another facility. [size=no report]

On Jan 18, a group of maintenance workers protested in front of the Ministry of Education in Nasr City demanding financial indemnities. They also demanded the resignation of Ministry of Education Dr Badr. Security Forces dispersed protesters. [size=no report]
On Jan 18, in Giza, around 150 workers of the Giza Onion Company set up a protest in front of the company headquarters against the non-payment of their salaries for two months. [size=150]

Between Jan 16-18, in Giza, in front of the Ministry of Agriculture, a group of Desert Research Centre workers staged a protest to demand the payment of their salaries. (coded as 3 events) [size=no report]
On Jan 19, in Quwaysin, a group of Menoufia Spinning and Weaving Company workers staged a protest in front of the Attorney General's office demanding the payment of their salaries. [size=no report]

On Jan 20, in Mansoura, families of Khadiga School for Girls students protested in front of the school against the lack of security, following an assault by young men on some students sometime in the preceding week(s). [size=no report]

On Jan 21, a group of youth from Delta protested in front of the Democratic Front Party headquarters in Cairo in solidarity with Tunisian protesters, inviting people to join in the protest on Jan 25th. [size=no report]

On Jan 21-22, inhabitants from Shirbin organized a sit-in in the Mosque after Friday's prayers in protest against the deterioration of public services and the detention of inhabitants. [size=no report]

column7: Wafd Party; Muslim Brotherhood; Bidaya Movement
column17: On Jan 21, in Awsim, in front of the local council, a group of political members of various parties, including the Wafd party and the Muslim Brotherhood, under the movement ""Bidaya"" (Beginning), protested against the state of emergency. [size=no report]

On Jan 22, in Alexandria, families of students from different schools set up a protest in front of the Governorate Bureau to demand the resignation of Minister of Education Dr Badr and the cancellation of education reforms which would transform national schools into experimental schools. [size=no report]

On Jan 22, in Cairo, a group of people, from the ""Group of 45"", staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Justice to demand the application of judicial decisions regarding their cases. They threatened to set themselves on fire. [size=approximately 45]
On Jan 21-22, inhabitants from Shirbin organized a sit-in in the Mosque after Friday prayers in protest against the deterioration of public services and the detention of inhabitants. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: A senior prison officer was killed by his subordinates as he tried to stop mass prison breaks during Egypts popular uprising against President Hosni Mubarak. The revelation was not widely known until October 2011.

On Jan 23, in Nasr City, hundreds of graduates from geological sciences universities, from different governorates, protested in front of the Ministry of Petroleum building to demand their appointment as engineers. [size=hundreds]

On Jan 23, in Garden City, Cairo, two supporters of NFF Parliamentary candidate Hussein Abu Gad assaulted Rania Fazza, Youm7 journalist, while she was covering parliamentary elections following the death of a deputy.
On Jan 23, in Cairo, in front of the National Party Headquarters, in the morning, around 100 inhabitants staged a protest against the seizure and selling of their lands. [size=100]
On Jan 23, in Tanta , at the Minshawi General Hospital, 600 doctors staged a protest against the delay of payment of their incentives. [size=600]

On Jan 23, in Bir Al Abd, tens of inhabitants blocked the main road in the center of Bir Al Abd, following a car accident which killed 3 people and injured 4. Police Forces interfered to disperse protesters. [size=tens]
A border guard is shot and killed when he exchanges gunfire with a drug smuggler near the Israeli border.
On Jan 24, in the Abdeen area of Cairo, in front of the Parliament, around 100 white taxi drivers protested against Ministry of Finance's taxes project. [size=100]

On Jan 24, in Cairo, a group of workers from the Scientific Center of Electronics and from the Academy of Scientific Research and Technology protested in front of the Ministry of Education against the Education Minister's decision to transfer them to the National Research Center. [size=no report]

On Jan 24, in Giza, in the morning, temporary workers of the Desert Research Center protested in front of the Ministry of Agriculture against administrative issues and demanding better salaries. [size=no report]
Demonstrators protest the Mubarak regime in a Cairo neighborhood.
Demonstrators protest the Mubarak regime in a Cairo neighborhood.

An AP photographer was hit in the face by a stone thrown by a police officer while he was covering protests in Cairo. He was also allegedly beaten by the officer. A guardian reporter was also beaten after being detained while covering the protests. 5 other journalists with local organizations were ""roughed up"" by police.

15,000 protesters who gather to denounce the Mubarak regime clash with riot police. Many injuries. Many opposition political parties are present, however, the Kifaya Movement reportedly was the primary organizer via social media. Teargas and water cannons implemented. 70 arrested. One police officer and five protesters killed in clashes. 1000+ arrested and 20 dead throughout the country in two days. At least 4 security officers and 36 soldiers were reported wounded.
Demonstrators protest the Mubarak regime in a Cairo neighborhood.

Protesters who gather to denounce the Mubarak regime clash with riot police. Many injuries. Many opposition political parties are present, however, the Kifaya Movement reportedly was the primary organizer via social media.
On Jan 25, in North Sinai, hundreds of people rioted in Al Arish, Joura, Mahadiyah and Sheikh Zuweiyid. [size=hundreds] (coded as 4 events)

Protesters who gather to denounce the Mubarak regime clash with riot police. Many injuries. Many opposition political parties are present, however, the Kifaya Movement reportedly was the primary organizer via social media.
Police fire teargas at anti-Mubarak protesters gathered in central Cairo.

Protesters who gather to denounce the Mubarak regime clash with riot police. Many injuries. Many opposition political parties are present, however, the Kifaya Movement reportedly was the primary organizer via social media.

Thousands of anti-government, anti-Mubarak demonstrators gather in Cairo and Alexandra to call for an end to Mubarak regime. Protesters moved throughout the streets, eventually settling in Tahrir Square. By the ousting of Mubarak their were a reported 365 dead and 5,500 wounded.
On Jan 25, in Baltim, a group of rioters threw stones at Police Forces and destroyed an ambulance. 5 people were injured earlier following riots against the government. [size=no report]
Demonstrators protest the Mubarak regime in a suburban Cairo neighborhood.
Protesters of the Mubarak clash with police, two demonstrators killed. A number of policemen were also injured.
Members of the Muslim Brotherhood protest the Mubarak regime in a Giza neighborhood.
On Jan 25, in Mahdia village, close to Rafah, around 500 Bedouins blocked roads and set tires on fire, demonstrating against the state of emergency. [size=approximately 500]
Protests were reported in the Egyptian governorates of Sharkiya, Monofia, Assiut, Kafr el Sheikh, South Sinai and Qena.
Thousands of anti-government, anti-Mubarak demonstrators gather in Cairo and Alexandra to call for an end to Mubarak regime.

Protesters who gather to denounce the Mubarak regime clash with riot police. Many injuries. Many opposition political parties are present, however, the Kifaya Movement reportedly was the primary organizer via social media.
On Jan 25, in Asyut, members of several political parties protested against the regime. Police Forces interfered and attempted to disperse them. [size=no report]
Protests were reported in the Egyptian governorates of Sharkiya, Monofia, Assiut, Kafr el Sheikh, South Sinai and Qena.
Dozens of protesters clashed with security forces outside the Egyptian Foreign Ministry offices before being dispersed by tear gas firing.

On Jan 26-27, in Cairo, 3,000 people demonstrated in front of the Lawyers' Association Building. Police Forces tried to force rioters, who decided to stay overnight inside the building, to leave (around 200 people) using tear gas. Clashes were reported in Ramses Street. On Jan 27, hundreds of people were still demonstrating in front of the Lawyers' Association Building. In the evening, Police Forces managed to enter the building to disperse rioters, injuring several. [size=3000]
Opposition demonstrators throw Molotov cocktails at a government building, a local headquarters for the National Democratic Party, in protest of the Mubarak regime.

Clashes broke out between hundreds of protesters ansd security forces on Galaa Street in Cairo, resulting in numerous injuries on both sides. The protesters burned tires and garbage and threw rocks at police who retaliated with tear gas. They were dispersed and regrouped at Tahrir Square.
As many as 10,000 protesters demonstrating in Tahrir Square were dispersed by riot police using teargas. Many injuries were reported. The protesters regroup soon after.
Riots were reported in Alexandira, Tanta, Mahala, Mansoura and some parts of Sinai during ongoing protests against the government.
Riots were reported in Alexandira, Tanta, Mahala, Mansoura and some parts of Sinai during ongoing protests against the government.
Riots were reported in Alexandira, Tanta, Mahala, Mansoura and some parts of Sinai during ongoing protests against the government.

Riots were reported in Alexandira, Tanta, Mahala, Mansoura and some parts of Sinai during ongoing protests against the government.

On Jan 26, in Asyut, a group of people protested against the government in front of the Sawiris building. Police Forces quickly intervened, using electric weapons to disperse protesters. At least 9 were arrested. [size=no report]
On Jan 26, in Cairo, hundreds of rioters entered Gamal Abd Nasser Metro Station and stopped the traffic, forcing the metro driver to get off. [size=hundreds]
On Jan 26, dozens of militants from the Bidaya Movement staged a demonstration in Awsim against the government. [size=dozens]
On Jan 26, Police Forces prevented protesters attempting to demonstrate in Ramsis Square in Maydan Ramsis, using violence against them. [size=no report]
On Jan 26, in Baltim, some 1,000 people demonstrated against the government. They clashed with Police Forces who used tear gas against rioters. Several people were injured. [size=1,000]

On Jan 26, in Suez, a group of people attended the religious funerals of a man who died during clashes with Police Forces the day before. Police Forces prevented people from marching in the streets to the cemetery, which led to renewed violent clashes. [size=no report]
Protesters light a police station on fire, clash again with police, four killed due to injuries sustained by gunshot wounds, many others wounded.
A Bedouin anti-government protester dies while clashing with police.
Bedouin anti-government protesters attempt to fire an RPG at a local police station, but instead hit a medical center.
Violent anti-government demonstrators clash with police.
Rioters wearing surgical masks to ward off tear gas firebombed a fire station, leading to firefighters jumping out of windows to escape the flames.

On Jan 26-27, in Cairo, 3,000 people demonstrated in front of the Lawyers' Association Building. Police Forces tried to force rioters, who decided to stay overnight inside the building, to leave (around 200 people) using tear gas. Clashes were reported in Ramses Street. On Jan 27, hundreds of people were still demonstrating in front of the Lawyers' Association Building. In the evening, Police Forces managed to enter the building to disperse rioters, injuring several. (coded as 2 events) [size=3000]
Arrests: Police forces arrest 20 members of the Muslim Brotherhood. It is unclear if they were openly protesting at the time of arrest.

Hundreds of protesters gathered outside a police station in Suez and clashed with riot police. The protesters threw molotov cocktails and were met with tear gas, rubber bullets and water cannons. The protesters were demanding the release of about 75 people arrested since the beginning of anti-government demonstrations.
On Jan 27, dozens of students of Fayyum University protested in front of the Faculty of Engineering against high prices, corruption, and nepotism. [size=dozens]

On Jan 27, in Giza, dozens of people protested against the government, close to Thalatheni Street. Hundreds others protested in front of the Giza Governorate Building, blocking Al Haram Street. [size=hundreds]

On Jan 27, in Sallum, a ""large"" group of inhabitants rioted, destroying buses and throwing stones at a police station. Tensions with Police Forces were reported, though there was no reporred interaction. [size=no report]
A human rights worker is killed during a prison riot.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29.
Demonstrators stormed the NDP HQ in the Tanta governorate.
Thousands of protesters attempted to storm the state TV building and the Foreign Ministry office (within a block of each other).

Anti-government protesters torch the local headquarters of the ruling National Democratic Party. Elsewhere in Cairo, demonstrators protest the fact the polices tear gas canisters have the words ""Made in USA"" printed on them.
Dozens wounded and twelve when protesters clash with police. Authorities attempt to shut down the internet.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29.
Demonstrators protest the fact the polices tear gas canisters have the words ""Made in USA"" printed on them.
An US embassy worker who went missing in January 28 is discovered dead weeks later.
As many as 40,000 protesters gathered in Al Mansurah and destroyed the HQ of the NDP in the city.
Tens of thousands of protesters demonstrated and set fire to the NDP HQ in Damietta.
Rallies were reported in Sharqiya.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29.
Non-violent activity: Telephone service is cut throughout the country in an effort to prevent the organization of protests. Internet was also cut by the government.
Thousands demonstrated in front of the main mosque in Al-Minyah.
Large numbers of protesters were reported in Aswan.
A demonstration was reported outside the presidential palace in Heliopolis.
Hundreds of people protested in Idfu, engaging in a march with a security cordon that started peacefully but ended in clashes once they reached a police station.
Protesters marched in Imbaba but were intercepted by security forces who fired tear gas, leading to clashes where protesters threw stones.
Around 2,000 protesters gathered in Giza Square but were dispersed by police using tear gas and water cannons before they could head to Tahrir Square.
Pro-Mubarak protest occurred on January 28, when NDP parliamentarians and local bosses held a sit-in in the city of Damietta.
A peaceful protest of about 2,000 people marched down Maadis agricultural road towards Dar El Salaam.
An Al-Jazeera correspondent, Ahmad Mansur, was assaulted by plain clothes security personnel. The location of the event was not reported.
Thousands of protesters gathered in front of the Al Azhar Mosque in Cairo. They were prevented by security forces who arrested many of them.
A large number of armed men systematically attacked and looted the City Center mall in the Maadi area of Cairo, and set fire to some shops.
Arrests: Opposition leader, Mohamed El Baradei, is placed under house arrest by security forces.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29. Protesters were also reported to hav gathered outside the Interior Ministry building. Three killed when they clash with police.
A senior police officer was kidnapped in Damietta by unidentified assailants.
Anti-government protesters break into a state funded television station.

Anti-government rioters attacked the state security HQ in Rafah. Three police officers were killed in the violence which allegedly included Bedouin protesters throwing hand grenades at the building and the police firing live rounds at the rioters.

Prisoners escape from four Cairo prisons when hordes of armed gangs attack the guards in an effort to free their fellow members. Police are able to arrest a few of the escapees. ""Dozens"" dead, 1,000 escape.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: Thousands of prisoners escaped from the Wadi Natrun jail overnight.
Demonstrators killed during clashes with authorities.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29.
Rioters clash with police and other security forces.
A journalist from New Zealand is assaulted while covering Egyptian protests.
An Egyptian journalist is shot while covering uprisings, dying a week later.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: At least 700 prisoners escaped from a prison in Fayoum, during which a senior police official was killed.
Demonstrators killed during clashes with authorities.

On January 28, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets of Alexandria, Suez, and Cairo, the capital. Police responded with tear gas, water cannons, rubber bullets, and live ammunition in an effort to prevent protesters from advancing towards the central squares of those cities. The Ministry of Health said 846 persons died during the protests in January and February. Most of these were killed on January 28 and 29.
Rioters gather, ten dead when they clash with authorities.
Demonstrators killed during clashes with authorities.
A Swedish tourist caught up in ongoing protests was allegedly tortured by police while under detention. He escaped when protesters set fire to the building he was being detained in.
Protesters again renew clashes with security forces. Death toll reaches 51.
Protesters gather outside the Interior Ministry building. Three killed when they clash with police.
Several thousand demonstrators clashed with police who used batons against them in Asyut.
Non-violent activity: Egypts president fired his cabinet in the face of ongoing massive protests against President Mubaraks government.
Residents began looting, many civilians clashed with protesters, defending their homes and businesses with stick, stones and knives.
A body was allegedly thrown out of a police car in downtown Cairo and was later picked up by a medical vehicle.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: In northwest Cairo unidentified assailants attacked guards at a prison, releasing hundreds of militants. The prisoners allegedly starte fires and attacked the guards within the prison as well. Several inmates were killed or wounded during the events (coded as 3).
Egyptian Military fighter jets ""buzz"" Tahrir Square protesters at a very low altitude in an apparent attempt to disperse the ongoing protests.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: Eight prisoners are killed during a prison riot. Later ""dozens"" of bodies (coded as 12) were reportedly seen on a road near the prison (Abu Zaabal) where the riot occurred with heavy gunfire also reported overnight. 2 police were allegedly included in the fatalities related to the events.
Over 10 rioters were killed in clashes with police near the Egyptian Interior Ministry building in Cairo in the early hours of the morning.
Arrests: A Israeli journalist is captured while covering Egyptian unrest, days later released.
On Jan 30 or Jan 31 (date unclear), in Suez, rioters attacked Ataqa Police Station and allegedly released 85 undocumented Eritreans. [size=no report]
Arrests: Police arrest six western, foreign, Al Jazeera English journalists in their hotel rooms.
The Muslim Brotherhood organized a large march in Alexandria starting from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque and ending at Ahemd Abou Soleiman Street.
Arrests: Soldiers detained about 50 people during an attempt to break into the Egyptian National Museum.

On Jan 31, a few dozen women gathered at Moustafa Mahmoud square in the Mohandiseen area of Giza to protest against the deaths of protesters in Egypt over the past week and to demand the overthrow of the regime. Several groups of unidentified men and women attempted to assault them, but some inhabitants prevented them and allegedly beat them. [size=no report]
Hundreds of protesters continue to camp in Tahrir Square.
On Jan 31, in Ismailia, about 1500 people from various political movements protested against the government. [size=1500]
On Jan 31, in Suez, 5,000 people gathered in Isaaf Square and marched in the city to demand the overthrow of the regime. [size=5,000]

On Jan 31, in Suez, Al Aboor neighbourhood, Bedouin armed men clashed with Military Forces, near the Administrative Security Forces camp. A group of inhabitants allegedly caught 3 Bedouins and handed them to Military Forces.
The Wafd Party joins to protest Mubarak.
A group of unknown people attacked a group of Mubarak protesters. No report of injury or death.
As many as 50,000 protesters rallied in Alexandria in front of the Qaed Ibrahim mosque, near El-Raml station in the Ash Shatibi area, to demand the departure of President Mubarak.

Security and hospital officials from the North Sinai governorate say 35 people have been killed in clashes in the region since Jan.25. About 2/3 of these were police (26 fatalities coded in other events in North Sinai; clashes divided into two events, one with Rioters, the other with UAG due to suspected involvement of armed groups, e.g. reporting of RPG attacks).

Security and hospital officials from the North Sinai governorate say 35 people have been killed in clashes in the region since Jan.25. About 2/3 of these were police (26 fatalities coded in other events in North Sinai; clashes divided into two events, one with Rioters, the other with UAG due to suspected involvement of armed groups, e.g. reporting of RPG attacks).
Unidentified armed men attacked a sit-in in Alexandria which was calling on the army to support ongoing protests.
Despite the advise of the State Department to leave Egypt, American students join in protesting Mubarak.

A group of pro-Mubarak supporters ride camels and horses into a crowd of protesters, but soon are surrounded, dragged from their animal and beaten by protesters. One of the captured attackers was identified as a State security officer.
Unidentified, unnamed rioters loot stores and orchestrate jail breaks of prisons.
Military moves into position around protesters, fire warning shots, teargas. Protesters throw home made bombs and rocks in return. 1,500+ injuries reported by days end. Others killed.
More than 350 are injured in clashes with police. The clashes began after the police ordered protesters to disperse and they refused. Members of the NDP also clashed with protesters.
Three die in bread riots over the course of a few days. The price of most goods has risen as much as 300% since unrest began.
About 500 Mubarak supporters rallied in support of the government outside the HQ of the state TV in Cairo.
On Feb 2, pro-Mubarak protesters demonstrated in front of the Presidential Palace in Saray al Qubbah. They started a march to Downtown Cairo. [size=no report]

On Feb 2, 4 Israeli journalists were arrested in Cairo by Military Forces allegedly for participating in protests against Mubarak's regime. Six French journalists were also arrested while covering protests.

Several hundreds people protesting against the government clashed with government supporters in Alexandria. Soldiers and plain clothes agents prevented a CBS News foreign correspondent  and her crew from filming demonstrations and ""marched them at gunpoint"" to their hotel.
A Swedish reporter is attacked by a group of violent protesters with knives, then arrested by police forces. Two Russian journalists for VGTRK television were also attacked.
Several thousands people rallied outside the Mustafa Mahmoud Mosque in the Mohandiseen area in support of President Mubaraks government.

On Feb 2, in Fayoum, thousands of activists from various political parties protested to demand the departure of Mubarak. Another protest in Qiman Fares district was staged simultaneously by thousands of Muslim Brotherhood and other anti-Mubarak activists. [size=thousands]
On Feb 2, in Al Sawaki Square in Fayyum, a demonstration in support of Mubarak took place. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (1981-2011) Prison Guards
column17: On Feb 3, a group of unidentified armed men attempted to release detainees in Tura Prison. They clashed with Police Forces. Dozens were reportedly injured and arrested.
A group of men described as ""plainclothes police"" attacked the HQ of the independent daily Al-Shorouk in Cairo. Two employees were injured and the HQ was evacuated.
A Greek journalist working for Khaterimini has been injured during clashes.
A journalist and a cameraman for CBS are attacked.
A journalist for Al-Arabiya suffers a concussion.

The Egyptian military forcibly separates protesters and Mubarak supporters, who had been engaging in sporadic clashes, into two larges groups in an effort to alleviate the violence between them. This included the deployment of at least 4 tanks which moved into positions around and overlooking Tahrir Square.
A group of Palestinians protest the Mubarak regime.
Six are killed and many more injured during a new wave of evening clashes.

On Feb 3, thousands of demonstrators staged a protest in Alexandria, against Mubarak in front of Al Qaeed Ibrahim Mosque. Another protest staged by government supporters was also reported. [size=thousands]
Two journalists for Al Jazeera are attacked by ""thugs"". A journalist for Al-Arabiya also suffered a concussion.
Five protesters are killed when shots are fired and sporadic clashes occur.

On Feb 3, in Al Qantara Al Gharbiyya, hundreds of rioters blocked the road between Port Said and Ismailia, and threw stones at policemen. At least seven were injured, including two police officers. [size=hundreds]

Supporters of President Hosni Mubarak opened fire on protesters demanding he quit, wounding seven, a witness said, after what many saw as an attempted government-backed crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrations.
A few thousand protesters gathered in Sheikh Zowaid, Al-Arish and Rafah which saw an absence of police or armed forces. The protesters were demanding the departure of President Mubarak.
Unidentified gunmen in a stolen ambulance opened fire on newly appointed VP Omar Suleimans car, killing his bodyguard and seriously injuring his driver and another guard. The VP escaped unharmed.

On Feb 4, security forces arrested 40 people from different nationalities, including Syrians and Palestinians, in Shubra Al Khayma, in Foundation Square. They were allegedly coming from Damietta and heading to Tahrir Square to participate in protests.
Anti-government protest march held. No report of police interference.
Residents hold an anti-government protest, no report of police involvement.
Residents hold an anti-government protest, no report of police involvement.
Residents hold an anti-government protest, no report of police involvement.
Residents hold an anti-government protest, no report of police involvement.
Anti-government protest march held. No report of police interference.
Military forces forcibly move 1,000 protesters away from pro-regime in an effort to quell violence.

Al-Jazeeras offices in Cairo were stormed and torched by unidentified individuals. Its website was also allegedly hacked. At the same time, unidentified individuals stormed Al-Hurras Cairo news bureau and threatened to kill two journalists on-air, leading to the immediate closure of the station.
Property destruction: Unidentified assailants armed with an RPG fired upon the state security HQ in Al-Arish, destroying the building but causing no injuries.
Arrests: 10 people carrying bombs were arrested by Egyptian security forces in the El-Sayeda Zanaib area of Cairo during ongoing protests for and against the government.

A large number of journalists were detained or assaulted today according to the CPJ. The assaults were allegedly undertaken by both Mubarak supporters and plainclothes security personnel, sometimes supporting each other, including rioters handing captured journalists over to the police. Equipment was also reportedly smashed. Some of the targets including Arab, Russian, US, European and South American journalists, as well as locals.
A few thousand protesters gathered in Sheikh Zowaid, Al-Arish and Rafah which saw an absence of police or armed forces. The protesters were demanding the departure of President Mubarak.
An on-duty Egyptian police officer was kidnapped by Al-Takfir wal Hijrah in Dakahlia governorate.
A few thousand protesters gathered in Sheikh Zowaid, Al-Arish and Rafah which saw an absence of police or armed forces. The protesters were demanding the departure of President Mubarak.

Protesters reorganize and regroup in Tahrir Square for more anti-Mubarak demonstrations. Coptic Christians joined Tahrir Square protests. Many Christians are supportive of the Mubarak regime, as they see it as a form of stability given their minority status.
On Feb 5, a number of demonstrators staged a protest in support of Mubarak in Mostafa Mahmoud Square, Agouza. [size=no report]
Property destruction: Attackers destroy a gas pipeline outside of Cairo.
A church in Rafah was targeted by a bomb blast but caused little damage and no injuries.
A Cairo bureau of Al Jazeera is ransacked by ""thugs"".
Mass protests against the Mubarak regime erupt at Sidi Gaber, a city square.
Copts join Tahrir Square protests. Many Christians are supportive of the Mubarak regime, as they see it as a form of stability given their minority status.
Anti-government protests have continued in Tahrir Square. The Egyptian army is restricting protesters from entering the area.
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
On Feb 6, in Cairo, hundreds of Ministry of Education employees demonstrated inside the Ministry's office in Abdeen, against the re-appointment of Dr Badr as Education Minister. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 7, in Izbaq Halq Al Jamal, dozens of engineers from Al Atf Electricity Company and Al Mahmudiyya organized a sit-in to protest against the difference between their salaries and the salaries of engineers in other electricity companies. [size=dozens]

On Feb 7, in Kafr Amlit dozens of engineers from Al Atf Electricity Company and Al Mahmudiyya organized a sit-in to protest against the difference between their salaries and the salaries of engineers in other electricity companies. [size=dozens]
On Feb 7, in Cairo, a number of employees from Al Azhar institute staged a protest to demand the resignation of the Head of Al Azhar Institutions Ibrahim Abd Al Aal. [size=no report]

Al-Takfir wal Hijrah fighters fired as many as 4 RPG at a police station. State security sources say at least 1 police officer was injured and the building was damaged. A Bedouin youth and suspected Al-Takfir wal Hijrah member was shot during the events.
On Feb 7, around 60 taxi drivers demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Finance, in Nasr City, Cairo, to demand new employment opportunities. [size=60]
Anti-government protests continued in Tahrir Square with the military present to deter violence. As many as 2,000 people had stayed overnight.
Protesters continue to gather in Alexandria to demonstrate against the government, although their numbers were smaller than the last few days.
Hundreds of Cairo residents protested outside a government office to demand cheaper apartments, threatening to go to Tahrir Square if their girevances were not addressed.
Suez saw small anti-government protests relative to recent events in the city.
On Feb 7, in Cairo, Ministry of Education employees staged a demonstration against the Minister of Education. Police Forces interfered to disperse them. [size=no report]
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime. At least 5,000 workers also went on strike in the city.

On Feb 8, around 100 security officers at EgyptAir Company demonstrated in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Civil Aviation in Sheraton, Cairo to demand the resignation of the head of the Egyptian aviation security sector Essam Jamal al-Din, for taking several arbitrary measures against them. [size=100]
On Feb 8, in Tanta, hundreds of workers from Sianco Company organized a sit-in to protest against financial irregularities. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 9, in Dokki, several hundreds employees of the General Authority for Cleanness and Beautification continued their sit-in in front of the building to demand higher salaries. [size=hundreds] (coded as two events)
On Feb 8, in Giza, around 1,000 teachers marched from Cairo University to Qasr Al Aini Street to protest against the government. [size=1000]

On Feb 8, in Cairo, a ""massive"" number of people protested in front of the Parliament in Maglis al Shaab Street, shouting slogans against the regime. Protesters raised a banner on the building stating ""Closed until the fall of the regime"". One soldier asked them to remove the banner. No clash reported. [size=no report]
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
On Feb 8, in Imbaba, hundreds of workers from General Organization for Government Printing Offices staged a demonstration to protest against low salaries. [size=hundreds]
On Feb 8, in Ismailia, hundreds of workers of Al-Temsah Company protested at the company's headquarters to demand the unification of wages and better working conditions. [size=hundreds]
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
Protesters once again gather in Tahrir Square to demand an end to the Mubarak regime. The group have met at the Square for three weeks.
On Feb 8, 500 health workers staged a demonstration in El Hussein University Hospital, in Gamaleya Cairo, to protest against the delay in the payment of their incentives. [size=500]
On Feb 8, around 500 workers staged a protest at the Central Opera, in Abdeen, to demand better salaries. [size=500]
At least 3 were killed and at least 10 injured after protesters clash with security forces who used live rounds in the Al Kharijah area of the New Valley.
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
On Feb 8, in Azbakeyah, Cairo, around 1,000 workers of Ramses Central company staged a sit-in to demand better salaries. [size=1000]
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
Protesters gather demanding an end to the Mubarak regime.
Anti-Mubarak protesters demonstrate in Tanta.
On Feb 9, in Cairo, Al Akhbar journalists and employees staged a demonstration to demand better working conditions in front of the newspaper's headquarters. [size=no report]
On Feb 8, in Dokki, several hundreds of employees of the General Authority for Cleanness and Beautification organized a sit-in in front of the building to demand higher salaries. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 9, in Giza governorate, tens of workers of the National Organization for Drug and Control Research staged a protest to demand better working conditions (location unclear, coded as Giza, geoprecision 2). [size=no report]
On Feb 9, in Hurghada, the army blocked dozens of demonstrators from entering the Red Sea Governorate Building. Demonstrators were demanding housing allocations. [size=dozens]
As many as 4,000 protesters blocked a railway line and burned tires in an anti-government demonstration.
A number of anti-government protesters have been arrested and tortured by the government according to human rights groups and Egyptian protesters.
A group of museum workers demonstrated outside the Supreme Council of Antiquities to demand higher pay.

On Feb 9, in Qasr Al Ayni, for the second day, tens workers from Roz Al Youssef, among which journalists, staged a demonstration to demand the departure of Chairman Karam Jabr in front of Roz Al Youssef offices. [size=tens]
Thousands protested in a number of cities, including Port Said.
Hundreds of state electricity workers protested outside the offices of the South Cairo Electricity company to demand the departure of its director.
On Feb 9, in Bulaq, train workers demonstrated to demand better salaries. The demonstrators gathered on the rail lines, preventing trains from entering. [size=no report]

Around 3,000 protesters demanding cheaper housing set ablaze the governorate headquarters in the city east of Cairo. The governors car parked outside was also torched. The army, stationed nearby, did not intervene.
Tens of thousand marched along the corniche to protest the Mubarak regime.
A few thousand workers from three state-owned companies -- two petroleum firms and one of the Suez Canal zone companies -- protested asking for higher pay.
Anti-regime protesters burn a police station.

Continued clashed between security forces and protesters in the Karga Oasis area resulted in 2 more killed and many more injured. Protesters allegedly also set a police station and courthouse on fire, demanding the removal of the provincial security chief.
Several hundred workers of a silk factory and fuel coke plant in Hlewan protested to demand better pay and working conditions.

Protesters gathered outside the Egyptian parliament and blocked its entrance to demand its dissolution as part of ongoing anti-government demonstrations. Soldiers surrounded the building during the demonstration.

During 4 days, in Maadi, between Feb 10 - Feb 13, hundreds of employees from the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency staged a sit-in in front of the Agency's headquarters to demand better working conditions and higher salaries. [size=hundreds] (coded as 4 events)

On Feb 10, in Alexandria, people demonstrated in front of Al Qaid Ibrahim Mosque against the government. Demonstrators reacted with anger to Mubarak's speech, demanding his immediate departure. [size=no report]
On Feb 10, transport workers demonstrated on the train tracks of the train station in Alexandria, shutting down train transportation, to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]

On Feb 10, in Cairo, following Mubarak's speech stating he would not step down, a group of 10,000 people upset by the speech marched from the Journalists Syndicate's headquarters to Maspero Television Building - planning to block the building. [size=10000]
Tens of thousands of workers and employees from various ministries and government departments staged demonstrations in the Tanta area of Al Gharbiyah, in Kfar al-Shaykh, Asyut and Suhaj.
On Feb 10, hundreds of employees, researchers and teachers protested in front of the Ministry of Agriculture, in Dokki to demand better working conditions. [size=hundreds]
On Feb 10, workers of Imbaba Garage, in Imbaba, staged a demonstration to demand higher salaries and the departure of the head of the Public Transport Authority. [size=no report]
Protesters again gather in Tahrir Square to demand Mubarak relinquish his post as President.

Tens of thousands of workers and employees from various ministries and government departments staged demonstrations in the Tanta area of Al Gharbiyah, in Kfar al-Shaykh, Asyut and Suhaj. In Tanta, sit ins were organized in public squares.

On Feb 10, for the second day, workers from various oil companies (Sianco, Petro Trade, Putagasco) protested in front of the Ministry of Petroleum in Nasr City to demand the unification of their wages with wages of workers in the oil sector. [size=no report]
The HQ of the security forces was attacked with RPGs in Rafah. At least one person was wounded in a gunfight between masked assailants and Egyptian security forces in the area.

Tens of thousands of workers and employees from various ministries and government departments staged demonstrations in the Tanta area of Al Gharbiyah, in Kfar al-Shaykh, Asyut and Suhaj. The protests in Asyut included employees from Asyut University and pharmecutical, oil, and gas companies.
Tens of thousands of workers and employees from various ministries and government departments staged demonstrations in the Tanta area of Al Gharbiyah, in Kfar al-Shaykh, Asyut and Suhaj.

About 3,000 medical staff at Cairos largest hospital, the Kasr al-Aini Teaching Hospital, staged a mass walk out and marched to the lower house of parliament to join protesters blockading the building.

On Feb 10, in Gesr El Suez, Cairo, transport workers organized a sit-in the garage of the Public Transport Authority of Suez Bridge to demand their integration to the Ministry of Transport, better working conditions and higher salaries. [size=no report]
On Feb 10, tens of workers gathered in front of the Ministry of Electricity and Energy in Al Abbasiyah, Cairo to demand better working conditions. [size=tens]
On Feb 10, in front of the National Eye Center in Raw Al Farag, Cairo, tens of workers staged a protest against corruption and in solidarity with demonstrators in Tahrir Square. [size=tens]
On Feb 10, thousands of lawyers staged a protest against the government, marching from the Republican Palace in Abdeen to Tahrir Square. [size=thousands]
About 3,000 protesters stormed a government building in Port Said and set fire to furniture and the governors car.

On Feb 10, around 500 employees, including health workers, from various offices demonstrated in front of the Egyptian Endowments Ministry General Bureau in Abdeen to demand better working conditions. [size=500]
24,000 textile workers walk off the job and padlock their building to show solidarity with the Tahrir Square protesters.
Bus drivers and other transport workers walk off the job show solidarity with the Tahrir Square protesters.
100 part-time nurses, paramedical staff and other employees of the al-Hilal General Hospital gathered on Ramses Street to protest against the government.
Large anti-government rallies have reportedly been staged over the course of mass unrest across Egypt in Damanhur and Luxor. Unrest in Luxor takes the form of industrial action.

A few hundred people gathered at the presidential palace in Heliopolis for an anti-government protest after President Mubaraks speech saying he wouldnt step down. Military forces guarded the palace with barbed wire.
On Feb 10, Abou Ghattas Parkings workers demonstrated on the train tracks, in Ramses station, Cairo, preventing the operation of the railways to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]
A large number of people protested peacefully in Al-Arish.
Non-violent activity: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has handed executive power to a junta of senior military commanders known as the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces.
On 11 Feb 2011, a female CBS journalist was sexually assaulted and beaten before being saved by a group of woman and soldiers.

More than 10,000 protesters tore apart barricades set up by the military outside the State TV and Radio building and protested outside it, blocking employees from entering. Soldiers were nearby but did not intervene.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: On Feb 11 or Feb 12, about 600 prisoners broke out of a Marj prison, in Cairo, after riots erupted. Unknown assailants opened fire on the prison guards during the events and entered the prison, releasing the prisoners. Clashes with security killed several and injured an unknown number. (fatalities coded as 3)
Protesters gather for a final protest, dubbed the ""day of farewell"" in several towns.
On Feb 11, in 6th October, thousands of people gathered in front of Al Hosary Mosque to demand the departure of Mubarak. [size=thousands]
Protesters gather for a final protest, dubbed the ""day of farewell"" in several towns.

On Feb 11, around 4,000 people demonstrated in the streets of Luxor to demand the departure of Mubarak. A number of them later organized a sit-in in front of the Governorate Office to demand the departure of Luxor Governor. Security Forces were present but did not interfere. [size=4000]
Thousands of people demonstrated in Al-Mahalla, Damanhur and Al-Mansura to demand the departure of President Mubarak.
On Feb 11, in Port Said, demonstrators reacted angrily to Mubarak's speech. Gunshots were fired by police to disperse the protesters (unclear if Police shot at protesters). [size=no report]
On Feb 11, 4,000 people demonstrated in the streets of Qina to demand the departure of Mubarak. [size=4000]

A group of about 1,000 protesters broke off from a larger demonstrations and attacked a police station and police vehicles with molotov cocktails. 10 people were killed and 50 injured during resulting clashes with police. Police allegedly surrendered to the protesters after the clashes and the protesters proceeded to release relatives and others held at the station.
On Feb 11, in Ras Gharib, hundreds of people demonstrated to demand the departure of Mubarak and the overthrow of the regime. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 11, as many as 100,000 people from Sharkia governorate demonstrated to demand the departure of Mubarak in Zagazig, in front of the Unknown Soldier Memorial, in the center of the city. [size=100000]

On Feb 11, in Tima, rioters demonstrated against Mubarak and tried to burn down the National Party's headquarters. They clashed with Police Forces, throwing rocks at them. Police Forces shot several times at the crowd and used tear gas against the demonstrators. No fatalities reported. [size=no report]
As many as 100,000 protesters gathered in Alexandria for a ""day of farewell"" protest.

40,000 protesters marched down a main avenue in Asyut to demand the departure of President Mubarak. They split up to protest in front of the main security HQ and provincial government HQ. Riot police were on hand but did not intervene.
A large number of people protested in Sohag and Minya, marching on local government HQs.
Tens of thousands marched to demand the departure of President Mubarak in Shebin el-Kom.
A large number of people protested in Sohag and Minya, marching on local government HQs.
Police opened fire on protesters in the town of Deirout in Assiut governorate, injuring at least 4 after protesters threw rocks at a police station.
On Feb 11, in Cairo, in front of Kazndar Mosque in Shubra, 300 people demonstrated to demand the departure of Mubarak. Hundreds later joined Tahrir square.[size=300]
Thousands of people demonstrated in Al-Mahalla, Damanhur and Al-Mansura to demand the departure of President Mubarak.
Protests were held in Beni Swayf.
Hundreds of thousands demonstrate in Damanhur to demand the overthrow of Mubarak
Hundreds of Egyptian police protest alleging corruption in their ranks, including order to shoot anti-Mubarak protesters.
Defection: 15 Army officers defect and join protesters against Mubarak.
About 5,000 people marched from the Nour Mosque in Abbasiyah towards Tahrir Square as part of ongoing anti-government protests.

At least 1,000 people protested on the morning of Feb.11 at the Presidential Palace in Heliopolis (following protests by a few hundred the night before) to contiue anti-government demonstrations. Military forces protected the palace behind barbed wire. About 50 Mubarak supporters also staged a pro-government protest.
Thousands of people demonstrated in Al-Mahalla, Damanhur and Al-Mansura to demand the departure of President Mubarak.
Protesters gather for a final protest, dubbed the ""day of farewell"" in several towns.

During 4 days, in Maadi, between Feb 10 - Feb 13, hundreds of employees from the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency staged a sit-in in front of the Agency's headquarters to demand better working conditions and higher salaries. [size=hundreds] (coded as 4 events)

On Feb 12, in Kum Umbu, during a peaceful march following Mubarak's resignation, unidentified gunmen opened fire on the crowd, killing one student and injuring four others. A group of ""thugs"" also attempted to release prisoners from the police station, while 100 others burned archives of Kum Umbu Court. Several buildings were damaged. [size=no report]
On Feb 12, in Cairo, hundreds of workers from El Tawheed wa El Nour organized a sit-in to demand better working conditions in front of the firm's headquarters, in Sherif Street. [size=hundreds]
On Feb 12, in Cairo, a ""large number"" of lawyers staged a demonstration to demand the resignation of the head of the Lawyers' Association and its treasurer. [size=no report]
On Feb 12, in Mohandiseen, dozens of workers from Americana organized a sit-in to demand higher wages. [size=dozens]
On Feb 12, in Qalyub, around 500 Nestle workers organized a sit-in to demand better working conditions in front of one of the firm's branches, close to Qalyub's Bridge. [size=500]
Greater number of police officers defect to aid protesters in their efforts.

Hundreds of Egyptian police officers protested in Ismailia over abuse and corruption by police and against senior police officers orders to fire on protesters. The protesters chanted ""police and people together"" as they marched.

During 4 days, in Maadi, between Feb 10 - Feb 13, hundreds of employees from the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency staged a sit-in in front of the Agency's headquarters to demand better working conditions and higher salaries. [size=hundreds] (coded as 4 events)
On Feb 13, in Alexandria, workers from the Arabian Polevara Spinning And Weave Company demonstrated to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]
On Feb 3, in Asyut, more than 1,000 workers from the Arab Contractors organized a demonstration in front of the firm's headquarters to demand higher salaries. [size=1000]

On Feb 13, Petro Trade workers organized a sit-in in front of the company's headquarters in Cairo, in front of the Ministry of Petroleum in Nasr City and of other governorates (unclear) to denounce corruption and to demand the departure of the Minister of Petroleum. (coded as 2 events, one in Nasr City and one in Cairo geoprecision 3) [size=no report]
On Feb 13, in Shirinqash village, workers of Mansoura Petrolum Company barricaded the Mansoura-Damietta road, and lit tires, to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]

On Feb 13, more than 100 workers and teachers from El Qawmia Schools in Agouza demonstrated inside the school to demand the departure of the headmaster, Nagi Al Shehabi, also head of the Generation Party (Gil Party). They reportedly prevented him from leaving the school. [size=100]

On Feb 13, a ""large number"" of police officers protested in front of Dokki police station to demand the end of the military regime. They then moved to the Ministry of Interior to continue their protest. [size=no report]
On Feb 13, hundreds of transport workers in Giza staged a demonstration inside Giza Traffic Prosecution office against corruption. [size=hundreds]

column9: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: On Feb 13, in Al Qata, a group of armed Bedouins attacked the Al Qata prison in an attempt to free prisoners. Military Forces clashed with the attackers. No fatalities reported.

On Feb 13, in Qina, around 300 workers from the Development and Agricultural Credit Bank staged a demonstration in front of the bank's headquarters. Around 50 workers from ACEM cement factory, 80 Coca Cola workers and 100 workers from Aluminum Factory also protested to demand better working conditions. [size=hundreds]
About 700 Egyptian workers staged sit-ins in Sharm El-Sheikh and El Gorah to demand raises.

On Feb 13, military forces entered Tahrir Square to disperse a group of demonstrators who refused to leave after the ousting of Mubarak, as they wanted additional constitutional reforms. Demonstrators clashed with the military, as they tried to move them to make way for traffic. The military dispersed the crowd within hours. The military later dissolved Parliament and assumed power of the county. [size=no report]

On Feb 13, in Cairo, more than 1,500 employees from the Ministry of Education staged a demonstration in front of the Ministry to demand better working conditions. Demonstrators reportedly forced the Minister to stay in his office. [size=1500]

On Feb 13, in Abdeen, Cairo, a number of demonstrators clashed with several leaders of the Endowments Ministry. Rioters assaulted one of the leaders, trying to prevent him from entering his car. They also entered the Ministry's building and attempted to break windows. [size=no report]
