On Feb 13, more than 400 Textile Equipment Company workers demonstrated in Halwan to demand better working conditions. [size=400]

1,000 Police officers march on the grounds of the interior ministry building to protest for higher pay. They scuffled with military forces who fired into the air to disperse them. They later withdrew to avoid antagonizing protesters.
About 700 Egyptian workers staged sit-ins in Sharm El-Sheikh and El Gorah to demand raises.

On Feb 13, in Al Azhar Mosque, hundreds of Al Azhar workers, from various sectors, including teachers, demonstrated to demand better working conditions. Some demonstrators reportedly clashed violently with security guards in an attempt to enter Al Azhar Sheikh's office. [size=hundreds]

During 4 days, in Maadi, between Feb 10 - Feb 13, hundreds of employees from the Egyptian Environmental Affairs Agency staged a sit-in in front of the Agency's headquarters to demand better working conditions and higher salaries. [size=hundreds] (coded as 4 events)

On Feb 13, in Nasr City, hundreds of Cairo Bank employees staged a demonstration in front of the administration office, against the appointment of advisers in the bank by former President Mubarak's son, Gamel Mubarak. [size=hundreds]
Pro-democracy supporters clash with pro-Mubarak supporters as the former protested. 10 dead, plus many others wounded.

Several thousands refugees from East African countries, including Ethipia, Sudan and Somalia, protested outside the UNHCR office on the outskirts of Cairo to demand resettlement in another country. They attempted to enter the building but were blocked by riot police. No incidents were reported however and representatives were allowed to enter.
Hundreds of public transport workers demanded better pay outside the State TV and Radio building in Cairo.
Dozens of graduates of archeology schools demonstrated outside the Ministry of Antiquities to demand jobs.
On Feb 14, a number of demonstrators took over the National Party's headquarters in Edfu, and put the land on sale. Lootings and destruction of goods around were also reported. [size=no report]
On Feb 14, in Mansoura, train workers went onto the tracks and prevented the trains from entering the station in a demonstration against corruption. [size=no report]
On Feb 14, in Mohandiseen, journalists from Al Watani newspaper staged a sit-in in front of the newspaper's headquarters to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]

On Feb 14, in Cairo, tens of workers and activists demonstrated in front of the General Union of Workers' headquarters. Several people inside the building allegedly threw empty bottles at the protesters, injuring several of them. [size=tens]
On Feb 14, in Helwan, health workers from El Saf Central Hospital demonstrated to demand higher wages. [size=no report]
Despite the forced removal of demonstrators from Tahrir Square by the military, several return the following day.

On Feb 14, in Nasr City, a number of workers from the Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics protested in front of the Agency against inequalities regarding wages between employees. [size= no report]

On Feb 14, in Nasr City, around 2,000 employees from Al Azhar University entered Al Azhar to demand the resignation of Dr. Salah Sadiq Siddiq, the university's president. The demonstrators reportedly destroyed furniture in the offices. Demonstrators demanded better working conditions and an end to corruption. [size=2000]
Hundreds of ambulance drivers demanding better pay lined their vehicles up along Cairos Giza district.

On Feb 14, in Cairo, around a hundred teachers from Kafr El-Sheikh, Fayoum, Beheira, Helwan and Qalioubiya, protested in front of the Ministry of Education in Abdeen, to demand better working conditions. [size=100]

Workers in banking, transport, oil, tourism, textiles, state-owned media and government bodies strike to demand higher wages and better conditions. The protests were in several cities. The striking initially began with a spike in food prices.

Workers in banking, transport, oil, tourism, textiles, state-owned media and government bodies strike to demand higher wages and better conditions. The protests were in several cities. The striking initially began with a spike in food prices.

Workers in banking, transport, oil, tourism, textiles, state-owned media and government bodies strike to demand higher wages and better conditions. The protests were in several cities. The striking initially began with a spike in food prices.
About 150 tourism industry workers protested at the Great Pyramids to demand higher wages.
Demonstrations of celebration gather as news of Mubaraks ousting spreads.

Several hundreds workers protested outside the state-run Egyptian Trade Unions Federation (ETUF) building demanding the dissolution of its board who they accuse of corruption. The workers traded bottles, stones and bricks with board supporters inside the building until soldiers separated the two sides.
On Feb 14, at Ramses station, Cairo, public transport workers organized a sit-in to demand higher wages and the departure of Samir Nawar, head of the Railway Organization. [size=no report]
Hundreds of police protested for a second day, this time in Tahrir Square, to demand better pay, with some also demanding the prosecution of their former boss, former Interior Minister Habib El-Adly.
Non-violent activity: Protest organizers involved in the Tahrir Square demonstrations have formed a ""Council of Trustees"" to negotiate with the countries transitional military council.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: Unidentified assailants attacked a prison in Minya as a riot was ongoing. Prison guards were able to quell the unrest. The attack was believed to have been coordinated with the riot.

On Feb 15, Abu Suleiman inhabitants staged a demonstration against a real estate construction project led by the Lagoon Company demanding the intervention of the army to stop the project. [size=no report]

On Feb 15, in Mohandiseen, unidentified men armed with swords entered the headquarters of Al Watani newspaper and assaulted journalists who have been participating for the second day in a sit-in to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]
On Feb 15, in Cairo, hundreds of tanneries workers and demonstrated on Salah Salem Road against poor living conditions. [size=hundreds]

Police storm the Interior Ministry Building, which is in control of and guarded by the Military in a protest for higher pay. Scuffles broke out and warning shots were fired into the air. One police members was severely hurt.
Hundreds of Cairo airport employees protested inside the arrivals terminal at the Cairo International Airport to demand better wages and health benefits.
On Feb 16, dozens of teachers and assistant teachers protested inside the Education Projects Support Fund, in Zamalek, Cairo to demand fixed appointments and better working conditions. [size=dozens]

About 200-300 archeologists gathered at the Egyptian Museum, following a smaller protest earlier in the day in Zamalek, and marched on the cabinet and parliament buildings to demand an end to corruption.
On Feb 16, around a hundred teachers protested in front of the Educational Syndicate in Al Gezra, to demand the departure of the Union's Secretary General, as well as higher wages. [size=hundred]

On Feb 16, tens of families of Islamic prisoners staged a protest to demand their release and the end of the Emergency Law in front of the Prosecutor General Office in Cairo governorate (location unclear). [size=tens]
On Feb 16, hundreds of teachers and assistant teachers protested in front of Maspero Building in Cairo to demand fixed appointments and better working conditions. [size=hundreds]
Government employees from the irrigation, education and health ministries protested outside the provincial government HQ in Ismailia.
On Feb 16, in Dokki, a protest was staged by researchers close to the Ministry of Agriculture, in front of the Animal Health Research Institute.[size=hundreds]

On Feb 16, in Dokki, hundreds of temporary workers and employees from various sectors, including farmers from Damietta governorate, demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Agriculture. A number of them tried to enter the building to meet the Minister, but security guards closed all entrances. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 16, thousands of inhabitants from Al Qabouti village staged a protest in front of Port Said's Security Governorate to demand the departure of the Governor and better living conditions. [size=thousands]

On Feb 16, while a number of workers were protesting against corruption in front of the Education Directorate in Sohag, a group of unidentified armed men in a car shot at them. No injuries or fatalities reported. [size=no report]
About 1,000 people demonstrated to demand that a chemical factory be closed in Port Said for alleged waste dumping in a lake near the city.

Workers from Egypts largest textile factory relaunched a strike over pay and to demand investigation into corruption at the factory in Mahallah al-Koubra. The strike had been suspended on Feb.13. Several hundred workers also held a sit-in in the factorys courtyard in front of the administrative building.

On Feb 16, in Cairo, a number of judges, lawyers, and prosecutors protested in front of the Ministry of Justice in Abdeen. A number of judges were demonstrating against the Council of Power and Discipline's decision to dismiss them, others arguing that they were forced to resign. [size=no report]

On Feb 17, 30 doctors organized a sit-in in front of Al Azhar University's main building after being refused to be appointed in Al Azhar University Hospital in Assiut. Report mentions that they also started a hunger strike. (unclear if the sit-in was in Assiut or in Cairo) [size=30]

On Feb 17, in Cairo, hundreds of lawyers staged a demonstration against corruption, in front of the General Union's headquarters. Protesters demanded the overthrow of the Syndicate's board. [size=hundreds]
On Feb 17, in Cairo, workers from Mahmoud Al Morshedy Company threw stones at the doors and glasses of the firm's headquarters. Police Forces intervened to disperse rioters. [size=no report]

On Feb 17, in Banha, Qalyoubia governorate, dozens of workers and employees staged a demonstration in front of the Education Directorate to demand higher salaries. Demonstrators also denounced former Education Minister's policies. [size=dozens]
On Feb 17, a group of young Bedouins blocked the road from Wadi Ferran to Sharm El Sheikh. The reason of their protest is unknown. [size=no report]
Movement of forces: The Egyptian military has deployed hundreds of additional soldiers to protect a pipeline that carries natural gas to Israel after an attack on the infrastructure on Feb.5.

About 15,000 workers of the Misr Spinning and Weaving Company factory in Mahalla al-Kubra (one of Egypts largest factories) held sit-ins from Feb.16-19 in front of the companies administrative buildings in the city.
1,500 workers from the Suez Canal Authority protested in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said. 500 of those protesting were in front of the provincial HQ in Ismailia.
1,500 workers from the Suez Canal Authority protested in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said. 500 of those protesting were in front of the provincial HQ in Ismailia.
1,500 workers from the Suez Canal Authority protested in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said. 500 of those protesting were in front of the provincial HQ in Ismailia.
On Feb 17, in Abdeen, Cairo, employees of the Ministry of Education demonstrated in front of the Ministry. Police forces prevented protesters from entering the building. [size=no report]
On Feb 17, in Heliopolis, around 600 education workers and teachers protested against the mismanagement of the school, inside Al Nasr National School. [size=600]

On Feb 17, public train drivers launched a strike, disrupting train operations in Turah Al Balad train station and in a number of governorates to demand higher salaries. Military forces intervened in Turah Al Balad station, Mansheya El-Masry to disperse demonstrators. [size=no report] (coded as 2 events, one in Cairo geoprecision 3, one in Tura).

Journalists from the state-run Al-Ahram news agency camped in the buildings lobby to prevent the chief editor from leaving with three boxes they believed contained sensitive documents. Security guards intervened and confiscated the boxes.

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: One of the biggest rallies yet was held in Tahrir Square (estimates of more than 250,000 people) to celebrate the one week anniversary of the ousting of Mubarak and to reiterate their demands to the governing military council. The rally was called by the Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution (CYR) made up of the April 6 Youth Movement, youth wing of the Muslim Brotherhood and supporters of Mohamed El-Baradei. Many military personnel were also at the protest, with a military band playing at one point during the rally.

column7: Muslim Group (Egypt); Muslim Brotherhood; April 6 Youth Movement; National Association for Change
column17: On Feb 18, in Aswan, more than 2,000 people, among which activists from various political groups (Muslim Brotherhood, April 6 Youth Movement, National Association for Change) participated in a victory march, celebrating the ousting of Mubarak. Demonstrators also demanded the release of prisoners and an end to corruption. [size=2000]

On Feb 18, Al Mahallah, following Friday's protests, hundreds of people marched in the streets to protest against corruption, and also celebrating the one week anniversary of the ousting of Mubarak. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 18, in Tanta, following Friday's protests, hundreds of people marched in the streets to demonstrate against corruption, and also celebrating the one week anniversary of the ousting of Mubarak. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 18, in Ismailia, political parties, among which January 25 Revolution Youth Coalition, organized a massive demonstration to demand the release of political prisoners and the repeal of the Emergency Law. [size=no report]

On Feb 18, in Sheik Zayed, inhabitants staged two demonstrations, one in thirtieth street, and the other one in front of the new governorate to demand justice for the ""Revolution's martyrs"". [size=no report]

On Feb 18, in Shibin Al Kawn, after Friday's prayers, thousands staged a demonstration in front of Al Abbassi Mosque to celebrate the one week anniversary of the ousting of Mubarak and to demand the departure of Shafiq government. [size=thousands]

On Feb 18, in Kharga, a group of people assaulted policemen in Al Sabt neighborhood and clashed with them, in front of the Nasser school. Rioters allegedly also burned several security buildings. At least one policeman was injured. [size=no report]
On Feb 18, several hundreds of airlines workers staged a demonstration in Cairo International Airport to demand better working conditions. [size=several hundreds]

On Feb 18, in Cairo, thousands of tourist guides and workers from the tourism industry gathered at Tahrir Square and marched, chanting slogans affirming that after Mubarak's departure, Egypt is safe for tourists. [size=thousands]

Several hundreds pro-Mubarak protesters gathered in the Mohandiseen area of Cairos Giza district at the same time as a large rally was held in Tahrir Square to celebrate his departure. The protesters dubbed it a ""sorry president"" rally for Mubaraks ouster.

About 15,000 workers of the Misr Spinning and Weaving Company factory in Mahalla al-Kubra (one of Egypts largest factories) held sit-ins from Feb.16-19 in front of the companies administrative buildings in the city.

Hundreds of thousands of people rallied outside the main mosque in Alexandira in the Ash Shatibi area and called for the departure of the new Shafiq government, employing the same chants used against Mubaraks government.
More than 250 workers at the Centamin/Sukari gold mine just outside Marsa Alam protested to demand better pay and Egyptian ownership of the mine (currently under Australian ownership).

On Feb 19, hundreds of students staged a demonstration in Cairo University, in Umraniyah, Cairo to demand an increase in the number of days of study, better health insurance and the right to take part in students' unions. [size=hundreds]
Police protested for 4-days in front of the Interior Ministry in Cairo to demand better salaries.

About 15,000 workers of the Misr Spinning and Weaving Company factory in Mahalla al-Kubra (one of Egypts largest factories) held sit-ins from Feb.16-19 in front of the companies administrative buildings in the city.
A group of 100 gather in Alexandria to protest in solidarity of the uprising in Libya.
About 300-400 protesters demonstrated in front of the Libyan embassy in Cairos Zamalek area to demand the departure of Libyan leader Muammar al-Ghaddafi..

On Feb 20, in Cairo, hundreds of students from the Workers' University and from the College of Industrial Education held a demonstration in front of the Ministry of Higher Education to demand a supplementary year equivalent to graduates' program from the Faculty of Engineering. [size=hundreds]
On Feb 20, in Nasr City, 50 Al Azhar graduates staged a demonstration in front of the university to demand their appointment as teachers. [size=50]

On Feb 20,in Al Jazira, Cairo, dozens of teachers protested against the Union's policies in front of the headquarters of the Educational Syndicate. They attempted to enter the office of Union's secretary, but were prevented by security personnel. [size=dozens]
On Feb 20, workers of the Ezz Dekheila Steel Factory in Dukhayla, Alexandria, staged a demonstration to demand better working conditions. [size=no report]
On Feb 20, in Cairo, around 200 workers of Al Ahram newspaper organized a demonstration to demand better working conditions. [size=200]

On Feb 20, in Doqqi, after a car prevented an employee from entering the Agricultural Hospital and allegedly hit him, a number of people demonstrating clashed with security forces from the Ministry of Local Development. [size=no report]
On Feb 20, around 300 workers from Omar Affendy Company organized a sit-in in front of the company's headquarters in Abdeen, Cairo, to demand better working conditions. [size=300]
On Feb 20, in Abdeen, Cairo, tens of high school students staged a demonstration in front of the Ministry of Education on Sunday morning to demand the delay of some of their exams. [size=tens]
Police protested for 3-days in front of the Interior Ministry in Cairo to demand better salaries.
Dozens of Libyans and Egyptians demonstrated outside the Arab League headquarters near Tahrir Square to protest against use of force by the Libyan government against anti-government protesters.

About 100 truck drivers protesters demonstrated in the port-town of Adabiya about rising tolls in the area and alleged mistreatment by the ports administration. Military forces arrived and detained at least 5 protesters. A woman was allegedly killed by a tank as she attempted to stop them from taking away her son. The protest swelled to about 1,000 people after news of her death spread.

On Feb 21, in Nasr City, around 4,000 workers of the Central Auditing Organization demonstrated in front of the CAO building, in Salah Salem street to demand the departure of the head of the Organization, Dr Al Malt. Several military tanks were deployed to help him get out of the building safely. No clashes reported. [size=4000]
On Feb 21, in Mansoura, in the evening, a group of activists organized a march to protest against the use of violence by the Libyan government against anti-government protesters. [size=no report]

On Feb 21, in Dokki, dozens of security personnel from Al-Rehab City staged a demonstration in front of Hisham Talaat Mustafa Group's headquarters, in Musadak Street, to demand better working conditions. [size=dozens]
Police protested for 3-days in front of the Interior Ministry in Cairo to demand better salaries.

On Feb 22, in Zahraa Al Maadi, more than 1,500 workers from a group of piping companies barricaded the road to Katameya, to demand higher wages and better working conditions. Demonstrators also burned tires. [size=1500]

On Feb 22, dozens of Egyptian and Libyan protesters demonstrated for the second time in front of the Libyan embassy in Cairo's Zamalek area to demand the departure of Libyan leader Muammar al-Ghaddafi. [size=dozens]
Employees of the Libyan consulate in Alexandria lowered the countries flag and joined anti-government protesters demonstrating outside the consulate building.

Over 1,000 protesters gathered in Tahrir Square in a symbolic protest organized by the April 6 Youth Movement after the governing military council responded to some of their grievances the night before.

On Feb 22, in Cairo, tens of workers from the Nile Cotton Ginning Company organized a sit-in in front of the Supreme Court on Qasr al Nile to demand the access to the dossier regarding the sale of company as well as better working conditions. [size=tens]

On Feb 22, a large number of Libyans and Egyptians renewed their demonstration outside the Arab League headquarters near Tahrir Square to protest against the use of violence by the Libyan government against anti-government protesters. [size=large]

On Feb 22, in Cairo, in the afternoon, a group of citizens from various governorates staged a protest in front of the Supreme Court in Qasr al Nile, demanding the release of more than 200 Egyptians imprisoned in Saudi Arabia. [size=no report]

On Feb 22, in Attarin, tens of recently retired workers from the Maritime Transport Company staged a demonstration in front of the company's main building in Fouad Street, following financial issues regarding their insurance. [size=tens]
On Feb 22, in Cairo, a large number of Egyptian families with relatives living in Libya staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to demand their repatriation. [size=large]

On Feb 22, in Menoufia workers of the Andorama Shebin Textile company in Menoufia started a strike to demand higher wages and better working conditions. They reportedly prevented the head of the company to get out of the building. [size=no report]

On Feb 22, in Hurghada, in the morning, nearly 2,000 police officers from various cities of the Red Sea governorate marched in the streets to demand better working conditions. They barricaded a road. [size=2000]

On Feb 22, angry villagers set fire to two Bahai homes after demonstrations against local authorities refusal to upgrade a marina for ferries connecting their island village to the mainland. The homes were owned by an official and were vacant at the time. [size=no report]
Police protested for 3-days in front of the Interior Ministry in Cairo to demand better salaries.

After a small demonstration outside a Cathedral in the Abbassiyah area of downtown Cairo, Coptic Christian protesters then marched to Tahrir Square, growing to around 2,000 by the time they arrived and staged a demonstration. Reports conflicted about whether they were demonstrating against the killing of a Coptic priest in Asyut or the demolition of a wall at a Coptic monastery that led to clashes between Coptic monks and soldiers. About 200 spent the night in the Square before leaving the next morning.

On Feb 23, in Cairo, Nasr City, hundreds of employees from the Ministry Of State For Administrative Development demonstrated in front of the Ministry against the project aiming at dismantling the Ministry and its projects. [size=hundreds]
An estimated 3,000 Copts riot through the streets Asyut, burning police cars and smashing windows in protests of a killing of a Christian priest.
A Coptic Priest is killed at his home during an alleged robbery. He was discovered with several stab wounds. The killing triggered several demonstrations.

4 Coptic monks and 1 army officer were injured when soldiers arrived at the Bishop Bishoy Monastery in Wadi Natrun and demolished a wall the monks had built after hearing about prison breaks during recent anti-government protests.

On Feb 23, in Cairo, 160 temporary workers from the Information and Decision Support Center organized a sit-in to demand better working conditions and their appointment as permanent workers. [size=160]

On Feb 23, in Dokki, hundreds of workers and temporary workers from various governorates demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Agriculture to demand their appointment and the abolition of temporary contracts. Protesters attempted to enter the building but were pushed back by military forces, who attempted to disperse them. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 23, in Awsim, a number of Muslim Brotherhood activists entered and took control of the National Democratic Party's headquarters, forcing the Party's secretary to leave the building. [size=no report]

On Feb 23, in Marsa Matruh, hundreds of activists and lawyers staged a protest in front of the Court to demand the departure or arrest of Ahmed Qidaf Ad Dam, in charge of Egyptian-Libyan relations. Demonstrators chanted slogans against Khadafi's government. [size=hundreds]
Several hundred Coptic Christians demonstrated outside a cathedral in the Abbassiya area in downtown Cairo after a service to denounce the killing of a Coptic priest in Asyut.

On Feb 23, in Cairo, more than a hundred employees and teachers from the Ministry of Education staged a protest in front of the Ministry in Abdeen, to demand better working conditions. The demonstrations disrupted traffic in the area. Security staff attempted to calm protesters, but reportedly failed to disperse the protest. [size=100]

On Feb 23, in Cairo, dozens of Egyptians demonstrated in front of the headquarters of the Arab League, located close to Tahrir Square. Demonstrators denounced the massacres carried out by the Libyan regime, and demanded actions against Qaddafi. [size=dozens]

After 4-days of protests outside the Interior Ministryto demand better salaries, police who had been dismissed from their positions used firebombs to set parts of the building on fire during continued protests. Soldiers failed to disperse the crowd despite firing into the air.

column8: El Basatin Al Gharbeyah Communal Militia (Egypt)
column17: During a confrontation with a microbus driver at Gavaer Square in the El Basatin Al Gharbeyah neighbourhood a police officer shot him, and was then attacked with knives by bystanders who were attempting to intervene in the incident when the gunshot occurred.
After a confrontation between people and a police office leading to a microbus driver being shot, people protested in Gazaer Square and shouted anti-police slogans.

On Feb 24, a number of Egyptian and Libyan demonstrators renewed their protest in front of the Libyan embassy in Cairo's Zamalek area to demand the departure of Libyan leader Muammar al-Ghaddafi and the intervention of Egypt in Libya. [size=no report]
On Feb 24, around 200 teachers protested in front of the Educational Syndicate in Al Jazira, Cairo, to demand the departure of the Syndicate's Secretary General Suleiman. [size=200]
On Feb 24, in Cairo, 2,000 workers from the Central Authority for Reconstruction staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Housing against corruption inside the agency. [size=2000]

On Feb 24, following a dispute between two families in Othman Moharram street, in Al Omraneyah, police officers attempted to interfere. One policeman, assaulted by one man, shot and killed a bystander by mistake. To avoid retaliation from the young man's relatives, police forces set up a security cordon in front of Omraneyah Police Station.

On Feb 24, in Nasr City, a number of employees from the Ministry Of State For Administrative Development renewed their demonstrations for the second day in front of the Ministry to demand the departure of the Minister after he decided to attach the Ministry to another administrative entity. [size=no report]

Tens of thousands gathered in Tahrir Square in what was dubbed the 'Friday of Cleansing and Protecting the Revolution,' demanding the resignation of the current government headed by Prime Minister Ahmed Shafiq.

On Feb 25, in Amiriyah, Alexandria governorate, thugs armed with white weapons and swords attacked civilians, using Molotov cocktails, in an attempt to seize their lands, injuring an unknown number. )
On Feb 25, in Alexandria, following Friday's prayers, thousands of people demonstrated peacefully in front of Qaid Mahmoud Mosque, to carry out reforms. [size=thousands]

On Feb 25, following Friday's prayers, people rallied to demand a new government and called for the dismissal of hold-overs from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak. Demonstrators clashed with Police Forces in front of the Security Directorate, throwing stones at policemen. Police used tear gas and fired at the rioters to disperse them. [size=no report]

On Feb 25, in Al Mahallah, 2,000 people gathered in Al Shoum Square to demand the release of political prisoners. Demonstrators also called for the dismissal of holdovers from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak. [size=2,000]

On Feb 25, following Friday's prayers, hundreds gathered in front of Moustafa Mahmoud Mosque in Dokki, Cairo to honor former President Mubarak and express their ""love and gratitude"". [size=hundreds]
On Feb 25, inhabitants in Imbabah organized a march in support of police actions during the Revolution. [size=no report]

The military forcibly removed Friday of Cleansing and Protecting the Revolution protesters with batons as they enforced a midnight curfew. Clashes and injuries were reported. The military later apologized for the aggressive use of force.
A group of students gather at the Pyramids to rally for tourism, which has been lacking since the popular uprising.

Tens of thousands rallied in Egypt, trying to keep up pressure on Egypt's military rulers to carry out reforms and calling for the dismissal of holdovers from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

Tens of thousands rallied in Egypt, trying to keep up pressure on Egypt's military rulers to carry out reforms and calling for the dismissal of holdovers from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak.
Protesters gather outside the Cabinet Office building for the Friday of Cleansing and Protecting the Revolution and demonstrated overnight.

Tens of thousands rallied in Egypt, trying to keep up pressure on Egypt's military rulers to carry out reforms and calling for the dismissal of holdovers from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak.

Tens of thousands rallied in Egypt, trying to keep up pressure on Egypt's military rulers to carry out reforms and calling for the dismissal of holdovers from the regime of ousted President Hosni Mubarak.
Authorities filed charges of 'thuggery' against a peaceful protester, arrested during a protest in Tahrir Square on February 26.
On Feb 26, in Shubra Al Khayma, dozens of inhabitants organized a sit-in in front of Shubra Al Khayma's power station demanding to connect electricity to their homes. [size=dozens]

After a bloggers case was deferred until next month (or potentially indefinitely), tens of demonstrators started a protest outside the court against the decision. The protesters accused the Ministry of Justice of bias in the case.
On Feb 26, dozens of teachers demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Abdeen, Cairo to demand their appointment and better working conditions. [size=dozens]

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: Protesters who demonstrated overnight outside the Cabinet Office building for the Friday of Cleansing and Protecting the Revolution were beaten as soldiers dispersed them when the curfew began at midnight. Some of the protesters attempted to resist the soldiers. At least 4 protesters were detained during the clash which left at least one protester injured.
On Feb 27, in Cairo, a number of disabled people staged a protest in front of the Parliament in Qasr al Ayni, to demand the departure of Shafiq's government. [size=no report]
About 3,000 fishermen protested outside the coastguard offices in Kafr el-Sheikh to demand enroachments on el-Borollous Lake be removed and more licenses for fish farms be created.
On Feb 27, around 300 students from Ismail Qabbani high school in Al Abbasiyah staged a protest in front of the Education Governorate in Abbasiya, Cairo. [size=300]

On Feb 27, in Alexandria, workers dismissed by Petrojet staged a demonstration in front of the company's building, located on the Desert Road, to demand their return to work and better working conditions. [size=no report]

On Feb 27, around 2,000 Abu Zaabal workers staged a demonstration in front of the company's headquarters to demand better wages and an end to corruption. [size=2,000] (location unknown, coded as Cairo geoprecision 3)
On Feb 27, thousands of imams and Al Azhar workers marched in Cairo to demand the financial and administrative independence of Al Azhar. [size=thousands]

On Feb 27, tens of workers from the General Authority for Agricultural Reforms demonstrated in front of the main building, next to the Ministry of Agriculture, in Dokki to demand higher wages. [size=tens]

On Feb 27, in 10th of Ramadan city, more than 500 workers, including employees and teachers, staged a demonstration in front of 10th of Ramadan's Educational Administration in to demand higher wages and better working conditions. [size=500]
Protesters remained camped in Tahrir Square overnight and stayed on Feb.27 following a violent dispersal on the night of Feb.25-26.

Villagers in southern Egypt blocked the Cairo-Asyut highway with burning tires protest official corruption in relation to government management of state-owned of bakeries. In another village near Asyut, three government buildings were set on fire by other protesters angry about government corruption.
Civil servants in Asyut went on strike and protesters in the city also set the former ruling party HQ on fire.

On Feb 27, hundreds of teachers renewed their demonstration in front of the Ministry of Education in Cairo to demand better working conditions. Dozens of students from Fayoum University also gathered in front of the Ministry, some to demand their appointment, others to demand a delay of the exams' period. [size=hundreds]

On Feb 28, in Fayoum, close to Yousef el sadeq area, hundreds of farmers took over agricultural lands belonging to the family of Dr. Youssef Waly, former Minister of Agriculture. The farmers said that these lands were taken away from them in the past and they were reclaiming land that belonged to them. [size=hundreds] (location unclear, coded as Al Nazla, geoprecision 2)
On Feb 28, in 6th October city, workers from Al Rachidi El Mizan organized a sit-in to demand higher salaries. [size=no report]
On Feb 28, in Giza Square, dozens of people, including policemen, staged a rally in support of police forces. [size=dozens]

On Feb 28, 3,000 workers from the Chemical Industries Development Company organized a sit-in in front of the building in Umraniyya to demand the departure of board members and the creation of a special committee composed of members of the syndicate in charge of fighting corruption. Demonstrators also demanded higher wages. [size=3000]

On Feb 28, in Cairo, 50 employees of the National Bank for Development organized a sit-in the morning in front of the bank's headquarters in Bursa Al-Jadida Street in Abdeen, demonstrating against the dismissal of two of their colleagues. [size=50]

On Feb 27 or Feb 28 (unclear), in front of the Ministry of Education in Abdeen, Cairo, around 2,000 high school students demanded a diminution of their education program as well as to delay their exams' period. [size=2000]
Unknown people attack Yemeni ambassadors convoy outside Asyut. The attacker was later arrested.
Two are killed in prison riot, 10 other wounded when guard open fire.

Most of the Central Auditing Agencys staff staged a protest demanding the departure of the agenys chairman. A fire later broke out on the second floor of the agency building. The chairman accused the protesters of setting the fire.
Protesters stage a ""sit-in"" following the arrest and sentencing of a human rights activist.
Arrests: Security forces arrest and detain seven protest leaders in a cafe near the pyramids.
Arrests: A correspondent and a cameraman working for Russia's Zvezda television channel were detained by men in plainclothes and held overnight.
Student protests demanding the resignations of senior university figures were successful in Helwan, Zagazig, Alexandria, Asyut and Sohag.
Student protests demanding the resignations of senior university figures were successful in Helwan, Zagazig, Alexandria, Asyut and Sohag.
Student protests demanding the resignations of senior university figures were successful in Helwan, Zagazig, Alexandria, Asyut and Sohag.
Student protests demanding the resignations of senior university figures were successful in Helwan, Zagazig, Alexandria, Asyut and Sohag.
Student protests demanding the resignations of senior university figures were successful in Helwan, Zagazig, Alexandria, Asyut and Sohag.

The fathers of 2 families, one Muslim and one Christian, and some of their relatives engaged in a gunfight in Sawl over a dispute related to a relationship between their children. The 2 fathers were shot dead during the fight.
Thousands of Egyptians demonstrated in Tahrir Square to demand continued reform. Later in the day, the new PM Essam Sharaf came to the square and was cheered by the demonstrators.

Protesters storm a building belonging to Internal Security. 50 are killed when the military opens fire. Reports say the protesters were demanding the abolition of the security service over human rights abuses committed during the rule of ousted President Hosni Mubarak
Protests occurred in Sharkia governorate to demand the disbanding of the state security forces.

After a clash between a Muslim and a Christian family in Sawl over a relationship between two of their children leading to deaths on both sides, a crowd of Muslims protested in front of a church in the area and later broke into it and torched it after police/military personnel had escorted Christians in the building to safety.
Thousands of Coptic protesters engaged in a sit-in in front of the state radio/TV building. They were protesting against a recent church burning.
Around 2,500 protesters stormed the state security building in Cairos Nasr City. They were attempting to acquire sensitive documents which they believed were going to be destroyed.

A group of 500 protesters storm the State Security headquarters armed with sticks and stones, the army responds opening fire. No report of injury or death. The group was trying to seize documents that would provide evidence of human rights abuses as well as preventing said documents from being destroyed.
Protesters stormed the state security HQ in Marsa Matrouh, gathering thousands of documents before setting the building on fire.
Demonstrators stormed the state security offices in Zagazig and Fayum.
Demonstrators stormed the state security offices in Zagazig and Fayum.
Hundreds of protesters surrounded the main offices of the state security agency in 6th of October City to demand an end to alleged burning of evidence of human rights abuses.
Unidentified armed men armed with swords and petrol bombs attack a group of about 500 protesters who were attempting to storm the state security building in the Lazoghly neighborhood of Cairo.
A large number of Cairo university students (mass comm) and professors protested to demand the firing of all the senior figures at the university.
After helping to overthrow Mubarak, Egyptian women - and some men - demonstrated today in favor of giving women more of a voice in building Egypts future. One woman is attacked by an unknown person.

After some men heckled a protest by women for more rights, the army was forced to intervene by firing into the air to disperse the rioters who attempted to attack the women. Some female protesters were beaten.

Egyptian women - and some men - demonstrated today in favor of giving women more of a voice in building Egypts future. Crowds of men turned up at the protest to shove and heckle the demonstrators and eventually chased them out of the Square after they outnumbered them. Women were reportedly beaten by the men.

Clashes between Copts and Muslims were reported in the Muqattam, Al Sayyida Aisha, El-Basatin, and Al Qalah areas of Cairo after Copts protested the burning of a church last week. At least 13 people (6 Copts and 7 Muslims) were killed and 140 injured (68 Copts and 72 Muslims) in the violence which broke out when Muslims attacked the Coptic protesters leading to stone throwing and clashes. Most of the casualties were reported in the Muqattam area, although at least 1 occurred around the blocked Autostrad.

Clashes between Salafists and Copts broke out on Autostrad road in the El-Basatin Sharkeya area of Cairo as Copts protested the burning of a church last week. At least one Copt was killed and 5 people injured during the fight.
Egyptian soldiers attempted to break up clashes between Copts and Muslims in the Muqattam district of Cairo with aerial firing but were not able to separate the two groups of rioters.
About 2,000 Christians blocked a main road in the eastern part of Cairo and threw stones at motorists. They were protesting the burning of a church last week.
13 Christians are dead after a group of Muslims clash with protesting Christians. 110 wounded. Is a battle rather than VAC, see source file p16
1,000 Christians gather to protest the burning of a Church last week.

Egyptian soldiers and men in civilian clothes violently broke up a sit-in by students in Tahrir Square, arresting at least 174 protesters. The men in civilian clothes armed with sticks, clubs and iron rods were sent in first and attacked the protesters for about an hour, allegedly taking some of them to the Egyptian Museum where they were detained and allegedly assaulted by security personnel. The military then moved in after to clear the Square.
A celebrity archeologist resigns his professional position in protest of how antiquities are cared for by the government.
Hundreds of Egyptians staged a demonstration in Tahrir Square to denounce sectarianism and support unity. Both Christians and Muslims were present at the demonstration.
Families of political prisoners being held in various Egyptian prisons protested in front of the cabinet building in the Zamalek district of Cairo to demand their immediate release.

The Egyptian army shelled 7 vehicles laden with arms and ammunition that had crossed over to just inside its border with Sudan. Casualties were estimated at 29. It was not clear who was killed in the attack.

Non-violent activity: The Egyptian Interior Ministry has disbanded the state security, often referred to as the secret police, which played a notorious role in targeting enemies of the state under former President Mubarak and in the recent anti-government unrest.

Mass comm students engaged in a sit-in at Cairo University say the military violently intervened to disperse them. A military spokesman says that they intervened peacefully as the protesters were blocking professors from leaving the university. The event occurred sometime after the sit-in started in March.
Twelve inmates were reportedly killed during a prison killing at the hands of guards.
A group of 100 gather in front of a department store to protest wages.
Thousands of people marched in Cairo against amendments to the constitution which will be voted on in a referendum tomorrow. They gathered in Tahrir Square and chanted ""Down with the Constitution"".
Islamists threw stones and shoes at opposition figure Mohamed El Baradei as he went to vote in a referendum on the military councils proposed constitutional amendments. He escaped unhurt.
A building fire is started by arsonists.

Thousands of police officers gather outside the Interior Ministry Building to protest for higher pay. They later set part of the building on fire during their protest. 8 people suffered from smoke inhalation due to the blaze.
The military used excessive force and carried out arbitrary mass arrests in various cities to disperse demonstrations and sit-ins on numerous occasions - beating and tasering those arrested.

Violent clashes broke out between pro- and anti-Mubarak protesters in front of the Egyptian Parliament (about 2 blocks from Tahrir Square). About 200 supporters of the former president clashed with 300 anti-government protesters, with both sides throwing bottles and stones before police intervened to break them up.

2,000 gather in Tahrir Square to call for ousted President Mubarak to be put on trial without delay. They also called for other former government figures to be tried for corruption and for the release of political prisoners. Copts called for an end to ethnic and religious strife in an adjacent protest.

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: Police detained a score of men who attempted to storm El-Mazraa Prison in the Torah area of Cairo and free hundreds of inmates. Those detained said they were attempting to release their relatives and friends who they say should have been freed under a new decree from the Interior Minister.
Around 200 protesters demonstrated outside the Egyptian Parliament (about 2 blocks from Tahrir Square) against a draft law that would ban strikes.
Egyptian clerics and employees of state Islamic religious bodies are demanding an end to what they say is rampant corruption by senior officials who manage religious endowments.
College students demonstrate in an effort to remove a dean appointed by Mubarak. The military dispersed them with several injuries.

On 01 April 2011, protesters gathered in front of Istiqama mosque in Al Jizah to demand criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials. The demonstrators headed towards Tahrir Square to join the ""Friday for the Rescue of the Revolution Day"" demonstration. [size=no report]

On 01 April 2011, protesters gathered in Imbaba in Giza to demand criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials. The demonstrators headed towards Tahrir Square to join the ""Friday for the Rescue of the Revolution Day"" demonstration. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: At least 6 police were injured in a prison riot at el-Qanater on the outskirts of Cairo. At least 9 inmates were injured when the guards opened fire to disperse the riot.

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: Thousands of people protested in Tahrir Square to demand criminal persecution of Mubarak and other regime officials. The demonstration was dubbed the gathering the ""Friday for the Rescue of the Revolution Day"".

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: ""Save the Revolution"" protests organized by the CYR were held in Alexandria to demand trials for Mubarak and his family.

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: People protest calling for criminal persecution of Mubarak and other regime officials. The demonstration was dubbed the gathering the ""Friday for the Rescue of the Revolution Day"".

On 02 April 2011, more than 200 protestors organized a sit-in in Tahrir Square in Cairo to demand the criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials, cancel anti-protest laws, and the dissolution of local councils. [size=more than 200]
Unidentified gunmen abducted the grandniece of late Egyptian leader Anwar Sadat from the Heliopolis and released her 24 hours later after a large ransom (USD 840,000) was paid to them.

On 04 April 2011, more than 150 protestors held a sit-in in Tahrir Square in Cairo to demand criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials, the cancelling anti-protest laws, and the dissolution of local councils. [size=more than 150]
Around 500 protesters in Sohag blocked a railroad to Aswan over repeated quarrels between two tribes in the area. They demanded greater police protection.

Hundreds of Copts from Al-Kamader village in Minya protested in front of the governorate building to demand that a service center be transformed into a church. This led a group of Muslims to besiege the facility.
Tens of demonstrators from Fayoum Governorate protested outside the cabinet building in Cairo to demand the sacking of the governor of their area for allegedly seizing land.
Hundreds of people gathered in Cairo to protest and demand the sacking of governors and members of the former NDP who hold government posts.
On 07 April 2011, more than 400 protestors organized a sit-in in Tahrir Square in Cairo to demand criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials. [size=more than 400]
Workers protested in front of a Telemisr factory on Al Haram street after the owners shut down the factory .

Tens of thousands of protesterss, including a group of Army Officers, demonstrated for the criminal persecution of Mubarak and his family. Some of those camped in the Square overnight. They were also allegedly demonstrating against the military council.
Nearly 2,000 pro-Palestinian protesters gathered outside the Israeli embassy in the Oula area of Giza as Israeli warplanes and tanks carried out attacks neighboring Gaza.
Two protesters are dead, 18 wounded, when the army tried to disperse them with force.

Estimates of 500 to thousands of potesters barricaded themselves in Tahrir Square with barbed wire following a violent crackdown by authorities on demonstrators there and demanded the removal of the military governing council to replace it with a civilian council. A bus and a truck were allegedly set on fire during the demonstrations by demonstrators armed with clubs.

Early on April 9 (around 2-5am), hundreds of soldiers backed by armored vehicles used batons, rubber bullets and live ammunition to break up a sit-in opposing SCAF's rule, wounding at least 71 protesters and killing two (according to medical sources reported on by the AFP). 42 people were also arrested.
More than 1,000 protesters remained in barricaded in Tahrir Square behind barbed wire and burnt vehicles after the military council backed down from a threat to disperse them.

On 10 April 2011, more than 100 demonstrators gathered in Tahrir Square demanding the opening of the square and the removal of barricades and barbed wire. Demonstrators demanding the removal of the barricaded and those who constructed it threw strones at each other. The barricade had been constructed by demonstrators demanding the prosecution of Mubarak and members of his government, who were accused of causing frictions between the people and the army. [size=more than 100]
On 10 April 2011, thousands of Al-Azhar Univeristy students demonstrated on Al-Azhar Univeristy campus in Nasr City to denounce the Israeli strikes on Gaza. [size=thousands]

Clashes broke out in the Saft El Laban area of Giza after a rumour that Copts had attempted to burn down Bilal Mosque. Some unidentified assailants then attacked the houses of Copts in the area, leading to clashes between Copts and Muslims with guns and knives that left 8 wounded. Police and soldiers later intervened to separate the two sides.

Hundreds of protesters remained barricaded in Tahrir Square and said they will continue their demonstration until Mubarak and his family are put on trial and a civil presidential council is created. A minor scuffle with soldiers was reported in one part of the Square but other protesters separated the two groups. Two groups of protesters also got into a scuffle over attempts to remove the barbed wire, while others threw stones at vehicles attempting to enter the Square.
Soldiers and police dispersed a demonstration in Tahrir Square which had been ongoing since the weekend. Hundreds of soldiers were present and a number of youths were detained.
Arrests: President Mubarak and two of his sons were detained as part of an investigation into the use of force against protesters during demonstrations in January and February.

On 13 April 2011, demonstrations took place in front of the Sharm el-Sheikh International Hospital in Sharm el-Sheikh demanding the expulsion of Mubarak and his family from the hospital and the town because of the negative impact his presence has on tourism in the area. [size=no report]
Fights have been reported in Mattareya Hospital over the past two weeks between families of patients over priority of treatment.
Tens of Al-Nasr Automative company workers protested in front of the cabinet building in Cairo to demand implementation of a pormise to pay the remainder of their ""early retirement incentives"".

An army officer and a group of men with him stormed a building in the Imbaba area where a conference organized by a FB group ""No to Trials for Civilians before Military Courts"". A scuffle broke out after the group burst into the hall, shouting that foreigners and journalists were present. At least one person was injured and 3 later arrested by police.

3 days of protests were held in Qena outside the governorate office against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as Qenas new governor. Salafi Islamists allegedly headed the protests.

On 15 April 2011, around 600 Mubarak supporters demonstrated in front of the state TV and radio building against putting him on trial and to denounce perceived insults directed towards the former Egyptian leader. Later, tens of demonstrators demanding that Mubarak stand trial marched to the state TV and radio building and clashed with the pro-Mubarak supporters. Military forces intervened to disperse the demonstrators and end the clashes. [size=around 600]

Thousands of Copts marched from Shoubra to Tahrir Square to demand the release of Copts detained during a sit-in outside the state TV and radio building, and to mark 40 days since violence in Muqattam led to the death of a Copt.

On 15 April 2011, more than 300 protestors gathered in Tahrir Square in Cairo to demand criminal prosecution of Mubarak and other regime officials, the cancelling anti-protest laws, and the dissolution of local councils. [size=more than 300]

3 days of protests were held in Qena outside the governorate office against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as Qenas new governor. Salafi Islamists allegedly headed the protests.

3 days of protests were held in Qena outside the governorate office against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as Qenas new governor. Salafi Islamists allegedly headed the protests.
Employees from the Helwan and 6th of October Governorates protested against the decision to to reincorporate the governorates into the Cairo and Giza governorates respectively.

Protests in Qina against the appointment of a police officer/Coptic Christian governor are in their 4th day. The demonstrators set up tents on a railway track, occupied a government building and blocked various roads in the city. The protests were allegedly headed by Salafists.

Hundreds of family members and friends of a man who had been killed surrounded the hospital where his allegedly killer was being treated and eventually broke in and killed the wounded man. Fighting was also reported on and around the premises.

Protests in Qina against the appointment of a police officer/Coptic Christian governor are in their 5th day. The demonstrators continue to block a railway track, occupy a government building and block various roads in the city. The protests were allegedly headed by Salafists.

Hundreds gathered in front of the Italian Embassy in Cairo to stage a candlelight vigil to commerate the death of an Italian activist who was kidnapped in Gaza and recently found dead after a video was posted online of him being beaten by members of the Monotheism and Holy War group. The demonstrators wanted to show solidarity with the murdered Italian activist.

2 Muslims were killed in a violent dispute with the family of a prominent Coptic Christian lawyer and member of the dissolved NDP in the Abu Qurqas area. The dispute was over a speed bump in front of his house which had been removed by a Muslim group. As the dispute became violent, house guards allegedly opened fire and killed two bystanders.

After the funeral for 2 Muslims killed by a Coptic Christains house guards in Abu Qurqas village in Minya, a mob ransacked a cafe owned by the lawyer as well as several Christian homes. At least 8 people were injured in what was reported as a clash, and 25 people arrested by police and armed forces which confiscated weapons from the cities residents.
Some residents of Abu Qurqas staged a protest on the Cairo-Aswan road in their area against recent violent clashes between Muslims and Copts in their area.
Protests erupted in Suez after the current governor of the area honored the former governor who has been accused of being responsible for the deaths of anti-government protesters and corruption.

Protests in Qina against the appointment of a police officer/Coptic Christian governor are in their 6th day. The demonstrators continue to block a railway track, occupy a government building and block various roads in the city, although the Cairo-Aswan highway was opened to traffic. The protests were allegedly headed by Salafists.

column7: National Front for Justice and Democracy
column17: Around 100 demonstrators, including dozens of notable Egyptian intellectuals, protested outside the Arab League HQ in Cairo. They were demonstrating against the nomination of a key aid of the former government as chief of the organization.

Thousands of protesters continued to demonstrate in Qina against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as governor. Railway tracks continued to be blocked by the protesters who are allegedly headed by Salafists.

About 5,000 residents of Suez governorate held a symbolic popular trial for their former governor outside the El-Arbeen Mosque in which he was accused of being responsible for killing anti-government protesters in the area and corruption. Their verdict was to set the former governor on fire as an example to other governors.
Tens of thousands of protesters, led to Islamic groups, gathered to demand the removal of a Coptic Christian Governor of the Qina Governorate. This marks their 7th day of demonstrations.
About 400 members of the Al-Gama Islamiyya group gathered outside the US embassy in the Garden City area of Cairo to demand the release of their spiritual leader, Sheikh Omar Abdel Rahman.

On 22 April 2011, thousands of demonstrators, including members of the Muslim Brotherhood, gathered in front of Qaid Ibrahim mosque and later headed towards the northern military area in Sidi Jabir in Alexandria to demand the removal of the current governor of Alexandria whom they accuse of election fraud when he was president of Alexandria University. [size=nearly 5000]

On 22 April 2011, thousands of protesters, led by Islamic groups, gathered in Abu Qurqas in Menia to demand an end to Muslim-Coptic tensions and conflicts and the removal of all unlicensed firearms from civilians and spaces of worship. [size=thousands]
On 22 April 2011, thousands of protesters gathered in front of general office of the Minya governorate to demand the removal of the newly-appointed governor of Minya. [size=2000]

Thousands of protesters continued to demonstrate in Qina against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as governor. Railway tracks continued to be blocked by the protesters who are allegedly headed by Salafists.

Protesters continued to demonstrate in Qina against the appointment of a former police officer + Coptic Christian as governor. Railway tracks continued to be blocked by the protesters who are allegedly headed by Salafists.

About 400 Mubarak supporters protested peacefully in front of the state TV and radio building against plans to put him on trial and to denounce perceived insults directed towards the former Egyptian leader. Later, protesters demanding Mubarak stand trial marched on the state TV and radio building and clashed with the pro-Mubarak supporters. Both sides hurled stones at each other resulting in at least 3 injuries on either side.

A couple hundred people staged a demonstration, led by Cairo University students, in front of the Israeli embassy in Giza demanding the expulsion of its ambassador and ending ties between Egypt and Israel. The protesters burned an Israeli flag and chanted slogans supporting Palestine.
Unknown saboteurs bombed an Egyptian gas pipeline in Sinai at dawn, forcing authorities to cut supplies to neighboring Israel and Jordan.

Hundreds of clerics from Al-Azhar, a respected Sunni Muslim centre of learning, demonstrated in Cairo to demand more independence for the institution and more democratic institutions. Simultaneously, microbus drivers went on strike and engaged in a sit-in in Cairo against what they call unfair traffic fines levied against them.

On 29 April 2011, Mubarak supporters demonstrated in front of the state TV and radio building against putting him on trial and to denounce perceived insults directed towards the former Egyptian leader. Later, demonstrators demanding that Mubarak stand trial marched from Tahrir Square to the state TV and radio building and clashed with the pro-Mubarak supporters using empty bottles and stones. Clashes resulted in several injuries. Military forces intervened to disperse the demonstrators and end the clashes. [size=large]

A few hundred protesters rallied in front of the Qena governorates HQ following calls for a million man march to reiterate demands to sack the current governor, after PM Essam Sharaf suspended him for 3 months on Apr.25. The Coalition of the January 25 Youth were one of the groups which attended the protest.
Salafist protesters staged demonstrations in front of Al-Fatah Mosque in Ramsis Square; outside Al-Nour Mosque in Abbassiya Square; and outside the Sharia Association Mosque in Ramsis.

About 2,000 Salafist Islamists protested outside St. Marks Cathedral to demand the release of 2 women they say are being held by the Coptic Church after allegedly converting to Islam. Church officials deny the accusations.

On 30 April 2011, thousands of people, including members of Al-Gamaa al-Islamiyya, gathered in front of Al-Nour Mosque in Abbasiya and headed towards the The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces building to demand the release of political prisoners who were arrested and subjected to military trials during the Mubarak era. [size=more than 5000]

On 1 May 2011, a number of security forces of the Red Mountain camp (assumed soldiers) declared a rebellion against the camp commander, because of his mistreatment of them. Demonstrators damaged camp property, including the commander's room. The location is coded as Nasr City (Geo Precision 2), which is the nearest to Jabal Al-Ahmar. [size=several]

On 1 May 2011, riot occurred between the villages of Tramsa and Hamedat in Qena governorate, where more than 700 people blocked the bridge between Dandara and Qena, in Tramsa, and set fire to cars and the electrical transformer, which led to power cut in the area. [size=more than 700]

On 1 May 2011, dozens of information center employees gathered in Tahrir Square and then headed to the Council of Ministers in Al-Qasr Al-Aini Street to protest against the slow transfer of their funds by the Ministry of Finance, and accused officials of various ministries of manipulating them. [size=dozens]
On 1 May 2011, Salafists started a sit-in in the city of Kharga against the return of the National Security Service to manage the State Security headquarters in the province. [size=no report]

Thousands of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to mark labour Day and show solidarity with Egypts workers. The demonstrators demanded recognition of independent unions, denounced the privatization of the public sector, and called for renationalization of Egyptian companies.

On 1 May 2011, there were verbal and physical confrontations between workers in Tahrir Square, celebrating their first anniversary after the January 25 revolution, against the families of the martyrs and a number of young people (pro 25 January), whom they were demonstrating against the establishment of a ceremony that was to be held this evening, with the blood of martyrs in this square. Which led to the cancellation of the artistic ceremony. [size=no report]

On 2 May 2011, dozens of teachers gathered in front of the Ministry of Education to demand a solution to the financial crisis, and find an alternative method of evaluating teachers to replace the tests of staff. There were confrontations between the demonstrators and a number of security personnel of the Ministry of Interior. Demonstrators crossed into the building, after opening the main gate. [size=dozens]

On 2 May 2011, a large number of workers and temporary staff of the forestation sector, imposed a strict siege on all entrances and exits of the Ministry of Agriculture and the reclamation of land, which prompted the security of the ministry barricade the gate closed from the inside. A number of demonstrators attacked the building, which led to breaking the glass of the main door of the ministry. They also attacked the staff and employees of the Ministry of Agriculture. [size=large]

On 2 May 2011, a number of relatives of Egyptian detainees in Libya broke into the headquarters of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to demonstrate against what they called ""the failure of the ministry to intervene to release their relatives,"" while ministry officials called for the armed forces to remove the people from within the ministry. [size=several]

On 2 May 2011, more than 100 doctors from the ''Doctors without Rights'' movement, gathered at the headquarters of the Medical Syndicate to protest the departure of the members of the emergency assembly meeting without drafting and sealing their decisions, in preparation for addressing the Ministry of Health and the military council. [size=more than 100]
Arrests: A CNN journalist is detained by the military, his camera confiscated.

On 2 May 2011, dozens of engineers from the power plants of the Al Wajeh Al Kubli electricity company, gathered to demand the dismissal of their chief engineer Abdul Mohsen Abdul Ghaffar, after they accused him of assaulting them, as well as protest against the low technical conditions of the company. The protests were in power plants Kurimat 1, 2, and 3, coded as Al Wasta the nearest town to the power plants with geo precision 2. [size=dozens]

On 2 May 2011, dozens of engineers from the power plants of the Al Wajeh Al Kubli electricity company, gathered to demand the dismissal of their chief engineer Abdul Mohsen Abdul Ghaffar, after they accused him of assaulting them, as well as protest against the low technical conditions of the company. The protests were in Asyut Al Walidiah power plant, coded as Asyut the nearest City to the power plant with geo precision 2. [size=dozens]

On 2 May 2011, the engineers of Ataqah power station gathered protesting to demand the implementation of the promises made by Minister of Electricity and Energy Dr. Hassan Younis to equalize incentives and allowances. [size=no report]

On 2 May 2011, dozens of quarry workers in Cairo staged a protest for the second time in front of the governorate building to demand the dismissal of the director of the quarry project and the termination of pension contracts. [size=dozens]

On 2 May 2011, dozens of archeologists organized a march in front of the Egyptian Museum to the Presidency of the Council of Ministers to demand the appointment of workers on temporary contracts, who have been on the job for 3 years. [size=dozens]

On 2 May 2011, dozens of temporary employees of the Atomic Energy Commission demonstrated in front of the office of Dr. Mohamed Taha al-Kulali, the head of the Commission, demanding he assign them officially. [size=dozens]

On 3 May 2011, a number of employees of the Ministry of Finance and members of the security of the ministry attacked Mona Zia, editor of ""Day Seven"", during the coverage of the strike by a number of junior employees of the minister's office, the technical office, and a number of sectors of the ministry, to demonstrate against the deduction of their salaries. Three female employees of the ministry tied the hands of the editor and took the papers she was carrying demanding security to expel her outside the ministry. [size=several]

Bedouin protesters blocked roads in different places on the Sinai Peninsula to demand the release of jailed tribesmen and the revokation of prison sentences against others. They forced tour buses to stop along roads headed to Sharm El-Sheikh and Mt. Sinai.

Mass comm students engaged in a sit-in at Cairo University to demand the removal of some of its executives were allegedly attacked with molotov cocktails thrown from outside the universities walls. No casualties were reported.
Protesters in Qina stormed a press conference being held by the Egyptian PM. Some were chanting that they want a Muslim governor for the province.

On 3 May 2011, around 150 supporters of the mayor of Sharabiya and Zawiya, organized a demonstration outside the headquarters of the Ministry of Justice, which led to confrontations with a number of citizens who were in front of the headquarters of the ministry. [size=around 150]

On 3 May 2011, demonstrators from the families of the victims of the January 25 revolution gathered in front of a court in south Cairo. After the first session of the trial of 13 police officers accused of killing and wounding demonstrators during the January 25 revolution, the court Hall witnessed a state of great anger. The victims' families destroyed the entire hall, broke the windows and the court platform and tried to break into the president's room. Before the start of the session, dozens of the people of the revolution's martyrs organized a demonstration and blocked the road in front of the South Cairo court, disrupting the traffic. Following the departure of the released defendants from the hall, demonstrators clashed with the Central Security Forces and the armed forces in an attempt to break down the barriers and capture the accused, resulting in unknown number of injuries. [size=large]

More than 90 detainees escaped from the Al-Sahel police station in Shubra with the help of armed men who broke into the station. Detainees families also gathered in front of the station and threw rocks at soldiers and police. One police officer was wounded during the violence. Security forces dispersed the crowds after the incident.

On 3 May 2011, dozens of workers at the Center of Technical Support in Alexandria, which is under the Ministry of Health and Population, gathered in front of the Cairo headquarters of the ministry, to demand the suspension of the decision to annex the headquarters of the Center and merge it to Alexandria governorate, and to maintian its dependence on the Ministry of Health. [size=dozens]

On 3 May 2011, dozens of residents of Sarsna village in Tamiya center orginized a protest in front of the General Office of Al Fayyum Governorate, to protest the lack of gas cylinders and the lack of access to the share allocated to the village. They confirmed that the village is large and has a daily share of 300 cylinders, but they only receive 300 cylinders every 10 days, and those who want gas have to search in the black market. [size=dozens]

On 3 May 2011, dozens of Egyptian mothers married to Palestinians and their children demonstrated in front of the Ministry of the Interior to demand approval of the decision to grant Egyptian citizenship to their children. [size=dozens]

Bedouin protesters blocked roads in different places on the Sinai Peninsula to demand the release of jailed tribesmen and the revokation of prison sentences against others. They forced tour buses to stop along roads headed to Sharm El-Sheikh and Mt. Sinai.

On 4 May 2011, the workers in the Support and Services Development project entered the Council of Ministers headquarters, climbed the walls, and broke the glass of gates and guard windows, after demonstrating in front of the Council to demand their confirmation after six years of their contract with Sharm el-Sheikh governorate. [size=no report]
One man was killed during clashes between police and armed men attempting to break into Dekrnes police station.

On 4 May 2011, hundreds of parents of the Martyr Jawad Hosny Primary School students in Imbabah demonstrated against the transfer of the school from government to experimental status, outside the main gate of the school. The demonstrators launched an ""attack"" (details not provided) on the province building, and asked to keep the school as ""governmental"" and not to convert it to ""experimental"", owing to the unmanageable costs they would incur. [size=hundreds]

Pro-Mubarak supporters gather outside a television station to denounce charges laid against him and to mark his birthday. Later as anti-Mubarak supporters arrived clashes broke out with stones being thrown and traffic blocked. The army later stepped in to separate the two groups. 67 were reported injured in the violence by the Ministry of Health.
On 4 May 2011, dozens of temporary employees of the Atomic Energy Organization continued their protest at the Aman nuclear center, to demand their contracts be adjusted. [size=dozens]

On 4 May 2011, a number of workers of the Abu Ghattas railway station in Cairo, protested in front of the engineer office Mustafa Qenaoui, head of the station, after a train ran over one of their colleagues Hosni Ibrahim Hammad, demanding the allocation of an ambulance for workshops to be used in case of emergency. [size=several]

On 4 May 2011, dozens of temporary employees of the Atomic Energy Organization continued their protest at the Inshas reactor to demand that they be fixed, and transfer from the sixth door to the temporary contracts category, according to their agreement with the head of the body, Dr. Mohammad Taha al-Qalali. [size=dozens]

On 4 May 2011, the people of Mansheyet Assem village of Minya el-Nasr in Dakahlia blocked the Mansoura-Minya el-Nasr road (coded as Dikirnis Geo precision 2). They stopped the train traffic after a girl was kidnapped from their village, and the police failed to return the girl and arrest the kidnappers. The demonstrators threatened to continue cutting off the road until the kidnapped girl returns. [size=no report]

On 4 May 2011, a demonstration by the Abu Ghattas workshop workers at the Ramses station occupied the tracks, disrupting service, to demand the establishment of an emergency ambulance unit for use in emergencies. [size=no report]
More than 2,000 workers of a private ceramic tile factory in el-Sadat City went on strike and staged 2 days of demonstrations to demand bonuses and permanent employment. They are members of the ETUF.

On 5 May 2011, dozens of Libyans and Egyptians staged a protest to support the regime of Libyan President Muammar Gaddafi in front of the Qatari embassy in Mustafa Mahmoud Square, raising Libyan and Egyptian flags, demanding solidarity with the Gaddafi regime and standing up against the rebels who called them ""advocates of division"", and denouncing the military intervention by the NATO forces. [size=dozens]

On 5 May 2011, around 200 farmers from agricultural land owners of the Egyptian Endowments Authority, blocked the road of Al-Qasr Al-Aini Street, by sitting on the ground to demand the ownership of their lands after paying double its value. There were severe clashes between them and car drivers, after cutting off access to the road for more than half an hour. [size=around 200]

Hundreds of Salafists, including dozens of veiled women, protested outside offices at Al-Azhar University to demand Egypts top cleric to take back his statement that the veil has nothing to do with Islam.

On 5 May 2011, demonstrators from the families of criminal prisoners blocked Magles Al Shab street in Cairo, after demonstrations for 3 days without reaching a solution with any of the officials. They were also joined by dozens of temporary workers in Damanhour General Hospital, sitting on the ground after the demonstration for two hours to demand their establishment in their jobs. The road cut continued for more than an hour, leading to some verbal clashes between car drivers and demonstrators. [size=no report]

On 5 May 2011, the workers of the ""Abu Ghattas"" workshops, demonstrated for the second day by standing on the rails at the Ramses station, stopping the movement of trains, demanding the establishment of an emergency ambulance unit to be used in case of emergency. [size=no report]

On 6 May 2011, thousands of Salafists performed the absent prayer for the spirit of Osama bin Laden, the leader of al-Qaeda, at Al-Nour Mosque in Al Abbasiyah. Several of them staged a march towards the US embassy amid intense security presence. The mosque witnessed clashes between the security forces and a number of Salafists because of their insistence on performing the prayer. Other clashes and verbal exchanges occurred as well, because of the refusal of a number of worshipers to perform that prayer. [size=about 150]
On 6 May 2011, a large number of real estate owners staged a protest in front of Radio and TV building in As Sabtiyyah area, demanding the cancellation of the inheritance system. [size=large]
Over 300 protesters marched from the Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the Israeli Embassy in Kafr Abdo district to show solidarity with Palestinians.

On 6 May 2011, around 1,000 Coptic protesters gathered outside the Cathedral of St. Mark in Al Abbasiyah, and the same inside the cathedral, in response to the Salafists' demonstration in front of the cathedral last Friday. The demonstration came amid an intense security presence. A number of Muslims joined the Coptic demonstration and chanted for national unity. [size=around 1000]
More than 2,000 workers of a private ceramic tile factory in el-Sadat City went on strike and staged 2 days of demonstrations to demand bonuses and permanent employment. They are members of the ETUF.

On 6 May 2011, dozens of Egyptian activists and the Preparatory Committee for the third Palestinian Intifada, organized a demonstration outside the Israeli embassy in Al Maadi, to demand the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador and prepare for the third Palestinian uprising, scheduled for May 15. They called for an end to Egypt's export of gas to Israel, and demanded the evacuation of the Israeli Embassy, and burned about ten Israeli flags in front of the embassy. More than 200 demonstrators from Tahrir square joined them as well. They also blocked the road at the top of the university bridge in front of the embassy. Security forces gathered to protect the embassy from storming by demonstrators. [size=more than 200]

On 6 May 2011, the movement ""I am Egyptian with the Intifada"" organized a march that emerged from Omar Makram Mosque after Friday prayers in Tahrir Square, which included more than 300 demonstrators in support of the Palestinian uprising on May 15. They then headed through Al Qasr al Ayni road to the Israeli Embassy to demonstrate in front of it. The Coalition of Arab People, together with the Youth Revolution Coalition, organized a march in Tahrir Square in solidarity with the Arab peoples and their revolutions.
