The demonstrators held a 10 meter flag bearing the flags of the various Arab countries. The march was joined by a number of Syrians and Libyans present in the square. They condemned the massacres committed by Bashar al-Assad against the rebels. During their tour in Tahrir Square, more than 500 Egyptian demonstrators and dozens of Libyans joined the Syrians, whom also condemned the massacres committed by Gaddafi. [size=Hundreds]

On 7 May 2011, a number of graduates of the Faculty of Computers and Information organized a stand in front of the Council of Ministers to demand the establishment of a syndicate of software engineers that supports the software industry in Egypt. On the other hand, dozens of employees of the card issuing centers in the various governorates joined as well, to demand permanent contracts and confirmed that the number is more than 850 employees working for 20 years in the center. A number of mentally handicapped people joined as well, condemning the paralympic committee whom neglecting the handicapped. While more than 2000 pharmacists came from Alexandria to demonstrate in front of the Council of Ministers to claim their lost rights and establish an independent body of their own, and reform the pharmaceutical sector in Egypt. Dozens of temporary workers in the General Office of Alexandria Governorate blocked the People's Assembly Street, which is the Council of Ministers, to demand their fixation as well. [size=Thousands]

15 people were killed and 220 wounded in a secretion clash among Christian and Muslims. The two groups clashed in the northwestern district of Imbaba after Muslims attacked a Coptic church to free a Christian woman they alleged was being held against her will because she wanted to convert to Islam. The SCAF said 190 were arrested in relation to the violence. The fatality count was taken from the National Council for Human Rights.

On 7 May 2011, dozens of Islamist lawyers protested in front of the Egyptian Lawyers Association in Cairo, to denounce the killing of Osama bin Laden by the Americans, calling on the international community and human rights organizations to investigate the killing, which they consider as a war crime. [size=dozens]

On 7 May 2011, the forces of the army, and the security department of Al Wadi Al Jadeed intervened to break the sit-in organized by the Salafists in the city of Kharga by force, after a week of sit-in protest against the return of the National Security Service to manage the State Security headquarters in the province, where more than 15 cars and central security vehicles headed to the headquarters of the sit-in, and surrounded the protesters in Gamal Abdel Nasser Street in Kharga, and the protesters did not show any resistance and they broke the protest. [size=no Report]

On 7 May 2011, the staff of the General Authority for Cultural Palaces gathered to protest against the presence of some directors of the old administrations and leaders belonging to the dissolved National Party in the decision of the Administrative Court. [size=no report]

On 7 May 2011, dozens of members of the Committee of the Iraqi community in Egypt, with the Intifada Free People of Iraq, organized a protest in front of the Iraqi embassy, demanding the exit of the US occupation from Iraq, and the departure of the corrupt government of Malki and the release innocent detainees. [size=dozens]
Around 7 May 2011, about 150 citizens from El-Salam city staged an open sit-in in front of the Cairo Governorate building until they receive housing units from the governorate. [size=about 150]

Clashes erupted when about 400 demonstrators, including both Christians and Muslims, gathered in Cairo to protest religious violence after a recent attack of two churches that resulted in death and injury. As they were assembling near Cairos High Court to travel to the state TV building, they were attacked by ""neighbourhood thugs"" who threw stones at them. The protesters threw stones back and then dispersed. Some injuries were reported.

After a march from the Cairo High Court to the state TV building was aborted, protesters regrouped at the state TV building to denounce violence the day before in Imbaba between Christians and Muslims. Thousands reportedly showed up for the event.
After clashes the night before, Christians and Muslims again fought along Luxor Street in the Imbaba area of Giza. Police blocked roads and made many arrests among those fighting.
On 8 May 2011, the rioters in front of the South Sinai Criminal Court broke one of the court's glass facades. [size=no report]
Christian and Muslim protesters demonstrated outside the Bibliotheca Alexandrina to demand unity between Muslims and Copts and to denounce the alleged reluctance of the SCAF to fight sectarianism.
About 30 Copts protested outside the US Embassy in Cairo following violence between Christians and Muslims which killed 12 in the Imbaba neighbourhood of Giza the night before.
Christians gathered in front of the state TV and radio building to protest religious violence after a recent attack of two churches that resulted in death and injury.

Christian and Muslim protesters demonstrated for a 2nd day outside the Bibliotheca Alexandrina to demand unity between Muslims and Copts and to denounce the alleged reluctance of the SCAF to fight sectarianism.

On 9 May 2011, shots were heard on Al-Sherbini street in Imbabah, causing panic among the people. According to eyewitnesses, the armed forces were forced to fire into the air after reports of the return of Salafists to demonstrate again. [size=no report]

column7: National Association for Change; April 6 Youth Movement
column17: On 9 May 2011, the National Assembly for Change and the April 6th movement, organized a march with the participation of more than 2,000 ""Muslim and Christian"" citizens, from Talaat Harb Street to Al Azraa Church, which is besieged by the army. [size=more than 2000]

On 10 May 2011, the armed forces, with the help of the Ministry of Interior, ended the sit-in of hundreds of El Salam city residents, in front of the Cairo Governorate building, and arresting some of the protesters inside the central security vehicles by security forces after they set up tents in front of the building for 9 days to get housing units. [size=hundreds]

On 11 May 2011, in front of the Council of Ministers in Al Qasr al Ayni, Cairo, dozens of shopkeepers in the new cities protested against the decision of Dr. Fathi ElBaradei, Minister of Housing, Utilities and Urban Development, to renew the temporary contracts for their shops for only three years, after which they will leave the shops completely. [size=dozens]
Workers of Nile Cotton Ginning Company protested and staged a sit-in in Mahalla el-Kobra.
Hundreds of Copts in Alexandria demonstrated against the recent violence in Imbaba.
Taxi drivers protested in Beni Sueif governorate to demand a rise in fares.
Hundreds of Bedouin blocked roads in South Sinai governorateto demand the release of their relatives.

On 11 May 2011, Copts demonstrating in front of the Radio and TV building refused to negotiate with security leaders to open the road for traffic, until their legitimate demands are met. [size=no report]

On 11 May 2011, more than a thousand Coptic Christians gathered in front of Al Azraa Church of the Virgin in As Sibaiyyah city, demanding the return of a christian girl named ""Christine Wahba"" (17 years), who disappeared in Kadri Osman buildings in the city of As Sibaiyyah west of Edfu Center the before. [size=more than a thousand]

On 11 May 2011, students of the Mechanics Department at the Higher Institute of Al Ahramat for Engineering and Technology, held a protest in front of the Ministry of Higher Education, criticizing the absence of a number of specialties announced by the center. [size=no report]

column7: FFPC: Free Front for Peaceful Change
column17: On 12 May 2011, the Free Front for Peaceful Change,protested against the complicity of the Arab and international communities, and the deliberate media blackout on what is happening with the Bahraini people in their country, in front of the Bahrain embassy in Cairo. [size=no report]

On 12 May 2011, a peaceful march was held under the slogan Long live the crescent with the cross"" to condemn the events of Imbaba. The march went from Imbabah Hamiyat hospital on the Nile Corniche in Imbabah to Al Azraa Church on Al Wahda Street. [size=no report]""
Tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to show support for Palestinians and advocate for national unity following clashes between Christians and Muslims in Imbaba.

On 13 May 2011, activists started a march from Nasr City towards the Rafah border in solidarity with Palestinians. The security forces intervened to disperse the protesters and arrested a number of them. [size=more than 150]
Protesters gather to show solidarity for the Palestinian people.

On 13 May 2011, a march from Izbat Al Nakhil near Al-Nozha city (coded as Geo precision 2), was also directed at the Corniche and the headquarters of the Radio and TV Building to join the protesters in condemning the events of Imbabah. [size=no report]
On 13 May 2011, a marches from Muqattam, was directed at the Corniche and the headquarters of the Radio and TV Building to join the protesters in condemning the events of Imbabah. [size=no report]
On 13 May 2011, Coptic demonstrators marched from Shubra towards TV building, to join the protesters in condemning the events of Imbabah. [size=no report]

On 13 May 2011, dozens of supporters of ousted President Hosni Mubarak, gathered in front of Mustafa Mahmoud Mosque in Mohandiseen, demanding that his trial stop. They also assaulted a citizen in Mustafa Mahmoud Square, while he was driving his car and passing through the square. [size=dozens]

On 13 May 2019, for the sixth consecutive day, thousands of demonstrators flocked to the Radio and TV building, and large numbers from all governorates poured in solidarity with the protesting Coptic youth, demanding national unity and holding perpetrators accountable for the recent events in Imbabah. 22 coalition, movement, front and association representing different national and local entities. Copts confronted four people coming from the direction of the Corniche, over their demand to break up the sit-in in front of the TV building, while security forces broke up the clash and took the four away from the area. [size=thousands]
On 13 May 2011, a march from Al Maadi was directed at the Corniche and the headquarters of the Radio and TV Building to join the protesters in condemning the events of Imbabah. [size=no report]
Protesters, waving Palestinian flags, protest outside the Israeli Embassy. The military fires warning shots to disperse the protesters.
Security Measures: The Egyptian authorities blocked access to the Sinai Peninsula ahead of a planned march from Tahrir Square to Gaza. They also stepped up security across the Sinai Peninsula itself.

On 13 May 2011, thousands of protesters gathered at Tahrir Square, to march and support the Palestinian cause on its first day in the third Intifada. Some of the demonstrators joined protesters in front of the TV building. [size=thousands]
Thousands of Alexandria residents attended a Muslim Brotherhood rally to show solidarity with Palestinians.
Thousands gathered at the Qaed Ibrahim Mosque in Alexandira to engage in prayers in support of Palestine. After their prayers the group marched to the Israeli consulate in Alexandria.
On 13 May 2011, Coptic demonstrators marched from Ghamrah towards the TV building, to join the protesters. [size=no report]

On 13 May 2011, dozens of families of Egyptian detainees in Saudi prisons, held a protest in front of the Saudi embassy in Murad Street in Dokki, demanding the release of their children and relatives, whom are political detainees in Saudi Arabia. [size=dozens]

On 14 May 2011, more than 70 students from technical institutes and diplomas, held a sit-in the office of Dr. Amr Ezzat Salama, Minister of Higher Education, Scientific Research and Technology, at he ministry of Higher Education, after the siege of the office from 3 to 7:30. Police forces intervened to calm the situation. [size=more than 70]
Violence protesting Christians of the Maspero neighborhood are attacked by unidentified men, two dead, 78 injured. The violence lasted over the course of two days.

On 14 May 2011, hundreds of young people gathered in Tahrir Square, from different governorates, in preparation of going to Rafah to participate in breaking the Israeli siege on the Gaza Strip, declaring their financial and moral support to the people of Gaza. They marched towards the Israeli embassy in Al Maadi joing others to demand the expulsion of the ambassador and lowering the flag from the embassy and eventually burned the Israeli flag. [size=hundreds]
Violence protesting Christians of the Maspero neighborhood are attacked by unidentified men, 60 injured. The protest itself lasts for 12 days.
An explosive is detonated near the tomb of a prominent Muslim sheikh.

On 15 May 2011, clashes between Coptic demonstrators and a group of rioters were renewed near the Radio and TV building, and Molotov cocktails were thrown at the Coptic demonstrators. The two sides exchanged rock-throwing, causing injuries among demonstrator and material damage. Police and army forces intervened to confront the aggressors and stop the violence. Gunfire was fired, injuring at least four Copts. Police fired tear gas to counter the groups who attacked the demonstrators. Demonstrators also attacked one of the cameramen, who was there to cover the event.

Arrests: Convoys carrying activists and aid heading for the Rafah border crossing with Palestine were turned back in Ismailia at military checkpoints (as well as other locations). Many participants were arrested.
A number of activists heading for Gaza which managed to make it past military checkpoints set up across the Sinai Peninsula protested at the Rafah border crossing in solidarity with Palestinians.
On 15 May 2011, a large number of Coptic youth in Alexandria held a protest in front of Alexandrina Library. [size=large]

On 15 May 2011, the Students Union at Ain Shams University, with the participation of the Muslim Brotherhood and some members of the political forces, organized a protest in the university, to support the Palestinian Intifada. [size=no report]
A wave of demonstrations in Manqabad over recent weeks left dozens injured during clashes with security forces. The residents are protesting against shortages of drinking water.

On 15 May 2011, dozens of workers from the Aswan Cement Factory (Medico), gathered at the factory headquarters southwest of Aswan to protest against the non-payment of their salaries, entitlements and delayed incentives. [size=dozens]
Thousands of demonstrators started gathering in front of the Israeli embassy in the evening to show solidarity with Palestinians and mark what they call the ""Nakba"".
Despite recent attacks on them Christians reassemble for anti-violence protests against them.

On 16 May 2011, three people on Monday took off their clothes during a demonstration in front of the Council of Ministers, to demand the government intervene immediately to save them, and end their suffering. [size=no report]
Drivers demonstrated in Kafr el-Sheikh to protest against a fuel shortage.
On 16 May 2011, a large number of Coptic youth in Alexandria, renewed their protest for the second consecutive day in front of Alexandrina Library. [size=large]

On 16 May 2011, dozens of Al Shariya officials demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Justice, to demand the establishment of their own union and the allocation of monthly salaries, pensions and health insurance for them, and called for the abolition of Article 20 from the list of officials. [size=dozens]
Students at several Egyptian universities, including at Alexandira, Manufiyah, Fayyum and Mansura staged rallies and protests in solidarity with Palestinians on Israels 63rd anniversary.
Students at several Egyptian universities, including at Alexandira, Manufiyah, Fayyum and Mansura staged rallies and protests in solidarity with Palestinians on Israels 63rd anniversary.
Students at several Egyptian universities, including at Alexandira, Manufiyah, Fayyum and Mansura staged rallies and protests in solidarity with Palestinians on Israels 63rd anniversary.
Students at several Egyptian universities, including at Alexandira, Manufiyah, Fayyum and Mansura staged rallies and protests in solidarity with Palestinians on Israels 63rd anniversary.

Thousands of demonstrators allegedly tried to storm the Israeli embassy (some demonstrators deny this) in Giza but were repulsed by military and police personnel. At least 24 stone-throwing demonstrators were injured in the incident, during which security forces fired rubbery bullets, live ammunition and tear gas at the protesters. An unspecified number of security personnel were also injured during the clashes. 350 were reported injured (45 seriously) and 140 arrested.
On 17 May 2011, there were physical confrontations between a number of Copts demonstrating in front of the Radio and TV building over the suspension of one of the demonstrators. [size=several]

On 17 May 2011, around 50 university professors from the Unified Coalition of Egyptian University Staff, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers to demand the dismissal of the Minister of Higher Education Dr. Amr Ezzat Salama. [size=around 50]

On 17 May 2011, witnesses said that clashes took place between security forces and an unidentified armed group in Sheikh Zuweiyid. Witnesses said that two cars opened fire on an ambush of the security forces and exchanged fire with them, the forces succeeded in seizing a car and its driver, who was detained while the other escaped, near the Imam Ghazali Secondary School for Girls in Kawthar neighborhood.

On 17 May 2011, Fathers of Al Roya, in cooperation with Save the Family Association, entered an open sit-in in front of Al-Azhar, to demand the dismissal of Sheikh Al-Azhar and Mufti of the Republic, after the Islamic Research Academy refused to amend the vision and personal status laws. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: On 18 May 2011, the military police dispersed the demonstrators in front of the entrances to the Accountability State Authority in Nasr City. They were demonstrating against the detention of their colleague Mohammed Al-Mashad, who was arrested on charges of possessing leaflets carrying insults and defamation against the head of the Authority. [size=no report]

On 18 May 2011, hundreds of Muslims gathered in Luxor, and detained two Christian youths and beat them, after spreading reports of them being seen with a Muslim girl in one of the buildings on Al Kawakeb street from Al Madina Al Munawwara street in Luxor. [size=hundreds]
On 18 May 2011, dozens of archaeological workers renewed their demonstration before the Council of Ministers to demand permanent work [size=dozens]
Hundreds protested in Tahrir Square to demand the release of all detained activists, including those arrested recently outside the Israeli embassy in Giza.

On 18 May 2011, dozens of veterinarians staged a protest in front of the General Veterinaries Syndicate in Garden City to protest the postponement of the Syndicate's council to hold elections. [size=dozens]

Coptic Christians engaged in a sit-in protest in front of the state TV and radio building have extended their demonstration following clashes outside a church in Ein Shams and the delay of a permit for the opening of a church in Minya.
After a group of hardline Muslims arrived to protest the reopening of a church, Copts and Muslims threw stones at each other in the Ein Shams neighbourhood and had to be separated by military police.

On 19 May 2011, hundreds staged a demonstration in front of the US Embassy in Garden City to demand the release of Sheikh Omar Abdul Rahman, who has been held in US jails for 18 years. [size=hundreds]
On 20 May 2011, hundreds of citizens held a stand to support the ruling military council in front of the unidentified soldier's monument in Nasr City. [size=hundreds]

Thousands protested in Tahrir Square and in the Maspero area (location of the state TV and radio building) against a rumour that the SCAF will grant former Egyptian leader Hosni Mubarak and his family amnesty.

Thousands protested in Tahrir Square and in the Maspero area (location of the state TV and radio building) against a rumour that the SCAF will grant former Egyptian leader Hosni Mubarak and his family amnesty.

On 20 May 2011, more than 2000 Muslims gathered in front of Almaza underwear factory in Ain Shams, after Friday prayers at Al Nour mosque facing the factory, stressing that they will not allow the conversion of the factory into a church. [size=more than 2000]

Protesters outside the trial of former Interior Minister Habib el-Adly and six of his assistants broke through a cordon of riot police and attempted to storm the courthouse but were pushed back after mild clashes.

On 21 May 2011, dozens of supporters of the former president staged a protest in front of the Radio and TV building, to support the military council and the armed forces, rejecting any presidential council of any kind, and demanding to release the former president with any guarantees the prosecution deems, as no evidence against him has so far been proven. [size=dozens]
On 21 May 2011, hundreds of Sinai Bedouins participated in a sit-in on the Egyptian-Israeli border in central Sinai according to local sources. [size=hundreds]

On 22 May 2011, a number of Pro-Mubarak Supporters gathered in front of the Ministry of Justice. During the exit of Ahmed Ezz, they threw stones at him. Police forces intervened to disperse them. [size=several]

On 22 May 2011, nearly 500 temporary workers at Petrojet, staged a protest in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Petroleum in Nasr city, to demand their return to their company, after they were laid off after several projects were stopped. [size=nearly 500]

On 22 May 2011, more than 100 students and graduates of labor engineering faculties started a sit-in at the headquarters of the Ministry of Higher Education, Scientific Research and Technolog. They went up to the seventh floor of the ministry in front of the minister's office and decided to sit down until their demands are met. [size=more than 100]

On 22 May 2011, dozens of Palestinian students staged a sit-in in front of the Embassy of the State of Palestine in Dokki, to protest against the ban on 19 students at the Higher Institute of Engineering and Technology in Al-Arish from attending the second semester exam. [size=dozens]

On 22 May 2011, nearly 200 temporary and trainee workers at the Egyptian Distribution Company (Town Gas) staged a protest in front of the company's headquarters in Al Warraq to demand an increase in wages and permanent work. [size=nearly 200]

On 22 May 2011, dozens of employees of Amoncito Textile Company held a protest in front of Egypt Bank headquarters, to demand the disbursement of 41 million of their remaining dues after being on the early pension, and the decision to liquidate the company. [size=dozens]

On 22 May 2011, dozens of workers who are on the early pension of Tora Cement Company, blocked Magles Al Shab street, and there were verbal altercations between them and the cars drivers. They stressed that they have not received profits since 1991 to 2005. [size=dozens]

On 23 May 2011, a large number of those injured in the January 25 revolution, staged a protest in Tahrir Square, in solidarity with the January 25 Youth Coalition, demanding the honoring of the wounded of the revolution, and their involvement in the national talks, and the suspension of military officers and police accused of assaulting protesters. [size=large]

On 23 May 2011, dozens of Fathers of Al Roya blocked Salah Salem's road in Nasr city, to demonstrate against the decision of the Islamic Research Academy to postpone consideration of amending family laws indefinitely. [size=dozens]

On 23 May 2011, dozens of employees of Amoncito Textile, and Arab American Textile Company, returned to protest in front of the headquarters of Egypt Bank, to ask the bank's management to pay the rest of their dues for early retirement. [size=dozens]

On 23 May 2011, the Syrian community in Cairo, rejecting Bashar Al Assad's stay as president of Syria, organized a silent protest in Al-Nozha, to condemn the crimes committed by Assad against the demonstrators who demanded his downfall. [size=no report]

On 23 May 2011, the family of the police secretary, Mohamed Abdel Moneim, famously referred to as Mohammed al-Sunni, whose papers were sent to the Grand Mufti to give his legal opinion on his execution, organized a protest in front of the Ministry of Justice against the decision to refer him in his absence. [size=no report]

On 24 May 2011, dozens of workers applying for work at various oil companies, blocked Magles Al Shab street, and there were verbal altercations and quarrels that almost reached violent clashes between them, and car drivers.The army intervened to disperse them after the road was blocked for nearly half an hour. [size=dozens]

column7: Bedouin Ethnic Group (Egypt); Al-Fawakhriyah Tribal Group (Egypt)
column17: On 24 May 2011, dozens of Al-Fawakhriyah tribal youths in Al-Arish blocked the international road of Al-Qantara Al-Arish to demonstrate against the disappearance of nine members of the tribe, who were allegedly abducted by the Tayaha tribe, which alleges that the Al-Fawakhrya kidnapped one of their members. [size=dozens]

On 24 May 2011, a number of lawyers from the Islamic Lawyers Association, and a number of salafists gathered in front of the Administrative Judiciary Court in Sidi Jabir, to demand the release of Kamelia Shehata. [size=several]

On 24 May 2011, nearly 150 preachers from Al-Azhar Coalition staged a march that began after noon prayers from Al Nour Mosque in Al Abbasiyah, towards the Military Council, to demand the independence and unity of Al-Azhar, and declaring an open sit-in until all their demands are met. [size=nearly 150]

On 25 May 2011, altercations occurred among nearly 150 temporary workers in the afforestation sector and car drivers, as they blocked Al Qasr al Ayni street to demand their fixation. Military and Police forces intervened to reopen the road. [size=around 150]

column7: Bedouin Ethnic Group (Egypt); Al-Fawakhriyah Tribal Group (Egypt); Muslim Group (Egypt)
column17: On 25 May 2011, the city of Al Arish, the capital of North Sinai, witnessed a large demonstration following calls to gather thousands from Al-Nasr, Al-Rifai and Al-Fawakhriya mosques to the Diwan of the governorate to stage a sit-in and close Al Arish. The Al-Fawakhriyah tribe gathered with all its families to face the phenomenon of kidnapping individuals, stealing cars, and terrorizing citizens. [size=no report]

On 25 May 2011, dozens of veterinarians staged a protest in front of the General Veterinaries Syndicate in Garden City, demanding the departure of the board of the union and threatened to organize an open sit-in if the union council did not respond to their various demands, especially the holding of elections according to the decisions of the General Assembly on July 30 of this year. [size=dozens]

On 25 May 2011, nearly 150 workers and temporary workers in the sixth section of the Ministry of Agriculture, and staff in the afforestation project, blocked Magles Al Shab street, and refused to let any car pass.There was also a verbal altercations between them and the drivers, and the workers demanded their appointment, or full contracts for three years. [size=nearly 150]

On 25 May 2011, more than 45 researchers and employees of Sheikh Zuweiyid Research Station of the Desert Research Center, started an open sit-in to protest what they called the procrastination of the Ministry of Agriculture, and the Administration in implementing the promises made by the two government bodies for jobs. [size=more than 45]

On 26 May 2011, nearly 60 laborers, diesel and traffic workers demonstrated at the Qina railway station, protesting their low salaries and not receiving allowances and profits, and gathered on railway tracks in front of the train 981. [size=nearly 60]
Demonstrations in support of the SCAF were reported in Nasr City.
Hundreds protest outside of a hospital that is hold Mubarak following a recent heart attack.
Hundreds of people protested outside the hospital where former President Mubarak is said to be staying in Sharm el-Sheikh.

5 protests were held in different cities in South Sinai. Bedouins blocked major roads, set tires on fire, and marched with guns. They were protesting against rumours of a potential amnesty deal for Mubarak and against the negative effects on tourism in the area.
Hundreds of citizens protested in Al-Arish to demand a quicker trial for former President Hosni Mubarak.
Thousands protested in front of the Al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque in Alexandria for a quicker trial for former President Hosni Mubarak.
A few thousand people protested on El-Arbiein street in Suez to demand a quicker trial for former President Hosni Mubarak.
""Tens of thousands"" gather to protest for a speeder trial of Mubarak. A heart attack has delayed they proceedings. They also call for a reform of the political system.
'Pro-reform"" protests were reported in Al-Gharbiyah governorate during a ""Day of Anger"" to demand quicker prosecution of former President Hosni Mubarak.
As many as 1000 people demonstrated in the El-Hussein area of Giza to show support for the governing SCAF.
28 detainees broke out of Al-Montazah Prison after they set their detention room on fire. 7 were later re-arrested.

On 28 May 2011, dozens of demonstrators continued their protest for the second day in Tahrir Square. The protesters have set up tents to emphasize the demands of the second revolution of anger, which include many new demands, most notably the execution of Mubarak and Habib Al Adly and rapid public trials. [size=dozens]

On 29 May 2011, parents of students of the Egyptian Nile schools affiliated with the Council of Ministers held a protest in front of the Council headquarters in Cairo, after they were informed of the possibility of transferring school dependency from the Education Development Fund of the Council of Ministers to the Ministry of Education. [size=no report] Nearly 200 members of the Egyptian Boy Scouts, starting from the heads of the 6-year-old Central Boy Scouts Association in Egypt, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers to demand the departure of the President of the National Council for Youth Mohamed Safi El-Din Kharboush. Owners of the Egyptian labor companies in Saudi Arabia blocked Magles Al Shab street, more than once in protest against what they called the ""monopoly"" of the Ministry of Manpower for the procedures of transferring Egyptian workers to Saudi Arabia during the coming Hajj season. [size=Hundreds]

On 29 May 2011, dozens of Bedouins in South Sinai closed the seaport of Nuweiba, and prevented any movement. The sources said that dozens of rioters closed the main gate and prevented the entry or exit of trucks to the port on the Red Sea coast, and negotiations are underway with them to know their demands. [size=dozens]

On 29 May 2011, dozens of farmers in Damietta organized a demonstration in front of the Ministry of Agriculture to protest what they described as the intransigence of the Ministry of Agriculture against them, and refraining from accepting requests for the purchase of an area of 1093 acres in the Faraskour Center of Damietta. [size=dozens]
Tens of doctors marched from the Doctors Syndicate to the Ministry of Health to demand the resignation of an allegedly corrupt Minister and other officials.

On 29 May 2011, a number of Giza lawyers organized a protest in front of the Prosecutor General Office in Al Rehab, to denounce the difficulties and suffering they find while working in courts and prosecutors, during investigations and mistreatment by prosecutors. [size=several]

Police at the Al-Atareen police station foiled an attempt by about 100 people to set free a relative who had been detained at the station. Police were supported by local residents in their efforts to fend off the assailants.
Three shot and killed for unknown reasons.
Arrests: Authorities detain a former Israeli military officer and accuse him of espionage.
On 29 May 2011, dismissed information center employees held a protest in front of the Ministry of Local Development in Dokki, to demand their return to the project. [size=no report]

On 30 May 2011, dozens of farmers from Monofiya and Beheira Governorates blocked Magles Al Shab street, to demand the return of 17,000 feddans they acquired by hand. The armed forces have recovered the land in the past few days. Dozens of rural women pioneers also joined the demonstration to demand permanent contracts, after they have been working for more than 15 years as temporary workers. [size=dozens]

On 30 May 2011, dozens of lawyers from Cairo and other governorates started a sit-in in front of the Egyptian Lawyers Association in Cairo, to demand the dissolution of the General Association Council and its sub-councils, and the downfall of its president Hamdi Khalifa and all its branches heads. [size=dozens]

On 30 May 2011, around 50 people, mostly women supporters of Rajab Hilal Hamida, a former member of the Parliament, gathered in front of the Ministry of Justice, while he was being remanded in custody pending his case, demanding his release. [size=around 50]

On 30 May 2011, male and female students from technical and commercial high schools, gathered in front of the Ministry of Education in Cairo, to protest against the issue of the exam questions which were outside of the course they studied throughout the year. [size=no report]

On 30 May 2011, dozens of Nile University students and professors held a sit-in at the university's temporary headquarters in the Smart Village near Sheikh Zayed City (coded as Geo precision 2), to protest their delayed move to the university's headquarters in Sheikh Zayed. [size=dozens]

On 30 May 2011, for the second day in a row, dozens of dismissed information center employees continued to demonstrate in front of the Ministry of Local Development in Dokki, to demand their return to the project. [size=dozens]

On 31 May 2011, a number of workers who were transferred to early pension in the Egyptian Tora Portland Cement Factory, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand the adjustment of compensation bonus. Another group of workers returning from Algeria at Orascom Telecom, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand Essam Sharaf return their financial and civil rights, treat workers equally, and provide compensation for their homes. [size=several]
About 100 people protested to demand freedom of expression and an end to military trials for civilians outside the offices of the military prosecutor.

On 31 May 2011, dozens of employees of information centers, blocked the international road of Arish-Rafah (coded to Sheikh Zuweiyid, at geoprecision 2), to demand the dismissal of the director of personnel affairs, and to pay their salaries which were stalled for two months. [size=dozens]

On 31 May 2011, the police broke up the sit-in of about 40 imams which lasted for three days in front of the office of the Minister of Endowments, Abdullah Husseini Hilal in Abdeen, due to preventing the minister from practicing his work, and disrupting the work of the ministry. [size=around 40]

On 1 June 2011, a number of temporary workers at the Desert Research Stations Center from 8 research stations under the Ministry of Agriculture, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers. Al Azhar graduates also protested there. Dozens of members of the movement ''For All Unemployed'' gathered in front of the Council of Ministers to demand that Dr. Essam Sharaf provide job opportunities for the movement's members, whether in the public or private sectors, or pay a monthly subsidy until jobs are obtained. [size=dozens]
On 1 June 2011, dozens of employees of the Egyptian Electricity Transmission Company held a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Electricity and Energy's office in Abbasiya. [size=dozens]

On 1 June 2011, dozens of employees of the Ministry of Education's Science and Technology Exploratory Centers, demonstrated inside the ministry's headquarters in Cairo, protesting against the lack of incentive for excellence for them for nearly a year. [size=dozens]

On 2 June 2011, dozens of assistant teachers demonstrated inside the headquarters of the National Center for Exams and Educational Evaluation in Muqattam, in demonstration against the withholding of the test result of their staff, because of errors in their data on the answer sheets, and its incompatibility with the ministry's database.There were confrontations between the assistant teachers, and a number of employees of the National Center for Exams and Educational Evaluation in Muqattam, after the teachers insisted on holding the staff inside the center and preventing them from leaving after the end of the official working hours. [size=dozens]

On 2 June 2011, the American University in Tahrir Square witnessed a gathering of hundreds of people wishing to meet Dr. Ahmed Zewail, but they were surprised by the security of the university preventing them from entering due to the lack of places. They held a protest in front of the gate and expressed their demand to attend and participate in the seminar. [size=hundreds]

On 2 June 2011, a march started in Tahrir Square with 300 independent young people heading to the Council of Ministers, in support of the second revolution of anger demanding Dr. Essam Sharaf to prosecute the symbols of corruption and the failure of the security authorities in decision-making. [size=300]
On 3 June 2011, about 100 teachers staged a protest march in front of the headquarters of the Educational Professions Syndicate in Cairo, towards the Radio and TV Building. [size=about 100]

On 3 June 2011, a number of families of those injured in the clashes in front of Al-Azbakiya Police Station gathered in front of Al Hilal Hospital, and threw stones at the hospital. Security forces intervened. [size=several]
Protesters, angry over the death of a bus driver, clash with police who respond with tear gas. This event occurred outside a police station. 10 injured.

On 3 June 2011, the residents of Al-Jamaliya, Al-Darb Al-Ahmar, visitors to Al-Bait and owners of bazaars and cafes in El-Hussein area, organized a mass protest in El-Hussein Square, to demand the return of the police more strongly than before the January 25 revolution, in order to maintain security, control prices and eliminate bullying. [size=no report]
On 3 June 2011, dozens of residents of Sharm el-Sheikh protested in front of the hospital demanding the departure of former President Mubarak from the hospital to another place. [size=dozens]

On 3 June 2011, the coalition of workers in tourism and hotels organized a demonstration in Tahrir Square after Friday prayers, to demand the fixation of temporary workers, especially those that have been working more than three years, like the decision of the Minister of Finance Samir Radwan. Nearly 1,000 demonstrators gathered as well to emphasize the demands of the revolution, which include the prosecution of symbols of corruption, and accelerate their trials, the issuance of a new constitution governing the country and the execution of Mubarak. Dozens of Tahrir Square demonstrators attacked the Coptic reporter for CTV channel during her coverage of Tahrir Square demonstrations on Friday, the security forces saved her by firing shots in the air to disperse the aggressors, and they put her inside a car to escape from Tahrir Square. The demonstrators also attacked the officer who fired shots in the air, and took his gun. [size=around 3000]
3 Egyptian soldiers were killed and a 4th seriously injured when a truck driver drove through their checkpoint. It was not clear what motivated the action.

On 4 June 2011, dozens of relatives of the police chief Mohammed al-Sunni, who was sentenced to death for the murder of protesters in Cairo's Zawya al-Hamra area, held a protest in front of the High Court, demanding a fair retrial. [size=dozens]
On or around 5 June 2011, hundreds of employees of the Parliament held a protest in the Parlimant courtyard to announce their strike to voice their demands. [size=hundreds]

On 5 June 2011, dozens of employees of Salmco Acrylic Yarn Manufacturing Company, started a sit-in inside the headquarters of the Ministry of Manpower and Immigration in Nasr city, to demand the minister reimburse the subsidy that was spent by the ministry's emergency fund. [size=dozens]

On 5 June 2011, traffic on the Magles Al Shab Street in front of the Council of Ministers witnessed severe turbulence after a number of protesters staged three protests in front of the Council of Ministers. Dozens of license holders suspended at the Ministry of Petroleum staged a demand for immediate appointment, denouncing their disapproval. [size=dozens]

On 5 June 2011, traffic on the Magles Al Shab Street in front of the Council of Ministers witnessed severe turbulence after a number of protesters staged three protests in front of the Council of Ministers. Dozens of agricultural research workers of the Ministry of Agriculture held a stand in front of the Council of Ministers to demand Dr. Essam Sharaf to appoint temporary workers who have been working for five years. [size=dozens]

On 5 June 2011, hundreds of Bedouin cut off the international road of Al Arish - Rafah in the Hamaydeh area of Sheikh Zuwayed. Hundreds of people set tires on fire and blocked traffic and fired heavily on the road, local sources said.
On 5 June 2011, about 100 employees of the Ministry of Education's office organized a protest to demand the dismissal of Mohamed Eid, director of the ministry's affairs department. [size=about 100]

Nearly 1,000 residents of el-Ayat staged a sit-in which disrupted rail service between Cairo and Upper Egypt to demonstrate against a mobile rely station. They were concerned over potential radiation emitted by the station. Some of the protesters were armed with shotguns which they fired into the air.

On 6 June 2011, hundreds of the first graduates of Al Azhar University announced their participation in an open sit-in in front of the Council of Ministers, because their demands for appointment were ignored by the ministry. [size=hundreds]

On 6 June 2011, hundreds of Al Salam camp residents demonstrated in front of the Radio and TV Building in As Sabtiyyah, blocking the road. There were several confrontations between them and the drivers of the cars, which led the Nile Corniche to be completely paralyzed by traffic. [size=hundreds]

On 6 June 2011, dozens of families of Egyptian citizens detained in Libya, tried to enter the Foreign Ministry building by force to demand fast intervention and communication with the Libyan authorities to release their relatives, accusing the ministry of being slow to take the necessary measures to release them. [size=dozens]

On 7 June 2011, dozens of citizens from the ""I am Egyptian with the Intifada"" movement staged a protest in front of the Israeli embassy in Al Maadi to denounce the crimes against the Palestinian people. [size=dozens]

On 7 June 2011, dozens of Al Salam camp demonstrators blocked the Nile Corniche, and confrontations between demonstrators and car drivers breaking out. Police forces intervened to negotiate with the demonstrators to break up the sit-in. [size=dozens]
5 employees of Petrojet who were part of a sit-in were arrested by military police after 2 weeks of staging a sit-in outside the Ministry of Petroleum offices.

On 7 June 2011, dozens of employees of the Egyptian Company for Electricity Transmission held a sit-in at the Ministry of Electricity and Energy, demanding that Dr. Hassan Younis, Minister of Electricity, pay the cumulative incentives promised during his meeting with them last April. [size=dozens]

On 7 June 2011, demonstrators protested against the poor services in the silos at Wad Natrun Center, and called on Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf to look at the conditions of the center during his inspection of them that day. [size=no report]

On 8 June 2011, four demonstrations occurred in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, organized by temporary employees of the Desert Research Center, first graduates of Al Azhar University, employees of Al-Nasr Company, and farmers, blocking the road till their demands are met. Dozens were arrested after the police forces intervened. [size=no report]
Members of the April 6 Youth Movement staged a protest commemorating the death of Khaled Saied.
An April 6 Youth Movement activist says she was detained by police and beaten before being released after about 6 hours.
About 20 people protested in Luxor over a land dispute. There were reports that the protesters had attacked tourists but the Egyptian authorities later claimed no violence occurred.

On 9 June 2011, dozens of primary school teachers demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Cairo and demanded to change their job titles, and transfer them from elementary to junior high and high schools. [size=dozens]

On 10 June 2011, dozens of demonstrators in Tahrir Square, after Friday prayers, raised banners calling for the completion of the demands of the revolution, including the demand for the execution of the former president and the restructuring of the police. They also assaulted a police secretary named Adel A. after shouting slogans calling for restructuring the Ministry of Interiors. Dozens of teachers staged a demonstration in Tahrir Square as well, demanding the formation of a teachers' parliament that will join experts and officials in formulating educational policy. [size=a couple of dozens]

On 10 June 2011, nearly 300 Salafists staged a march from Omar Makram Mosque in Qasr Ad Dobarah, to demand the release of Abu Yahya, who was arrested pending an investigation into the recent events in Imbabah. The march went to TV Building, through Tahrir Square. [size=nearly 300]
On 11 June 2011, 120 students of Al-Azhar University held a protest in front of the military council to demand a fast release of Mohamed Lotfy and Juma Jalal. [size=120]

On 11 June 2011, more than 20 youths of the Tagammu Party entered an open sit-in inside the party's central headquarters in Qasr Al-Nile, in protest against the inclusion of former leaders from the National Party to the Tagammu party's membership during the past months. [size=more than 20]

On 11 June 2011, workers at the Nubaria power station in Behera governorate near Al Teiriya (coded as Geo precision 2), entered an open sit-in inside the ""main control"" room in the station, to protest against the ignoring of the Ministry of Electricity, and refusing to pay accumulating bonuses. [size=no report]

On 11 June 2011, hundreds of workers at the electricity company Ayoun Mousse Power Plant, in Suez, held a sit-in in protest against the low wages and the non-amendment of their pay list. [size=hundreds]

On 12 June 2011, 4 groups of people held a protest in front of the Council of Ministers. People with special needs working for Ezz Dekheila company in Alexandria gathered to demand equality. The staff of the quarry project in Helwan organized a vigil in front of the Council of Ministers, demanding the honor of separating quarry projects nationwide away from localities. A number of archaeological workers organized a protest, demanding Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi and Dr. Essam Sharaf to remove Zahi Hawass, Minister of Antiquities and Investigate into his involvement in wasting public money and full responsibility for the theft of the Egyptian Museum. Dozens of Ideal company employees also organized a protest to demand Sharaf for payments, compensation and equality with their colleagues and the implementation of the Cabinet's decision on bonuses. [size=more than dozens]
Arrests: An Israeli-American, Ilan Grapel, is arrested and charged with espionage.
On 12 June 2011, dozens of parents of Al-Azhar students who failed the exams protested in front of Al-Azhar in El-Gamaleya. [size=dozens]

On 12 June 2011, hundreds of class teachers from different governorates staged a demonstration in front of the Organization and Administration building in Nasr City, to demand their fixation. They also broke into the main gate of the building, and prevented Safwat al-Nahas, the head of the center, from leaving, which forced him to flee the demonstrators from a back door at the center. [size=hundreds]

On 12 June 2011, dozens of parents of students of Shaimaa Preparatory Government School in Muqattam, protested in front of the Ministry of Education headquarters in Cairo, after their daughters failed to pass the third grade preparatory exams. [size=dozens]

column7: Fishermen (Egypt); Labour Group (Egypt); Women (Egypt); Government of Egypt (2011-2012)
column17: On 13 June 2011, a group of fishermen from Izbat al Burj in Damietta governorate organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, demanding the Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf, and Dr. Ayman Farid Abu Hadid, Minister of Agriculture, exclude fishing hooks users from the decision to ban fishing in the Mediterranean, because it doesn't harm the sea. 22 female workers in the Ministry of Family and Population in the Family Friends Program in Kafr El-Sheikh, held a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, calling on Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf to appoint their jobs. Also, dozens of disabled employees of Ezz Dekheila Company continued to demonstrate for the second day in front of the Council of Ministers, demanding Dr. Essam Sharaf to treat the disabled employees like others working in the company and raise their basic salary. [size=no report]

On 13 June 2011, dozens of dismissed information center staff gathered in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Local Development in Dokki, to ask Minister Mohsen Al-Numani to allow them to return to the information centers and provide the necessary funds. [size=dozens]
On 13 June 2011, dozens of disabled workers in South Delta electricity company in Tanta protested for jobs. [size=dozens]

On 14 June 2011, thousands of Coptic Christians held a protest in front of the Security Directorate building in Minya to demand authorities to search for two disappeared Christian girls. [size=about 1000]

On 14 June 2011, a march of dozens of veterinarians was launched in front of Dar Al Hikma in Al Qasr al Ayni, towards the Council of Ministers to deliver a memorandum containing a series of demands, the first of which is an independent veterinary entity under the Council of Ministers. [size=dozens]
Employees of the Suez Canal authority began protests in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said to demand higher pay and better working conditions.
Employees of the Suez Canal authority began protests in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said to demand higher pay and better working conditions.
Employees of the Suez Canal authority began protests in Ismailia, Suez and Port Said to demand higher pay and better working conditions.
On 14 June 2011, A number of disabled workers in Ezz Dekheila Company in Alexandria continued to demonstrate in front of the Council of Ministers demanding equality. [size=several]
On 15 June 2011, in Minya, Coptic Christians demonstrated, demanding authorities search for two disappeared Christian girls, three policemen and six Coptic demonstrators were injured. [size=hundreds]

On 15 June 2011, fishermen of Idko Center closed Al Maddiya bridge near Khurshid (coded as Geo precision 2) with a garbage truck, concrete blocks, and two electricity poles and stones, to prevent the passage of cars and the train passing through the village, to demonstrate against the Ministry of Agriculture's decision to ban fishing from today for one month. [size=no report]

On 15 June 2011, violent confrontations between demonstrating workers and train passengers erupted when the demonstrations stopped all train traffic at Cairo-Port Said. The workers of Zagazig workshops occupied the rails at Zagazig railway station, demanding the implementation of the new incentive structure. [size=no report]
On 15 June 2011, a number of disabled workers in Ezz Dekheila Company in Alexandria continued to demonstrate in front of the Council of Ministers demanding equality. [size=several]
Protesters from El-Salam started a sit-in outside the Maspero building (As Sabtiyyah) to demand housing units after having been living in camps for months.
Egyptian police allegedly shot dead 4 Sudanese migrants as they tried to cross the border illegally into Israel.

On 15 June 2011, dozens of journalists staged a protest in front of the Journalists Syndicate in Qasr Al-Nile, to denounce the attack on the Coptic TV channel reporter ""Mary"" while covering the recent demonstrations in Tahrir Square. [size=dozens]
On 15 June 2011, dozens of the General Coalition of Police Secretaries, staged a protest at Tahrir Square, to demand the abolition of military courts and arbitrary transfers. [size=dozens]
Protesters engaged in a sit-in outside the Maspero building to demand housing clashed with passersby in the area. It was not clear what prompted the violence.

On 16 June 2011, a number of imams excluded by the dissolved state security service from various governorates, protested in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand that Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf, and Minister of Endowments Dr. Abdullah Al-Husseini, re-appoint all excluded imams, and preserve their financial rights and equality. Also, a number of disabled workers in Ezz Dekheila Company in Alexandria continued to demonstrate in front of the Council of Ministers demanding equality. [size=several]
Hundreds of disabled people protested in downtown Cairo to demand the protection of their rights and employment.

On 16 June 2011, dozens of social specialists protested in front of the headquarters of the General Union in Cairo, against the refusal of the Minister of Housing to issue the ministerial decision on the project of social specialists housing. [size=dozens]

On 17 June 2011, a number of disabled employees of Ezz Dekheila company in Alexandria moved their demonstration today to Tahrir Square, to demand equality. Another 500 protesters gathered in the square, which led to traffic disruption, and many expressed their opposition to talk about the corruption of sports, stressing that the main demands of the revolution and demonstrations are the urgent trial of Mubarak and his people, and the dissolution of local councils. [size=around 500]

On 17 June 2011, dozens of Salafists gathered in front of Al Nour Mosque in Al Abbasiyah, to demand the release of Salafi activist Moftah Mohamed Fadel ""Abu Yahya"", detained for inciting sedition on the events of sectarian strife in Imbaba. [size=dozens]
On 17 June 2011, Al Sawaki Square in Al Fayyum witnessed a mass protest of hundreds of Al Fayyum people in the square, to protest against the killing of 18-year-old Mohammed Mahmoud. [size=hundreds]

On 18 June 2011, the Council of Ministers Street witnessed three protests by people demanding jobs, including dozens of employees of the legal departments of the government, who organized a silent protest to demand the establishment of a public authority for the legal department of the government. A number of employees of the National Sports Council also organized a rally, demanding jobs. A third group of disabled persons in Ezz Al-Dekheila Company, resumed their sit-in in front of the Council to demand equality. [size=more than dozens]

Egyptian soldiers fired into the air to disperse protesters who were allegedly trying to storm a Suez Canal authority office in Ismailia. The protesters were employees of the canal authority and had been engaged in ongoing demonstrations to demanding higher salaries and better working conditions.
On 18 June 2011, a number of NDP supporters of former Minister of Housing Ahmed al-Maghrabi staged a protest in front of the New Cairo Court at the Fifth Settlement in New Cairo City. [size=several]
On 18 June 2011, dozens of engineers protested in front of the headquarters of the General Syndicate in Cairo, demanding the reduction of the powers of the irrigation minister. [size=dozens]

On 18 June 2011, more than 300 workers in marble factories and workshops blocked the international highway in Shaq al-Taban area in Kirdasah near Tura Public Prison, to demonstrate against the Minister of Industry's decision to raise marble import duties, which would harm their interests and lead to the disruption of their work. [size=more than 300]

On 19 June 2011, journalists started a sit-in at the office of Deputy Prime Minister Dr. Yahya al-Jamal in protest against the failure to implement the decision issued by the Council of Ministers to assign them to national newspapers. [size=no report]

On 19 June 2011, three protests over employment were organized in front of the Council of Ministers, initiated by holders of suspended Licenses at the Ministry of Petroleum, demanding the prime minister, to immediately appoint holders of suspended licenses. Also a number of disabled workers in Ezz Dekheila Company in Alexandria continue to demonstrate for the seventh day in front of the Council of Ministers, demanding Field Marshal Mohamed Hussein Tantawi and Dr. Essam Sharaf equality. [size=several]

On 19 June 2011, three protests over employment were organized in front of the Council of Ministers, initiated by holders of suspended Licenses at the Ministry of Petroleum, demanding the prime minister, to immediately appoint holders of suspended licenses. A number of families in the eastern district of Shubra Dakahlia, which their old real estate was removed, gathered demanding Dr. Essam Sharaf access to housing units. [size=several]

On 19 June 2011, dozens of teachers with temporary contracts gathered in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Education in Cairo, to protest the failure of educational directorates to implement the decision of the Minister of Education to appoint teachers and administrators who have been working for three years. [size=dozens]

On 19 June 2011, a number of workers at Al Hilal Hospital in Al Fawalah, organized a protest against the treatment of the Director General of the Red Crescent Society in Giza, ""Ezzat Al-Sbaa"". [size=several]
On 19 June 2011, dozens of Al Salam camp residents gathered this morning in front of the Cairo governorate headquarters, to demand alternative housing units for the camps. [size=dozens]

On 20 June 2011, a number of contract workers at Al Ahram specialized hospital, held a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, demanding that Dr. Essam Sharaf, and Dr. Ashraf Hatem, Minister of Health let them return to work. [size=several]

On 20 June 2011, nearly 50 workers from Telemisr, a manufacturer of electrical devices, protested in front of the office of Minister of Manpower and Immigration Dr. Ahmed El-Borai in Nasr City, to demand their return to work and restart the company at full capacity. [size=nearly 50]
On 21 June 2011, about 20 Egyptian activists gathered in front of the Spanish embassy in El Gezra, to demand Spanish authorities extradite Egyptian businessman Hussein Salem. [size=about 20]

On 21 June 2011, the Egyptian Family Protection Coalition, and the Egyptian Men's Revolution Movement, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to ask Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf, and Minister of Justice, to drop the family laws issued under the former president, which was requested by his wife. [size=no report]

On 21 June 2011, a limited number of police secretaries staged a protest in front of the house of Major General Mansour Al Issawi, Minister of Interior, located in Mourad Street in Giza, to demand an increase in their wages. [size=several]
On 21 June 2011, dozens of teachers protested in front of the Ministry of Education against not changing their job titles. [size=dozens]
On 21 June 2011, administrators and workers at the control of the general high school exams in 6th October City, stopped working and held a protest against not being appointd so far. [size=No Report]

On 21 June 2011, the families of the martyrs of Alexandria started a sit-in in front of the Alexandria Criminal Court after the decision to release the officers involved in the killing of their children in the events of Friday of Anger. [size=no report]
On 21 June 2011, the Egyptian Family Rescue Movement organized a protest in front of Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf's house in Dokki, to demand a change of personal status law. [size=no report]

On 22 June 2011, a number of temporary workers at the Desert Research Centers under the Ministry of Agriculture, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand Dr. Essam Sharaf and Dr. Ayman Farid Abu Hadid, Minister of Agriculture to appoint temporary workers. Dozens of imams excluded by the former state security, protested in front of the Council of Ministers, to demand Dr. Essam Sharaf, and Minister of Awqaf Abdullah al-Husseini, immediate re-appointment. [size=dozens]

On 22 June 2011, three thousand information center employees, broke into the main door of the Ministry of Local Development in Dokki, to demonstrate inside the ministry's campus, demanding the necessity of dismissing Mohsen Al-Nomani, Minister of Local Development. [size=3000]
2 Egyptian police officers were killed and 2 others injured by unidentified gunmen in Al-Arish. The police were deployed at a security post outside a bank.

On 22 June 2011, 250 workers of the Swiss company ""Kahromica"" for metal and plastic industries, in 10th of Ramadan city, organized a protest against the administration's moves to sell the company to an Egyptian investor. [size=250]
On 22 June 2011, nearly 200 Pro-Mubarak Supporters, protested in front of Abdeen court. [size=nearly 200]

On 22 June 2011, a number of workers of Al-Nasr for Casting demonstrated in Tanash, in conjunction with the company's general assembly on Wednesday. During their demonstrations in front of Al Nasr castings branch, the workers confirmed that the chairman of the company, Fathallah Mohamed Kamal, seeks to restructure the company with its three shareholders in order to make decisions without the workers' approval. [size=several]
On 22 June 2011, more than 200 employees of the Real Estate Authority gathered in front of its headquarters in Cairo to demand the payment of their financial entitlements. [size=more than 200]

On 23 June 2011, passengers of the developed train No. 141 sat on the rails, blocking the movement of trains (Aswan - Cairo), putting wooden pieces in Raqqa station near Al Ayyat (coded as Geo precision 2) to prevent the movement of trains coming to Cairo in order to prevent the 999 air-conditioned train from crossing their train. [size=no report]

On 23 June 2011, Qasr Al-Aini Street experienced a traffic disruption after a number of temporary workers at the specialized sports medical centers of the National Sports Council, organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand Dr. Essam Sharaf appoint them immediately. [size=No Report]

On 23 June 2011, dozens of students from the literary section of the General high school, gathered in front of the Ministry of Education in Cairo, to express their anger over the difficulty of the geology exam questions. [size=dozens]

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: On 23 June 2011, dozens of tourism workers were injured in Sharm el-Sheikh, after groups of Bedouin from the area attacked the shops and cafeterias of the workers' housing, to demand payment of monthly royalties for their protection, which was rejected by the shopkeepers and they clashed with the Bedouins who rained the shops with gunfire, which resulted in gunshot injuries of dozens of workers, and the military police forces intervened to protect the civilians.

On 23 June 2011, 250 workers of the Swiss company ""Kahromica"" for metal and plastic industries, in 10th of Ramadan city, protested against the administration's moves to sell the company to an Egyptian investor. [size=250]

On 24 June 2011, demonstrators of Tahrir Square burned the Israeli flag denouncing the crimes committed by Israel against the Palestinians, demanding a boycott of American goods, because they support Israel in its sabotage and they threatened to burn the American flag. [size=no report]
Tens of Egyptians protested outside the Spanish embassy (Zamalek) to demand the extradition of businessman Hussein Salem and the return of his funds in Spain.

On 24 June 2011, dozens of families of the martyrs and wounded of the revolution started a sit-in in front of the TV Building in As Sabtiyyah to demand the inclusion of former president and Anas al-Fiqi, Tariq Kamel and Hatem al-Jabali in the list of suspects in the case of killing and injuring the rebels, they were also blocking and opening the road regularly. [size=dozens]

A small gathering of pro-Mubarak demonstrators in Mohandiseen swelled into an 800-strong protest by early evening, demanding the immediate release of the former president. Arguments with about 300 anti-Mubarak demonstrators let to clashes resulting in dozens injured.

On 24 June 2011, 250 workers of the Swiss company ""Kahromica"" for metal and plastic industries, in 10th of Ramadan city, organized a protest against the administration's moves to sell the company to an Egyptian investor. [size=250]
150 employees of Petrojet began a sit-in outside the Egyptian Ministry of Petroleum (Nasr City) after the minister refused to meet with them to discuss their grievances.

Muslims rallied in the village of Awlad Khalaf outside a plot of land where a church was under construction, claiming it was illegal. Salafis allegedly attempted to bulldoze the church, leading to a clash involving with Christians that resulted in at least 3 bullet wounds and a stabbing.

On 25 June 2011, dozens of lawyers and workers of the company ""ARSCO ASEC"" staged a protest in front of the Office of Counselor, Mr. Abdel Aziz, President of Cairo Appeal Court, for the second time to protest against Mahmoud Sprut, the investigation judge in the ''site of the camel''. [size=dozens]
On 25 June 2011, the Muslim Brotherhood organized a silent protest in front of Al Ittihad Club in Alexandria to demand the dismissal of Dr. Yehia El Gamal. [size=no report]

On 25 June 2011, 250 workers of the Swiss company ""Kahromica"" for metal and plastic industries, in 10th of Ramadan city, organized a protest for the fourth day in a row against the administration's moves to sell the company to an Egyptian investor. [size=250]

On 25 June 2011, dozens of citizens of Sheikh Zuweiyid demonstrated outside gas cylinders filling station on Sheikh Zuwayed Al-Joura road, where they blocked the road, demanding tighter control to prevent smuggling of gas cylinders to Gaza Strip. [size=dozens]

On 26 June 2011, a number of temporary workers in sports medical centers organized a demonstration to demand Prime Minister Dr. Essam Sharaf appointment them, which led to traffic disruption in Al Qasr al Ayni Street, and confrontations between them and the policemen because they objected to blocking the road by police to prevent them from holding a demonstration in front of the Council of Ministers. [size=several]

On 26 June 2011, hundreds of workers at the Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation held a protest, in front of the ministry's building in Al Warraq, against the ministry's bonus disbursement to engineers for more months than they received. [size=hundreds]

On 26 June 2011, in response to the decision to postpone the trial of Al Adly until July 25th, the families of martyrs and wounded from the revolution demonstrated in front of the Radio and TV Building in As Sabtiyyah, by blocking the road refusing the decision to postpone the trial. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2011, a group of ""anti-corruption watchers"" organized a protest in front of the Central Auditing Organization on Salah Salem Street in Nasr City, to demand the dismissal of the head of the organization as part of the former regime. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2011, the imams, who were excluded for security reasons, resumed their sit-in in front of the Ministry of Endowments in Bab al Luq, demanding appointment after their sit-in in front of the Council of Ministers was broken up. [size=no report]
Protesters threw stones at police cars escorting a former minister to his court hearing, clash with riot police. They were angry over the deferral of his trial.

On 26 June 2011, 40 doctors specialized in Natural Medicine gathered inside the Ministry of Health in Cairo, to oppose the separation of doctors from the specialized ones technically and administratively, and to demand the cancellation of the decision issued by the Minister of Health, which requires the presence of specialized doctors in Natural Medicine clinics. [size=40]

On 26 June 2011, a number of researchers at the Agricultural Research Center organized a protest in front of the headquarters of the center in Giza, objecting to the non-adjustment of their financial and administrative status at the Center. [size=several]

On 27 June 2011, Al Qasr al Ayni Street experienced a demonstration with drums, dance and national songs, to force officials to hear the voices of protesters who were prevented by the Central Security Forces from entering the Magles Al Shab Street. The families of the martyr Mahmoud Khaled Qatb closed Al Qasr al Ayni road, protested against delay of his body for more than 3 hours. Verbal altercations occurred between parents and cars' drivers. [size=no report]

On 27 June 2011, the families of martyrs and those injured in the January 25 revolution, continued their demonstration in front of the TV Building in As Sabtiyyah, and refused to open the road, insisting that it should not be opened until their demands are met, which included the urgent trial of Mubarak and his aides publicly. [size=no report]

On 27 June 2011, dozens of young people, with the participation of the Free Egypt Revolution Coalition, gathered in front of the Spanish Embassy in El Gezra, to demand the revocation of Spanish citizenship of the fugitive businessman Hussein Salem, and hand him over to Egypt after recovering the money he looted from the Egyptian people. [size=dozens]

On 27 June 2011, dozens of residents of Kafr ash Shaykh, governorate gathered in front of the Foreign Affairs Ministry building in Bulaq, demanding the return of their relatives from Libyan territories. [size=dozens]

About 3000 relatives of those killed during the Mubarak protests demonstrated in Tahrir Square. They clash with police who attempt to disperse them. Over 66 injured. Protests and clashes last two days. (Some reports claimed as many as 600-1,000 injured)

On 28 June 2011, a number of temporary workers in specialized gardens, staged a protest in Al Qasr al Ayni Street in front of the Council of Ministers, to demand that Dr. Essam Sharaf, Prime Minister, appoint the workers. Imams also continued their sit-in in front of the Council of Ministers. [size=several]

On 28 June 2011, there were physical confrontations between demonstrators in front of the Council of Ministers and security forces. Residents of Al Salam camps denied involvement in these clashes. [size=no report]

On 28 June 2011, in a rapid development of events in front of Al Azhar in El-Gamaleya rioters sat on the ground in front of the main doors of the building, making it difficult for the leaders of Al Azhar and the members of the Islamic Research Complex to leave. Security forces intervened. [size=no report]
Protesters clash with police outside the Interior Ministry Building (El-Sayeda).

On 29 June 2011, a number of demonstrators marched to the headquarters of the Ministry of the Interior in Cairo, and surrounded the building, causing confrontations with security forces. A number of them threw bricks at the building, and the security forces responded by throwing tear gas at them, which resulted in injuries. Demonstrators also set a number of tires and wood on fire in the street near the ministry. A number of residents living in the area joined the security forces and participated in the clash against the demonstrators. [size=several]

On 28 June 2011, the security-excluded imams moved their sit-in, which entered its seventh day, from the sidewalk of Al Qasr al Ayni Street, to the Council of Ministers to ask Dr. Essam Sharaf to re-appoint them. [size=no report]
Arrests: A Britain and an American civilian are detained by police during clashes.

About 3000 relatives of those killed during the Mubarak protests demonstrated in Tahrir Square. They clash with police who attempt to disperse them. Over 66 injured. Protests and clashes continued overnight into the next day (Jun.29). Some reports claimed as many as 600-1,000 injured.

On 30 June 2011, the central security forces fired shots in the air on Ibrahim Najib Street in Cairo, which leads to the Interior Ministry, after the demonstrators threw stones at them. [size=no neport]
Protesters again demonstrated in Tahrir Square, resulting in new clashes with police. Many injuries reported. The protesters also allegedly have pitched tents in the Square.

Members of the April 6 Youth Movement allegedly assaulted Muslim Brotherhood members engaged in a rally outside the al-Qaid Ibrahim Mosque in Alexandria. The MB members dispersed to prevent the outbreak of clashes, although the April 6 Youth members allegedly also attacked the transports being used to ferry MB members to and from the venue. A number of injuries were also reported due to stone throwing at both MB members and passersby.

Protesters converged on Cairos Tahrir Square on Friday to join camping pro-democracy activists ahead of a demonstration planned after Muslim noon prayers to push for reforms. Protesters remain for several days.

3 people were killed during riots in Salloum which broke out after the killing by police of an alleged smuggler on the border with Libya. Four police cars were torched during clashes between protesters and police/military personnel.
About 200 protesters remained in Tahrir Square after a large rally the day before.

Police used live ammunition to disperse some masked gunmen who opened indiscriminate fire on civilians from a flyover near Terminal Square in Cairos Abooud neioghbourhood. No injuries were reported. It was not clear what motivated the event.
A group of saboteurs destroy a gas pipeline connecting Israel. This is the third time this line has been bombed over a short amount of time.
Protesting Suez Arsenal workers shut off electricity to the city. Suez Arsenal Company employees shut down the electricity to Port Tawfik district in Suez and lock the gates of company premises.
A group of unidentified armed men attack pro-democracy protesters in Tahrir Square leaving many injured.

A youth was killed during clashes between police and relatives who attempted to a storm a police station to free about 50 suspects taken in a drug raid on the Ezbet Abou Qarn slum of Cairo the day before.
Thousands of protesters gathered at El-Arbaeine Square in Suez to demand ""jutice for the martyrs"" following the release of some police accused of killing protesters.

Hundreds of Egyptian protesters have lobbed rocks at the security headquarters and set fire to police cars for two days (Jun.5-6) in Suez, as growing impatience over delays in trying former regime officials and police accused of killing protesters. One protester was reported injured, shot in the head.
Hundreds of Sues residents staged a sit-in at the El-Arbaeine Square to protest against the release on bail of 7 police accused of murdering protesters.

Hundreds of Egyptian protesters have lobbed rocks at the security headquarters and set fire to police cars for two days in Suez, as growing impatience over delays in trying former regime officials and police accused of killing protesters. One protester was reported injured, shot in the head.
Members of the Muslim Brotherhood join an ongoing protest already populated with pro-democracy supporters.
Egyptian police shot dead an Eritrean migrant as he tried to cross the border illegally into Israel.

Dozens of Egyptians protested, both Muslims and Christians, in Cairo to demand the introduction of civil marriages alongside existing religious marriages, to make it easier to get divorced and remarry.
Protests were held in Sharm el-Sheikh and al-Arish in line with a national day of protest called to keep pressure on the SCAF to prosecute corruption and continue to reform the government.
Protests to keep up pressure on the SCAF to prosecute corruption and continue reform of the government were reported in Ismailia, Fayoum and Aswan.
Protests to keep up pressure on the SCAF to prosecute corruption and continue reform of the government were reported in Ismailia, Fayoum and Aswan.
Protests to keep up pressure on the SCAF to prosecute corruption and continue reform of the government were reported in Ismailia, Fayoum and Aswan.
Hundreds of protesters set up a tent camp in Assiut to continue to put pressure on the SCAF to root out corruption and continue to reform the government.

Tens of thousands of Egyptians crowded into Tahrir Square on Friday, demanding the resignation of the interim government. The Muslim brotherhood was also present. The protest lasted over several days. Roads barricaded on the third day.
Protests were held in Sharm el-Sheikh and al-Arish in line with a national day of protest called to keep pressure on the SCAF to prosecute corruption and continue to reform the government.

A protester was shot in the head by an unidentified gunman during a protest in Suez over the release on bail of police accused of killing protesters. Reports conflicted on whether the protester died after reaching a nearby hospital. The protest was also in line with others held today to demand the SCAF continue to reform the government.
Protesters gather in various cities to call for an end of the interim government. The protests lasted over the course of several days.

Thousands attended protests calling for the SCAF to meet the demands of anti-government protests earlier this year were held in Alexandria outside the al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque, among other major cities.
Protesters remained in Tahrir Square as well as many other city centres to continue to put pressure on the SCAF. They continued to block traffic and have set up tents.
A protester from Tahrir Square claims he was abducted for about a week and tortured by police while he was in their custody after being found badly hurt on a road in the capital on Jul.14.

Protesters gather in various cities to call for an end of the interim government. The protests lasted over the course of several days. The military deploys troops to this area after the treat of the Suez canal being disrupted.
Protesters gather in various cities to call for an end of the interim government. The protests lasted over the course of several days.
