Military police on Sunday forcefully dispersed a sit-in by thousands of Suez protesters blocking the Suez-Ain Sokhna desert road, which supports canal traffic.
Police use batons to disperse protesters after they block roads with trucks.

Protesters in Tahrir Square blocked access to Cairos largest government office as part of ongoing protests to put pressure on the SCAF to continue reforms and prosecute corruption. About 27 protesters also began a hunger strike to demand the government address the demonstrators grievances.
A few thousand protesters continued to camp in Tahrir Square despite a power cut to the area and reported thefts.
Arrests: Four US nationals are held by Egyptian authorities during sit-in protests.

Protesters gather to call for the prosecution of violent police. About 3,000 protesters also gathered outside the Egyptian Peopls Assembly and cabinet offices. Later, about 30 assailants carrying knives and sticks attacked the protest camp in Tahrir Square, injuring 6 people.
A gas pipeline is blown up for the fourth time since February.
Hundreds of protesters resumed a sit-in in the El-Raml Station (Ash Shatibi) as part of ongoing demonstrations in major Egyptian cities.
Thousands of protesters demonstrated at El-Arbaein Square in Suez as part of ongoing demonstrations in major Egyptian cities.

Non-violent activity: The Interior Ministry has announced that it is firing 668 police officers in the ""biggest reshuffle in the history of the Egyptian police force"". Protests related to the use of force by police against protesters have been staged in recent weeks.
Protesters gather to call for the prosecution of violent police.
A sit-in was started in the Port Tawfiq area of Suez as part of ongoing demonstrations across the country over corruption and police brutality.
Protesters claim four individuals who had started a hunger strike were tortured by police in Suez.
Protests have continued in Tahrir Square over the slow pace of reforms and police brutality against protesters.
Protesters gather to denounce military generals who failed to meet their reform expectations.
More than 500 people demonstrated at Roxy Square (Mansheya El-Bakry) to show solidarity with the SCAF.
Protests were again held at Al-Arbaein Square in Suez to demand faster reform of the government by the SCAF.
Dozens of protesters marched from Tahrir Square to the Prosecutor Generals office to demand quick trials for those accused of attacking and killing protesters during the ""January 25 Revolution"".

Protesters gather to press for government reforms. The military used excessive force and carried out arbitrary mass arrests to disperse demonstrations and sit-ins - beating and tasering those arrested.
Clashes broke out between security forces and protesters calling for an end of the military governance. Many arrests are made.
Protesters clashed with military police during demonstrations against the SCAF in Alexandria.

Thousands of protesters tried to march to the Defense Ministry of Egypt when they were attacked by groups of men wielding knives, sticks, stones and molotov cocktails. At many as 150 people were reported injured in the events. Military forces also fired into the air and used barbed wire blockades to block the protesters march; the attackers seem to have been supporters of the military.
Train drivers held a sit-in strike for a few hours around the Ramses Railway Station in Cairo to protest a new incentive system.
Hundreds of protesters threw stones at a convoy of vans taking away former Interior Ministry Habib al-Adly as his murder trial was postponed until Aug.3.
Canal workers, upset about pay, clash with military police. 38 injuries.

4 people, including at least 2 civilians and a military officer, were killed and 12 police conscripts injured when about 150 unidentified gunmen tried to break into the Al-Arish police station. The men entered town riding jeeps and motorcycles and fired into the air before arriving at the police station; they also displayed black flags reading ""There is no God but Allah"".
2 Coptic Christians were killed and 2 injured in a shooting in Abu Qurqas in Menia governorate by unidentified gunmen.
Two are dead and twelve injured after armed men rampage through a city.

Egyptian forces shot at African migrants attempting to cross the border into Israel from the Sinai. During the incident, some of the bullets hit an Israeli army vehicle, although no injuries were reported.

Various ""unity"" protests were held in Alexandria to demand a faster trial for Mubarak, corrupt officials and police involved in attacking protesters. Islamists and Salafists were prominent in some of the protests.

Tens of thousands of people protested in Tahrir Square to show solidarity and unity in their efforts to demand reform following former President Mubaraks ouster. A number of different parties and organizations were represented, including Islamist groups.
Unidentified assailants attacked a pipeline near Al-Arish with grenades and gunfire, leading to clashes with Egyptian soldiers.
Police clash with suspected gunmen, make arrests.
Rights organizations have accused Egyptian security forces at El-Wadi El-Gedid prison of torturing prisoners, including protesters.
Police beat protesters, destroy their tents. Many arrests made.
Clashes in Sharm el-Sheikh resulted in 3 people injured after Mubarak was transferred from a local hospital to a courthouse in Cairo.

The military used excessive force and carried out arbitrary mass arrests in various cities to disperse demonstrations and sit-ins on August 1 - beating and tasering those arrested. Cairo was among those cities.

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: Several hundred protesters camped out in Tahrir Square clashed with hundreds of military police and central security forces who stormed the square in an attempt to dismantle the sit-in. Police fired into the air and used batons, while the protesters responded with stones and rocks. Dozens were reported injured, including security personnel, and 111 were detained. The military police and the central security forces cordoned off the square and closed off all access to it using tanks. [size=hundreds]

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: On 02 August, hundreds of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to denounce the dispersion of the sit-in by the military police the previous day. The military police cordoned off the Square's garden and deployed hundreds of police officers to the area to prevent another sit-in. [size= hundreds]

On 02 August 2011, 6 unidentified gunmen, suspected to be members of a militant group, attacked the general hospital of Al Arish and stole the corpse of a Palestinian youth that was killed during previous clashes. The gunmen opened fire on guards and stole the body before fleeing the area.

column7: Suez Youth Bloc; April 6 Youth Movement
column17: On 02 August 2011, a demonstration took place in Al-Arbaeen Square in Suez to denounce the violent dispersion of the Tahrir Square sit-in by the military police. The protest was attended by 200 people including members of Suez Youth Bloc and April 6 Youth Movement. [size= 200]

column7: RYA: Revolutionary Youth Alliance; Muslim Brotherhood; Wafd Party
column17: On 02 August 2011, a civilian protest took place in front of the Syrian embassy in Cairo during which protesters denounced the Asad regime violence against civilians and demanded the expulsion of the Syrian ambassador. The protest was attended by 150 people including members of the Muslim Brotherhood, the Wafd Party, and the Revolutionary Youth Alliance. [size= 150]

53 people were injured in clashes between pro- and anti-Mubarak protesters outside the Cairo police academy where his trial is being held. Police forces later separated the two sides, although stone-throwing continued.
Petrol bombs were thrown by unidentified people at the Arab League headquarters. No casualties or serious damage was reported.

Military police used aerial firing and batons to break up a meeting of activists who were engaged in a traditional Ramadan meal at Tahrir Square. At least one protester was injured. Protesters who attempted to stage a funeral for a protester who died of his injuries were also dispersed earlier in the day.
A Christian is killed and four Muslims are injured in a clash following an auto accident.

Dozens of protesters holding a sit-in in front of the Maspero (state TV) building were cordoned off and the roads around the station closed by police to put pressure on them to move to a different location.
Dozens of Egyptians angered by the absence of police protection in their town set fire to a police station after looting its armory and freeing jailed inmates.
Egyptian police shot dead a Sudanese migrant and wounded 2 others attempting to cross illegally into Israel.

column9: Military Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Military Police
column17: A demonstration, took place in Tahrir Square. Clashes, involving stone-throwing, erupted between members of the police and demonstrators when some of the demonstrators attempted to enter the Square's garden. The military police intervened and formed a chain around the garden. [size=200]

Egyptian police and military carried out raids and arrests in Al Arish in search of Islamist militias suspected of carrying out the attack on the second police station Al Arish. A gunman was killed during clashes with the police and the military when they attempted to arrest him. 15 people were arrested and large quantities of weapons and other military equipment were sized during the raids.

34 people were injured in clashes between pro- and anti-Mubarak demonstrators outside the courthouse at the police academy where his trial is set to begin. Police reinforcements were deployed to the area after the police failed to stop the clashes. [size=no report]
Protesters gather outside court as Mubarak trial resumes.
Egyptian police foiled an attack on a pipeline near Al-Arish. They captured 4 gunmen along with their weapons and some explosives.

On 16 August 2011, Egyptian military and police forces, supported by special forces, continued raids in in Al-Arish in search of suspected Islamist militias. A gunman riding a motorbike shot and killed a police officer the raids. 10 suspected Islamist militia fighters were arrested.

On 17 August 2011, four unidentified gunmen driving a truck opened fire on Raysa checkpoint at the eastern entrance of Al Arish. Two similar attacks took place at Lahfan and Al-Mazra'a checkpoints (no coordinates available) south of Al-Arish.

On 17 August 2011, a demonstration organized by a number of Salafi groups took place in front of Nour Mosque in Al Abbasiyah in Cairo denouncing the proposed Supra-Constitutional Principles document. [size= no report]

On 17 August 2011, Egyptian military and police forces continued raids in Al-Arish and its surroundings. Large quantities of weapons, including 10 hand grenades and 15 RPGs and TNT, were seized during the raids on a weapon storage and factory in Za're' area west of Al Arish. 3 people were arrested in connection.
A Sudanese man and another sub-Saharan African migrant were killed by Egyptian border guards as they attempted to illegally cross into Israel. 4 others surrendered and were detained.

On 17 August 2011, clashes took place between Sawalha Bedouins and members of the police in southern Sinai, which resulted in the killing of 2 members of the Sawalha clan. In response, members of the Sawalha clan blocked the Abu-Raids-Tur Sinai highway for several hours.

Five Egyptian policemen were killed when an Israeli plane fired a rocket at militants it was tracking, hitting point 79 in the Naqab desert . A sixth policeman died on 10/09/2011 from injuries sustained during the airstrikes.
Clashes took place between Egyptian forces and unidentified gunmen near the border with Israel. Clashes resulted in the killing of 1 soldier and 2 injured.

On 19 August 2011, demonstrators gathered in front of the Israeli consulate in Roushdy in Alexandria to denounce the Israeli airstrikes that killed 5 Egyptian military police officers. Some of the demonstrators attempted to storm the embassy before the police intervened and cordoned off the area. [size= no report]

Protesters gathered outside the Israeli embassy in Giza to denounce the deaths of 5 Egyptian police in an airstrike by the Israeli air force. 6 Islamist political groups joined the protests. The army deployed reinforcements and tanks to the area in anticipation of the possible storming of the embassy by protestors. [size= hundreds]
On 19 August 2011, clashes took place between Egyptian forces and unidentified gunmen in Raysiya area in Al Arish, following an attack on a checkpoint in the area.

Despite an apology from the Israeli government protesters gather outside the Israeli embassy after five Egyptian soldiers were killed by IDF forces. Egyptian military forces brought reinforcements to the area to prevent the storming of the embassy by protestors. [size= tens]
A coordinator for the El Baradei campaign is abducted by unknown people and held for 24 hours.

On 20 August 2011, Egyptian police seized a vehicle carrying large quantities of weapons, including 25 anti-aircraft missiles, at a checkpoint on Al-Alamayn Highway near Wadi Natrun in Behera. The gunmen driving the vehicle exchanged fire with the police before fleeing the area.

column7: January 25 Revolution Youth Coalition; Muslim Brotherhood
column17: Thousands of demonstrators, including Revolution Youth Coalition and Muslim Brotherhood members, protested outside the Israeli embassy at Giza against the recent Israeli airstrike which killed 5 Egyptian police in the Sinai. Protestors demanded the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador. One protester lowered the Israeli flag and replaced it with an Egyptian one. [size= 3000]

Protests over the Israeli air forces killing of 5 Egyptian police in an airstrike were held in front of the cabinet building in downtown Cairo. Protestors were joined by tens of Cairo University students. Protestors demanded the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador. [size= hundreds]

On 23 August 2011, protestors continued protesting in front of the Israeli embassy in Giza demanding the expulsion of the Israeli ambassador in response to the killing of 5 Egyptian military police officers by Israeli airstrikes. [size= no report]
A woman was injured by a rocket fired from the Gaza Strip which hit Rafah.
200 people gather outside the Israeli embassy to call for the ambassadors expulsion. This is in response to the death of five soldiers along the border with Israel.
A hotel employee attacks and severely injures a Russian tourist.
Muslim residents of Merinab in Aswan blocked roads into the village to protest against work being done to renovate a church sometime after it began on Aug.26 (reported on Sept.16).
Hundreds of soldiers move into Tahrir Square to disperse protesters who have been camping for several weeks. The crowd was there protesting the speed of government reforms.

On 03 September 2011, police forces continued raids in Al Arish and other areas in northern Sinai in search of armed groups. An unknown number of gunmen were arrested during the raids. Several civilians complained of being attacked and assaulted by the police during the raids.
Protesters gathered outside the Saudi Arabian embassy to denounce the ""maltreatment of Egyptians in the Kingdom"" and to demand the release of Egyptian detainees.

Police repulsed supporters of the former president Mubarak who attempted to storm the courthouse at Cairo's police academy where he was on trial. Some of the demonstrators were detained. The pro-Mubarak supporters also clashed with anti-Mubarak supporters inside and outside the courthouse. 11 people were injured in the clashes. 22 people were arrested, including a 1 member of April 6 Youth Movement. [size=no report]
A number of Sudanese refugees staged a sit-in in front of the UNHCR office in Cairo to demand resettlement in a 3rd country.
While in court a fistfight breaks out between supporters and detractors of the Mubarak regime.
Mubarak protesters attack police forces outside the court house building during the trial of Mubarak.
A large number of people protest for government reform. Injuries after fights begin with the police and military.

Demonstrators broke down a wall and entered the Israeli embassy, angered the death of five Egyptian soldiers along the border they share with Israel. About 30 demonstrators stormed the embassy and dumped documents out the windows. Members of the Ultras clashed with the police using stones. 3 demonstrators were killed in clashes with police (spread between two events). Estimates of injuries over the weekend related to the embassy riots were as high as 1,049. [size=thousand]
A large number of people protest for government reform. Injuries after fights begin with the police and military.
A large number of people protest for government reform. Injuries after fights begin with the police and military.
A large number of people protest for government reform. Injuries after fights begin with the police and military.
On 09 September 2011, thousands of protesters gathered in front of the High Court in Cairo to denounce corruption and reject military tribunals for the prosecution of civilians. [size= thousands].

Demonstrations continued outside the Israeli embassy in Cairo. Demonstrators clashed with the police and threw Molotov cocktails and stones at them to which the police responded with the firing of live ammunition and tear gas. Protestors set fire to a number of vehicles that were parked in the area. The military brought reinforcements to the area. 1049 protesters were injured and 3 were killed (fatalities spread between two days of demonstrations), one of whom suffered a heart attack and died later in the hospital. [size= thousands]

On 10 September 2011, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in front of the Al Jizah police headquarters. Demonstrators attempted to storm the building and threw stones at the police to which the police responded with tear gas and warning shots in the air. Tens of demonstrators were injured. [size= hundreds]
Arrests: 200 people suspected of involvement in the Israeli embassy riots over the weekend were arrested by military police over the weekend, with at least 92 of those arrested today.
Around 100 Islamists protested outside the US Embassy in Cairo against the detention of Egyptian-born Sheikh Omar Abdel-Rahman who is serving a sentence for terrorism-related offense from 1993.
Security Measures: Egyptian security forces allegedly stormed the offices of Al Jazeera in Cairo.

On 12 September 2011, clashes took place between Egyptian military forces and unidentified gunmen following an attack by the gunmen on a military checkpoint in Abu Tawilah area in Rafah. Clashes resulted in the injury of 2 civilians.
Protesters gather in Tahrir Square to denounce the expansion of the emergency law at the hands of the military rulers.
Hundreds of Egyptians marched from Tahrir Square to the nearby government HQ, demanding the abolishment of the countries emergency law.

On 20 September 2011, clashes took place between Egyptian military forces and unidentified gunmen at one of its checkpoint in the western desert at the border with Libya. The gunmen were in the process of smuggling weapons, including light machine guns and ammunitions, into Egypt.
On 21 September 2011, hundreds of protesters gathered in Al Jizah to denounce the emergency laws and the use of military tribunals to prosecute civilians. [size= hundreds]
On 21 September 2011, members of the El-Fawkhriya Clan barricaded three roads in Al Arish following the arrest of the 3 members of the clan by police in the town. [size=no report]
A group of masked gunmen opened fire on the Deputy Agriculture Ministers car, injuring the minister in at least 4 places. He was taken to hospital by his driver.
5,000 teachers gathered outside the cabinet headquarters in Cairo to demand better pay, vowing to pursue a strike that has crippled several schools around the country.
On 24 September 2011, unidentified gunmen opened fire on a police vehicle at the checkpoint at KM 42 along Qina -Safagha highway.

A civilian was injured when unidentified gunmen opened fire and set off an explosion targeting a pipeline. The authorities suspect Islamist extremism. Two people suffered burns. The attack, the sixth on the pipeline, targeted a pumping station about 25 kms west of the city of el-Arish
On 28 September 2011, tens of protesters gathered in Shubra and headed towards Tahrir Square to demand the hand over of power to a civilian government. [size= tens]
Dozens of doctors demonstrated in front of the Egyptian Supreme Court, demanding an immediate investigation into the alleged mistreatment by a prosecutor of a doctor in Hurghada last week.
Gunmen shot dead a civilian church guard and wounded another south of the Egyptian capital before fleeing.

Egyptian security forces again stormed Al Jazeeras offices, confining its journalists to one room and confiscating equipment. The security personnel allegedly also roughed up their staff and took their identity papers.

On 30 September 2011, hundreds of protesters gathered in front of the Ministry of Defence in Kubri al Qubbah in Cairo to denounce the SCAFs new electoral law and to demand the end of the state of emergency. The police deployed reinforcements in the area and cordoned off the building to prevent protesters from storming the building. [size= hundreds]

20000 protesters gathered in the Cornish area in Alexandria alongside large protests in Tahrir Square against the SCAFs new electoral law and to demand the end of the state of emergency. The protesters headed towards the military area in the northern part of the town. [size=20000]
On September 30, a mob burnt down the Mar Girgis church in Marinab village in the city of Edfu, in Aswan.
Tahrir Square marched to the Israeli embassy and demolished a wall around the embassy in the Giza area of Cairo.

On 30 September 2011, hundreds of civilians gathered in front of Al-Istiqama mosque in Al Jizah to denounce the SCAFs new electoral law and to demand the end of the state of emergency. [size= hundreds]
Protesters blocked Al-Arish road and marched along it to ""reclaim the revolution"". They set tires on fire and put up barricades to stop cars.
Protests were staged in Suez alongside large protests in Tahrir Square against the SCAFs new electoral law and to demand the end of the state of emergency.

Thousands of protesters, mainly members of April 6 Youth Movement and Al-Wasat Party, begin returning to Tahir Square to ""reclaim the revolution"" amid anger over the military rulers handling of the transition. [size=thousands]

Protesters continue their Tahrir Square protest, showing dissatisfaction with the military transition to civilian rule. Egyptian riot police later cleared Cairo Square of the demonstrators that had stayed on after Fridays demos.
On 1 Oct 2011, a vigil was held by teachers in front of the administrative building of the university in Asyut, Assiut, to demand the resignation of the president of the university. [size=no report]

On 1 Oct 2011, nearly 3000 employees of the Public Transport Authority demonstrating in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, cut off Al Qasr al Ayni Street, demanding an increase in their wages. [size=nearly 3000]
Coptic Christians staged protests in various governorates around Egypt over an attack on the rebuilding of a church in Aswan.
Property destructon: An unknown group set a Coptic Christian Edfu church alight. The Copts blame Muslim groups.
On 1 Oct 2011, dozens of members of Engineers Syndicate staged a protest in front of Abdeen court in Abdeen, Cairo, against guarding of the Syndicate. [size=dozens]

Egyptian riot police on Saturday cleared Cairos Tahrir Square of protesters who had wanted to stage a sit-in following a demonstration demanding an end to emergency laws and a speedy transfer of power to civilians from military rulers. Following the clearing about 100 protesters immediately return.

Egyptian riot police on Saturday cleared Cairos Tahrir Square of protesters who had wanted to stage a sit-in following a demonstration demanding an end to emergency laws and a speedy transfer of power to civilians from military rulers. Following the clearing about 100 protesters immediately return.

On Oct 2, 2011, hundreds of Al-Azhar teachers blocked Salah Salem Road, besieged the headquarters of Al-Azhar sheikhs in El-Gamaleya, Cairo, attempting to enter it, while the central security forces confronted them. Teachers were demanding Al-Azhar Sheikh to immediately fixate all Al-Azhar contractors. [size=hundreds]
6,000 university professors, faculty and students protested at Ain Shams University to demand the resignation of the president.

On 2 Oct 2011, more than 2000 members of the peasant union applying for visas to work in the upcoming Hajj season, protested in front of the Ministry of Manpower and Immigration in Nasr City, Cairo, accusing the ministers of agriculture and manpower of manipulating and selling visas. [size=more than 2000]

On 3 Oct 2011, dozens of political activists staged a vigil in front of the military prosecutor in Nasr City, Cairo, calling for a halt in military trials and referrals of detainees to civilian courts. [size=dozens]

On 3 Oct 2011, dozens of residents of Dweika protested and started a sit-in in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, demanding the Prime Minister recognize their rights to the apartments allocated to them. Another group of Public Transport Authority workers held a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, again, against ignoring their demands by officials of the Authority. Also, dozens of members of the Association affected by the rent law held a vigil in front of the Council as well in Cairo, to demand the release of the landlord-tenant relationship in the old real estate and the cancellation of the inheritance of contracts. [size=a couple of dozens]

On 3 Oct 2011, 1000 copts belonging to the Coptic movements and unions held a protest in front of the General Bureau of Aswan Governorate, to demand the rebuilding of the removed parts of the Merenab Church in Edfu. [size=1000]

On Oct 3, 2011, dozens of technical students staged a demonstration in front of the Ministry of Higher Education headquarters in Cairo, to demand a reduction in the minimum of university admissions and open the door for transfers from one college to another. Demonstrators tried to enter the building, but the building's security stopped them, and they throw stones as well. [size=dozens]

On 3 Oct 2011, dozens of students from the Faculty of Archeology at Cairo University in Giza, and a number of professors and faculty members, gathered in front of the entrances of the faculty, blocking the doors leading to the office of College Dean, demanding his dismissal. [size=dozens]

Hundreds of Egyptian Copts staged a sit-in outside the Maspero (state TV) building o demand Aswans governor step down and a church in Marinap village be rebuilt. Later in the day Egyptian police used force to end the sit-in.

On 4 Oct 2011, dozens of Sharia and Law graduates, April 6 Youth Movement and Tahrir Movement organized a protest in front of the High Court House in Cairo, demanding the independence and purification of the judiciary system. [size=dozens]

On 4 Oct 2011, dozens of temporary workers at the Ministry of Irrigation and Water Resources, demanding jobs, blocked Al Qasr al Ayni Street, preventing vehicles from passing in protest against officials ignoring their demands. [size=dozens]

On 4 Oct 2011, dozens of students of technical diplomas organized a march from Cairo University in Giza, to the Ministry of Higher Education, to demand a reduction in the minimum of university admissions and open the door for transfers from one college to another. [size=dozens]

On 4 Oct 2011, dozens of teachers at the National Research Center protested in front of the headquarters of the Center in Dokki, Giza, to demand the payment of quality incentives as well as the election of all leaders of the center. [size=dozens]

On 4 Oct 2011, a protest was organized in front of the state council in Dokki, Giza, by workers in Madinati Project against the appeal filed by an engineer over the invalidity of the new city contract. [size=no report]

On 4 Oct 2011, a number of workers in Safaga port in Safaga city (coded as Hurghada with Geo precision 2) closed the port completely after they went on a strike and entered a sit-in in front of the port, preventing entry or exit of any passengers or cars from the port. [size=several]

On 4 Oct 2011, dozens of students from the Faculty of Archeology at Cairo University in Giza, and a number of professors and faculty members, gathered in front of the entrances of the faculty, blocking the doors leading to the office of College Dean, demanding his dismissal. [size=dozens]

On Oct 4, 2011, dozens of demonstrators protested in front of the military prosecutor in Nasr City, Cairo, in solidarity with blogger Michael Nabil and those arrested in front of the Ministry of Defense the preceding Friday. The demonstrators chanted slogans condemning the military council for are prosecuting civilians in military courts. A woman was arrested as well while filming the protest. [size=dozens]

On 4 Oct 2011, hundreds of workers of the Holding Company for Spinning and Weaving in Shebin El-Koum organized a march from the company's headquarters in Abdeen, Cairo, to the Council of Ministers, demanding the Prime Minister implement the ruling issued by the Administrative Court a few days prior, to cancel selling the company. [size=hundreds]
Coptic Christians riot, protesting against the Aswan Governor after their church is burned by a Muslim group, they believe. They continue the protest in the evening with a sit-in.
Coptic Christians gather in the Shubra to protest and show their solitary with Copts in Aswan. They gather in front of a TV building.

On 5 Oct 2011, a number of employees of the Egyptian Company for Valves (IFACO) organized a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to ask the prime minister to activate the letter of the General Petroleum Authority concerning the incorporation of (IFACO) into Petrojet as a branch. [size=several]

On 5 Oct 2011, more than 150 lawyers organized a vigil in front of the High Court in Cairo, to protest against the Judicial Authority Law, which was established by the Supreme Judicial Council Committee, and its privileges to judges and disadvantages to lawyers with imprisonment and a fine if any of them violated the system of trial hearings. [size=more than 150]
Tens of protesters demonstrated in front of the Journalists Sydnicate against the SCAF ""violation of fredom of speech"".

On 5 Oct 2011, dozens of students from the Faculty of Archeology at Cairo University in Giza, and a number of professors and faculty members, continued to gather in front of the entrances of the faculty for the third day in a row, blocking the doors leading to the office of College Dean, demanding his dismissal. [size=dozens]

On 5 Oct 2911, residents of As Sibaiyyah village blocked the railway between Luxor and Aswan governorates, demonstrating against what they called ""the failure of the Coast Guard police"" to retrieve the bodies of their relatives in an accidental sinking in the Nile River. [size=no report]

On Oct 5, 2011, students and graduates of the Tanta Nursing Institute held a demonstration and tried to enter the Ministry of Health in Cairo, for the fourth time, against the failure to respond to their demands to issue a decision to enroll them in the nursing institutes of universities. [size=no report]
The military claims it has gained control of a restless area of Sinai that has been a problem since the uprising against Mubarak.

On 6 Oct 2011, a number of protesters staged a peaceful march from Al Qasr al Ayni Street, Cairo, against the military rule and poverty and to denounce the activation of the emergency law. [size=several]
Dozens of take-offs from Cairo airport were delayed as air traffic controllers resumed a go-slow protest to demand higher wages.
Hundreds gathered in Tahrir Square to urge the SCAF to swiftly hand power to civilian rule.

On 8 Oct 2011, thousands of Muslim Brotherhood teachers and their allies rallied inside and in front of the General Union of Teachers in Az Zamalik, Cairo, protesting against the failure to hand over the union committees to the first-level winners in elections so far. [size=thousands]
About 200 students at Alexandria University engaged in a sit-in were attacked by people in plain clothes, who threw bottles, sticks and rocks, who were also backed by university security.
Dozens of public school teachers demonstrated in front of the Cabinet building over its failure to set a timetable for meeting their demands following mass strikes at schools across Egypt.

At least 36 people were killed and 272 injured in clashes between Coptic Christians and Egyptian security forces on Sunday near the state television building, known as Maspero. One soldier is killed and 20 injured. Dozens arrested.

On Oct 9, 2011, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Abdul Munim Riad Square, while stone-throwing continued between demonstrators and security forces, who fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=hundreds]

column16: HRW; Globe and Mail; Daily News (Egypt); Nile News TV; CPJ
column17: At least 25 were killed, including three soldiers and a journalist, and as many as 330 injured when a Coptic Christian march to the Maspero (state TV) building was opposed by the security forces. There were also claims that there were clashes between Muslims and Christians, while other Muslims were also present to protest with the Christians and were calling for unity. The army claimed some of the protesters were carrying firearms at the time, as some of the soldiers killed and wounded were shot, while others threw stones and petrol bombs. Many of those killed were allegedly run over by military APCs.

column7: Muslim Group (Egypt); Labour Group (Egypt); Government of Egypt (2011-2012)
column17: On 9 Oct 2011, hundreds of imams of the Ministry of endowment and its workers protested in front of the ministry's building in Bab al Luq, Cairo, demanding fast issuance of a decree to publicize the preachers union, and purge the ministry from elements of corruption, and the selection of missions abroad on the basis of efficiency. [size=hundreds]
An unknown group throws sones at protesting Copts, killing four of them.

On 9 Oct 2011, a third group of owners of fish cages in Damietta, protested for the second time in front of the Council of Ministers, in protest against the decision of the former governor of Damietta, to withdraw the licenses of fish cages, and remove them from the Nile water. [size=no report]

On 9 Oct 2011, a number of temporary workers at the Ministry of Agriculture held a protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand their fixation in their jobs, raise their wages, and equality with state employees. [size=several]

On 9 Oct 2011, temporary contracts staff at the Ministry of Education in Cairo, resumed their protests inside the ministry's general office, where dozens of them gathered and objected to what they described as delayed recruitment procedures despite the approval of the Central Organization and Administration for their appointment. [size=dozens]

On Oct 9, 2011, armed masked men continued to block the Al Arish-Al-Awja road in central Sinai near Al-Raysan village (coded as Geo precision 2), and threatened all those who tried to pass through it, demonstrating against ignoring their demands to cancel the absentee verdicts imposed on a large number of Sinai people, which are fabricated according to them. [size=no report]

On October 9, during the dispersal by military police and riot police of a protest of Coptic Christians in front of the state TV building in Cairo, at least two military vehicles ran over and killed 13 protesters and a further 24 were killed by live ammunition.

Muslims and Christians clashed outside a hospital where protesters injured during violence in downtown Cairo were taken. A number of protesters had marched to the hospital which set off the clashes, and several cars were set on fire during the incident.

On Oct 10, 2011, a group of demonstrators threw stones at the Journalists Syndicate in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, and assaulted the union's security, after a number of Copts were reportedly hiding inside, causing injuries, and setting fire to all signs in front of the union. [size=no report]
On 10 Oct 2011, hundreds of Copts demonstrated inside the Cathedral of St. Mark in Al Abbasiyah, Cairo, demanding that Pope Shenouda III defend the Copts' right. [size=hundreds]

On Oct 10, armed masked men continued to block the Al Arish-Al-Awja road in central Sinai near Al-Raysan village (coded as Geo precision 2), and threatened all those who tried to pass through it, demonstrating against ignoring their demands to cancel the absentee verdicts imposed on a large number of Sinai people, which are fabricated according to them. [size=no report]

On Oct 10, a group of families of the martyrs of Maspero events, protested in front of the Coptic hospital in Al Azbakeyah, Cairo, in conjunction with the exodus of bodies from the hospital morgue towards the cathedral. [size=no report]
Several hundreds Copts protested and threw rocks at police outside a Cairo hospital where those injured in protests the day before were being cared for.

On Oct 10, 2011, Ramses street witnessed fierce confrontations between Copts and Muslims, which resulted in a number of injuries, while unknown persons set fire to one of the buildings a few meters from Maydan Ramsis, Cairo, and set fire to more than seven cars. The police broke up the confrontations and fired tear gas to disperse the rioters. [size=no report]
A doctor was kidnapped by an unidentified group who questioned him about last weeks Maspero clashes. The doctor was released after 6 days.

column7: January 25 Revolution Youth Coalition; Coptic Christian Group (Egypt)
column17: On 11 Oct 2011, Youth Coalition of the Revolution in Al Baher Al Ahmar in Al Omraneyah, Giza, and a number of Copts staged a protest to condemn the events of Maspero (state TV), and clashes between the army and demonstrators. [size=no report]

column9: Coptic Christian Group (Egypt); Muslim Group (Egypt); January 25 Revolution Youth Coalition
column17: On Oct 11, 2011, Muslims and Copts attending the funeral of the victims of the Maspero events, led by the Revolution Youth Coalition, were attacked by unidentified group throwing stones and empty bottles, as they returned from the Cathedral headquarters to Tahrir Square, forcing them to climb up a bridge to escape. The march returned to Tahrir Square. [size=thousands]
On 11 Oct 2011, thousands of Copts and many Muslims mourned the bodies of Maspero's victims in front of the Cathedral of St. Mark in Al Abbasiyah, Cairo, amid angry slogans. [size=thousands]

On Oct 11, armed masked men continued to block the Al Arish-Al-Awja road in central Sinai near Al-Raysan village (coded as Geo precision 2), and threatened all those who tried to pass through it, demonstrating against ignoring their demands to cancel the absentee verdicts imposed on a large number of Sinai people, which are fabricated according to them. [size=no report]

On 12 Oct 2011, dozens of April 6 activists staged a silent vigil with candles in front of the Supreme Court in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, to mourn the victims of the Maspero clashes, which killed and injured more than 300 people. [size=dozens]

Around 12 Oct 2011, hundreds of workers and employees of the National Research Center in Dokki, Giza, started a sit-in inside the headquarters of the Center in protest against the ignorance of the head of the Center for their demands and threatened to strike and move the sit-in to the Council of Ministers or the Ministry of Scientific Research if their demands were not met. [size=hundreds]

column7: April 6 Youth Movement; Students (Egypt); Socialist Revolutionaries
column17: On Oct 13, 2011, students of the April 6 Movement, the Liberation Movement, and Socialist Revolutionaries staged a 40-minute silent mourning in front of Cairo University dome in Giza, in black clothes, for the lives of Maspero victims. [size=no report]

On Oct 13, 2011, a march of dozens of media professionals, youth parties and the Maspero Youth Union took place in front of Akhbar El Youm Foundation building in Bulaq, Cairo, on its way to Maspero Radio and Television building to demand the media be purged of corrupt leaders. [size=dozens]

On Oct 14, 2011, a number of worshipers at Al-Azhar Mosque in Cairo, attacked dozens of activists and youths, who were organizing a march in front of the mosque after Friday prayers after chanting against the army and the military council, with stones. [size=several]
On Oct 15, 2011, a number of the martyrs' families protested in Al Basatin, Cairo, and other areas as well, in conjunction with the trial of officers accused of killing protesters. [size=several]

On Oct 15, 2011, the march of the First World Revolution reached its last destenation in Tahrir Square, Cairo, roaming the square several times to denounce the slow prosecution of the symbols of the former regime and to demand the independence of the judiciary. [size=no report]

On Oct 15, 2011, Akhbar Al-Youm students in Bulaq, Cairo, continued their demonstration for the second consecutive week to demand the departure of the dean of the academy. They also clashed with the security forces, while holding the dean in his office demanding his resignation. [size=no report]

On Oct 15, 2011, dozens of workers at Nasser Social Bank gathered in front of the Ministry of Solidarity and Social Justice in Al Omraneyah, to demand the payment of incentives and justice for all employees. [size=dozens]
Dozens of Egyptian journalists staged a symbolic protest outside their syndicate in downtown Cairo against a court ruling suspending polls for their unions board members and chairman.

On Oct 15, 2011, a number of the martyrs' families protested in Al-Qubba Gardens, Cairo (coded as Ash Sharabiyah with Geo precision 2), in conjunction with the trial of officers accused of killing protesters. [size=several]

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: In October immigration officials forcibly deported three Eritreans. Prison officials in Shallal gave Eritrean embassy officials access to 118 detained Eritrean men who were asylum seekers and beat them to force them to sign paperwork agreeing to return to Eritrea.
On Oct 15, 2011, a number of the martyrs' families protested in Al-Amireya, Cairo, and other areas as well, in conjunction with the trial of officers accused of killing protesters. [size=several]

On Oct 15, 2011, a number of the martyrs' families protested in Al-Darb Al-Ahmar, Cairo, and other areas as well, in conjunction with the trial of officers accused of killing protesters. [size=several]
On Oct 16, 2011, dozens of students of the April 6 Movement organized a silent mourning with black clothes in front of Cairo University in Giza, for the lives of Maspero victims. [size=dozens]

On Oct 16, 2011, dozens of doctors staged a protest in front of the Attorney General's Office in New Cairo City, Cairo, to denounce the disappearance of the coordinator of the strike of doctors at the Nile Hospital in Shubra, who disappeared under mysterious circumstances a week ago. [size=dozens]
On Oct 16, 2011, copts rallied in front of the Coptic cathedral in Al Abbasiyah, against Hussein Tantawi to condemn the attacks on Copts last Sunday, which killed 27 Copts. [size=no report]

2 Egyptian police officers were injured in an attack by Shubra neighborhood residents on a police station. They were allegedly trying to take control of land owned by the police station. The assailants used firearms and petrol bombs during their attack on the police station.
Students of the MSA started a sit-in protest and strike to demand better quality of education, facilities and activities.
Employees of Telecom Egypt protested outside the companies HQ on Ramses Street. They are currently engaged in an ongoing protest.

On Oct 18, 2011, dozens of ""No Military Trials for Civilians"" movement and a number of families of detainees arrested in the Israeli embassy events, staged a protest in front of the Journalists Syndicate in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, to denounce the military trials of civilians and demanded the military council to immediately release a number of detainees. [size=dozens]

On Oct 18, 2011, more than 250 lawyers staged a protest in front of their union headquarters in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, protesting against the draft of the judiciary authority of postponing the elections of the lawyers union indefinitely, announcing that they will strike until their demands are met. [size=more than 250]
On Oct 18, 2011, Telecom Egypt employees organized a protest in front of Dokki Central in Dokki, Giza, in which they revealed the abuses of the company's board members. [size=no report]

On Oct 18, 2011, a number of political activists, lawyers, members of human rights centers and relatives of those accused in the attacks on the Israeli and Saudi embassies, protested in front of the headquarters of the Supreme National Security Prosecution in Fifth Settlement in New Cairo City, Cairo, which is investigating the case. [size=number]

On Oct 18, 2011, dozens of residents of Dweaiqa, blocked Magles Al Shab Street in Cairo, sitting on the ground to prevent the passage of cars, to demand the ownership papers of the housing units. [size=dozens]

On Oct 18, 2011, a number of political, youth and Coptic movements staged a protest in black clothes in Dawaran Shubra to pay tribute to the victims of the Maspero events that took place last Sunday. [size=several]

On Oct 19, 2011, a number of residents of 6th of October City and dozens of residents of Dweika organized a protest on the pavement of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, sitting on the ground to demand the ownership papers of the residential units. [size=dozens]

On Oct 19, 2011, dozens of lawyers staged a protest at 6th of October Elementary Court in Giza Square, Giza, against the draft law on the judiciary authority, which was submitted by the Supreme Judicial Council to the Military Council during the past days, which authorizes the judge to imprison lawyers in court session crimes. [size=dozens]

On Oct 19, 2011, lawyers at the Talkha District Court in Talkha, Dakahlia refused to attend the sessions and proved in the minutes of the hearing before Chancellor President of the Court their objection to the new law, they gathered in front of the deliberation room to prevent the judge from moving into the Hall for the hearing. [size=no report]

On Oct 19, 2011, more than 50 students at Akhbar Al Youm Academy in 6th October City, Giza, organized a vigil in front of the headquarters of the old building in Akhbar Al Youm Foundation, as an objection to the dismissal of 10 students by the Academy Administration after protesting to demand the departure of the dean of the Academy. [size=more than 50]

On Oct 19, 2011, dozens of lawyers staged a protest in front of the Criminal Court of Fifth Settlement in New Cairo City, Cairo, objecting to the draft of the judiciary authority of postponing the elections of the lawyers union indefinitely. [size=dozens]

On Oct 20, 2011, hundreds of lawyers staged a protest at 6th of October Elementary Court in Giza Square, Giza, against the draft law on the judiciary authority, which was submitted by the Supreme Judicial Council to the Military Council during the past days, which authorizes judges to imprison lawyers in court session crimes. [size=hundreds]

On Oct 20, 2011, dozens of political activists and a number of political movements and coalitions staged a vigil in front of the High Court in Cairo, to condemn the events of Maspero, in which dozens of people were killed and injured. [size=dozens]
Protesting MSA students engaged in a sit-in since Monday were locked in campus and not allowed to leave by university security on Thursday night.

On Oct 21, 2011, a march took place from Omar Makram Mosque in Qasr Ad Dobarah, Cairo, towards Tahrir Square, after Friday prayers, in protest against the crimes committed by Bashar Al-Assad in Syria, demanding his departure. [size=no report]
A prominent Egyptian political talk show host has suspended his program indefinitely to protest what he said are attempts by the government to stifle free expression.

On Oct 22, 2011, dozens of workers at Nasser Social Bank staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Solidarity on Al Qasr al Ayni Street, demanding not to renew expired contracts for workers who reached the age of pension. [size=dozens]

On Oct 22, 2011, dozens of employees of Telecom Egypt staged a protest in front of the Supreme Court in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, to denounce what they called corruption within the board of directors of the company and to demand restructuring of wages. [size=dozens]
Workers blocked Qasr al-Aini street in the Garden City area over the assault of a colleague of theirs by an army officer who allegedly beat him with a stick.

On Oct 22, 2011, thousands of Sheikh Abu Ishaq Al-Hwaini supporters rallied in front of the court of Kafr Al Sheikh in Gharbia governorate (coded as Al Mahallah al Kubra with Geo precision 2) during the hearing of the first indictment of Al Hwaini because of the defamation of the Grand Mufti of the Republic. [size=thousands]

On Oct 22, 2011, dozens of lawyers protesting before Halwan Court in Halwan, Cairo, prevented prosecutors and counsellors from entering their offices after they closed the doors of the court as part of their strike that began several days ago, to demand the implementation of the amendment of the Judicial Authority Law. [size=dozens]

On Oct 22, hundreds of lawyers demonstrated in front of the North Cairo Elementary Court in Al Abbasiyah, Cairo, holding up the flag of Egypt, announcing the continuation of their demonstrations against the draft law of the judiciary authority, and demanding a date for the elections of the Lawyers union. They also broke into the court to protest against the continuation of work going on in courts despite their demonstrations. [size=hundreds]

At least 10 people were injured, some by gunshots, in clashes between protesting residents and armed security guarding a building owned by a businessman. The protesters were angry over the construction of a wall in the area.

On Oct 23, 2011, dozens of lawyers protesting before Maadi Court in Al Maadi, Cairo, prevented prosecutors and counsellors from entering their offices after they closed the doors of the court as part of their strike that began several days ago, to demand the implementation of the amendment of the Judicial Authority Law. [size=dozens]

On Oct 23, 2011, dozens of broadcasters, directors and programmers working in the Media sector, protested in front of the manager's office in Al Qasr al Ayni, Cairo, calling for justice and equality with their counterparts working in TV. [size=dozens]

On Oct 23, 2011, dozens of employees, and workers affiliated with the Ministry of Industry and Trade, organized an open sit-in at the department of the authority in Misr al Qadimah, Cairo, in protest against their poor financial and work conditions. [size=dozens]

On Oct 23, 2011, dozens of employees, and workers affiliated with the Ministry of Industry and Trade, organized an open sit-in at the department of the authority in Dokki, Giza, in protest against their poor financial and work conditions. [size=dozens]

On Oct 23, 2011, confrontations and fights took place between the citizens in the village of Bisat, Talkha Center, Dakahlia, to control the Tawhid Mosque, and between the son of the mosque's land donor and some Salafists and Ansar Al Sunna, who were accused by citizens of breaking the external door and windows of the mosque. [size=no report]
About 3,000 low ranking police rallied in front of the Interior Ministry to demand a 200% pay raise and an end to military trials for police.
On Oct 24, 2011, more than 100 police secretaries at the old airport in Al-Nozha, Cairo held a protest and strike to voice their demands. [size=more than 100]
Thousands of Egyptian lawyers staged demonstrations to protest proposed amendments to a new judiciary authority law. They marched to the High Court and Judges Club HQ.
Strikes: Thousands of Egyptian police launched a nation-wide strike to demand better salaries and a purge of former regime officials from senior security posts.

On Oct 25, 2011, a number of members of the Association affected by the old rent law protested again in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to demand the liberation of the relationship between the landlord and the tenant. [size=several]

On Oct 25, 2011, hundreds of workers and investors in Madinaty project staged a protest in front of the State Council in Dokki, Giza, coinciding with the lawsuit filed against the new Madinaty contract. [size=hundreds]

On Oct 25, 2011, the April 6 Youth Movement announced an open sit-in in front of the Attorney General's office in New Cairo City, Cairo, until the release of Sherif El-Rouby, a member of the movement's political bureau who disappeared on October 22. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: On Oct 25, 2011, families of the detained prisoners took advantage of the strike by police secretaries, and broke into the prison in 10th of Ramadan City in Sharkia governorate, setting fire in the first floor, and a number of rioters outside and the families of the detained prisoners threw a number of Molotov cocktails, and set fire to the building from the outside, killing 1 prisoner and wounding several others including police officers. Total fatalities coded to 1. [size=no report]
Thousands of Egyptian police officers gathered outside the Interior Ministry to call for the removal of the Interior Minister.

On Oct 25, 2011, a number of those excluded from being appointed in the Central Auditing Organization protested in front of the Authority's headquarters in Salah Salem Street in Nasr City, Cairo, demanding the vice president of the agency to solve their problem and sign their appointment decisions after passing in medical examination tests. [size=several]

On Oct 25, 2011, medical workers including doctors and staff in Al Agouza Police Hospital in Al Agouza, Giza, held a protest to demand their right to be treated in the hospital where they work. [size=no report]
Egyptian policemen stormed a security building, as 3,000+ went on strike nationwide to demand the ""cleansing"" of their institution and better pay. The protest lasts for two days.

On Oct 26, 2011, medical workers including doctors and staff in Al Agouza Police Hospital in Al Agouza, Giza, entered an open strike after protesting for two days to demand their right to be treated in the hospital where they work. [size=no report]

On Oct 26, 2011, dozens of lawyers protested in front of the North Cairo Elementary Court in Al Abbasiyah, Cairo, announcing the continuation of their protests against the draft law of the judiciary authority, and demanding a date for the elections of the Lawyers union. [size=dozens]

On Oct 26, 2011, a number of graduates of the Tanta Nursing Institute blocked Al-Falaki Street in Abdeen, Cairo, sitting on the ground, and prevented cars from crossing, objecting to the Ministry of Health ignoring the demonstrators' demands to join the nursing departments of the Ministry of Health. [size=several]
The Nadeem Centre for the Rehabilitation of Victims of Violence claims that a prisoner was tortured to death by police after he was caught smuggling a SIM card into his cell.

On Oct 27, 2011, Al-Azhar scholars organized a solidarity vigil at Al-Azhar Mosque in Al-Darb Al-Ahmar, Cairo, where thousands rallied to support the scholars of Egypt and Al-Azhar against the attack they faced from the Salafi sheikhs. [size=thousands]

On Oct 27, 2011, a number of employees of Al-Nasr Steam Boilers Company resumed their protest in front of the Council of Ministers in Cairo, to ask the director of the business sector to vote on the recommendations of the committee formed under his chairmanship to discuss the demands of workers. [size=several]

On Oct 27, 2011, the security forces of the army and police continued their operation on the ""Family House"" project in 6th of October City, Giza, to evacuate the armed group who seized the apartments, amid clashes between the two sides. Security forces fired shots in the air to force them to evacuate apartments, after they refused to leave. Police also arrested dozens of people involved.

Around Oct 27, 2011, hundreds of police secretaries and members started a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Interior in Cairo, to demand the dismissal of Interior Minister and his aides, and the abolition of military trials for police secretaries, and the application of the career hierarchy of police secretaries and members, as well as to include them in health care. [size=hundreds]

On Oct 27, 2011, dozens of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square, Cairo, to denounce the military council's failure to respond to the demands of the people, and to hold presidential elections in order to hand over power to an elected president and government in mid-2012. [size=dozens]

On Oct 27, residents of Kafr Al Hessa village of Banha Center blocked the agricultural highway and railway for 3 hours to prevent the autopsy of a man who died in an altercation between two families in the village and another family in a neighboring village. They also set fire to tires, and used concrete blocks to block the road for about three hours. [size=no report]

On Oct 27, 2011, dozens of members of the movements of ""6 April"" and ""support ElBaradei"" and a number of young independents staged a march, starting from Dawaran Shubra, Cairo, to the end of Shubra Street, to mobilize citizens to be in Tahrir Square the following day, to demand that the military council hand over power to an elected civilian government, and also the independence of the judiciary system. [size=dozens]

On Oct 28, 2011, hundreds of protesters including 6 April Youth staged a protest in front of the radio and television building in As Sabtiyyah, Cairo, to demand the cleansing of media from corrupt leaders, and the submission of information minister for trial on charges of sedition between Muslims and Copts, and a call for an end to torture in Egyptian prisons. [size=hundreds]

On Oct 28, 2011, a number of families and relatives of the prisoner Essam Ali Atta, who was killed after being transferred from his prison, staged a sit-in in front of Zeinhom morgue in Qasr Al-Nile, Cairo, while receiving the body of the victim, a number of political activists and youth of the April 6 Movement also took part in the demonstration. [size=several]

Protesters clashed with soldiers and police in Cairo after a funeral procession for a man a rights group claims died from police torture after he was caught smuggling a mobile phone chip into his cell. Dozens of protesters hurled stones at soldiers and police after relatives of Essam Atta brought his coffined body to Tahrir Square. No report of injuries or causalities.

On Oct 28, residents of Al-Manawat village, located in the center of Abu an Numrus city, Giza, blocked Egypt-Assiut highway, and closed the gas plant in Tamwah village, demonstrating against the non-fulfillment of their demands. [size=no report]

On Oct 28, dozens of citizens blocked the road in front of the entrance of Sheikh Zayed City in Giza, carrying a number of banners demanding retribution for the student who was killed after policemen shot him in the car in Sheikh Zayed City, they also set fire to the police car in front of Sheikh Zayed Hospital. [size=dozens]
Around Oct 28, 2011, a young student was killed after policemen shot him in the car in Sheikh Zayed City for driving through the police ambush.

Several thousand protesters in Cairo called on the ruling military on Friday to promptly transfer power to a civilian government and exclude old regime figures from politics. The group chanted ""down with the military"" and called on the ruling generals to ""return to the barracks."" The uprising was sparked in part by calls from activists on a Facebook page initially set up to protest that death of another young man, Khaled Said, after a beating by police.

On Oct 29, 2011, demonstrations escalated by Muslim Brotherhood teachers in front of the Syndicate of Educational Professions in Az Zamalik, Cairo, where they blocked the bridge of Qasr Al-Nile, which led to traffic disruption in the area. [size=no report]

On Oct 29, 2011, dozens of citizens, political activists and political movements protested inside the High Court building in Cairo, to denounce the military trials of civilians, demanding that they be stopped and that all those referred to the military trials be referred to civilian ones. [size=dozens]

On Oct 30, 2011, thousands of Muslim Brotherhood teachers decided to sit in in the headquarters of the Syndicate of Educational Professions in Az Zamalik, Cairo, to pressure the Syndicate Council to hand over union committees to the winners in the elections. [size=thousands]

On Oct 30, 2011, dozens of the occupants of the October housing units and Family Home project"" units protested after the police and army evacuated the units in the last two days in front of the Ministry of Housing in Al Qasr al Ayni Cairo to demand housing units. [size=dozens]""

On Oct 30, 2011, hundreds of students from Al Azhar University and some of the faculty demonstrated, blockading the university presidency building in Nasr City, Cairo, and preventing staff from entering and leaving. [size=hundreds]
Police arrest and detain a civil rights activist, sparking a protest.

On Oct 30, 2011, dozens of political activists and ""No Military Trials for Civilians"" group, and the April 6 Movement staged a sit-in in front of the military court in Nasr City, Cairo, in solidarity with the activists who were summoned for questioning by the military prosecutor on charges of inciting the recent Maspero events. [size=dozens]

On Oct 30, 2011, hundreds of employees of the Grand Egyptian Museum organized a vigil in front of the headquarters of the museum in Al Haram, Giza, to demand employment of all temporary employees of the museum and the elimination of corruption and purge the museum from the remnants of the former regime. [size=hundreds]
A group representing people with disabilities staged a protest in front of the Cabinet building, demanding equal rights.

On Oct 30, 2011, a limited Coptic march emerged from Dawran Shubra, Cairo, which went through Shubra streets, with the participation of nearly 150 protesters against the military council, which is deemed responsible for the recent Maspero events leading to the death and injury of more than 300 people. [size=nearly 150]

On Oct 30, 2011, a number of air traffic controllers, organized a protest in front of the Civil Aviation Ministry's office in Al-Nozha, Cairo, to demand the cancellation of the decision to transfer them to the Air Academy. [size=several]

On Oct 30, 2011, dozens of workers from Misr Monofiya Spinning and Weaving Company held a protest in front of the headquarters of the Trade Union Federation in Al Azbakeyah, Cairo, to demand the head of the union's temporary committee to pay them urgent aid, especially with the approach of Eid Al-Adha. [size=dozens]

On Oct 31, 2011, dozens of citizens protested in front of the headquarters of the Ministry of Housing in Al Qasr al Ayni, Cairo, for the second consecutive day, demanding to fix their status in the housing units they are living in temporarily, in the project of housing youth in October. [size=dozens]

On Oct 31, 2011, car drivers, motorcyclists and pedestrians clashed with a number of demonstrators, including taxi drivers from Behera, and temporary workers at the Tameya Central Hospital in Fayoum, after the demonstrators intercepted the pedestrians' road in Al Qasr al Ayni Street, Cairo, and prevented them from passing. Demonstrators also assaulted motorists, smashed a windows of a car, injured a motorcycle driver with a severe nose bleed. [size=no report]

On Oct 31, 2011, Al-Azhar University students continued their sit-in for the eighth day in a row in Nasr City, Cairo, and detained the security personnel of the university building who managed to get out later. They were demanding the election of leaders, changing the student list, and amending law 103. [size=no report]
On Oct 31, 2011, dozens of South Sinai Bedouin tribesmen protested in Ras Sudr, South Sinai, demanding the release of Sinai detainees in Israeli prisons. [size=dozens]

column7: EFITU: Egyptian Federation of Independent Trade Unions; Labour Group (Egypt)
column17: On Oct 31, 2011, dozens of members of the Egyptian Federation of Independent Trade Unions and a number of candidates on the workers seat, organized a protest in front of 6th of October Elementary Court building in Giza Square, Giza, to denounce the refusal of the examination committee in the court to accept their candidacy papers on the seats of workers in the parliament. [size=dozens]

More than 3,000 Egyptians marched through downtown Cairo, protesting the militaries arrest of a prominent blogger-activist. The military says he is suspected of inciting Christian protesters to attack soldiers during an October 9th demo.

On 1 November 2011, lawyers protested outside the Egyptian Bar Association building in the Qasr Al-Nile neighborhood of Cairo against the President of the Association and called for a purge of the judiciary and for their involvement in monitoring the upcoming elections. [size=not reported]
Security measure: On 1 November 2011, Egyptian police destroyed four tunnels dug into the Gaza strip that came into the Salah al-Din and Brahmah areas of Rafah district in North Sinai governorate.

On 1 November 2011, a group of roughly 25 journalists protested in front of the Egyptian parliament in the Haidaq al-Qubba neighborhood of Cairo against a Deputy Prime Minister for Political Development and Democratic Transformation, calling the individual corrupt.[size=25]

On 1 November 2011, a group of April 6th Movement supporters marched to Talaat Harb Square where they briefly scuffled with residents of the area before police broke up the fight. The group was marching against the continued detention of Alaa Abdel Fatteh, the death of other activists, and against the continued use of the emergency law. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported. [size=unknown]

On 1 November 2011, a group of families of individuals killed on January 25th of that year carried out a protest vigil in front of the Welfare Building in the As-Sayyidah Zainab area of Cairo, calling for a speedy prosecution of those responsible for the killings. [size=not reported]

On 2 November 2011, dozens of members of a group calling itself Movement for All Unemployed demonstrated in front of the Prime Minister's office in the Haidaq Al-Qubba neighborhood of Cairo. The group's members threatened collective suicide if the government did not provide them with public sector jobs. [size=dozens]

On 3 November 2011, a march commemorating the slain activist Mina Daniel arrived at the Ramses Square in the Shubra junction in the Al Sahil neighborhood of Cairo district. The marchers, which consisted of a large group of Coptic Egyptians, demanded the release of detainees from military prisons, the resignation of the Information Minister, and prosecution for those responsible for the deaths at Maspero. [size=not reported]
On 3 November 2011, unidentified gunmen attacked and stole the car of a Freedom and Justice Party candidate as he was driving through Menoufia governorate.
On 3 November 2011, dozens of Ghad Political Party supporters held a vigil in the Talaat Harb Square in solidarity with their detained leader, Ayman Nour. [size=dozens]

On 3 November 2011, a group of Salafi Front supporters demonstrated in front of the Saudi Embassy in Duqqi area of Giza governorate, calling for the release of fellow members detained in Saudi Arabia. [size=not reported]

On 3 November 2011, unidentified gunmen attacked the car of the Bishop of Bani Swayf as it was traveling to the village of Bayad al-Arab in the Beni Suef governorate. The gunmen forced everyone out of the car and stole the vehicle and drove off.

On 4 November 2011, dozens of Freedom and Justice Party members marched in the Al Aguza district of Giza governorate as a way to show support for party members running in the upcoming elections. [size=dozens]

On 6 November 2011, dozens of Muslims who were praying during Eid al-Adha marched to Tahrir Square following their prayer and called for a halt to military courts, the release of political prisoners, and a swift transition to civilian rule in the country. [size=dozens]
On 6 November 2011, rioters set a fire on a railway near Sohag to denounce the nation-wide shortage of fuel.
On 7 November 2011, hundreds of Egyptians marched from downtown Cairo to Torah prison in solidarity with an activist currently being investigated by the military courts. [size=hundreds]

Security measure: On 8 November 2011, a joint police and military force imposed a curfew on the villages of Awlad Khalaf and Lower Awlad after clashes between residents of the two villages the night before.

On 9 November 2011, Syrian demonstrators blocked the entrance to the headquarters of the Arab League in Tahrir Square and prevented a number of representatives from Syrian revolutionary councils from entering. [size=not reported]
On 9 November 2011, dozens of supporters of the activist Alaa Abdel Fattah protested in front of Tura Prison, demanding his immediate release. [size=dozens]
On 10 November 2011, over 3,000 Freedom and Justice Party supporters marched through Nasr City as a sign of support for their candidates in the upcoming elections. [size=more than 3,000]
On 10 November 2011, an Egyptian pipeline sending gas to Israel and Jordan was hit by an explosion in North Sinai Governorate. The pipeline had already been attacked six times since February.

On 11 November 2011, thousands marched from the Coptic Orthodox Cathedral in Abbaseya to Tahrir Square on Friday, in memory of the 27 killed in the October 9th crackdown on the Maspero protest. [size=thousands]
On 11 November 2011, dozens of Al-Nour Party supporters marched in support of their candidates for the upcoming elections through the Al-Ahram district of Giza governorate. [size=dozens]
Hundreds of Salafists protested outside Frances embassy in Cairo against the publishing of a picture of the Muslim prophet in a French satirical magazine.
Environmental protesters gather to denounce a fertilizer plant. One person is killed and 11 wounded when police move in to disperse them. Two other civilians killed.

On 12 November 2011, a group of family members of those killed in the protests on January 25th held a vigil in front of the Council of Minister's office in the Haidaq Al-Qubba district of Cairo, calling for a speedy trial for those responsible. [size=not reported]

On 12 November 2011, a group of recently fired police secretaries stormed past the police security cordon at the Egyptian parliament in the Haidaq Al-Qubba neighborhood of Cairo and demanded that they be reinstated in their jobs. [size=not reported]
On 12 November 2011, unidentified gunmen assaulted a worker at a petrol station at the Cairo International Airport, seriously wounding him.

On 12 November 2011, residents of the town of Baltim in Burullus district in Kafr El-Shikh governorate blocked the international highway leading between Alexandria and the Suez Canal to condemn the violence that had occurred in the preceding days. [size=not reported]

Arrests: Egyptian security officials have arrested two leading members of an Islamist armed group, known as Al-Takfir wal Hijra, suspected of being behind attacks on a pipeline supplying gas to Israel and Jordan.
Environmental protesters gather to denounce a fertilizer plant. At least 2 people were killed and 11 wounded when police move in to disperse their sit-in on a road in Damietta.

On 13 November 2011, hundreds of youths protested against military trials for civilians in downtown Cairo. They marched and then rallied in Tahrir Square, calling for compensation from the Mubarak era and the end to corruption. [size=hundreds]
Employees of the Supreme Council of Antiquities (SCA) protested outside their offices in the Zamalek area of Cairo to demand the resignation of the newly-appointed secretary-general.

On 15 November 2011, dozens of Bedouin youth clashed with police in front of the Balaim Petroleum Company headquarters in the town of Abu Raidis over demands that the company fulfill promises to employ a certain number of Bedouin workers. 3 officers were seriously wounded in the clash. [size=dozens]

On 15 November 2011, more than 5,000 people demonstrated in the town of Al Arish against the recent security operations in the area which had been carried out after a number of attacks. [size=more than 5,000]

On 15 November 2011, more than 50 family members of those martyred or injured during ""the revolution"" began a sit-in in Tahrir Square and announced their boycott of the parliamentary elections. They set up tents and vowed to continue their protest until the demands of the revolution are implemented. They also set up roadblocks on the square and prevented cars from passing through. [size=hundreds]

On 15 November 2011, dozens of workers from the Misr Fertilizers Production Company (MOPCO) protested in front of the Egyptian parliament it in the Haidaq Al-Qubba neighborhood of Cairo against the closure of a fertilizer plant in Damietta. A protest in Diametta several days prior had turned deadly. [size=dozens]

On 16 November 2011, hundreds of ETUF workers began sit-in in front of the ETUF offices on Galaa Street in downtown Cairo to protest against the labour minister who they say is attempting to destroy the country's burgeoning labour movement. [size=hundreds]

On 16 November 2011, a group of 300 Freedom and Justice Party supporters marched through the Ghamarah area of the Al Zahir neighborhood of Cairo in support of their party's candidates in the electoral district.[size=300]

On 17 November 2011, twenty-nine people were injured in a Cairo suburb when residents clashed with a group of Christians marching through the capital to commemorate those who died in confrontations with the army on October 9th.

On 17 November 2011, a group of 300 Freedom and Justice Party supporters marched through the Shubra area of the Al Sahil neighborhood of Cairo in support of their party's candidates in the electoral district. [size=300]

On 18 November 2011, more than 2,000 Islamist and secular protesters, including April 6th Youth Movement and Al-Nour Party protesters, gathered in Cairos Tahrir Square on Friday for a mass rally to press the ruling military to hand over power to a civilian government. Police clashed with protesters when they attempt to disperse them. Some demonstrators flew the Egyptian flag, while others including ultraconservative Salafis waved a banner declaring Islam's holy book, the Quran, to be ''our constitution.'' and demanded the withdrawal of the 'peace document'.

On 18 November 2011, a number of rioters broke into a building next to the Ministry of Interior in the Abdin neighborhood of Cairo, thinking that television cameras in the building were broadcasting a story describing demonstrators in Tahrir Square as thugs. As it turned out, the cameras were only taking pictures of the demonstrators. On the same day, demonstrators marched to the Ministry of Interior building and attempted to break inside before police responded with tear gas. Demonstrators also set tires on fire to prevent police from returning to Tahrir Square. [size=not reported]
On 18 November 2011, a group of dozens of residents of Al Arish demonstrated in call for the handover of power from the military council to civilian forces in April 2012. [size=dozens]
Clashes have broken out near the security directorate office in the Smouha area of Alexandria every night between Nov.19-22.

column16: Uncut Index on Censorship; Reporters Sans Frontieres
column17: Journalists were allegedly beaten by security forces in Cairo and other cities as demonstrators protested to demand a civilian government across Egypt. At least one in Cairo was allegedly detained and beaten by personnel from the interior ministry.
An Al-Ahram reporter was allegedly beaten and detained by Egyptian security forces while covering protests in downtown Cairo.

On 19 November 2011, Islamic groups convene on Tahrir Square to protest to military junta, and to demand a civilians government through elections. Riot police clear the square by using tear gas, protesters respond by throwing rocks while groups of pro-government thugs clashed with the demonstrators. 4 were reported dead while at least 750 were injured. A young man wounded on the day later succumbed to his wounds on the 30th of the month. Riot police later withdrew from the square. At least 1,500 protesters stayed in the square overnight.
Three US students detained by Egyptian police after participating in protests over the weekend claimed they were beaten and threatened during their detention.

column16: Uncut Index on Censorship; Reporters Sans Frontieres
column17: Journalists were allegedly beaten by security forces in Cairo and other cities as demonstrators protested to demand a civilian government across Egypt. At least one in Cairo was allegedly detained and beaten by personnel from the interior ministry.

On 20 November 2011, an Egyptian demonstrator was killed and 15 were wounded in protests against the country's military rulers in front of the security headquarters in the Smouha area of Alexandria. Clashes were reported between the protesters and security forces. Several thousand were reported to have taken part in the demonstrations.

On 20 November 2011, police at Cairo International Airport broke up a clash between supporters and opponents of the Bashar al Assad regime that took place as a plane form Syria landed at the airport. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported. [size=50]

column16: Youm7; Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: On 20 November 2011, journalists were assaulted in Alexandria during ongoing protests to demand civilian rule. At least one was detained an beaten by security forces. This occurred when thousands of people marched after a funeral in the morning for a man killed by security forces.

On 20 November 2011, thousands of rioters clashed with hundreds of soldiers and police in Tahrir Square; 11 are reported dead from clashing while over 700 were reported wounded. 40 police officers were wounded and 18 of the protesters were arrested. The police were trying to evict demonstrators who had camped out in the Square. Clashes between rioters and security forces were also reported at the Interior Ministry which is just a few blocks away from Tahrir Square. The Shura Council building was set on fire by a tear gas bomb.
