On 20 November 2011, clashes broke out between a group of lawyers and supporters of Al Nour Party candidates in front of the North Cairo courthouse in the Al Wayli neighborhood. No fatalities were reported.
Anti-military junta protests spread into other cites around Egypt. No report of police clashes.
On 20 November 2011, Muslim Brotherhood students gathered and chanted slogans against the military outside Helwan University in Cairo. [size=not reported]
Anti-military junta protests spread into other cites around Egypt. Police fired tear gas to disperse protesters in Suez.
One police officer was killed and another injured in Egypts Sinai during clashes with members of an Islamist group suspected of attacks on a pipeline.

There were reports of clashes between protesters and security forces in near the security directorate office in the Smouha area of Alexandria. The clashes escalated from those reported on Monday, and left as many as 39 injured after rocks, rubber bullets and tear gas were traded between the two sides.

On 21 November 2011, demonstrations and clashes with security forces continue into the third day. 23 were reported killed while hundreds more have been injured (some estimates were as high as 1,750). Nearby buildings were set on fire. The military governing cabinet tenders their resignations in response to the violence, though most military officials refuse. 3 Americans students were arrested for allegedly throwing petrol bombs during the protests on Sunday.

Agreement: On 21 November 2011, Egypt's cabinet has resigned en masse amid ongoing protests which have seen more than 30 killed in Tahrir Square and many hundreds injured in clashes between protesters and police.

On 21 November 2011, more than 2,000 demonstrators clashed with police in front of the Security Directorate in the town of Asyut with the former throwing bricks and stones and the latter responding with tear gas. A number of demonstrators were wounded although no number was recorded. [size=2,000]

On 21 November 2011, demonstrators attempted to storm the Security Directorate building in Al Mansurah when police responded by firing rubber bullets and live ammunition, wounding a number of demonstrators. The demonstrations turned into hit-and-run attacks between the rioters and police. No fatalities were reported. [size=not reported]

On 21 November 2011, Egyptian police clashed with a group of smugglers on the border with Israel in the Rafah crossing, as the latter was attempting to smuggle several African migrants into Israel. One Egyptian police officer was wounded during the clash with no fatalities reported.
Three American students were arrested by Egyptian police for throw petrol bombs at them. They are later released.
An American journalist claims to have been sexually assaulted at the hands of police during rioting.
Clashes were reported in Mahalla between security forces and protesters, coinciding with ongoing protests against military rule throughout Egypt.

Clashes have broken out near the security directorate office in the Smouha area of Alexandria every night between Nov.19-22. 2 protesters were killd over the course of the protests (1 coded in a previous event).

column7: FPJ: Freedom and Justice Party; CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: On 22 November 2011, a group of Freedom and Justice Party, Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution, and supporters of Mohammad El Baradei marched from Bulaq neighborhood in Cairo calling for the immediate transition from a military council to a civilian-led government. [size=unknown]

On 22 November 2011, the death toll from confrontations between rioters, including students and Syrians who marched in solidarity, and police around Egypt has reached 30 (26 coded in previous events), the health ministry said on Tuesday, as the violence raged into a fourth straight day, including in among tens of thousands of protesters and large numbers of police in Tahrir Square and the nearby American University. Fatalities for events on the 22nd coded to 4.
Protests were reported in several Egyptian governorates in solidarity with those going on in Tahrir Square (specific locations not provided).
Protests were held in Suez; no clashes were reported.
Hundreds have been injured in protests and clashes with police across Egypt, including in Ismailia.
Clashes were reported in Mahalla between security forces and protesters, coinciding with ongoing protests against military rule throughout Egypt.
University students from Cairo, Ain Shams and Helwan universities marched to Tahrir Square on Wednesday.
Hundreds of people marched from Al-Qaed Ibhrahim Mosque to the Northern District military leadership HQ following days of clashes with security forces in Alexandria.
Clashes near the security directorate office in the Smouha area of Alexandria on Nov.22 carried over into the morning of Nov.23.

On 23 November 2011, rioters clashed with police on Al Bustan Street in Talaat Harb Square with demonstrators erecting iron barriers to try and prevent security forces from entering nearby Tahrir Square. Dozens of rioters were wounded by tear gas and rubber bullets. [size=not reported]
University students from Cairo, Ain Shams and Helwan universities marched to Tahrir Square on Wednesday.
University students from Cairo, Ain Shams and Helwan universities marched to Tahrir Square on Wednesday.
Two female journalists, one American, one French, were beaten and sexually harassed by police officers and other unidentified assailants (""thugs"") while they were covering clashes in Tahrir Square.
Clashes were reported in Mahalla between security forces and protesters, coinciding with ongoing protests against military rule throughout Egypt.

Agreement: On 24 November 2011, police and protesters have agreed to a truce after 6 days of deadly clashes which left at least 41 people killed and thousands injured (the number of injuries is disputed).

Protester and police clash for the 6th straight day. Police fire teargas and rubber bullets at the demonstrators. Many report the use of live ammunition by police. The fatality count from the 6 days of protests has reached 41 (38 coded in previous events). As many as 180 police and a number of soldiers have been reported injured in the clashes.
A French journalist claims to have been sexually assaulted by protesters while covering the rioting.

On 24 November 2011, Israeli border forces and Egyptian police clashed with Bedouin smugglers along the Israeli-Egyptian border in Rafah district in North Sinai governorate as the latter attempted to infiltrate Israel across the border. 2 Egyptian police were killed during the clash.
Protesters blocked the entrance to the Egyptian cabinet HQ in a bid to prevent the newly-named PM Kamal al-Ganzuri from entering the building.
Clashes were reported in Mahalla between security forces and protesters, coinciding with ongoing protests against military rule throughout Egypt.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.

On 25 November 2011, masked gunmen again blew up a gas pipeline which supplies Egyptian gas to Israel for the eighth time this year. During the attack a pipeline guard was allegedly taken hostage and released afterwards. The attackers are suspected members of the Takfir wal-Hijra. 2 explosions were reported along the pipeline, while a third bomb did not detonate. A conflicting report said the pipeline was destroyed on Sunday. No fatalities were reported.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.
Thousands of protesters rallied in Alexandria, Mansoura, Qena, Sohag, Assiut, Aswan, Suez and Ismailia in solidarity with those protesting in Tahrir Square to demand an end to military rule.

On 25 November 2011, thousands of protesters gathered in Abbasiya Square in Cairo to show solidarity with the SCAF, calling themselves the ""Million Man March of the Silent Majority"". [size=thousands]

On 25 November 2011, thousands of protesters marched in Tahrir Square demanded the resignation of the military leaders responsible for violence in recent days. Protesters disarmed a group of thugs who arrived seeking to cause trouble. The protesters also began a multi-day sit in. [size=thousands]

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: On 26 November 2011, Tahrir Square protests continued. Protesters, including the Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution vowed to remain until civilian rule is brought to the country. Medical officials said that one demonstrator has been killed outside the country's cabinet building while clashing with police. [size=unknown]

On 26 November 2011, residents of the village of Akwa in the district of Dyarb Ngim set fire to tires and blocked the main road through the town to condemn recent insecurity in the town. [size=not reported]

Tahrir Square protests continue. Protesters vow to remain until civilian rule is brought to the country. Medical officials say that one demonstrator has been killed by unknown individuals outside the countries Cabinet building.

On 27 November 2011, gunmen assumed to be Al-Takfir wal Hijrah members, again detonate an explosive on a gas pipeline leading to Israel, just outside Al-Arish, after a recent attack on Friday. A 3rd device was found by security forces, unexploded, on the pipeline.

On 27 November 2011, a group of students marched from Cairo University to meet the sit-in taking place in front of the Council of Ministers building next to Tahrir Square. The protesters called for an immediate handover to a civilian-led government. [size=not reported]
After a Muslim was killed by a Christian in al-Ghureizat village in Sohag, Muslims set fire to Christian houses (no casualties reported) before police and soldiers intervened to stop the attacks.
A Muslim resident of Ghureizat village in Sohag was killed after a fight with his Christian neighbour over the building of a wall.
Two anti-junta protesters described as ""rioters"" by Nile News TV were arrested by police during an event near a ballot station in Nasr City.

A disqualified candidate in the ongoing elections from the Tamman family clashed with his rival from the Galal family after the disqualified candidate blocked the roads leading to the polling station in the Assiut village of Dayrout. A gunfight broke out although no injuries were reported.
On 28 November 2011, Muslim Brotherhood members fired over the heads of supporters of the Freedom Party near the Etsa Kiir school in Alexandria with neither injuries nor fatalities reported.
Protesters who had been sitting in at Tahrir Square since Saturday staged a march around the Square as voting began on Nov.28. Many protesters declared they would be boycotting the polls.

On 29 November 2011, a number of individuals broke into a voting location in the Halwan neighborhood of Cairo after voting had closed. Police and army soldiers removed the individuals which caused injuries. No fatalities were reported. [size=not reported]

On 29 November 2011, despite elections the previous day, between 62-80 rioters were injured in clashes with police in and around Tahrir Square involving thrown rocks, glass bottles, birdshot and Molotov cocktails. Some of those rioting also clashed with street vendors in and around Tahrir Square.

On 30 November 2011, a number or representatives of candidates who ran in the elections that took place the day before staged a sit-in in front of the electoral committee's headquarters in city of Shubra Al-Khayma to protest against the cancellation of the counting of votes. [size=not reported]
Protesters regroup in Tahrir Square vowing not to leave until the army gives up power.
Protesters remain in Tahrir Square.
On 1 December 2011, a number of supporters of Hosni Mubarak staged a sit-in in front of the State Council building during a hearing on the former president's legal case. [size=not reported]

On 2 December 2011, thousands of protesters marched in Tahrir Square demanding the end of military trials for civilians, speedy trials for those responsible for the death of protesters, and the immediate handover of power to a civilian authority. [size=thousands]
On 2 December 2011, military junta supporters assemble in the Al Abbasiyah area of Cairo to show support of the military rule. [size=unknown]

column7: FPJ: Freedom and Justice Party; Al-Nour Party
column17: On 3 December 2011, representatives and supporters from the Freedom and Justice and Al-Nour parties began a sit-in at the Al-Nadha Youth Center in the Al Matariyah neighborhood of Cairo to protest the alleged manipulation of electoral lists. [size=not reported]
On 3 December 2011, Al-Wasat party members staged a protest at the 5th constituency vote count committee HQ over alleged rigging of the results of the election. [size=unknown]

On 4 December 2011, 4 people were injured in a brawl between street vendors in Tahrir Square as they fought over the ""best spots"" for sales in the area. 7 vendors wielding bladed weapons attacked the others in the Square.

On 5 December 2011, demonstrators blocked the entrance to the Temple of Abydos due to a week-long shortage of butane gas cylinders. The demonstrators also blocked the railroad line between Cairo and Aswan. [size=unknown]
On 5 December 2011, thugs attacked voters in the Qasr Al-Nile district of Cairo while accusing Muslim Brotherhood cadres of rigging the election. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.
On 5 December 2011, rioters attacked the car of the president of the electoral counting commission and stole electoral papers as the car drove through the Al Salam district of Cairo. [size=unknown]

On 5 December 2011, unidentified gunmen shot at the top Freedom and Justice Party candidate as he was traveling by car in the first district of Sharkia governorate. The driver and candidate were wounded when the car crashed while no fatalities were reported.
Members of the Muslim Brotherhood and Egypts military clash over differences of the new constitution.

On 8 December 2011, a group of protesters demonstrated near the Kasr al Ain Hospital in Hadaiq Al-Qubba district of Cairo in solidarity with those who lost their sight during demonstrations in the country. [size=unknown]
Around 1,000 Egyptians rallied near the pyramids in Giza against their perception that an Islamist government to undermine tourism.

On 9 December 2011, dozens of demonstrators including members of the April 6 Youth and Kifaya Movements staged a protest in front of the Ministry of Defense in the Al Abbasiyah area of Al Wayli district in Cairo calling for the military to hand over power the following April. [size=dozens]
On 9 December 2011, dozens of demonstrators marched from Tahrir Square to Parliament with coffins symbolizing those lost during the Egyptian revolution. [size=dozens]

On 10 December 2011, some thugs in Tahrir Square attempted to close the square again to traffic and attacked and smashed some cars which led to altercations with other people in the square. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

On 12 December 2011, a number of Kifaya Movement members yelled slogans of support in front of the High Court in the Maadi district of Cairo. Passerbys got into verbal altercations with the group, claiming they do not represent all Egyptians. [size=unknown]

An engineer was severely beaten by an army officer in front of Al-Azhar as he accompanied a group of protesters marching from the Cabinet HQ to the school. 25 soldiers allegedly engaged in assaults on the protesters.
A polling station in the Saif area of Giza was shut down for 3 hours after a shoot-out between candidates.

column9: DPP: Democratic Peoples Party; Al-Nour Party
column17: On 15 December 2011, Muslim Brotherhood members scuffled with supporters of the DPP and al-Nour parties in the Ossim village area of Giza as the 2nd-round of polling wrapped up. Security forces later intervened to prevent further scuffles.

column9: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: Scuffles were reported between Revolutionary Youth Council and FJP campaigners near the Ossims El-Bahwashi School in Giza.
Supporters of the Egyptian Bloc said their HQ was attacked by thugs who threw molotov cocktails at it.

column9: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: A candidate from the Revolution Continues Alliance was beaten in Sharkia by military police when he attempted to enter a polling station.

On 15 December 2011, army forces fired over the heads of demonstrators outside the Imam al-Busairi school in Bulaq district of Cairo. The demonstrators were attempting to storm the school which was being used as a polling station. [size=unknown]

On 15 December 2011, supporters of Freedom and Justice Party and an independent candidate exchanged fire outside the Gamal Abel Nasser school in Bulaq Al-DakrUr district of Giza governorate. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

On 15 December 2011, army forces broke up a clash between Al-Nour Party supporters and supporters of an independent candidate in the village of Al Sanjara in Sharkia governorate after the latter accused the Al-Nour Party of illegally dealing with and contacting voters in the area. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported during the scuffle. [size=unknown]

On 16 December 2011, At least 300 are injured and 17 reported killed during clashes between military, police forces and anti-government protesters. When security forces attempted to disperse them the protests threw stones and set fire to the nearby Shura Council building. The security forces were dispersing a sit-in outside the Egyptian Cabinet building in the Tahrir Square area with several 2 army soldiers reported wounded by rioters.
An elected MP was assaulted by security forces as he attempted to check on the situation in the al-Qasr al-Aini street area where clashes between security forces and protesters had been ongoing.

Soldiers stormed an anti-military protest camp outside Egypts cabinet building Friday, beating women with sticks and hurling chunks of concrete and glass onto protesters from the roof of the parliament.

On 16 December 2011, dozens of protesters demonstrated in front of the military headquarters in the town of Alexandria against the attack on protesters near the Council of Ministers in Cairo taking place on the same day. [size=dozens]

On 17 December 2011, security forces and police continued to clash with demonstrators from the day before in the area of Tahrir Square, resulting in a number of casualties. A library housing many irreplaceable books and documents burned in the violence with rioters breaking through police barriers and the army firing tear gas and rubber bullets. As many as 157 people were detained over the course of the 2 days of clashes.

On 17 December 2011, students and other protesters demonstrated in front of Al-Azhar University in Nasr City district of Cairo demanding retribution for the killing of Sheikh Emad Effat and the rest who were killed in protests in front of the Council of Ministers . [size=unknown]
A pipeline carrying natural gas to Israel is bombed for the 10th time of this year. Al-Takfir wal Hijrah is suspected.

On 18 December 2011, clashes between Egyptian military and police and demonstrators in Tahrir Square entered the third day, with 4 fatalities reported. Several nearby schools were closed by the Education Ministry in response to the clashes.
Weapons seizure: on 18 December 2011, Egyptian armed forced foiled an attempt by unidentified smugglers to sneak in 14 rifles and 80k rounds of ammunition from Libya into Matrouh governorate.

On 18 December 2011, dozens of political activists demonstrated in front of the Journalists' Syndicate in the Al Azbakiyya area of Cairo to denounce the use of violence by police and army units and to demand the overthrow of the military rule of the country. [size=dozens]

column6: Police Forces of Egypt (2011-2012) Prison Guards
column17: On 18 December 2011, a defendant in the case of the riot near the Shura Council died under interrogation in a prison in the Sayyida Zainab area of Cairo city.

On 19 December 2011, battles with police and military continued, 3 more reported dead from clashes. Live rounds were reported fired by security forces reported while rioters threw Molotov cocktails. 17 people were killed in total between Dec.16-19, including some who later died of their injuries (extra fatalities coded on Dec.18) while 12 were wounded over the two day clash.
Students at Cairo Universitys Faculty of Economics and Political Science protested on campus in solidarity with the victims of the Qasr al-Aini street clashes.

On 19 December 2011, Egyptian military and police forces raided an Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigade weapons stash 20 km south of the city of Al Arish where they seized a number of light weapons and explosives.
On 20 December 2011, thousands of Egyptian women marched in downtown Cairo against excessive force and sexual violence used by the Egyptian army against female protesters. [size=thousands]
On 20 December 2011, several hundred protesters gathered outside the Egyptian Supreme Court to show solidarity with the SCAF. [size=hundreds]
Military forces blocked El-Khalifa El-Maamoun Street to prevent a march of 1,500 students from Ein-Shams to the Ministry of Defense.

On 21 December 2011, hundreds of demonstrators marched in front of the American Embassy in Qasr al Nile area of Cairo and mourned the death of a political activist killed in the recent riots in Tahrir Square. The rioters chanted slogans and threw rocks at the American embassy. [size=hundreds]

On 21 December 2011, dozens of mourners marched from Tahrir Square in Cairo to the Zeinhoum morgue to condemn the killing of a political activist killed in protests in the Square several days prior. Later the same day, 3,000 demonstrators from over 26 different Islamic and political groups marched from Tahrir Square to protest the violent response by government forces to the protests in Tahrir Square over the weekend. [size=thousands]

On 22 December 2011, hundreds of students marched from Ain Shams University in Al Wayli area of Cairo to pay tribute to a political activist killed in protests the day prior. The students also called for the military council to step down immediately. [size=hundreds]

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: Hundreds of protesters marched to condemn attacks against female protesters and demand a transition from military rule in Asyut. A number of organizations participated, including the Revolutionary Youth Coalition and the SDP and DFP.
Demos against military rule were held in Port Said, Ismailia, and Luxor.
Demos against military rule were held in Port Said, Ismailia, and Luxor.
Demos against military rule were held in Port Said, Ismailia, and Luxor.
Hundreds of protesters marched on Arbain Square in Suez to protest against the SCAF and recent attacks on female demonstrators. The demo was organized by the Suez Youth Bloc.
A small group of protesters demanded an end to military rule in Tanta.
About 500 people gathered in front of a marine base in Baharai to show support for the SCAF.
A number of marches made their way through Cairo before arriving in Tahrir Square to join demonstrations against the SCAF.
Thousands gathered in Abbasiya Square to show solidarity with the SCAF and the PM as a rival protest was ongoing in Tahrir Square.
On 23 December 2011, police and rioters again clashed in Tahrir Square over military rule and other unpopular government decisions. More than 10,000 were gathered. [size=thousands]
Thousands of people protested in Alexandria denouncing what they called the ""armies crimes against protesters"" in the context of rival protests for and against the SCAF in Cairo.
Journalists at the Rose Al-Youssef newspaper started a sit-in against their editor-in-chief and the dismissal of their colleagues.
Renewed clashes inter their second day. Three reported killed.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: About 25 people protested outside the HQ of the al-Fagr newspaper in Dokki district. The protesters were angry because the newspaper was seen as anti-military.

On 25 December 2011, dozens of students and Ultras Zamalek football fans demonstrated in front of the high court in Ain Shams area of Cairo and demanded the release of those detained in connection with recent protests. [size=dozens]
On 26 December 2011, dozens of demonstrators held a silent march around the Al Abbasiyah area of Cairo in solidarity with the Tahrir Square protesters. [size=dozens]
Hundreds marched in Nasr City to denounce military rule.

Security Measures: On 28 December 2011, Egyptian justice officials and police raided offices of 17 civil society organizations on Thursday as part of an investigation into foreign funding of such groups in Egypt. The groups included Human Rights Watch, the National Democratic Institute (NDI) and the International Republican Institute (IRI). All are US based organizations.

On 28 December 2011, dozens of families of those killed in protests in the past year demonstrated in front of a police academy in New Cairo-1 area of Cairo where former president Hosni Mubarak, his sons, and other associates were being put on trial. [size=dozens]

Around 200 Coptic Christians and Muslims clashed in Bahij, Al-Udar, and Sallam villages in Assiut after a drawing of the Prophet was included in a post on a local Christian students Facebook page. A number of villagers were injured in the clashes.

Around 200 Coptic Christians and Muslims clashed in Bahij, Al-Udar, and Sallam villages in Assiut after a drawing of the Prophet was included in a post on a local Christian students Facebook page. A number of villagers were injured in the clashes.

Around 200 Coptic Christians and Muslims clashed in Bahij, Al-Udar, and Sallam villages in Assiut after a drawing of the Prophet was included in a post on a local Christian students Facebook page. A number of villagers were injured in the clashes.
On 29 December 2011, unidentified gunmen shot a police vehicle in the village of Qaha in the Kalyoubia governorate, killing 1 police officer and wounding 2 others.

column7: CYR: Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution
column17: On 29 December 2011, dozens of demonstrators including Coalition of the Youth of the Revolution members protested in Sayyida Zeinab area of Cairo against the acquittal of a police officer accused of wounding and killing protesters. [size=dozens]

On 30 December 2011, Egyptian soldiers clashed with Muslim protesters angry over the publishing of a picture of the Prophet on a Christian Facebook page. The protesters were attempting to block fire crews after some Christian homes were burnt. The soldiers then sealed off the villages of Bahij, Al-Udar and Sallam. 5 security personnel and a number of villagers were injured in the clashes.

On 30 December 2011, Egyptian soldiers clashed with Muslim protesters angry over the publishing of a picture of the Prophet on a Christian Facebook page. The protesters were attempting to block fire crews after some Christian homes were burnt. The soldiers then sealed off the villages of Bahij, Al-Udar and Sallam. 5 security personnel and a number of villagers were injured in the clashes.

On 30 December 2011, Egyptian soldiers clashed with Muslim protesters angry over the publishing of a picture of the Prophet on a Christian Facebook page. The protesters were attempting to block fire crews after some Christian homes were burnt. The soldiers then sealed off the villages of Bahij, Al-Udar and Sallam. 5 security personnel and a number of villagers were injured in the clashes.
On 30 December 2011, dozens of demonstrators protested in Sayyida Zeinab area of Cairo against the acquittal of a police officer accused of wounding and killing protesters. [size=dozens]

Hundreds gather in Tahrir Square to commemorate those killed in the uprising that toppled former President Hosni Mubarak. Mubarak is charged with involvement in the killings of more than 800 people during the anti-government protests that forced him from office in February.

On 31 December 2011, residents of the village of Abu Ghalib set fire to the Orascom Company equipment and facilities in the Manshiyat al Qanatir area of Giza governorate to protest the establishment of a power station in their village that they believed to be a nuclear power plant which was, in fact, not the case.

Arrests: April 6 Youth Movement activists were detained while hanging up posters comparing images of soldiers after the 1973 war with Israel with pictures of troops beating women in Cairo during protests last month, according to a member of the group. The four were released a few days later.
Clashes between Egyptian troops and a Bedouin tribal group when the government tried to evict the Bodouin from state-owned land. The deaths reported.
Protesters gather to ""remind"" MPs of their demands near the anniversary of the initial uprising. Several groups were represented.
Protesters gather to ""remind"" MPs of their demands near the anniversary of the initial uprising. Several groups were represented.

A group of Bedouin militants took control of the Aqua Sun resort complex near Taba, demanding a ransom of four million Egyptian pounds (approximately $662,000). No tourists were at the site when it was seized, but Egyptian staff members were taken hostage.

Despite recent differences Copts and Muslims march from Shubra to Tahrir Square, the epicenter of the revolution, raising pictures of the martyrs who lost their lives during the January uprising and the subsequent clashes throughout the year.

Tens of thousands of protesters in Alexandria marked the first anniversary of the Jan 25 uprising as five marches met in front of Al-Qeddesine Church chanting against military rule. There were other demands chanted from different groups as well, such as a raise in the national minimum wage.
Clashes between democracy demonstrators and members of the Muslim Brotherhood Party erupt during a larger protest. No reports of casualties.

Thousands return to Tahrir Square to celebrate the first anniversary of the ""Day of Revolt"", but it soon descended into a protest. The target of the crowd's anger was Field Marshal Mohammed Hussein Tantawi, Mr Mubarak's Defense Minister for twenty years, who now heads of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (SCAF).
Security forces are able to defuse a bomb on an airplane arriving from Libya.

Egyptian Bedouins captured 25 Chinese workers in Sinai to demand the release of relatives detained over bombings in the peninsula between 2004 and 2006. The group threatens torture if their demands are not met.
The killing of two Copts sparks a protest of 1,500.
Unknown assailants shot dead two Coptic Christians in a village of southern Egypt on Thursday, prompting an angry protest by more than 1,500 of their co-religionists.

A group of Muslims go on a rampage when rumor spread a Copt had a ""intimate picture"" of a Muslim woman on his cell phone. Many homes and shot owned by Copts were burned. Eight families were forcibly evicted by the attackers.

Scores of opponents of Syrian President Bashar al-Assads regime stormed the Syrian embassy in Cairo on Friday before being dragged away by security forces. Many of the rioters were able to fight their way into the building before arrest.

Non-violent activity: Egypt has banned at least ten Americans and Europeans from leaving the country, including the son of Ray LaHood, the US Transport Secretary, raising tensions with Washington over the Egyptian military's treatment of human rights and democracy-building groups.
Following Friday prayers many protesters gather in Tahrir Square for a mass rally to demand democratic change.
Egyptian protesters demonstrated outside the state-run TV premises, known as Maspero, to demand ""purging"" of state media of those linked to the former regime
Protests continue in Tahrir Square following the initial gathering to mark the anniversary.
Armed men scuffle with Maspero television protesters.

Thousands of protesters marched on Egypts parliament demanding a swift end to army rule, and some turned their anger on the leading Islamist movement they accused of doing the militaries bidding. Some youth members of the Muslim Brotherhood, whose Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) won nearly half the seats in the recent parliamentary election, formed a cordon in the street leading to parliament to prevent protesters from approaching the building. ""The people want the fall of the Brotherhood,"" protesters chanted.
A second group of Chinese workers are kidnapped by tribal Bedouins. The group was freed several days later.

On 1 February 2012, a massive riot occurred at Port Said Stadium in Port Said, Egypt, following an Egyptian Premier League football match between El Masry and El Ahly. 74 people were killed and more than 500 were injured after thousands of El Masry spectators stormed the stadium stands and the pitch. El Ahly ultras claim that they were specifically targeted given their vocal highly televised calls for the SCAF to step down, as well as their open mockery of the previous regime and the SCAF. The ultras were one of the largest organized bodies of resistance in street protests after the absence of the Muslim Brotherhood following parliamentary elections
Protesters gather in the Giza neighborhood of Mohandessin to denounce police following a deadly soccer riot in Port Said.

Two men were killed in clashes Thursday between Egyptian police and protesters in the northeastern city of Suez, medical sources said, amid growing anger after 74 people died in violence after a football match. The two that were killed were shot by police. An army officer was also reported killed.
Egyptian police on Thursday fired tear gas at protesters to prevent them from reaching the interior ministry headquarters in Cairo. About 20 people were injured.
Ultras Protesters gather to express their anger at police not doing more to quell rioters after a recent soccer riot in Port Said where 70+ people died. 388 are reported injured.
Protesters gather to denounce police for not doing enough to quell soccer riot violence in Port Said.
Gunmen attack a police station in eastern Cairo and freed detainees.

Egyptian Bedouins seized two female American tourists and their Egyptian tour guide on the road to the historic monastery of St Catherines in Sinai. The location was known as Wadi al-Soal. The two were released several hours later.
Crowds gather to denounce military rule.

Mobs, continuing to express their displeasure with police following deadly soccer riot in Port Said clash with police for the second day. 1,482 reported injured over the two days, Twelve killed total.
Protesters gather for a second day in Suez to express their displeasure with police following a soccer riot.
Police fire tear gas at stone throwing rioters near Tahrir Square.
Two demonstrators die in the third day of post soccer clashes with police.
Five people are wounded when soccer riot demonstrators clash with police for the third day.
Rioters throw stones at a police station and steal weapons in a Cairo suburb.
Police fire tear gas at demonstrators who have gathered in the area and clashed with police for several days.
Following the death of a compatriot in Egyptian custody Ansar al-Jihad al-Alami bombs a gas pipeline that leads into Israel in retaliation.

In an effort to quell rioters following several days of clashes police erect a barrier near the Interior Ministry Building to insulate it from demonstrators. Despite their efforts many in the mob continued to throw rocks and petrol bombs. One reported dead of a gunshot wound, one later died due to wounds sustained.

Movement of forces: Former presidential candidate Mohammed El Baradei said on Wednesday amid calls for civil disobedience on Feb. 11 to demand a swift handover of power to civilians. Military rulers mobilize across the country in the following day in anticipation of the unrest.
Protesters demonstrated outside Egypts Ministry of Defense, demanding the military to end its rule and hand over power to civilians.

Arrests: Veteran labour unionist Kamal El-Fayoumi was arrested in the industrial city of Mahalla along with an Australian journalist, an American student, a translator and a driver on allegations of inciting Mahalla residents to join a nationwide call for civil disobedience.
Two hundred gather in Tahrir square to mark the anniversary of the Mubarak ousting as well as to call for a national strike. Many see the low number as a reflection of public indifference.
Hundreds of Egyptians, mainly from conservative political parties or groups, gathered in front of the Syrian Embassy in Cairo calling for the immediate discharge of the Syrian ambassador from Egypt.
A large group gathers to protest the Syrian regime.
Border fighting between organized militia and Egyptian forces.
Weapons Seizure: Israeli forces discover a large explosive in a Israel/Egypt border area.
Arrests: Police arrest a senior al-Qaeda operative coming from Pakistan, though the man denies ties to the group.
Two explosions on Monday hit a pipeline which supplies Egyptian gas to Israel and Jordan, marking the 13th such attack in just over a year.

Protesters outside the U.S. Embassy in Cairo supporting the Egyptian militaries crackdown on international pro-democracy groups clashed with demonstrators rallying against the countries military leadership. Dozens of people were injured.
A man fires gunshots from Egypt into Israel, aiming at guards. The Israelis return fire, killing the man.

Army forces clashed Tuesday with protesters and families of martyrs attending the trial of police officers accused of killing Jan. 25 protesters in Alexandria. Scuffles broke out when protesters chanted against police and army forces, which provoked the army forces.

Dozens of anti-military activists tore down a wall in central Cairo on Friday erected by the military in December to end bloody clashes with protesters. The activists chanting anti-military slogans used sledgehammers and cables to bring down the concrete blocks of the wall.
An unknown group or individual fired several rockets into Israel from Egypt.
Unknowns detonate an explosive and destroy a portion of a gas pipeline.

Thousands of Salafist presidential candidate Hazem Salah Abu Ismail supporters demonstrated in Cairos Tahrir square while hundreds demonstrated in Alexandria to show their support for him in light of the ongoing debate on his mothers reported US citizenship.

Thousands of Salafist presidential candidate Hazem Salah Abu Ismail supporters demonstrated in Cairos Tahrir square while hundreds demonstrated in Alexandria to show their support for him in light of the ongoing debate on his mothers reported US citizenship.
Clashes at the Egypt/Libya border after rioters burned a military building.
Armed men opened fire at a police checkpoint, two dead one injured.
Islamists gather to protest several candidates they support being disqualified for various paperwork reasons in an upcoming election.

Thousands of protesters gathered ahead of a planned rally against the ruling military and presidential candidates who served under ousted leader Hosni Mubarak. The group of 10,000 believed the generals would sabotage the election process for their own political benefit.
Tens of thousands of protesters spanning all political factions marched Friday from Al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the Central Military District chanting against the military rule.
When a former Mubarak official and former Prime Minister announces his candidacy for the Presidency it is met with protests.

Hundreds of Islamists demonstrated in Cairo on Friday against Egypts ruling military council, demanding that senior officials from the deposed regime of Hosni Mubarak be banned from running for president.

Assailants attacked demonstrators gathered outside the Defense Ministry in Egypts capital to call for an end to military rule with rocks and firebombs, killing one protester and wounding 30. The protesters responded in kind. It is believed the assailants were residents of the neighborhood upset with the Salafists politics.

Security services in Cairo arrested 24 demonstrators from an informal settlement in Duwaiqa for storming the Cairo municipality headquarters, closing its gates, taking the officials hostage and assaulting the governor's car. The group was protest a lack of housing units in their community.
Following an attack and street battle two days earlier protesters return to government buildings premises to continue.
Those opposed to military governance continue their protest outside the defense ministry building in Cairo.
Unknown assailants attack protesters camped outside the Defense Ministry building. Protesters respond in kind. 9 reported deaths, plus at least 50 injuries. Army deployed to quell violence.

Eleven people are reported to have been killed in the protests near the defence ministry building.Protestors say attackers set on them at dawn using rocks, clubs, fire bombs and firing shot guns. About 100 people were injured.
An Egyptian policeman was killed and two others were injured Wednesday in an attack by unknown people in the Sinai Peninsula.
A photographer sustained an upper jaw fracture and a split upper lip when she was hit full in the face by a stone thrown by demonstrators
23 reporters subject to violence, one was shot in the back but survived
Abdul-Rahman Youssef, a contributor to the human rights website hoqook.com, was attacked by a man armed with a knife.

Egyptian troops blasted protesters with water cannons, tear gas and live ammunition, trying to prevent them from marching on the Defense Ministry in clashes that left one soldier and two journalists dead and around 373 people injured [CNN Wire]. Egypts military rulers on Saturday imposed an overnight curfew and deployed soldiers around the Defence Ministry (Reuters).
Protest outside press syndicate, Egyptian reporters demand release of detained fellow journalists.

HRW claims that Egyptian soldiers beat and tortured protesters they had arrested at a demonstration near the Defence Ministry this month. The soldiers arrested at least 350 protesters, including 10 children and 16 women, on May 4 amid violence over a sit-in begun a week earlier in protest at the exclusion from Egypts presidential race of Hazem Abu Ismail.
Sudanese citizens and Darfuri refugees rallied in front of the UN High Commissioner for refugees in Cairo
Protesters threw stones and shoes at Egyptian presidential candidate Ahmed Shafiq
A policeman was shot dead outside a polling station in Cairo in a gunfight between rival supporters of political candidates. One man was injured.
Street artists stage a graffiti protest against SCAF by covering the martyr wall in Tahrir Square before the city authorities could whitewash it
more than 200 people participated in a march against the poll result organised by April 6 movement and the Revolutions Youth movement
Hundreds of revolutionary activists and representatives of national powers marched from Port Fouad ferries areas in a demonstration demanding the presidency for Hamdeen Sabahi.

In Cairo, thousands marched down July 26 street downtown and Ramses street in front of the High Court building in a protest against the runoff where Brotherhood candidate Mohamed Mursi and ex-prime minister Ahmed Shafiq will compete,
mobs of young men used bricks to smash the windows of Ahmed Shafiqs headquarters setting fire to it. 8 people were arrested.
hundreds marched in Al-Shatbi area downtown protesting the election outcome
Twenty people were injured and four shops were wrecked in clashes between supporters of presidential candidates Mohamed Mursi and Ahmed Shafiq in Sohag

Protesters began filtering into Tahrir Square to participate in the ""Disenfranchisement Friday,"" protests to demand that presidential candidate Ahmed Shafiq be barred from running for the countries highest office.
American embassy confirms abduction of two men in Sinai Peninsula; Believed to be latest in rash of kidnappings by Bedouins
One policeman was killed and six were wounded in two separate clashes on Monday between Bedouin tribesmen and security forces at two police posts in the southern area of Egypts Sinai Peninsula
Amidst protests in Cairo, Alexandria and Suez, In Damietta, hundreds organised a march where a number of revolutionaries and Salafists participated.
Thousands of Egyptians flocked to Cairos iconic Tahrir square and other places on Tuesday to protest the verdict handed down in ex-president Hosni Mubaraks case
A sexual assault on a woman during a mass demonstration occurred in Tahrir Square.

Unknown individuals set fire to the belongings of another group of protesters by the Supreme Court in July 26 street. The Supreme Court building witnessed some damage and tension earlier on Wednesday as raged protesters broke its interfaces and accused its staff, as they entered the building, of corruption.
In Suez, around 200 members of Suez Youth Bloc and April 6 movement in addition to some Brotherhood members and Salafists organised a protest

A mob of hundreds of men assaulted women holding a march demanding an end to sexual harassment Friday, with the attackers overwhelming the male guardians and groping and molesting several of the female marchers
Around 200 supporters of Hosni Mubarak began a protest on Saturday which they said would continue until the deposed Egyptian President is transferred from prison to hospital.

Clashes broke out Saturday between Muslim and Coptic students in the Assiut University women s dorms after a Coptic student reportedly proselytized Christianity to Muslim students, leaving 12 students and supervisors injured.
Up to 12 people were killed in a gunfight between members of two tribes from a southern Egyptian village sparked by a long-running row over land ownership. 3 people were wounded.

Non-violent activity: Egypts military police and intelligence will be able to detain civilians and refer them to military tribunals under a government decree issued on Wednesday that was criticised as a dangerous move by human rights groups.

Hundreds of Egyptians marched to the iconic al-Tahrir Square on Thursday night in preparation for mass protests on Friday after a top court ruled the parliament illegal, but kept an ex-prime minister in the presidential race.
Thousands of people turned out for a major protest in the Mediterranean city of Alexandria on Friday
A few protesters chanted slogans in Cairos Tahrir Square, but the call for mass protests went fairly unheeded
Egyptians protesting the exoneration of key regime figures have settled into sit-ins.
Militants crossed into Israel from Egypts Sinai Desert and fired on Israelis building a barrier on the border killing one worker, before soldiers shot dead two of the attackers.
Egyptians protesting the exoneration of key regime figures have settled into sit-ins.
Egyptians protesting the exoneration of key regime figures have settled into sit-ins.
Thousands of demonstrators gathered in Cairos Tahrir square on Tuesday to protest against the complementary constitutional declaration the ruling military council issued on Sunday.
thousands of people packed Cairos Tahrir Square accusing the SCAF of a power grab.
Egyptians packed Tahrir Square in Cairo through the night on Saturday, waving flags and chanting for the end of military rule
A number of parties and political powers are organizing a million-man demonstration in front of the military parade stand at Nasr City to support the ruling military council
Egyptians protesting the exoneration of key regime figures have settled into sit-ins
Egypt has seized a large weapons consignment, including Grad rockets, that had been smuggled from Libya and could have been headed to the Gaza Strip

Hundreds marched from Alexandrias al-Qaed Ibrahim mosque headed to the Northern military area in Sidi Gaber to call for full transfer of power and denounce the complementary constitutional declaration issued by the ruling Supreme Council of Armed Forces (SCAF).
Egyptians protesting the exoneration of key regime figures have settled into sit-ins
Dozens of students demonstrated outside Cairo University to protest the cancellation of exams and the closing of the university for a visit by President Mohamed Morsy
A soldier was killed and four injured after unidentified gunmen aimed at their vehicle near the village of Hasna, in the center of Sinai,
Sawfat Hegazy, the pro-Muslim Brotherhood preacher who gave the sermon at Friday's gathering in Tahrir Square, physically and verbally attacked two photographers covering the day's events.
A sit-in at Nasr Citys Unknown Soldier Monument entered its second day following Fridays stand to acknowledge the ruling military councils constitutional declaration.
A sit-in at Tahrir Square, led by the Muslim Brotherhood, has condemned the constitutional amendments, arguing it restricts presidential authorities.
Religious vigilantes claimed responsibility for stabbing to death a Student in Suez

journalists organised two demonstrations in front of the Press Syndicate building and Ahram organisation to protest against the criteria the Shura Council set for choosing editors of national newspapers
Three unknown assailants in al-Minya, Egypt, attacked two Coptic Christian youths with knives and robbed them of 1,300 pounds

Unidentified gunmen on Thursday allegedly robbed the Walaa Currency Exchange office in the Mariouteya district in Giza Governorate, stealing nearly LE1million before fleeing. The suspects were chased and gunfire was exchanged between them and the police, however, none of the suspects were arrested.
Change to armed group: Coptic activists announced on Thursday the establishment of secular group called 'Christian Brotherhood' as a parallel to the Muslim Brotherhood.
clashes erupted after a quarrel between a lawyer and a non-commissioned police officer at Nasr City police station. Lawyers and policemen were injured
Armed bearded men believed to be radical Islamists, attacked and seriously injured four young men with guns
Egyptian lawyers protested on Saturday outside a police station in northern Cairo a day after clashes there left a dozen people injured

Egyptian security forces and military police chased and arrested 6 activists in the city of Suez after a court jailed 7 rights activists for between 6 months and three years. Nine people were reportedly injured in the attack.
Morsi supporters and detractors clashed outside the Popular Assembly as the opposition threatened to prevent lawmakers from convening
protests outside the presidential Al-Urubah palace, Heliopolis, in protest against President Mursis decree to reinstate the parliament.
Thousands of Egyptians gathered in Cairos Tahrir Square to protest attempts by the Constitutional Court to revoke a decree by freshly inaugurated President Muhammad Morsi.

A political activist and an engineer suffered from physical assault as they were exiting the State Council. The assaulted was sprayed with water and got shouted at. Similarly, Al-Fakharany was sworn at by the proponents of president Morsis decision to reassemble the Parliament and his clothes were torn as a result of the physical assault.
Abu Al-Ezz Al-Hareery was assaulted as he was passing by Tahrir square by a group of Muslim brotherhood protestors.
Israeli troops shot dead a man trying to infiltrate the Sinai border with Egypt and wounded another on Friday
Two U.S tourists were held hostage in the Sinai Peninsula on Friday by Bedouin tribesmen seeking the release of an imprisoned kinsman

Members of liberal and Christian political groups staged several popular demonstrations against Clintons visit outside the US embassy in Cairo, the presidential palace and the Four Seasons hotel in which Clinton is staying.
Protesters in Alexandria threw tomatoes, one of them hitting an Egyptian official in the face at Hilary Clintons car
Demonstrators gathered outside Administrative Court in Cairo as judges hear cases on future of parliament, constitutional addendum and constitution-drafting body
Angry workers storm Suez government buildings in frustration at lack of progress on long-standing grievances; security forces fire tear gas to disperse protesters

Fourteen soldiers were injured on Wednesday 18/7/2012 in clashes with protestors trying to storm the Syrian embassy in Cairo. Two armoured personnel carriers were damaged and five people were arrested.
Two Egyptian soldiers were shot dead on Thursday in the north Sinai region bordering Israel

Doctors at Kafr Al-Sheikh Hospital decided to engage in a strike and close the hospital after police officers attacked two doctors leading to one of them suffering from a broken hand and internal bleeding in the abdomen and another suffering from a possible bleeding.
Gunshots fired across the border from Egypt hit an Israeli army bus but caused no casualties

Muslims on Friday set fire to Christian homes in a village near the Egyptian capital after a fight between a Muslim man and a Christian laundry worker who singed his shirt while ironing it, police said. At least one person was wounded in an exchange of fire bombs and a 25 year-old Muslim man wounded in the sectarian clashes has died.
A number of journalists declared a sit-in at the parties headquarters in Dokki in protest against the decision to change Al-Wafd party top journalists

Hundreds protested at Alexandrias Corniche road in Al-Mansheya area asking for a policeman to be brought to justice for shooting at three people resulting in the death of a young man and the injury of others.
Protesting for Burma in Cairo
Angry Muslims attacked a church and Christian homes outside Cairo on Wednesday, sparking clashes that wounded 16 people
One person died and three others were injured in clashes between security officers and protesters

Five gunmen who killed 16 Egyptian guards near the border with Israel before crossing into the Jewish state in an armoured vehicle have been killed

Dozens of protesters demonstrated outside the residence of Israels ambassador to Egypt in Cairo on Monday night, demanding that the government cease all diplomatic relations with the Jewish state in light of Sundays attack

Egyptian military attack helicopters have fired missiles on suspected Islamic militants in Sinai after an attack on security checkpoints. A ground assault of 100 soldiers conducted ground raids killing 20 militants.
Crowds prevented a newspaper editors entrance into the Media Production City and then proceeded to assault both Mr. Khaleds person and property
Three security checkpoints were attacked by suspected Islamic militants . Six people were wounded

Movement of forces: Trucks carrying dozens of armoured personnel carriers mounted with machine guns rolled through El-Arish heading to the east, where Bedouin Islamist militants have established a presence in villages near the borders with Gaza and with Israel
Militant gunmen attacked a police station. No one was hurt
Protests in support of the army were organised in the north Sinai town of al-Arish

column8: Military Forces of Egypt (2012-2013) Border Guards
column17: Gunmen attacked a checkpoint in Egypts Sinai Peninsula overnight, causing no casualties
Scores of demonstrators on Saturday protested against President Mohamed Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood
Jihadist groups attacked an Egyptian police station in the city, using rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns

Egyptian security forces killed six gunmen in a raid on a village of North Sinai. Security officials said they found chemicals used to make explosives, rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns with the militants in El-Jurah village. One of the gunmen was seriously wounded

A tribal leader and his son in Egypts Sinai Peninsula were shot dead by militants
Clashes erupted between Egyptian troops and militants in a border village . No casualties
A group of armed men opened fire on an army checkpoint in Sinai on Wednesday but ran when forces returned fire.

Accompanied by Apache aircraft, police and army forces raided Al-Raysan after receiving information that armed men were in hiding in the mountains. Three suspects were captured with a ton of marijuana.
Several thousand supporters of Egyptian President Mohamed Morsi held a rally in Cairos Tahrir Square
Police arrested 20 people for blocking a main road in Egypt in a protest over the alleged torture and death of a man
Masked assailants attacked Egyptian policemen returning from a raid in Sinai using a rocket-propelled grenade, wounding four.
Protest to take place in Cairo on Wednesday against possible IMF loan to Egypt

Hundreds of protesters rallied on Friday in Cairo against President Mohamed Morsi. There were reports of clashes between protesters and pro-Muslim Brotherhood groups on Talaat Harb Street, near Tahrir Square but no injuries reported.
Dozens scuffled in Ismailiya, east of Cairo after an anti-Morsi protest
A protest against Egyptian President and the Muslim Brotherhood continued in Cairo. In a separate incident an Egyptian man set fire to himself in protest about losing his job.
The militant, Ibrahim Ouda Bereikat, died in a blast as he tried to fire a rocket into Israel. Security sources said he might have been killed by a landmine.
militant was killed in Egypt by a missile launched from an Israeli plane

column7: Egyptian Socialist Party; Popular Alliance Party; Egyptian Communist Party
column17: A number of political movements participated in a march to express their rejection of the International Monetary Funds (IMF) loan
Egyptian police said they found a decapitated head in Sinai of a man kidnapped by Islamist militants
Thousands of Egyptians marched down Talaat Harb street in downtown Cairo on Friday night in a mass protest against what they called The Muslim Brotherhoods ""takeover"" of power in Egypt.

Hundreds of Egyptian writers and artists staged a protest on Sunday, 2 September in front of the Shura Council (upper house) building to protest the first leaked drafts of the constitution that is being written by the Constituent Assembly
a group of bearded policemen staged a protest in uniform by Cairos interior ministry
Gunman attacked an army outpost in the Sinai peninsula. Militants fired rocket-propelled grenades on the army personnel, who responded in a 15-minute fire exchange in North Sinais Sheikh Zuweid town.
Egyptian security forces have clashed with dozens of protesters in front of the Syrian Embassy in Cairo, chanting against the Syrian President Bashar Assad. 7 protesters arrested, 16 injured.
A group of unidentified armed men attacked a military ambush on Arish airport road in North Sinai on Thursday, a security source said.
In Minya, dozens of the Islamic Jamaa members organized a protest in solidarity with Syrians in front of al-Rahman mosque, calling for a decisive stance towards al-Assads regime.

In North Sinais Arish, several powers organized a protest following the Friday noon prayer where demonstrators held banners denouncing al-Assads regime and chanted slogans such as ""Egypt and Syria stand united.""
In Fayoum, the Brotherhood organized several protests attended by hundreds who condemned al-Assads regime
In Alexandria, hundreds of the Brotherhoods members and those who belong to the Islamist current protested in front of al-Qaed Ibrahim mosque in solidarity with the Syrian people.
Qaliubiya witnessed a number of protests to support the people Syria against the regime.

Egyptian tour guides will protest outside the Egyptian Museum in central Cairo on Sunday, demanding better pay and conditions after a year of turmoil for the hospitality sector.""

Ultraconservative Islamist protesters climbed the walls of the United States Embassy in Cairo on Tuesday and took down the American flag, replacing it with a black flag with an Islamic inscription to protest a movie attacking Islams prophet, Muhammad.
Coptic activists in Egypt are to stage a vigil on Wednesday in protest against a film deemed offensive to Islam that sparked violence outside US missions in Egypt and Libya

Security forces fired teargas to disperse stone-throwing demonstrators near the U.S. embassy in Cairo late on Wednesday, some 24 hours after protesters scaled the walls and tore down the flag over a film insulting the Prophet Mohammed. Between 30 and 70 people were injured.
