Defusal: Army Thwarts Attempt to Bomb Church in Sinai
Egypts Interior Ministry said that investigations have revealed that a scuffle between a now-arrested defendants and a protester started an attack that led to more than 15 injuries on Saturday.

column7: National Front for Egypts Women; Women (Egypt)
column17: Egyptian women demonstrate in front of the Shura Assembly against the new election law while demanding more rights for minority groups.

Protesters gather outside the Saudi embassy to demand the release of an Egyptian lawyer who has been sentenced to five years in prison and 300 lashes by the General Court of Jeddah in Saudi Arabia. Security scuffled with protesters and media outside the Saudi Embassy in Cairo where protesters had gathered.

Scuffles ensued on Tuesday between protesters and security forces in Alexandrias railway station after protesters cut off the railway line following the tragic Bardashin train accident that happened overnight. The security forces fired teargas to disperse the protesters following the injury of three central security officers during the scuffles.
Non-violent activity: Beni Suefs Criminal Court acquitted General Ahmed Shawqi and 10 of his aides on Tuesday from charges of killing protesters during the 2011 uprising that toppled Hosni Mubarak.

A building in a village south west of Cairo housing a reception hall and nursery was destroyed on Wednesday January 16 by a mob following a rumour that it was a church. Extremists armed with hammers axes and old electricity poles descended on the building in Fanous Village, Tamia District, Fayoum Province, and razed the structure to the ground.

Thousands of supporters of Al-Ahly club demonstrated in Cairo on Friday to demand severe punishments for 75 people on trial for dozens of deaths in Egypts worst football disaster. Al-Ahly supporters marched from the clubs Cairo headquarters to Tahrir Square, with many protesters chanting slogans hostile to Mubaraks successor, Islamist President Mohamed Morsi.

Police in Egypt clashed on Friday with a crowd of furious Muslims who tried to storm a church after claiming a Coptic man was involved in an case of child abuse. Dozens of Muslims went on the rampage in the southern city of Qena, destroying two Coptic-owned shops and then marching on the church in a bid to storm it before police fired tear gas to disperse them.
A protest led by women from the families of football fans who were killed in the Port Said killing took place on Friday, demanding those responsible for the killing be held accountable.
Hundreds of Egyptian Islamists on Friday protested outside the French embassy building in Cairo against Frances recent military interference in Mali.

Riot police fired tear gas Saturday to disperse dozens of demonstrators throwing rocks outside an Alexandria courthouse where the cities ex-security director and other officers are on trial for thekilling of protesters during Egypts 2011 uprising.

Five people were killed overnight Sunday in a northern Cairo district as clashes erupted after a police officer accidentally killed a man while chasing a drug dealer. The clashes broke out outside a police station in the Shubra el-Kheima district when relatives and neighbours of the dead man gathered and then attacked the police with guns and Molotov cocktails.
Weapons Seizure: The Egyptian authorities have seized a tonne of explosives inside Martyr Ahmad Hamdi tunnel. The explosives were on their way to being smuggled from Cairo to the Sinai.

Scuffles resumed on Sunday in Alexandria between the security forces and the protesters as the latter torched the third police car after setting fire to two central security cars. Protesters broke into the courthouse and started a small fire, which was soon extinguished.
In Suez, protesters have climbed the governorate building, raising the Suez flag and declaring the fall of the governor and the Morsy regime.
Thousands of people protested in Port Said on Saturday to demand separation from the state of Egypt. The protesters chanted for a Port Said state and against Al Ahly sports club and Ultras Ahlawy.

Hundreds of protesters have surrounded the Office of Al-Mahala City Council, declaring the illegitimacy of President Morsy, the independence of Al-Mahala from the current regime and the establishment of an executive council.
In Alexandria the municipal council building was occupied by protesters who declared independence from the ""Brotherhood regime"" before they were attacked and dragged out of the building.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: Security forces arrested 13 demonstrators engaged in a peaceful sit-in protest at the home of the prime minister in Dokki, calling for his resignation.

Hundreds of members of the hardcore soccer fans (Ultras White Knights) and other political forces staged mass protests on Tuesday in front of Alexandrias court complex in solidarity with those arrested in the background of Sundays clashes near the Criminal Court.

Clashes broke out on Tuesday in front of the police station of Matrouh Governorate.The clashes took place between the families of people accused in a smuggling case and the security forces as they tried to break in the police station. The security fired bullets and teargas bombs to disperse the people. 46 injured (24 of whom policemen).
Egyptian protestors set fire to an attachment of the Scientific complex in downtown Cairo on Thursday, following skirmishes between protestors and security men.

Four people on Thursday were injured in clashes between protesters and security forces in Cairos al-Qasr al-Aini street and Tahrir Square. Police clashed with protesters who tried to dismantle a wall of concrete blocks shutting off a street leading to Cairos Tahrir Square, to ease the movement of demonstrators. Egyptian protestors set fire to an attachment of the Scientific complex in downtown Cairo on Thursday, following skirmishes between protestors and security men.

An Egyptian group called ""Black Block"" on 25 January attacked a police station in the north coastal city of Alexandria. A journalist said the group, whose members wore black uniform and were all masked, attacked Al-Manshiyah police station and threw Molotov Cocktails at the police forces there. He said the police forces responded by opening fire in the air. They also tried to attack the municipal council building in the city, but the security forces managed to prevent them and cordoned off the building.

Hundreds of protesters in Minya on Friday demonstrated demanding the downfall of the regime on the second anniversary of the January 25 revolution. In Minya, protesters marched through the cities streets until they reached al-Shohadaa Square.

Five people were killed on Friday during clashes between police and protesters in the canal city of Suez. A number of protesters also broke into the Suez city council and declared a sit-in amid ongoing clashes with security forces surrounding the building. Over 30 injured in clashes.
Egyptian protesters on Friday set fire to the Muslim Brotherhood party headquarters in the canal city of Ismailiya.
In Ismailiya, protesters entered the building, set fire to a room used by security services and looted furniture and equipment.
Six members of the security forces tasked with guarding the Suez city council were shot after unidentified assailants shot at them with automatic machine guns. Five were killed.

Cairos Tahrir Square on Friday witnessed a huge explosion after unknown assailants had thrown a burning gas cylinder inside al-Hawatiya School playground behind the American University in Cairo building.
Scores of protesters on Friday cut off the Corniche and the tramway in al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosques area in Alexandria and placed cement barriers on the tramway.
The Muslim Brotherhoods website, Ikhwan Online, reported on Friday that unidentified assailants attempted to torch its headquarters in Tawfiqiya in downtown Cairo. Several injuries reported.

Scores of protesters on Friday attempted to break into the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhoods Freedom and Justice Party in Sharqiyas Zagazig, an Aswat Masriya eyewitness reported. The protesters hurled stones at the headquarters and set car tires alight in front of it.

Thousands of citizens in Damietta on Friday participated in a number of marches from different mosques to al-Saa Square chanting slogans against President Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood. The protesters denounced the sovereign Islamic bonds projects which the government plans to implement.
Hundreds of protesters who broke into Kafr al-Sheikhs city council on Friday demanded that the governor tenders his resignation, giving him a two-hour ultimatum to respond to their demand.

Thousands of protesters accompanied by Ultras Masrawy and Green Eagles (fans of al-Masry football club) on Friday participated in marches in Port Said on the second anniversary of the January 2011 uprising.

Dozens of protesters on Friday hurled stones at security forces stationed behind the cement wall in Sheikh Rihans Street in downtown Cairo. TV footage on al-Arabiya news channel showed police forces hurling teargas canisters at the protesters.

Clashes erupted on Friday noon between protesters and security forces in front of the local municipality in Alexandrias Kom al-Dekka neighbourhood. An Aswat Masriya eyewitness reported the absence of security bodies in most areas where protests are taking place in the city. 19 injured.
A number of protesters on Friday broke into the Suez city council and declared a sit-in amid ongoing clashes with security forces surrounding the building. Over 30 injured in clashes.
Security forces on Friday tear-gassed hundreds of protesters headed Cairos Shura Council.

Several cases of sexual assault have been reported from Tahrir Square on Friday, 19 being cases of women being groped, verbally assaulted or raped. The assaults took place amidst demonstrations against the government.
Movement of forces: The Second Field Army troops are deployed in Port Said city to help restore security and stability in the Canal city.
300 people have gathered in Nubar Street, hurling stones at the security forces safeguarding the Interior Ministry
Egyptian state-run Nile News TV carried an urgent screen caption quoting its correspondent as saying: ""Protesters block 6th October bridge [in downtown Cairo], causing traffic paralysis

Clashes broke out between police and protesters on Saturday in the Egyptian canal city of Suez amid deadly unrest sparked by death sentences handed down to 21 people over football-related violence last year.
Clashes erupted on Saturday between security forces and protesters following the verdict announced earlier by Port Said Criminal Court resulting in at least 30 fatalities.

In Tanta, hundreds of protesters attempted to break into Tanta courts complex on Saturday but were stopped by security forces. The situation intensified when protesters started hurling rocks at security forces, which responded by firing tear gas into the crowds of protesters.
Rioting sparked by death sentences passed on fans of a local football team rocked Egypts Port Said for a second straight day on Sunday, leaving another 7 people dead and more than 460 injured

Angry anti-riot policemen on Sunday barred Egypts interior minister from attending the funeral of two colleagues killed in clashes in the city of Port Said. The action was taken in protest at police not having been armed with live rounds to protect themselves.

Security measures: Egypts president declared a state of emergency and curfew in three Suez Canal provinces hit hardest by a weekend wave of unrest. The curfew and state of emergency, both in force for 30 days, affect the provinces of Port Said, Ismailiya and Suez

Security measures: Egypts president declared a state of emergency and curfew in three Suez Canal provinces hit hardest by a weekend wave of unrest. The curfew and state of emergency, both in force for 30 days, affect the provinces of Port Said, Ismailiya and Suez

Security measures: Egypts president declared a state of emergency and curfew in three Suez Canal provinces hit hardest by a weekend wave of unrest. The curfew and state of emergency, both in force for 30 days, affect the provinces of Port Said, Ismailiya and Suez

Hundreds of demonstrators began on Sunday night to block entrances and exits of most bridges in Cairo in protest against the speech President Mohamed Mursi gave earlier. Protesters torched car tires and used them to block the entrances and exits.

Television footage showed on Sunday heavy clashes between protesters and security forces near Cairos Nile Corniche. Teargas was fired by security forces heavily on protesters, while the protesters threw stones at them. The nearby French Lycee building was also gutted by a fire started overnight during clashes between protesters and security forces.
An office belonging to the FJP party was set aflame in Damanhour city of Beheira . A real estate taxes building in the same area was robbed before also being burnt.
In Cairo the French Lycee building was gutted by a fire started overnight during clashes between protesters and security forces near Tahrir Square.
Gunfire and tear gas were used as clashes continued in Port Said on Sunday, raising the total number of casualties to at least 34 dead and 416 injured; 17 suffered gunshot wounds.
In Damietta, an unidentified vehicle fired shots at the headquarters of the Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) in the Senaneya area on Sunday.
Meanwhile, dozens from the Popular Current youth cut on Monday the international Blatim road which connects Kafr al-Sheikh to Baltim.

Thousands of protesters took to the streets on Monday in Alexandria in a march from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the area of Sidi Gaber to commemorate the ""Friday of Rage on"" which took place on January 28 of 2011

Around 3,000 protesters in Suez organised on Monday night a protest to march from al-Arbaeen Square to al-Geish Street to demand ending the 30-day curfew President Mohamed Mursi has imposed on three Suez Canal cities.

Scuffles erupted between the security forces and protesters on Monday, leaving 16 of the security forces injured, as the protesters threw bricks at them causing minor head wounds. An eyewitness told Aswat Masriya that the scuffles resulted in torching an armored vehicle after the protesters threw Molotov cocktails at it. The scuffles left around 112 protesters injured and many more suffered from suffocation because of the teargas.
Scuffles erupted between protesters and security forces in downtown Cairo, resulting in the injury of dozens, and torching an armored vehicle that belonged to the security forces. One person killed.
Witnesses said protesters took to the streets of Ismailiya as the 9:00 pm (1900 GMT) curfew went into effect to stage ""breaking the curfew"" demonstrations.
Two people died in fighting between protesters and security forces in the riot-hit canal city of Port Said on Monday, including one in front of a police station.
Egypts Second Field Army members on Monday thwarted an attempt to break into Port Said General Prison. A group of six armed people on motorcycles clashed with army forces and exchanged gunfire.

Looters broke into a Nile-side luxury hotel in the Egyptian capital early Tuesday, taking advantage of clashes in the streets outside to trash shops and the lobby before police and demonstrators alerted via social media drove them out.
A march from Sayeda Zainab arrived at Qasr Al-Nil peacefully in order to get to Tahrir Square.

Kromer, a father of three, was snatched on Jan. 29 as he drove home from his practice in the village of Nazlet el-Amoden. For the next 27 hours, he endured beatings, insults and threats to his life, while blindfolded, a bandage sealing his mouth and cotton balls in his ears. Kromers case is part of a dramatic rise of kidnappings targeting Christians, including children, in Egypts southern province of Minya, home to the countries largest concentration of Christians but also a heartland for Islamist hard-liners.
Scuffles intensified on Wednesday between the security forces and protesters near Simon Bolivor Square in Downtown Cairo. Two people died in clashes between protesters and police.
On Wednesday morning a protestor was shot dead on Qasr Al-Nil bridge by ""unidentified assailants,"" according to state affiliated news agency Al-Ahram.

Clashes between protesters and police have persisted near Simon Bolivar Square since Wednesday night and continuing into the early hours of Thursday morning. Police exchanged rocks with protesters before resorting to using tear gas.

The governorate of Kafr El-Sheikh also witnessed renewed violent clashes outside the Governorate Building. According to Al-Shorouk News, 92 were injured including 13 police officers. Many of the injured had suffocated from the heavy use of teargas by police forces.
Police staff injured as gunmen attacked a prison in Al-Ismailiyah governorate.

Thousands of Egyptians marched in protest in the Suez Canal city of Port Said. Reports suggest a sentiment among residents that they are fed up of negligence and mistreatment by central government and that they want virtual independence.

column7: Al-Wafd Party; Al-Dostour Party; Al-Karama Party; Socialist Revolutionaries; Sinai Freedom Movement
column17: Protesters gather in the North Sinai city of El Arish following Friday prayers. The demonstrators were chanting against President Mohamed Morsy.
At least three people reportedly in possession of Molotov cocktails were arrested in Mansoura, Daqahleya. Protesters had blocked a major road and the railway during the Friday protest.
Eight protesters (another report suggests over a dozen) were injured in clashes which erupted in Kafr Al-Sheikh, adding to a string of injuries in the governorate
Hundreds in Alexandria participated in two marches headed to the cities local municipality and to Sidi Gaber Station Square as part of the ""Friday of Salvation"" demonstrations.

In the governorate of Minya police thwarted an attempt to storm into the Muslim Brotherhoods headquarters, MENA reported. This came after clashes where police fired tear gas at protesters and protesters threw rocks at the police.

Hundreds of protesters marched from Rabaa al-Adaweya Mosque in Nasr City headed to Cairos presidential palace. Participants included prominent politician Amr Hamzawi, Karima al-Hefnawi, producer Mohamed al-Adl, script writer Medhat al-Adl, actor Hani Salama, and actress Basma.

column16: Daily News (Egypt); Africa News; AFP; AP
column17: Protesters denouncing Egypts Islamist president hurled stones and petrol bombs through the palace gates on Friday, clashing with security forces who fired tear gas and water cannons, in the first significant violence at the presidential palace in eight days of protests. 88 people injured, 20 arrested, 1 death - 23 yr old Mohammed Hussein Qarni shot. Video released of riot police beating 48-year-old Hamada Saber.

Hundreds in Alexandria gathered in front of the security directorate to protest against the treatment of Hamada Saber, the man who was caught on camera being beaten and dragged on the ground naked by police at the presidential palace on Friday.
Injuries were also reported in Kafr El-Sheikh, where according to the health ministry 13 people were confirmed injured after clashing with police.

Protesters threw stones and bottles at the Egyptian prime ministers motorcade on Saturday as he tried to enter Cairos Tahrir Square after overnight clashes nearby and at the presidential palace, 11 people injured
On Saturday night, several hundred mostly young protesters again gathered outside the palace and were throwing rocks and Molotov cocktails at the compounds walls, 88 injured
Amr Abdel Reheem died in Heliopolis Hospital two days after he was shot near the presidential palace.

A 12-year-old street vendor Omar Salah, was killed on Feb.3 near the U.S. Embassy and Tahrir Square during clashes in the area. Activists discovered his death coincidentally as they were searching for missing protesters in hospitals.
Clashes erupted between security forces and young protestors in Al-Shaykh Rihan Street, near to the Ministry of Interior. Protestors hurled stones at security forces, which responded with tear gas.

Clashes broke out in the Nile Delta on Monday between demonstrators and riot police after the funeral of Mohammed al-Guindi, who died in custody. Protestors threw stones at police, who responded tear gas and birdshot.The chief of police said the protesters torched an armoured police vehicle and threw petrolbombs at provincial and police headquarters. He said police detained up to nine people.18 injured.
Mohammed Saad, a 20-year-old protester, died of his wounds sustained during clashes with security forces on Friday.
A 28-year-old activist, and a 20-year-old protester, died of their wounds sustained during clashes with security forces on Friday.
A large force backed by armoured vehicles raided a desert area 10 km from Houseinat, south of Al-Arish. They found 99 rounds of anti-aircraft shells and explosives buried underground

Hundreds of Egyptians marched Wednesday to demand an end to sexual violence against women. Men and women, holding huge flags of famous Egyptian female icons, marched from Sayyeda Zeinab mosque to Tahrir Square chanting against the interior ministry, which is accused of failing to bring perpetrators to justice.

Members of the 6 April Youth Movement marched from Abdeen Court to the Egyptian High Court of Justice in Downtown Cairo on Wednesday, demanding justice for the death of the one of its members, 16-year-old Gaber ""Jika"" Salah, who died in November.
Mohamed El-Meshtawi, editor of Masryoon newspaper was attacked by a group of unknown armed men with bladed weapons.
Scores of protesters cut off Al-Arish international road to protest against arresting individual in Siwa Oasis.South Sinai security chief said that protestors in South Sinai blocked Al-Tur-Suez Road.

Protesters demanding a change of government and amendment to disputed articles in the constitution, as well as conducting a ""serious national dialogue"", prevented employees from entering the Qaliubiya governorate building and set up tents in front of the main and back entrances to the building.
In Kafr el-Sheik, riot police fired tear gas at protesters rallying in front of the office of governor Saad el-Husseini.
The Kafr Al-Zayat Police Station in the governorate of Gharbeya was surrounded Saturday night until the early hours of Sunday by a group of youths from different political parties and movements.
Thousands of demonstrators on Friday gathered at Damiettas al-Saaa Square to protest against the rule of President Mohamed Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood.
Protesters in Monofeyas Shebin al-Kom on Friday participated in marches to demand holding early presidential elections and amending disputed articles in the constitution.
Several parties on Friday organised protests in Suezs al-Arbaeen Square to demand ousting President Mohamed Mursi and sacking Prime Minister Hisham Kandil and Interior Minister Mohamed Ibrahim
In Kafr al-Zayat, two people were injured in altercations with the police in front of a police station after the protesters had attempted to break into the station.

Scores of protesters on Friday hurled stones and petrol bombs at Malahas city council in an attempt to break into the building. Demonstrators set on fire the Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) headquarters. 28 injured in Gharbiya

Thousands of Egyptians marched across the country on Friday to denounce the rule of Islamist President Mohammed Morsi and his fundamentalist Muslim Brotherhood. In Cairo protesters gathered at the central Tahrir Square and outside the presidential palace. Egyptian security forces backed by water cannons fired tear gas at rock-throwing protesters outside the presidential palace in Cairo
Carrying Egyptian flags and pictures of slain protesters, demonstrators took to the streets in Cairo, Alexandria, the restive Suez Canal city of Port Said and several Nile Delta cities

Thousands of Egyptians marched across the country on Friday to denounce the rule of Islamist President Mohammed Morsi and his fundamentalist Muslim Brotherhood. In Alexandria, protesters tore down a Brotherhood sign at the groups office and set it on fire. 20 injured.
In Tanta security forces fired tear gas canisters in clashes with rock-throwing protesters. 65 injured.

Egyptian police on Friday fired tear gas at protesters who lobbed petrol bombs and set off fireworks outside the presidential palace, amid nationwide rallies against President Mohamed Morsi. Spokesman for the Ministry of Health stated one person dead and 216 injured across country.
Police used teargas bombs to prevent an attempt at freeing 13 defendants charged of killing a police captain.

Dozens of youth gathered in front of the public governors office, protesting against the fact that they were not given jobs as part of the cities recent 500 Jobs Contest initiative. Protesters attempted to block the Al-Arish/Rafah Road when they were surrounded by security forces attempting to protect the entrances and exits to the governors office.
A number of protesters shut down Tahrirs Mogamma on Sunday to voice their demands.

A number of debtors to the Principal Bank for Development and Agricultural Credit protested outside the banks branch in Bir Al-Abd, claiming that they had not received the same debt relief package provided to other farmers in the city.

Hundreds of police personnel in the Kafr Al-Sheikh governorate closed down the security directorate building and blocked traffic in front of it. They demanded retribution for police officers killed and demanded security procedures be reconsidered to allow officers be armed
A number of vendors in the cities main market succeeded in blocking the Al-Arish/Rafah road in protest against the local governments recent decision to impose new fees on their businesses.

Relatives of Nasir Al-Shafai, who was recently arrested for his alleged involvement in violent events that occurred in Suez on the second anniversary of the 25 January Revolution, marched on Sunday, to the cities Al-Wafd Party headquarters, demanding party officials intervene to help secure his release.
Masked men blocked trains at a central Cairo subway station, standing on tracks and getting into fistfights with some waiting passengers who tried to stop them.
The 6 April Youth Movement (Ahmed Maher Front) conducted a march in Downtown Cairo, vowing an escalation of peaceful protests, before the larger marches took place.

About 1,000 protesters gathered in central Cairos Tahrir Square, a protest hub. ""The revolution continues"" read some banners, as others chanted ""After blood has been spilled, there is no legitimacy.""

Security forces sprayed protesters with water hoses and tear gas outside the presidential palace. Some protesters broke out in chants: ""The people want to bring down the regime,"" while others responded by throwing stones.
Hundreds of government opponents marched through the streets of Alexandria.

Protesters locked shut the doors of the main administrative building for state services just outside the station at Tahrir Square, while others blocked traffic at a main bridge on the other side of town near the presidential palace by standing in the road.

Dozens of policemen rallied Tuesday outside local security administration headquarters in at least 10 provinces, holding protests to demand they not be used as a tool for political oppression in the countries ongoing turmoil.
Nearly 1,000 women gathered in Cairo to denounce recent sexual assaults.

Arrests: Six activists were arrested by police on Tuesday evening in a cafe at Raml Station in Alexandria. Journalist Ahmed Mohamed Refaat was detained, along with Islam Mahmoud Saleh, Yousry Al-Nagar, Al-Sayyed Ali, Gamil Al-Shaary, and Atef Al-Asmar. The six were politically active and members of various opposition groups and movements,

Non-violent activity: The Egyptian Cabinet approved on Wednesday a new law governing protests. Cairo Insitute for Human Rights Studies claims ""The draft law stipulates that protesters must submit a notification at least five days in advance, ignoring the spontaneous nature these protests often have.""
Christian farmer Ishaq Azizs 17-year-old daughter Nirmeen went missing on Valentines Day, fueling speculation that she has converted and will reappear with a Muslim husband once she turns 18.

In the latest allegation of a detainee dying from abuse, Mahienour el-Masry, a local activist who is following the case, said 35-year-old Hassan Shaaban was picked up by police near a protest area last week but was continuously denied his diabetes and heart medication. He was reported dead Thursday.

column16: Arabic Network for Human Rights Information
column17: The Arabic Network for Human Rights Information (ANHRI) said a number of assaults on journalists occurred last Friday, including an attack on Alaa AbdulBari, a photographer for Nisf El-Dounia magazine . Another photographer, Eman Helal from Al-Masry Al-Youm, was harassed by protesters while covering the ""protest against violence"", organised by Islamic groups in support of the president. ANHRI said Helal was targeted ""because she is a woman"".
Weapons Seizure: Egyptian security officials say they have seized two tons of explosives headed to the Sinai Peninsula.

In a show of support for the president on Friday, around 5,000 Islamist supporters of the Gamaa Islameya (Islamic Group) and its political arm (the Building and Development Party) gathered in Al Nahda Square in front of Cairo University for a rally dubbed ""No to violence.""
Another march headed to the main courthouse to demand justice for a 12 year-old vendor killed by the military earlier this month.

column16: Egypt State Information Service; AFP; AP; The Middle East Journal; Daily News (Egypt)
column17: Several thousand people descended on the Defense Ministry calling for retribution for the deaths of protesters during military rule. Eyewitnesses reported that members of Ultras Ahlawy attacked activists during the protest

In Alexandria, protesters marched from the Al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque and gathered in front of the house of detained activist Hassan Mostafa in the Moharram Bey district calling for his release. Mostafa was taken into custody three weeks ago after he went to a prosecution office to file a complaint stating that activists were being detained without following the required legal procedures for the detention and without undertaking any investigations.
A small protest was also held in Al-Mamar Square of Ismailia, where protesters gathered after Friday prayers chanting slogans criticising the Muslim Brotherhood and Morsis rule in Egypt.

column16: Nile News TV; Egyptian Organization for Human Rights
column17: Demonstrators torch school in Al-Santah city, burn tires along highway, prompting response by security forces;peaceful demonstrations in Tanta with exception of attack on school - Al-Santah, attack on school in which MB members where meeting, continued altercations between demonstrators. Among those arrested were 15 children, according to Egyptian Organization for Human Rights (EOHR)

South Rafah residents held a poetry reading on Friday night in protest over Law 203, passed by Egypts Defense Minister last December, which prevents residents from owning or using land within five kilometers of Sinais eastern border with Israel.

Protesters were beaten and handed to security forces by street vendors in Downtown Cairo on Saturday, after they allegedly attempted to break into the Cairo Appeals Court, Located in the Egyptian High Court of Justice building.
Scores of members of revolutionary movements stage protest in Suez to demand realization of revolutions goals, release of detained revolutionaries, denounce attempts to intimidate opposition in Suez.

Scores of opposition activists demonstrate in Kafr al-Shaykh to demand realization of revolutions goals amid heavy security presence near state establishments. Demonstrators hurled stones at security forces guarding governors office, stormed foyer of local council building, security forces did not converge on scene to avoid escalation.
In Al-Minufiyah Governorate, opposition forces organised demonstrations to demand realization of the revolutions goal amid heavy security presence around state institutions.
Port Said channel correspondent reported small demonstrations, noted the death of a demonstrator who was hit by stray bullet near police station.

In Al-Gharbiyah Governorate, hundreds of demonstrators hurl stones at members of Al-Mahallah City Council, attempt to storm councils offices amid strict measures by security forces. Protesters hurled rocks and Molotov cocktails at the building and security forces, who responded by firing warning shots in the air and teargas bombs. Protesters blocked Al-Bahr Street using car tires, disrupting traffic and transportation within the city. On Friday, hundreds protested against President Mohamed Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood at Al-Bahr Street, blocking the street and preventing cars from passing through. A driver hit four protesters and ran over 14 year-old protester, Mahmoud El-Qott as he passed through the street.El-Qott was transferred to hospital, but died shortly after he arrived.

A group of Saharawi students, organized after Friday Prayer a sit-in, in which they denounced the Moroccan military trial of the 24 Saharawi political prisoners of Gdeim Izik. The sit-in, which was organized at Tahrir Square in the capital Cairo, was attended by dozens of Egyptian citizens

column16: Daily News (Egypt); Egypt State Information Service; The Middle East Journal; AFP; AP
column17: Around 1,000 liberal activists rallied outside the Qasr al-Kobba palace, one of the presidents secondary palaces. Police fired tear gas to disperse the crowd who tried to scale its walls. Hundreds of protesters threw stones at the palace, while the security forces responded with water cannons. Thirty protesters, including a number of minors were detained.

A number of marches were staged from the Al-Qaid Ibrahim Mosque in Alexandria against the Muslim Brotherhood and the Interior Ministry. Protesters also marched from the Al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque and gathered in front of the house of detained activist Hassan Mostafa in the Moharram Bey district calling for his release. Mostafa was taken into custody three weeks ago after he went to a prosecution office to file a complaint stating that activists were being detained without following the required legal procedures for the detention and without undertaking any investigations.

Calm prevails at Tahrir Square, while it is still closed to traffic. Al-Tawfiqiyah area locals disperse demonstration outside High Court of Justice demanding prosecution of those responsible for killing a demonstrator.

Non-violent activity: Egypt will arm low ranking policemen with pistols, a security source said on Saturday, after they held protests demanding weapons and better work conditions amid a spike in violent crime.
On Saturday, police and civilian mourners at the funeral of a police captain who died the previous night in a gunfight, badly beat a man they believed was involved in the shooting, witnesses said.

After days of protests and strikes conducted by police warrant officers, Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim agreed to 19 of the protesters demands.The nationwide strike primarily demanded the repeal of the protest law passed by the Shura Council, Egypts upper house of parliament. The new protest law bans military and police personnel from engaging in any acts of protest, which includes strikes and sit-ins. The striking policemen also demanded the removal of the Minister of Interior from the cabinet. Dozens are participating in the strike in Assiut, Luxor, Aswan and North Sinai while hundreds did so in Monufia and Qalyubia. Several cities, including Mansoura and Beni Suef, saw policemen temporarily suspend their sit-in to give authorities time to respond to their demands.

The new protest law bans military and police personnel from engaging in any acts of protest, which includes strikes and sit-ins. The striking policemen also demanded the removal of the Minister of Interior from the cabinet. Dozens are participating in the strike in Assiut, Luxor, Aswan and North Sinai while hundreds did so in Monufia and Qalyubia. Several cities, including Mansoura and Beni Suef, saw policemen temporarily suspend their sit-in to give authorities time to respond to their demands.

column9: FFPC: Free Front for Peaceful Change
column17: Member of the Free Front for Peaceful Change (FFPC) movement Ibrahim Hanafi was abducted and tortured in Sharqiya, allegedly by Muslim Brotherhood members.

Father Mikhail of the Fayoum Archbishopric has denied claims of an attack on the church. A group of assailants allegedly hurled stones at the church in the village of Sarsena, in the Tamiya district, in Fayoum

A conference for the National Salvation Front (NSF) in Suez was attacked on Friday by unidentified men. The conference was nearing its end when anti-NSF chants were heard outside, coming from men Amin described as ""bearded"". Soon afterwards, two men got out of a car and fired two shots at the podium and three shots in the air.

Violent clashes broke out between protesters and security forces in Mahalla on Saturday after the death of a 14 year-old protester on Friday. Mahmoud Haroun, an activist and Mahalla resident, said that security forces from the nearby Mahalla Second Police Station became angry at the protesters chants and attempted to disperse them. Clashes broke out between both sides, leaving 36 injured,Haroun claimed that security forces used teargas and birdshot during the clashes, adding that most of the injuries were caused by birdshot.

Security source at Interior Ministry reports arresting 57 rioters in Cairo, Al-Gharbiyah, Alexandria governorates. Source says 30 arrested outside Al-Qubbah Palace, including one in possession of gun.

Security source at Interior Ministry reports arresting 57 rioters in Cairo, Al-Gharbiyah, Alexandria governorates. Source says 30 arrested outside Al-Qubbah Palace, including one in possession of gun.

A funeral for Egyptian police officer Hisham Tema took place in Beni Sweif on Saturday. Tema was injured during his attempt to settle an armed clash between two families in el-Ghamrawi and Ezbat el-Safeeh areas. He passed away in hospital after one hour as he sustained serious injuries. (Date of death unspecified)

Hundreds of Ultras Ahlawi youths demonstrate in Port Said to call for civil disobedience. Hundreds of anti-government protesters blocked central roads and work was halted for a second day in Egypts restive coastal city of Port Said,
Report on Egyptian police officers deliberately killing an arrested man suspected of killing one of their colleagues
Hundreds of anti-government protesters have blocked central roads and work was halted for a second day in Egypts restive coastal city of Port Said,

Dozens of protesters held a silent demonstration on Sunday in front of the Forensic Medical Authority in Cairo, to reject reports issued by the authority for those who died during several incidents since the 2011 Revolution. Protesters claimed the authority is corrupt and partial, accusing it of forging reports to hide the truth behind the cause of death for many revolutionary figures. Several revolutionary groups participated in the demonstration, including NWT, the Our Name is Mohamed El-Gendy campaign, Essam Atta group, and the Popular Current.NWT held a press conference on Saturday, where it stated there were 800 detention and 70 death cases occurred in Egypt during the period from 25 January to 11 February 2013. NWT claimed that detentions included 400 minors, adding that detainees were tortured and assaulted physically and sexually.

A strike by workers at the Portland Cement Factory in Alexandria was violently dissolved as it entered its fourth day on Monday by the security forces, who allegedly used dogs to disperse the workers. At least 28 workers were arrested in the aftermath of the security forces attack, stated the Egyptian Centre for Economic and Social Rights (ECESR).

Security source at Interior Ministry reports arresting 57 rioters in Cairo, Al-Gharbiyah, Alexandria governorates. Source says 30 arrested outside Al-Qubbah Palace, including one in possession of gun.

Thousands of soccer fans and anti-government protesters blocked roads and enforced a work stoppage in Egypts restive city of Port Said to protest ""injustices"" by the government, disrupting rail services and forcefully evicting workers from their factories and the provincial governments offices. The ""Green Eagles"" fan club also disrupted work in the Mediterranean cities main telephone exchange and sent students home from several schools in their Sunday protest.
Arrests: The state prosecution authority ordered the detention of Islamist preacher and TV anchor Abu Islam on Sunday, in order to investigate him on charges of contempt of Christianity.

Ayman Mahni also claimed in an online video he was tortured and raped by the police after his arrest in Alexandria. Mahni stated he was on his way to pay his telephone bill on 3 February, when he came across a rally protesting the beating of Hamada Saber. Mahni claimed he was randomly arrested and taken to a Central Security Forces camp where they frequently tied his hands and covered his face with a black bag. Mahni claimed he was told he would be released if he confessed to being a Black Bloc member. He said he was electrocuted and tortured as well.

Karim Nasser, a protester arrested for allegedly rioting and attacking authorities, claimed he was sexually assaulted while in police custody. He filed a report to the prosecutor general, claiming to have been tortured and sexually assaulted inside New Cairo Police Station after his arrest on 8 February. Nasser claimed he was subjected to torture and rape alongside at least 20 other detained men. A medical report revealed anal injuries and also showed that Nassers left arm was dislocated after he was suspended from the arm while being tortured.

In the southern province of Assiut, private minibus drivers who operate local transportation lines have protested a lack of diesel for the past few days, waiting in a parking lot for hours and threatening to block railroads if diesel is not made available.
Mahalla also witnessed another round of protests, where protesters gathered in front of the city council building calling for civil disobedience.

Demonstrations in front of the courthouse in solidarity with Osama El-Refaey, member of the Al-Dostour Party, who was arrested last week in Beheira on charges of attempting to burn a government building, according to his lawyer, Mohammed Abouelela. Trial postponed.

Kafr El-Sheikh followed in the footsteps of the canal cities, with its first day of civil disobedience on Tuesday as protesters closed down the governorate building, Tax Authority, and the insurance directorate. A spokesperson for the 6 of April movement (the Ahmed Maher front) in Kafr El-Sheikh, affirmed the protesters demands and added that they initially took to the streets in solidarity with the residents of Port Said.

Egypts Ministry of Interior appealed on Tuesday to the protesters holding a sit-in at Tahrir Square to open the square and help the government operate the traffic in the area.Political movements and parties have started an open-ended sit-in at Tahrir Square since November, following a constitutional decree issued by President Mohamed Mursi which gave him sweeping powers and shielded his decisions from court challenges.

A third day of protests and strikes brought the restive city of Port Said to a halt on Tuesday, as demonstrators demanded security officials be held accountable for the killings of over 40 residents in riots last month.
Members of the Awlad Ali tribe protested on Wednesday in front of the Prosecutor Generals office, demanding that Judge Ahmed El-Zend, head of Egypts Judges Club, has his judicial immunity removed.

Scores of Copts on Wednesday evening organised a protest inside the Abbasiya Cathedral in Cairo following Pope Tawadros II recent statement to the Middle East newspaper that civil disobedience in pointless.

Tens of women gathered on Wednesday in front of the Prosecutor Generals office, in the High Court complex, protesting against statements insulting women made by several high profile figures recently.Protesters brandished signs expressing their anger over government policies and stating their demands. They criticised the Shura Council for the recent statements it has made about women, blaming women protesters for sexual harassment and claiming that women should not participate in protests.Shahenda Maqlad, a prominent female activist and the secretary general of the Farmers Union, attended the protest. Maqlad came to prominence after a Morsi supporter was photographed forcibly shutting her mouth during protests at the Itihadiya presidential palace two months ago.
In Ismailia protesters gathered on Wednesday morning in front of the governorate building and the city council in solidarity with Port Said.

A strike in Port Said entered its fourth day on Wednesday as Egyptian demonstrators demanding justice for protesters killed by police shrugged off a government pledge to inject money into the canal city. The protesters are demanding justice for at least 40 demonstrators killed in clashes with police in late January after a court sentenced 21 Port Said soccer fans to death over a deadly football riot last year.

In Al-Ismailiyah Governorate, political activists continue to encourage civil disobedience near state establishments, schools to demand governments ouster, formation of national salvation government, political guarantees of fair parliamentary elections. Senior Army commander warns that locals would bear costs of any civil disobedience.

Civil disobedience in Port Said entered the fifth day on Thursday, with popular movements calling for escalations.An Aswat Masriya reporter said that ports remain shut, leading to financial losses that severely affect the already ailing economy of the Middle Easts most populous country.Eighty percent of schools in Port Said have suspended their classes where attendance is at 50 percent while many markets are closed and streets are empty.

Scores of protesters on Friday chanted slogans in Cairos Tahrir Square calling for the intervention of the Egyptian army, an Aswat Masriya witness reported. Hundreds gathered in the square to protest against the rule of President Mohamed Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood.
Hundreds of demonstrators took to the streets of Port Said on Friday to demand justice for protesters killed by Egyptian police, as a strike in the Suez Canal city entered its sixth day.

In Damietta protesters used more peaceful methods as they launched the ""I am not paying"" campaign and formed a human chain from Saa Square, extending across the entire corniche, state-owned Al-Ahram reported.

In the city of Mahalla, protesters blocked the main road near Shoan Square by burning tyres, demanding President Mohamed Morsis regime ""be put on trial for its crimes"" and chanting against the policeProtesters also closed down all shops in the square. Security forces attempted to disperse the demonstrations which resulted in clashes with protesters throwing rocks at police who are launching teargas canisters from within armoured vehicles. Hundreds of protesters attacked the police station with rocks and Molotov cocktails on Friday, leaving several police officers injured.

A protest was held in front of the prosecutor generals office on Saturday, calling for finding Mohamed El-Sawy, a journalist at the Masrawy news outlet, who was reportedly kidnapped on Wednesday and punishing his kidnappers.

The workers in Port Saids marine shipyard, the employees of transport companies and the management of the Suez Canal Movement Authority, all declared on Saturday, the seventh day of civil disobedience, that they will join the disobedience, saying they will not be secluded from the demands of the people of Port Said. An Aswat Masriya eyewitness said that civilians closed all the customs ports and prevented the entry and exit of all cars except for the ambulances.

Four political prisoners held in the Tura Reception facility have begun a hunger strike in protest over conditions in the prison and poor treatment at the hands of guards, according to prisoners families.all four prisoners had been placed under 23 hour lockdown in one cell located within the facilitys al-Dawai prison block. Units in this block are 2 square metres in size, and have no ventilation or access to water.Inmates also experienced verbal abuse at the hands of police and guards, according to Alam.

A general strike in the canal city of Port Said, meanwhile, entered its second week on Sunday, with most shops and factories closed down. Protesters in the Mediterranean city have entered the eighth day of civil disobedience on 24 February. Demonstrators block all roads and railway traffic, cut off all transportation from and to the coastal city.

In the northern city of Kafr el-Sheikh, hundreds of quarry workers stormed the governorate headquarters to protest against working conditions and forced employees out of the building, chanting against governor Saad al-Husseini, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood.

Thousands of brick workers blocked railroad tracks from a southern city to Cairo for a second day Sunday to protest rising industrial oil prices, causing the cancellation of some services, security officials said.
In Giza, protesters gathered on Sunday night in front of the governorate building blocking Al-Haram Street and calling for civil disobedience.
An HSBC bank branch manager was beaten by a group of military officers following an argument between bank employees and an officer on Sunday.

Protesters on Sunday blocked the doors to Cairos main administrative building as part of a growing campaign of civil disobedience around the country against Islamist President Mohamed Morsi.A group of protesters closed the doors of the Mugamma, a massive labyrinth of bureaucratic offices on the edge of Tahrir Square, leaving only a side exit for employees to leave, employees told AFP
Mahalla trains resumed service on Sunday after protesters blocked the cities railways for almost an hour, in an attempt to implement civil disobedience in the city.

A church in Shubra Al-Kheima was surrounded on Monday evening amid attempts to carry out legal reconstruction of the building.Abu Makkar church was in the process of constructing an annex for the building when Salafis surrounded the premises in an effort to halt work on the new addition.

For the third consecutive day, families of prisoners in Sinai blocked off the Al-Arish central Sinai road in southern al-Arish, preventing night shift workers from arriving at cement factories in the centre of the peninsula.

Port Saids continuing civil disobedience has entered its ninth day, with protesters continuing to block roads and shutting down government buildings.Three of the regions largest maritime shipping lines, CMA-CGM from France, COSCO from China, and MAERSK Line from Denmark, have redirected their cargoes from Port Said to the Israeli port of Eilat,

Missing activist Mohamed El-Shafaai was identified at the Zeinhom morgue in Cairo on Sunday evening. The cause of death was two bullet wounds, one of which was to the head.El-Shafaai was reportedly still alive when found, but succumbed to his wounds at Al-Helal hospitaThe circumstances surrounding El-Shafaais death are still obscure,El-Shafaai had been missing for over three weeks before he was identified in the morgue.

Security forces in Daqahliya on Monday teargassed protesters who gathered around the city council building and attacked security forces. The demonstrators stopped traffic in al-Geish street near the building and hurled stones at security forces.
Demonstrations are staged in Cairo against the Ikhwanization [consolidation of power of the Muslim Brotherhood] of the army.
Weapons Seizure: White weapons (knives and swords) and Molotov cocktails seized in Tahrir Square in acquisition of outlaws

Around 300 members of the 6 April Youth Movement gathered in a protest outside the courthouse in Minya on Tuesday afternoon,demanding justice for the death of one of their members, 17-year-old Gaber ""Jika"" Salah, who was shot in the back during clashes between protestors and police on Mohamed Mahmoud Street last November.

In Daqahleya, clashes took place at noon on Monday in front of the governorate building.16 protesters were arrested, 14 of them minors, while three journalists were attacked, according to 6 April activist Wael Ghareeb, by Muslim Brotherhood members. Police forces dispersed the clashes using teargas bombs.

An Egyptian security official says protesters have thrown firebombs and rocks at police who tried to re-open Cairos central Tahrir Square, where a sit-in has brought downtown traffic to a standstill for nearly three months. Around 70 protesters and street vendors were arrested during the skirmish at Tahrir. At least 13 children were among the 56 arrested when security forces raided Tahrir Square early on Tuesday morning.The report stated that the ages of the detained children ranged between 12 and 18.

A number of the countries power stations were shut down on Tuesday after residents surrounded the facilities and demanded jobs for their relatives. Stations in Banha, Ain Sokhna and North Giza had shut down operations for the third day in a row.

A sit-in began on Tuesday night in the city of El-Sheikh Zuweid in North Sinai calling on the cities residents, along with those in Rafah and Central Sinai, to protest for 10 days in hopes that their demands would be heard and brought before President Mohamed Morsy.The sit-in was held in a public park in one of the cities squares, and was attended by dozens of tribesmen and political activists.

A protest also occurred in Matariya of Daqahleya when protesters surround the city council building, expressing solidarity with the cities joining in with the civil disobedience. No violence was reported following the protest.

A number of protesters were injured on Tuesday in Mansoura, in the governorate of Daqahleya, following violent clashes that broke out between protesters and Central Security Forces (CSF).During the clashes CSF reportedly used extensive amounts of teargas, in addition to birdshot, while protesters threw Molotov cocktails and rocks at security forces.

Violent clashes broke out on Wednesday in Damietta between security forces fending a police station and family members of a dead victim who seek vengeance from the murderer who is arrested in the stationAn Aswat Masriya witness said that the police forces fired gunshots and teargas bombs to disperse the raged family members who want to take the law into their own hands. He said that the situation keeps getting worse.

A number of the countries power stations were shut down on Tuesday after residents surrounded the facilities and demanded jobs for their relatives. Stations in Banha, Ain Sokhna and North Giza had shut down operations for the third day in a row.

A number of the countries power stations were shut down on Tuesday after residents surrounded the facilities and demanded jobs for their relatives. Stations in Banha, Ain Sokhna and North Giza had shut down operations for the third day in a row.
Protesters in Cairos Nasr City demanded on Friday the Armed Forces intervention against the rule of President Mohamed Mursi under the slogan ""No to the brotherhoodization of the army.""
Hundreds of people turned out in Tahrir Square on Friday to protest against President Mohamed Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood.

Clashes erupted when dozens of residents threw firebombs and rocks at police. In anticipation of renewed clashes, police had set up checkpoints and increased their presence around the Mar Girgis church in Aswan. The clashes resumed on Friday afternoon between the police forces and protesters who accused the church of kidnapping a Muslim woman with the intention of converting her to Christianity. They also tried to storm into the church which caused the injury of three, one of them a police officer. The security forces threw teargas bombs to disperse the protesters.

Dozens staged protests on Friday in front of Abdeen Palace in downtown Cairo to demand allowing bearded police officers back to work. A number of Salafi (ultraconservative) Parties joined the protests dubbed ""No to exclusion.""
Last Friday, journalists protested in front of the syndicate over the death of fellow journalist Al-Hosseini Abu Deif last December.

The Press Syndicate issued a statement on Sunday condemning the attack on syndicate president Mamdouh Al-Wali by journalists protesting outside the syndicate building. The attack took place on Friday as Al-Wali attempted to enter the syndicate.
Demonstration takes place in Alexandria to protest economic situation. Demonstrators raise slogans protesting attempts to ""dominate country by Muslim Brotherhood"";

Police arrested six persons who threw petrol bombs and stones at Mar Girgis church in Aswan. The clashes resumed on Friday afternoon between the police forces and protesters who accused the church of kidnapping a Muslim woman with the intention of converting her to Christianity. They also tried to storm into the church which caused the injury of three, one of them a police officer. The security forces threw teargas bombs to disperse the protesters. Major General Hassan Abdul-Hay, security chief of Aswan, told reporters late Saturday that ""family and social reasons,"" not religion, were behind her disappearance, and she had not converted.

Kom Ombos church, Mar Girgis, has been under attack for the past three days from what residents described as ""unknown assailants."" Mostly in their teens, hundreds of young boys and men have been surrounding the church, showering it with rocks and Molotov cocktails, with Central Security Forces (CSF) trucks and soldiers fighting the assailants with teargas grenades.

The violence is not only limited to the church. Seventeen-year-old Copt Abanob, whose arm was covered with medical bandages, explained he was attacked by a young man also in his teens who had first asked him whether or not he was Christian.

Students at the British University in Egypt (BUE) took control of the university auditorium on Saturday, demanding the current administration resign over allegations of corruption. The students are accusing the administration of squandering student funds and being part of the former regime.

Hundreds of protesters were marching towards Alexandrias local city council in the Kom El-Dekka district, where they planned to hold a protest, when several men attacked them with knives and fireworks, leaving some injured.

Hundreds protested in Talaat Harb Square in Downtown Cairo on Saturday against President Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood, in solidarity with the citizen killed by Central Security Forces (CSF) in Mansoura on Friday. During the protest, minor clashes broke out between protesters and street vendors, who accused protesters of paralysing their work. Arguments also took place between protesters and car drivers who were angry because the protest caused traffic jam.

Hundreds of protesters were marching towards Alexandrias local city council in the Kom El-Dekka district, where they planned to hold a protest, when several men attacked them with knives and fireworks, leaving some injured. Two protesters were injured and received treatment immediately, while the remaining protesters fell back, ending their march.
Demonstrations take place outside Interior Ministry to protest visit of US secretary of state to Egypt.
Security agencies in Suhaj foil attempt to break into police department by unidentified individuals protesting dismissal of chief detective.

column16: Daily News (Egypt); Al Ahram; AP; AFP
column17: Also Saturday, a police car in the restive Suez Canal city of Port Said when the protesters refused to allow a police car passage, the driver fired warning shots into the air and rammed into the crowd, hitting five people. The protesters, who are angry with the police, then torched a number of vehicles at a nearby police station, the AP reporter said.Several hundred protesters then threw firebombs at the nearby police station, causing part of it to catch fire.

Egypts Interior Ministry, which oversees the countries police force, said a protester died and dozens were wounded before dawn Saturday in Mansoura where about 400 people protested outside the local council office. The ministry said protesters were chanting anti-government slogans before they cut off a main road and threw firebombs at the building. Activists there told The Associated Press that a protester, Hossam Eldin Abdullah Abdelazim, was killed when an armored police vehicle crushed him to death during the clashes. A funeral was held for him later in the day. One report suggests 4 people were killed, another report claims 2 others died.

column16: Agence Tunis Afrique Presse; AFP; AP
column17: A policeman was killed Sunday and an army officer was wounded when they were struck by gunshots fired by unknown assailants outside the headquarters of the Port Said governorate in northeast Egypt. Fighting throughout the day Sunday killed two policemen and three civilians as protesters pelted police forces with rocks and fire bombs and the force responded with tear gas, and birdshots, while military troops got caught in the middle trying to stop the violence. One report suggested 6 people died. Up to 600 people were injured.

Residents of the governorates of Qena, Aswan and Al-Sharqeya blocked railways and roads on Sunday morning in protest over the fuel shortage. Groups in Zagazig, Al-Sharqeya, also blocked the railroad for some hours. Yasser Al-Refaei, a Revolutionary Youth Coalition representative in Al-Sharqeya, said the groups resolved the blockage after negotiations with governmental officials. Two families quarrelled over their places in a long queue at a gas station, which then escalated into violent fighting. Both families used weapons, leaving two people dead and five others injured.

In Sundays protest at Misr International University, students demanded a pedestrians bridge outside the university gate to prevent accidents. Protesting students marched to University Deputy Chariman, Hassans office to put forward their demand. They claim to have been stopped by the security personnel.

The offices of the Popular Current and Social Popular Alliance Party, located at the nearby Suez Canal Street, were used as field hospitals and treated injured protesters.El-Shaer said the CSF fired teargas bombs into the building where both offices are located, before breaking into the Social Popular Alliance Partys office, destroying it, and arresting several people. He added that the CSF broke into the Popular Current office 15 minutes later, destroying the office and beating doctors and patients inside.

Massive demonstration takes place in Al-Daqahliyah Governorate to denounce acts of violence. Demonstrators criticize security men's way of dealing with protesters, call for dissolving current government.
Elsewhere in Egypt, dozens of protesters blocked el-Bahr street at the Shoon Square in Gharbiyas Mahalla city with burning tires and roadblocks. Protesters also hurled stones at passing cars.
Security forces stormed Cairos Tahrir Square at dawn to open it to traffic.According to the TV, 39 people were arrested with guns, Molotov cocktails and tear gas in their possession.

Hundreds of Egyptian football fans briefly blocked a main road to Cairos international airport on Sunday, forcing a delay in visiting US Secretary of State John Kerrys departure, an airport official saidThe Al-Ahly fans blocked the road in anticipation of a court ruling this weekend in which rival supporters in Port Said face sentencing over a deadly post-match riot. The Al-Ahly fans want them convicted.

Protesters threw petrol bombs and stones at the police station in Port Said after the authorities decided to move prisoners awaiting a verdict over alleged involvement in a deadly football riot. Police responded with tear gas. 253 people were injured in the clashes.
Protesters in Ismailia near the vital Suez Canal block the main road and try to block the railway, announcing they are joining the civil disobedience campaign seen in nearby cities.
Ittihad of Alexandria players have boycotted the clubs training session on Sunday to protest non-payment of their salaries.

Violent clashes between police forces and civilians broke out late Sunday in front of the InterContinental Semiramis Hotel on Cairos Nile Corniche. Al-Ahrams Arabic-language news portal reported that a number of rioters near Abdel-Moneim Riyad Square had set a police vehicle ablaze, before Central Security Forces replied with teargas.

Residents of the governorates of Qena, Aswan and Al-Sharqeya blocked railways and roads on Sunday morning in protest over the fuel shortage. In Aswan, drivers blocked Al-Sadat road after they were unable to fill their fuel tanks, reported state-owned Al-Ahram. Security officials were able to clear the blockage an hour later.

Residents of the governorates of Qena, Aswan and Al-Sharqeya blocked railways and roads on Sunday morning in protest over the fuel shortage. In Nag Hammadi, Qena, tens of taxi drivers and farmers blocked the railway from 7 am on Sunday, Governmental officials negotiated with the protesters and by noon had convinced them to resolve the blockage.

Protests broke out in Mansoura city on Sunday in reaction to the violent clashes the city has witnessed during recent days. The clashes began when mourners threw rocks at security forces located at one of Mansouras prisons, as they passed by the prison on their way from Al-Nasr mosque towards the Abdel Azeem families cemetery. Security forces fired cautionary gunshots in the air and clashes ended as mourners moved on towards the cemetery.Hours later, violent clashes again broke out between hundreds of protesters gathered at Al-Thawra Square and CSF members. Protesters hurled rocks at the CSF who fired an extensive amount of teargas bombs and birdshot

Protesters reopened on Monday Cairos ""6 of October Bridge"" to traffic after it was closed for around an hour. Protesters had stopped a police vehicle and set fire to the car, which halted the traffic on the bridge.
Muslims set fire to the house of a Coptic Christian, who was accused of molesting a neighbor child, adding to sectarian tensions in Egypts south.

Thousands of residents of the restive Suez Canal city of Port Said in eastern Egypt rallied Monday in a funeral procession for civilians killed during street battles with security forces, as military police deployed to secure the gathering.

The Media Official for the Security Forces said on Monday that unknown assailants fired random gunshots at the police forces and the army assigned the secure Port Said, injuring a number of soldiers. An Aswat Masriya eyewitness said earlier that the police forces fired teargas bombs at armored vehicles that belong to the army.

Hundreds of members of the hardcore soccer fans (Ultras Alexandria) besieged the headquarters of the Central Bank and cut off a main road in Alexandria. There were no acts of vandalism or any damages in the bank.The banks siege lasted for about 40 minutes, paralyzing the traffic in the area.
Meanwhile, the Niles Courniche downtown withstands chasing between the security forces and the protesters, as they hurl stones at each other for the second day in a row.

Tension between students and the administration at Misr International University (MIU) over road safety measures reached a peak on Monday.Protesting students gathered on Monday to condemn the referral of 12 students to investigation.

Workers from National Societe Generale Bank (NSGB) held a protest outside bank headquarters in downtown Cairo. The strike was organised by an independent workers union to prevent the sale of NSGB to the Qatar National Bank.

The 6 April Movement announced on Monday that Khaled Al-Aqqad, a movement member, has been missing for five days. 6 April accused Homeland Security (formerly State Security) and the Ministry of Interior of being behind his disappearance.

Parts of a government complex were set on fire as protesters throwing stones and firebombs clashed with police firing tear gas and birdshot Monday in a new day of clashes that have caught the military in the middle of fighting in the restive Egyptian city of Port Said.The renewed clashes came hours after thousands of city residents rallied in a funeral procession. Two more protesters died as a result of the Monday clashes between police and protesters. Al-Sayad said one of those who died was not involved in the clashes and was killed by live bullets fired by police. A Ministry of Interior official stated that one policeman died Monday as a result of injuries sustained during Sundays clashes.

Clashes also broke out on Tuesday near Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo between police and demonstrators, who gathered for the funeral of an activist, Mohamed El-Shafaai, killed during protests in January and whose body took several weeks to identify.

Police officers opened fire at a family as they approached a security checkpoint in Mahalla-Samanood road, leaving the whole family dead. Police were looking for a stolen vehicle similar in description to the families car.The four killed were two parents, one of their sons, and a relative.

During the time of the funeral prayers, a protest organised by Nation Without Torture campaign took place outside the Forensic Medical Authority calling for retribution for the protesters killed as well as the prosecution of Ihsan Kameel, head of the authority, for allegedly forging medical reports,

Fresh clashes broke out on Tuesday between police and protesters in the restive Suez Canal city of Port Said, Tension was running high around the main security building, which was set ablaze on Tuesday for the second day in a row, with anti-riot police firing tear gas at protesters hurling petrol bombs. One person died from head wound caused by teargas canister fired by police during protests.

An Egyptian police officer was killed by unknown assailants on Tuesday morning in a failed attempt to raid the Ahly Bank in Old Cairo.From a white van, the assailants fired shots at the police patrol, aiming at the head of the police station but killing one of his officers instead.

Ultras Ahlawy youth raised chants against the interior ministry before clashing with the security forces in the Dokki neighborhood of Giza, The protesters and the security forces hurled stones at each other. The security forces fired teargas bombs while the protesters used fireworks.

Funeral prayers for Nassef were held inside the police mosque after which dozens of police officers temporarily blocked Salah Salem road, an essential traffic artery, in protest of the death of their colleague.
News reports say scores of youths blocked road connecting Al-Mansurah to Jamasah to protest Interior Ministrys ""violence"" towards demonstrators.

column16: Al Ahram; Daily News (Egypt); Aswat Masriya (Egypt); AP
column17: Strikes: Thousands of police officers across Egypt (including in Ismalia, Port Said, Al Mansurah, Suez, Cairo, Asyut, Luxor, Tanta, Zagazig, Al Arisk, Kafr, Qina, Minya, Alexandria, Gharbeya, Sinai) join nationwide strike calls from 5 March to protest the politicization of the force in favour of the presidents Muslim Brotherhood party and call for the dismissal of thef Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim.

Clashes re-erupted Wednesday between tens of protesters and police near the US embassy where security presence is most intense. Protesters, mostly young, blocked the Nile Corniche with a tree as they continued to throw rocks at the police.

Six people were killed and three others injured Wednesday in a fire exchange between security forces and outlaws in Egypts Gharbiya governorate, around 80 km north of the capital Cairo, official news agency MENA reported. The confrontation took place when gunmen opened fire on security forces once they saw their police vehicle, killing two of the gunmen and another four people who happened to be at the area. The police seized a stolen car and a number of machine-guns in the operation.

In Sinai, dozens of security personnel across different directorates are protesting against what they describe as ""inhumane and degrading"" working conditions. They also demand to be armed so they can defend themselves while on duty

Members of Egypts Ultras Ahlawy groups protested on Wednesday at the Giza security directorate, At least five-thousand Ultras members gathered in protest. The angry young protesters threw fireworks at the police building and set on fire an empty police truck parked outside.
Two people were also injured during clashes in Ismailia.

Strike:Hundreds of officers at three CSF camps in the Nile Delta city of Mansoura in Daqahlia governorate (located northeast of Cairo) are on strike for the second consecutive day. They are calling for the dismissal of Egypts interior minister, Mohamed Ibrahim,

Meanwhile, in the city of Mahala Kubra in the governorate of Gharbia, an aswat masriya witness said that the governorates security directorate has sent for additional security reinforcements after the clashes escalated between the security forces and protesters.
Clashes in the governorates of Dakahlia resulted in two people injured.
Acquaintances of a family killed by the police on Tuesday held a protest in Al-Shoon Square in Mahalla on Wednesday, calling for the punishment of police officers who killed the family.

A group of Damietta residents took out their anger on banners of the Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) headquarters during Mohamed El-Shafaais funeral on Tuesday. One participant stated that the procession participants smashed the FJP banners to express their anger. Tayseer Abdallah, FJP member of the Shura Council from Damietta, denied that the party headquarters was attacked.
Two intellectually disabled persons, one an orphaned minor, were arrested at random by police in early March and released with signs of physical abuse

Clashes between protesters and police have broken out in Port Said despite efforts by the military to separate the two sides. Protesters hurled stones at police, prompting the police to respond with tear gas. 157 injured.

South of the capital, in Assiut and Luxor, policemen protested what they say is new Interior Minister Mohammed Ibrahims attempts to use the force to protect the Brotherhood as part of nationwide strike calls. In Cairo, dozens of policemen blocked the entrance to one of the cities main police stations and expressed anger at Morsis policies.

South of the capital, in Assiut and Luxor, policemen protested what they say is new Interior Minister Mohammed Ibrahims attempts to use the force to protect the Brotherhood as part of nationwide strike calls. In Cairo, dozens of policemen blocked the entrance to one of the cities main police stations and expressed anger at Morsis policies.

South of the capital, in Assiut and Luxor, policemen protested what they say is new Interior Minister Mohammed Ibrahims attempts to use the force to protect the Brotherhood as part of nationwide strike calls. In Cairo, dozens of policemen blocked the entrance to one of the cities main police stations and expressed anger at Morsis policies.

Egyptian police fired tear gas at protesters as clashes resumed on Thursday in Port Said. The daily clashes resumed after protesters marched on the police headquarters. Police fired tear gas as soldiers, deployed in the city since late January, moved in to guard the police building. An Egyptian protester was shot dead and 73 people reported injured.
Striking policemen held a sit-in outside Morsis house in his hometown of Zagazig, northeast of the capital.
Central security recruits protesting in Tanta forced an Al-Jazeera television team out of the strike, accusing the Qatari-owned channel of defaming the image of the interior ministry.
The owner of the Dostour newspaper Reza Edward threatened to break up a sit-in in front of the newspaper headquarters as the sit-in entered its seventh day.

The Egyptian Coalition on Childrens Rights (ECCR) reported on Wednesday that security forces have been using children as human shields in clashes along the Nile Corniche in Downtown Cairo.The report stated that during clashes on the Corniche, police officers were putting children as young as 12 in the front lines to repel attacks by protesters, often arming these children with stones and Molotov cocktails.

Against background of demonstration by police officers to protest against holding officer, who is charged with running over citizen on 1 March, another15 days in custody, police stations in Al-Mansurah shut down
Live two-way from Alexandria with Nile TV correspondent, who says police officers staging sit-in, raising slogans criticizing Interior Ministry policy in dealing with situation.
Sporadic clashes between security forces, demonstrators take place in Nile Corniche.

Egypts Sinai Peninsula, where two British tourists were freed just hours after their kidnapping on Thursday. A military intelligence official said the couple was released unharmed after police promised the Bedouin kidnappers that they would release a detained relative who had been arrested and accused of smuggling weapons from Libya to Egypt. Security forces at South Sinai Security Directorate liberate two British tourists who were kidnapped while traveling to Ras Sidr.

Friday saw modest protests against President Mohamed Morsi and the Ministry of Interior in the Delta and Lower Egypt regions as well as Cairo and Alexandria. In Downtown Cairo hundreds gathered in Tahrir Square demanding the removal of President Morsi and the handing over of power to Supreme Constitutional Court Chairman Maher El-Behairy.

Gen. Ahmed Mahmoud Wasfi, commander of the 2nd Field Army, addressed protesters outside the main police headquarters, where the bottom floors were gutted by fire during the clashes the past week. He called on residents to call off a wave of strikes and civil disobedience that has shut down much of the work in the city the past three weeks.

Security Measures: Egypts police forces withdrew from the streets of the restive Egyptian city of Port Said on the Suez Canal and the military took over main security duties Friday, trying to calm a wave of protests and deadly clashes that turned into virtual revolt against the government.

Friday saw modest protests against President Mohamed Morsi and the Ministry of Interior in the Delta and Lower Egypt regions as well as Cairo and Alexandria. In Mansoura, the capital of Daqahleya, protesters took to the street again, surrounding the Daqahleya governorate security directorate. There have been no clashes with the police so far.

More than a thousand people marched in Downtown Cairo on Friday to mark International Womens Day, marching from Talaat Harb Square to the High Court. The protesters demanded rights for women in Egypt.
