Central Security Forces (CSF) conscripts and police NCOs are holding a sit-in, demanding the removal of Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim.

Protesters marched through Kafr El-Sheikh city in Kafr El-Sheikh governorate from the Rahma Mosque in the west and the sports stadium in the east, holding up loaves of bread signifying their dissatisfaction with the state of the economy.
Police officers shut down Muharam Beik Police Station, also demanding the removal of Ibrahim.

Clashes erupted in the Gharbeya city of Mahalla between protesters and police forces in front of the Second Mahalla Police Station, exchanging rocks and teargas canisters.Protesters surrounded the station, calling for the removal of President Morsi and Minister of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim, and the end of Muslim Brotherhood rule.

Friday saw modest protests against President Mohamed Morsi and the Ministry of Interior in the Delta and Lower Egypt regions as well as Cairo and Alexandria. Dozens of youth clashed with policemen on the nearby Qasr Al-Nil bridge and in Simon Bolivar Square near the American Embassy.
Alexandria Protesters have broken into the temporary governorate building in Alexandria. The main governorate building was abandoned following intense clashes in the area last week.

Movement of forces: A number of units were concentrated in Central Sinai, in the areas of Al-Husna, Nakhal and Al-Qasima. The units aim to control roads leading into northern and southern Sinai, Ismailia, and the Ahmed Hamdi Martyr tunnel to Suez.

Shortly after the verdict was announced Saturday, suspected fans of Cairos Al-Ahly club who had gathered in the thousands outside the teams headquarters in central Cairo went on a rampage, torching a police club nearby and storming Egypts soccer federation headquarters before setting it ablaze. The Egyptian Football Federation decided subsequently to halt all football activity in Egypt for an indefinite period, reported AlArabaiya News Channel.

Several protesters in Port Said, a strategic city at the Mediterranean end of the Suez Canal, sought to disrupt shipping in the vital waterway by releasing small speedboats into the traffic lanes, although the effort failed to disrupt shipping. Others set fire to tires on the cities dock to prevent ships from coming in, but that again was quickly abandoned.
Arrests: Security agencies arrest leading Muslim Brotherhood member in Al-Minya
Arrests: Muslim Brotherhood leader and former member of the Peoples Assembly for the Freedom and Justice Party was arrested in the Upper Egyptian governorate of Qina.

The independent Egyptian newspaper El-Watan reported on Saturday that a mob attacked and vandalised its offices in the early morning.""More than 40 people torched the entrance to the building, stormed it and destroyed its contents,"" the daily reported on its website.

In unrelated violence, at least two protesters were killed on Saturday in clashes between riot police and stone-throwing demonstrators on a Nile-side street in central Cairo. One of the dead persons suffocated from inhaling teargas and the other died from a rubber bullet wound, the source confirmed. Nineteen others were injured in the clashes near two luxury hotels and the U.S. and British embassies.

In Port Said, a city that for weeks has been in open rebellion against the Islamist president, several hundred people, many of them relatives of the defendants, gathered outside the local government offices to vent their anger. They chanted slogans against Morsis government and the verdicts.

Security Measures: Egypts Assistant to Minister of Interior in Sinai District, Osama Ismail, said on Saturday that state of emergency is declared in Sinai due to information received by the Intelligence Office stating that a group of Jihadists are planning an attack on the Police in the governorates of South and North Sinai.

Groups of masked people roamed downtown streets burning two fast-food restaurants that are rumored to belong to an Islamist Businessman, reported the Middle East News Agency.Several gunshots were heard in the area while citizens formed popular committees to protect shopping malls and houses.

Egyptian police officers closed on Saturday all the police stations in Alexandria and reduced the presence of the Central Security Forces in front of Alexandrias Security Directorate, in an escalation of their protest against the policies of the Interior Ministry for not responding to their demands.

Seven people were injured in renewed violent confrontations that took place late on Saturday by a Mahala police station in Gharbiya. Trying to raid the station, protesters hurled stones and Molotov cocktails at security forces who responded with teargas to disperse them.

Members of 6 April Youth Movement (Ahmed Maher front) gathered in front of Abdeen Court on Saturday, to protest the arrest and detainment of their members, and demanding investigations into the death of Gaber ""Jika"" Salah.
In Minya, police officers closed the gates of the security directorate.
The strike covered police stations in Cairo, Alexandria, Gharbeya, Suez Canal cities, Qena, Luxor, Sinai as well as several other governorates.
The strike covered police stations in Cairo, Alexandria, Gharbeya, Suez Canal cities, Qena, Luxor, Sinai as well as several other governorates.
Strikes:The strike covered police stations in Cairo, Alexandria, Gharbeya, Suez Canal cities, Qena, Luxor, Sinai as well as several other governorates.

Muslim Brotherhood leaders condemned the murder of a 17-year-old member who was repeatedly stabbed in the chest on Friday as he defended a girl from being sexually harassed by a small group of unknown assailants in Alexandria. Mohamed Khamis Ahmed was rushed to the hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries the next day.
Clashes also took place on Saturday, as protesters hurled rocks and Molotov cocktails at Mahalla second police station after their gathering at Al-Shoon square was attacked by armed men.
Central Security Forces (CSF) conscripts assaulted two human rights lawyers who were defending detained protesters in the Qasr El-Nile prosecution office located in Abdeen Court.

column16: Egypt State Information Service; Nile News TV
column17: Troops deployed near some embassies in downtown Cairo are being attacked by rioters, said the ministry. Clashes between protesters and security forces continued for the second day in a row following a court verdict in the so-called Port Said Stadium ""killing"" case on 9 March

column16: Egypt State Information Service; Nile News TV
column17: Minor clashes broke out at Helwan University on Sunday between students affiliated with the Muslim Brotherhood and revolutionary students a few hours prior to the student union elections beginning in the university. Eventually, confrontations broke out between the chanting students and students affiliated with the Brotherhood, according to Wessam El-Bakry, spokesperson of Soot El-Talaba.

Microbus drivers brought traffic in Giza to a standstill after initiating a strike on Sunday morning in response to the countries current diesel fuel crisis. Dozens of drivers blocked the entrance to the Ring Road on Al-Bahr Al-Azam Street in Giza and the Ring Road itself, using bricks and microbuses to prevent vehicles from entering the vital roadway.

An explosion occurred near the city of Nakhal in central Sinai on Sunday afternoon. One report claims it was launched by a group of unnamed militants.No casualties have been reported.At the time of print, it was still unclear what damage the explosion has caused, if any. A source in the Egyptian military confirmed that an explosion took place but added that investigations are currently underway to find out the reasons behind the explosion.

Dozens of protesters gathered on Sunday morning in Bir al-Abd in Northern Sinai, locking the doors to the City Council Building and preventing workers from entering while setting tires alight. They demanded that the government provide jobs for the unemployed and chanted against the Muslim Brotherhood,

In the city of Al-Arish, the Union of Unemployed Workers of Northern Sinai organised a protest on Sunday morning in front of the Public Governors Office, and demanded that job opportunities in Service Directorate positions or in the City Council be awarded to city residents.

Protesters burned a flag belonging to the Libyan Embassy in Cairo on Monday to protest the death in prison of an Egyptian Christian suspected of proselytizing in Libya. The protesters are also angry over reports that around 100 Coptic Egyptians are being held by an ultraconservative Islamist Libyan militia.

Clashes between protesters and security forces around Mahalla Second Police Station continued on Sunday, although the stations police officers are on strike.Protesters gathered in Al-Shoon Square on Sunday before moving towards the nearby Mahalla Second Police Station, which they attacked with rocks and Molotov cocktails, according to activist and Mahalla resident Mahmoud Haroun.
Protests and a sit-in in Belbeis called for the dismissal of Mayor Hassan Deba, a member of the Muslim Brotherhood.

Five detainees arrested for attempting to torch the Muslim Brotherhood headquarters in Moqattam were released on an EGP 500 bail on Tuesday.The eight detainees interrogation took place on MondayDuring his interrogation, Samir claimed that he had received a blow to the head during his arrest. The Egyptian Coalition on Childrens rights stated that four of the eight detainees are minors aged between 15 and 18 years old.

In a telephone call on 12 March to the Swedish-Eritrean radio journalist Meron EstefanosAhlam said how frightened she was as two male hostages had been brutally murdered that day in front of her eyes, and in response to her crying the kidnappers had grabbed and beaten her.
8 year old Eritrean Ahlamand her parents are victims of human trafficking in north-eastern Sinai. They have been subject to beatings.

Scores of demonstrators from Ramlat Bulaq block Nile Corniche road leading to Television, Radio building in Cairo. Demonstrators demand dismissing Cairo governor, deputy governor for not giving them substitute homes until now.
Construction workers in Suez close Al-Sukhnah Port power station, hold sit-in there to protest hiring people from outside governorate at station.

Trouble started on 12 March when female students objected to the quality of the food served and the poor state of the buildings and facilities. They held a protest, after which they were called into two meetings with officials who promised change would begin on Saturday.

At least 24 people were arrested in the aftermath of clashes with the police in front of Shebin Al-Kom court in Menufiya on Wednesday.Hundreds of Ultras Ahlawy members, Al-Ahly football club fans, surrounded Shebin Al-Kom court in Menufiya on Wednesday demanding the release of Mohamed Gamal Helal, a member of the group. Helal was arrested in front of the security directorate and was charged with vandalism and being a member of the Black Bloc group
The Coptic Youth Front held a protest on Thursday outside the Libyan embassy in Cairo demanding the release of all remaining Egyptian Christian detainees in Libya.

Students of Misr International University (MIU) entered the second day of a sit-in at the university campus, calling for cancelling the expulsion of six students, better road safety, and freedom to protest.

A civilian was killed and eight recruits were injured Wednesday as the police chased a number of armed thugs in Egypts Delta governorate of Qalyubiya, some 40 km north of the capital Cairo, Health Ministrys media spokesman Yahya Moussa told Xinhua.
Al-Ahram newspapers website reported that pro-army demonstrations were also held in Damietta in northern Egypt.

Demonstrators in Cairo and several cities on Friday protested against President Mohamed Mursi and the Muslim Brotherhood amid chants calling on the armed forces to assume power nine months after they transferred it to Mursi.
Masses of demonstrators marched in Port Said to protest against the rule of Mursi and the Brotherhood days after a court ruling that sentenced 21 to death in the 2012 Port Said football killing.

In Alexandria, hundreds of protesters headed from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the Northern Military Area in the city to demand releasing political prisoners and sacking the chief prosecutor general.Scores of people including some ""Black Bloc"" members partially halted traffic at Alexandrias Corniche, an Aswat Masriya witness reported.
Oppositionists and unemployed youths in Suez organised a demonstration in al-Arbaeen Square to demand completing the revolutions objectives and providing job opportunities for youth.
Scores gathered at al-Shoun Square in Gharbiya to protest against the regime while others demonstrated in Tantas al-Shohadaa Square and chanted anti-Mursi slogans.

22 lawyers were accused of assaulting a senior judge at a Matay court in Minya governorate after chanting against him and preventing him from entering the court. The incident was reported to have taken place in March 2013. Eyewitnesses claimed that the lawyers were ""angry at the judge for giving harsh sentences to their clients in cases of illegal constructions on agricultural land"".

The Nile Delta city of Tanta saw clashes between police and dozens of anti-government protesters Friday evening. Dozens of anti-government protesters blocked a main road and besieged the cities security directorate, as well as the governors office, Friday evening. Police forces fired rounds of teargas intermittently as clashes lasted about four hours.

Hundreds of Egyptian football fans protested outside the public prosecutors office on Saturday, demanding the release of fellow members of their Ultras hardcore fan group. Chanting and clapping in unison, the Ultras closed off the area outside the prosecutors office in central Cairo to demand the release of 38 members arrested in the Nile Delta province of Menufia for ""belonging to an illegal group.""
In addition to that, some journalists staged a protest objecting to being denied entry to the press conference.

Meanwhile, around 500 persons who belong to Islamist Parties staged protests in front of the stadium to protest the entry of anti-revolution personal into the stadium during the presidents press conference.

Mahmoud Farouq, 24, died in Al-Ahrar Hospital in Zagazig on Saturday, according to state-owned Al-Ahram. Farouq was hit in the head with a teargas canister and sustained a severe skull fracture and internal bleeding in the brain.

On Saturday, dozens of bakery owners who receive subsidized wheat from the government protested in Cairo against the austerity measures and shortages of diesel fuel. The protest was held amid economic reforms the government is seeking to boost the economy and ensure that subsidized bread reaches millions of poor Egyptians who complain that the bakeries sell the wheat for a profit

Police fired tear gas to disperse thousands of supporters and opponents of President Mohammed Morsi during clashes that erupted on Saturday as he launched development projects in southern Egyptian where residents have long complained of being neglected by the central government. The rioting came as Morsi was trying to reach out to residents of Sohag, one of Egypts poorest southern cities.

An alleged assault against journalists occurred Saturday evening outside the Brotherhoods headquarters where journalists were covering a meeting.The journalists say that after activists sprayed anti-Brotherhood graffiti on the ground outside the headquarters, the Brotherhood guards attacked with sticks and chains.

Residents of an Egyptian village beat two people suspected of crimes and left their bleeding bodies to hang in a public square, security officials said on Sunday. There were conflicting reports over the reasons for the attack in the Mahallat al-Ziad village in the Nile Delta province of Gharbiya.

Dozens of journalists are protesting against what they claim were assaults on their colleagues by members of Egypts Muslim Brotherhood from which President Mohammed Morsi hails. They protested Sunday outside the Journalists Syndicate in the Egyptian capital, Cairo
Mahalla microbus and taxi drivers blocked roadsand railways across the city on Sunday in protest to the ongoing diesel crisis in the city.
In an event in Beheira on Sunday, activists bore signs calling for the release of Mustafa and all other detainees who had been unjustly arrested.
Striking microbus drivers continued to block roads and ralways across Mahalla on Monday, in protest against the ongoing diesel crisis in the city.
Around 150 demonstrators gathered in Victoria, Alexandria, on Monday evening for a demonstration in solidarity with imprisoned activist Hassan Mustafa.
Calm prevails outside Muslim Brotherhood headquarters in Al-Muqattam following clashes between demonstrators, security men

Hundreds of Muslim villagers in Egypts south have attacked Christian-owned stores in search of a girl whose family claims was abducted. The villagers assaulted the stores Tuesday and surrounded two churches in the city of al-Wasta in Bani Suef province in Egypts south. Security forces guarded the churches. No casualties were reported.The college-aged girl disappeared around one month ago. The crowd accused local Christian of kidnapping her.

Arrests: Egyptian security forces arrested a close aide and a cousin of Libyas former dictator Moammar Gadhafi on Tuesday following an hours-long siege of his home in central Cairo Police had surrounded his home in the Cairo neighbourhood of Zamalek before dawn. Shots were fired during the siege, but witnesses gave conflicting reports as to whether Qaddaf al-Dam opened fire in the air to drive police away or police had fired the shots as they tried to storm the building. There were no injuries reported.

Photojournalists protested in front of the Shura Council on Tuesday in reaction to increasing numbers of attacks against media workers in Egypt. Given the recent spate of attacks against journalists covering demonstrations, several Non-Governmental Organisations have condemned the excessive use of force against media personnel.
Railway traffic stops in Sidi Jabir, Alexandria, as citizens demonstrated to protest fuel shortage.
Clashes erupted in the working class neighbourhood of Shubra on Monday night, leaving three dead and 26 injured, according to the Ministry of Health, in a street fight between two families.

A small protest took place in front of the High Court building in Cairo on Tuesday, organised by members of Tawfik Okashas Al-Faraeen television channel and supporters from his hometown. The protesters said they want the Prosecutor General to rescind the six month sentence handed to Okasha in a case regarding an unpaid divorce settlement between him and his ex-wife Reda Al-Qardawy, but they also support Okasha more generally in all his legal cases.Protesters prevented the Daily News Egypt from covering the event, alleging the journalist worked for ""foreign hands"". Last year Tawfik Okasha was accused of insulting the president on 30 separate charges.
Hundreds of bakers block entrance to Egyptian supply ministry on Tuesday to protest government scheme to reduce flour subsidies and penalise violators.

The female students were assaulted by male employees in the dorms. A university employee forcibly removed the veil one female student was wearing. In another incident, six girls were hit by a taxi and had to be taken to a hospital.

Al-Azhar University students are calling for change in student dorms after a week of protesting and marching against poor living conditions in the dorms.Amr Al-Faramawy, the coordinator of Al-Azhar Students Movement, said some of the girls who were holding a hunger strike to push forward their demands were taken to a hospital on Tuesday after their health deteriorated.
A small group of imams protested on Wednesday in front of the Ministry of Endowments against the spreading Muslim Brotherhood influence inside the ministry.
Protesters gathered by Bab Al-Khala Court early Wednesday in support of the 31 detainees who were later released

In Gharbeya, a protest was held on Wednesday against the attack on the office of Deputy Minister of Endowments Sabry Ebada; few were injured in the attack. The protesters stated that about 60 imams affiliated with the Brotherhood attacked Ebadas office for his stances against the Brotherhood.

A group of protesters gathered in front of the military prosecution building in Suez on Wednesday against the dispersal of unemployed demonstrators the evening before in Port Tawfiq. The protesters also demanded the release of six arrested protesters.Personnel from the Third Field Army removed barriers erected by protesters in order to allow trucks to enter Port Tawfiq on Tuesday night so that they could continue loading and unloading ships at the port.

On 21 March 2013, Egyptian witnesses and officials say villagers in Ezbat el-Gindy beat to death a young man after catching him trying to steal a car in a new case of vigilante violence. [size=no report]

Armed Bedouin tribesmen in Egypts Sinai peninsula on Friday kidnapped two tourists, an Israeli man and a Norwegian woman, as they travelled between two beach resorts, police said. Six gunmen intercepted the tourists car and forced them into their truck, the officials said. The pair had been travelling between the resort of Taba, on the border with Israel, and Dahab further south

Egyptian protesters have ransacked an office of the Muslim Brotherhoods political party in the northern coastal city of Alexandria. It was the second such attack on an office of the Islamist group on Friday. The first was in the Cairo neighborhood of Manial. Both attacks happened as opponents and supporters of the Brotherhood clashed near the groups headquarters in Cairo.
Protesters from 6 April Ahmed Maher have surrounded President Mohamed Morsis home in the Fifth Settlement after Friday prayers.

Ahmed Rabei was allegedly attacked by members of FJP as he was leaving the FEP office on Friday. FJP members dragged him and beat him all the way from the FEP office until they arrived at the FJP office where they detained him for three hours, according to Shehab Wagih, spokesperson for FEP.

Egyptian protesters have ransacked an office of the Muslim Brotherhoods political party in the northern coastal city of Alexandria. It was the second such attack on an office of the Islamist group on Friday. The first was in the Cairo neighborhood of Manial. Both attacks happened as opponents and supporters of the Brotherhood clashed near the groups headquarters in Cairo. At least 190 people were injured as bloody clashes erupted Friday between Muslim Brotherhoods (MB) supporters and opponents near the groups headquarters in the Egyptian capital of Cairo and other governorates across Egypt,

Meanwhile, in Manial district of Giza, some anti-MB protesters broke into the headquarters of the groups political arm Freedom and Justice Party (FJP), according to state-run Al-Ahram Online news website. The ground floor of the FJP headquarters was totally smashed including the offices and the furniture, while some demonstrators attempted to set fire to the place until others prevented them.
28 people were injured so far in clashes between pro and anti-Muslim Brotherhood protesters in Cairos Al-Muqattam district and in Al-Sharqiyah governorate.
Similarly, in Gharbiya governorates largest city of Mahalla, anti-MB protesters sit fire to the MB headquarters turning all contents into ashes but no casualties were reported.

The Maspero Youth Union (MYU) confirmed on Saturday that a missing Coptic activist was found at Al-Helal Hospital, with clear signs of torture. Amir Ayad, who is also a member of the fact-finding committee investigating the torture and imprisonment of Copts in Libya, went missing Friday night, a member of the union reported. He was found Saturday morning at Al-Helal Hospital; with signs of flagellation apparent across his body.

Students gathered outside the university gates in the morning to protest the use of violence against them by police forces at a sit-in the day before injuring as many as nine students, according to MIU student Mena Alaa.

A group of villagers killed a mental patient mistaken for a thief Saturday in northern Egypt, state-run news agency MENA reported. Residents of a village near Zagazig town in Sharqiya, about 65 km north of the capital Cairo, chased the man, who they believed was stealing a car, until he jumped into a canal. The villagers pulled him out, killed him and mutilated his body. An investigation later revealed the man was a mental patient on his way to get his monthly medications at a local hospital.

Train services in the south of the country from Cairo to Aswan resumed operations after protestors in the Al-Ayat city in the Giza governorate ended a demonstration that blocked the cities train crossing for more than 11 hours.

Around 200 Islamists blocked Gate 2 of the Egyptian Media Production City (EMPC) on Sunday in protest of what they describe as media bias against Islamists and unfair coverage of the Friday clashes in front of the Muslim Brotherhood headquarters.Several newspapers such as state-owned Al-Ahram reported that their journalists were attacked as they attempted to cover the protest.At the time of print reports from inside EMPC indicated there were clashes between protesters and security forces. A truce was negotiated shortly after.

Dozens of taxi drivers staged a protest on Monday blocking the 6th of October Bridge in Cairo against a new tax and the lack of security in the country. Taxi drivers also called on the government to do something about the low level of security at night on the roads, adding that many of them finish work earlier because the highways become dangerous at night.

When news broke that student Omar Yassin had received a one-month suspension for his participation in demonstrations, the demonstrating students became outraged and attempted to enter the campus, Alaa said.Security forces from an independently contracted security company then began attacking students with rubber bullets and rocks in addition to spraying them with fire extinguishers in an attempt to keep them at bay, student Haleem El-Sharani said. The crowd of students began retaliating in anger against the security forces that in turn fought back as the violence escalated late into the afternoon
Arrests: Opposition lawyer Hamdy Al-Fakharany was arrested on Tuesday near Damanhour for allegedly inciting violence against the Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) headquarters in Al-Gharbeya.

Students gathered outside the university gates in the morning to protest the use of violence against them by police forces at a sit-in the day before injuring as many as nine students, according to MIU student Mena Alaa.
Protesters managed to re-erect road blocks by noon.Protestors have occupied the square since late November when President Mohamed Morsi issued his controversial decre

Scores of Ultras Masrawy members rally outside Real Estate Registry headquarters in Port Said, causing its closure until tomorrow morning. Members requested power of attorney to Armed Forces to run countries affairs, withdraw confidence from President Morsi.

Arrests: Security officials raided Tahrir Square on Wednesday morning, arresting 53 individuals, in an attempt to reopen the area to traffic. The detainees have been taken to the Qasr Al-Nil police station where they await their hearing Wednesday afternoon, said Amr Imam, a human rights lawyer working on the case.

The Egyptian navy on Wednesday foiled three men's attempt to cut an internet cable in the Mediterranean in the northern governorate of Alexandria, state-run Ahram online reported. The naval forces arrested the three men in diving suits on a boat near Shattby beach when they attempted to cut the cable, the report quoted a security source as saying, adding that the three were referred to investigative authorities.

Also on Thursday, in the town of Al-Wasta in the central governorate of Beni Suef, members of the Salafist Nour Party and El-Gamaa El-Salafaya (the Salafist Group) gathered in front of the police station to protest the alleged kidnapping of a 20-year-old Muslim woman who they claim was forced to convert to Christianity

Clashes have broken out between hundreds of locals outside a church in the city of Kom Ombo in Aswan on Thursday, as reports circulated that a 37-year-old Muslim woman had been kidnapped and forced to convert to Christianity. Teargas was being fired by security forces, and there were reports of clashes between Copts who were protecting the church and local Muslims who were throwing rocks.

The Egyptian Popular Current stated on Thursday that security forces have surrounded the groups office in Mansoura, where many injured protesters are sheltering, and are refusing to allow medical aid into the building. According to a Thursday statement by the opposition group, there are dozens of people inside the office suffering from asphyxiation, due to the numerous volleys of teargas fired Wednesday night during clashes at the building.

Egypts state-owned Channel One ran the following urgent caption: ""Reporter of Egyptian television: Partial closure of Tahrir square for traffic.""Following there was another caption: ""Reporter of Egyptian television: Clashes between protestors and drivers of vehicles in Tahrir square.""

Together with Al-Masry, activist Ranwa Youssef was arrested and sexually harassed inside a police station. Photographer Sameh Mashali, a young activist known for documenting clashes, was arrested as well in Alexandria, on the same day but in a different protest. He was beaten first.

Hundreds of protesters on Friday headed to the High Court of Justice in downtown Cairo to protest the prosecutor generals action against several activists. Demonstrators protest arrest of political activists, opposition figures against backdrop of acts of violence at Muslim Brotherhood headquarters in Al-Muqattam
On Friday night in Alexandria, well-known activist Mahienour Al-Masry, together with several others, was arrested after they staged a protest in support for those detained in the latest clashes.

In an impromptu move, 6 April Youth Movement- the group led by Ahmed Maher- surrounded the house of the Minster of Interior Mohamed Ibrahim, in a protest labeled "" a prostitute of all regimes""; in reference to the ministry of interior. Hundreds of the movements members gathered at 1.30 am on Friday holding female undergarments, which they threw at the minsters house, as a sign of political prostitution and subservience to the current government.The protesters chanted against the police and demanded justice for all who were killed in clashes.At time of reporting, the movements Spokesperson Mohamed Adel reported clashes between the protesters and the police, in which teargas and bird-shots were used against ""unarmed"" demonstrators, with at least two members arrested.

In Al-Gharbiyah Governorate, scores of youth, who belong to revolutionary movements, organize demonstrations in Al-Mahallah to protest arrest of activists during Al-Muqattam events. Demonstrators demanded achieving revolution goals, investigation into Al-Muqattam events.
In Suez, activists stage demonstration in Al-Arbain Square to demand sacking general prosecutor.
In Al-Sharqiyah Governorate, members of political parties demonstrate in Al-Zaqaziq city. Security forces tighten presence outside President Morsis house in Al-Zaqaziq.
Clashes between demonstrators take place in Sayyidi Jabir area, Alexandria. Demonstrators hurled stones, Molotov cocktails.
35 ambulances were deployed in riotous governorates; 15 in Cairo s Tahrir Square, 10 in Alexandria and 10 in Gharbiyas city of Tanta

In Alexandria, 12 policemen were injured as 200 people attempted to break into Al-Raml police station after an overnight fight between some Islamist supporters and liberal opponents of President Mohamed Morsi, MENA quoted General Amin Ezz Eddin, assistant interior minister and head of Alexandria police department, as saying. Protesters subsequently deny attacking police station.

Meanwhile, another 10 policemen were injured at Beheiras Wady al-Natron police station as about 150 people hurled stones at the station and attempted to break into it until security men shot in the air and fired teargas bombs to disperse them.

President Mohamed Morsi appeared at the Egyptian Engineering Associations celebrations of Egyptian Engineers Day on Saturday.A few protesters gathered in front of the conference centre rejecting the associations invitation to Morsi, who was an engineer before becoming involved in politics.They held banners accusing Morsi of killing protesters and holding him responsible for deteriorating economic and political situation in the country
The 6 April Youth Movement, led by Ahmed Maher, blocked on Saturday night the doors of the High Court where the public prosecutors office is located, demanding the release of detained members.

Following the arrest of protesters at Al-Raml on Friday night, lawyers in solidarity with the detainees have decided to carry-out a sit in at Al-Raml Prosecution.According to Ahmed El Mansi, all protesters were beaten during the protest and 13 were arrested.
The 6 April Youth Movement claimed on Saturday night that some of their members were attacked during a sit-in outside the prosecutor generals office at the High Court building.
Air traffic completely stopped on Sunday in Alexandrias Borg Al-Arab International Airport, following protests by hundreds of its guards demanding better working conditions and improved salaries.
A family of Bedouins renewed their sit-in on Sunday morning in front of the North Sinai Public Office, demanding that authorities reinstate their Egyptian citizenship.

Shepherd workers continue sit-in for the third day. Dozens of workers at the Shepherd Hotel held a sit-in in front of the hotel building in Downtown Cairo to protest against the hotels managing company EGOS.

Port Said residents protested on Sunday against statements made by the head of the revolutionary victims fund Khaled Badawy, who said that those who died during the latest Port Said clashes are not on the funds list of victims of the revolution.

Protesters staging a sit-in in Tahrir Square were attacked early on Sunday morning. Unknown assailants attacked the square at dawn, burning tents erected by demonstrators, according to state-owned news agency MENA. No serious injuries were reported

State-run Nile News TV said in an ""urgent"" caption at 0810 gmt on 31 March that the fans of the TV satirist, Basim Yusuf, gathered at the High Court to support him as he arrived upon an arrest warrant issued against him on charges of insulting the president and disdaining religion. The TV said that the protesters included members of the opposition 6th April movement.
The cabinet announced the death of Captain Mahmoud Mohamed came one day after the death of Lieutenant Mohamed Raafat Ahmed Mohamed in Aswan after a battle with guns with outlaws.

Shepherd workers continue sit-in for the third day. Dozens of workers at the Shepherd Hotel held a sit-in in front of the hotel building in Downtown Cairo to protest against the hotels managing company EGOS.

Clashes erupted Monday in Egypt when dozens of people attempted to break into a police station, leaving one person killed and another injured. Dozens of people gathered outside the police station in Minya governorate and hurled stones at security personnel and fired shots in the air.
The cabinet announced the death of Captain Mahmoud Mohamed came one day after the death of Lieutenant Mohamed Raafat Ahmed Mohamed in Aswan after a battle with guns with outlaws.
A thief was beaten to death by some villagers in Egypts northern Qalyubiya governorate over an attempt to steal a truck, state-run Al-Ahram Online reported Tuesday.

Shepherd workers continue sit-in for the third day. Dozens of workers at the Shepherd Hotel held a sit-in in front of the hotel building in Downtown Cairo to protest against the hotels managing company EGOS.
Hundreds of butane gas distributers break into Supply Ministry to protest cooking gas price hikes, drop in profit.

Violent clashes broke out on Tuesday between Al-Ismaily football club fans and Central Security Forces (CSF). Several Al-Ismaily fans and CSF personnel were reportedly injured after the match at Air Defence stadium.

Thousands of Mansoura University students demonstrated on Tuesday to protest what they describe as administrative negligence on campus and at the universities hospital, which, they allege, had led to the death of a student, following a car accident.

Students stormed the gates of the Cairo headquarters of Egypts Islamic Al-Azhar University on Tuesday after hundreds suffered food poisoning at a dormitory, security officials said.No violence was reported at the protest, and the state prosecutor has ordered an investigation into the food poisoning.
Security forces recruits organize protest at Shubra al-Khaymah military barracks, claiming mistreatment. Recruits demand transfer of military camp commander, more weapons.

An Egyptian rights group condemned on Wednesday what it described as ""continuous sexual and physical assaults"" on nurses in some hospitals of Port Said. The rights group documented video testimonies of nurses where they described the violations they were subjected to while practicing their jobs. Nurses also detailed narratives of being beaten by relatives of patients, for reasons such as the absence of doctors or accusations of theft.

Amnesty International has received repeated reports of brutal violence used against captives in Sinai, including rape and sexual abuse, beatings, burning and other violent and cruel treatment. The organization is calling on the Egyptian security forces to investigate urgently reports that refugees and asylum-seekers are being held captive in compounds in northeast Sinai.

Dozens of secondary students protested at the Ministry of Education on Wednesday morning, in support of fellow students. Protesters supported student and former detainee Ahmed Taha, who was barred from taking school exami-nations, despite paying fees to do so.

In Sundays protest at Misr International University, students demanded a pedestrians bridge outside the university gate to prevent accidents. Protesting students marched to University Deputy Chariman, Hassans office to put forward their demand. They claim to have been stopped by the security personnel.

The Friday demonstration at Mashiakhet al-Azhar (administration building of al-Azhar) in Cairo was compounded by similar ones in the governorates of Qena, Luxor and Aswan, with the participation of large numbers of Coptics backing al-Tayyeb.

The Friday demonstration at Mashiakhet al-Azhar (administration building of al-Azhar) in Cairo was compounded by similar ones in the governorates of Qena, Luxor and Aswan, with the participation of large numbers of Coptics backing al-Tayyeb.
According to state-owned Al-Ahram, hundreds of demonstrators marched in Mansoura protesting against intervention in Al-Azhars affairs.

Thousands of demonstrators on Friday participated in marches in Cairo, Alexandria and Luxor in support of the independence of al-Azhar and its Grand Imam Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb. Hundreds gathered near al-Azhar Mosque and chanted slogans supporting al-Azhar Grand Sheikh and opposing the Muslim Brotherhood.

Thousands of demonstrators on Friday participated in marches in Cairo, Alexandria and Luxor in support of the independence of al-Azhar and its Grand Imam Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb. In Luxor, hometown of al-Tayeb, demonstrators gathered at Abul Hoggag Square behind Luxor Temple to express their support for al-Tayeb.

Thousands of demonstrators on Friday participated in marches in Cairo, Alexandria and Luxor in support of the independence of al-Azhar and its Grand Imam Sheikh Ahmed al-Tayeb. A march grouping scores of demonstrators took off from Alexandrias al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to support al-Azhar Sheikh against what they called attempts to thwart al-Tayeb and pave the way for the ""Brother-hoodisation"" of al-Azhar,

Anti-Mursi protesters in Alexandria clashed with unknown persons in Somouhas Victor Emmanuel Square on Friday. Central security forces tear-gassed both parties to disperse them metres away from Alexandrias security directory.

Head of Irans Interests Section in Egypt Mojtaba Amani said the few protesters who attacked his residence in Cairo are backed by countries which are against the growing relations between Iran and Egypt. A crowd of protesters attacked the residence of Amani in a Cairo suburb reportedly in protest at the warming relations between the two countries. The crowd staged the protest in front of Amanis residence on Friday [5 April] and tried to scale the walls and break into the building, but was blocked by the police.
Live two-way from Tanta with Nile TV correspondent; He says complete calm observed since yesterdays protest after 6 April Movement decided to move protests from Tanta to Al-Mahallah.

Fighting flared on Friday night in Al-Khusus, in Qalyubia governorate. An argument escalated into a gun battle with assault rifles between the Muslims and the Christians.""Five people were killed in the clashes, including four Christians. In addition to this, six others were wounded, at least two of whom were suffering gunshot wounds,"" a security official said. The death toll from recent sectarian violence in the village of Al-Khosous north of Cairo has risen to six, Al-Ahrams Arabic-language news website reported on Thursday. Report from Xinhua suggests 7 dead.

Protesters battled police in several Egyptian cities on Saturday, with at least eight people reported injured, after rallies to mark the anniversary of a key opposition movement turned violent. At least eight people were wounded in the clashes in Cairo and in the southern province of Fayoum, the official MENA news agency reported.

Protesters battled police in several Egyptian cities on Saturday, with at least eight people reported injured, after rallies to mark the anniversary of a key opposition movement turned violent. Police also fired tear gas at protesters in the coastal city of Alexandria and in the Nile Delta city of Mahalla, where demonstrators attacked a police station with petrol bombs, MENA reported.

Protesters battled police in several Egyptian cities on Saturday, with at least eight people reported injured, after rallies to mark the anniversary of a key opposition movement turned violent. In central Cairo, live television showed footage of protesters throwing stones at police in armoured vehicles, amid burning tyres on a main road near the court. The police fired heavy volleys of tear gas.

Protesters battled police in several Egyptian cities on Saturday, with at least eight people reported injured, after rallies to mark the anniversary of a key opposition movement turned violent. Police also fired tear gas at protesters in the coastal city of Alexandria and in the Nile Delta city of Mahalla, where demonstrators attacked a police station with petrol bombs, MENA reported.

In Sharqeya, skirmishes between protesters and security forces broke out after protesters advanced towards President Mohamed Morsis home. Protesters chanted against the Brotherhood and the president and were met with teargas.
Live two-way from Al-Mansurah with Nile TV correspondent to discuss protests, developments there.

Approximately 60 students at the Al-Azhar College for Girls in Assiut protested against the administration on Sunday for the way it has handled an investigation, in which a female student is facing an investigation for being a Shia. The protesting students object to the practice of Shiism.
A small number of protesters gathered outside the court in Alexandria, in a show of solidarity with workers at the Alexandria Container Holding company, whose trial was postponed until 16 June.

The Freedom and Justice Partys legal advisers office in Damietta was torched in the late hours of Sunday. Legal adviser for the party in Damietta Yasser Dawoud alleged the office was torched by members of the 6 April and Revolutionary Socialists movements. Dawoud said around 100 people, including 20 ""thugs"", were responsible for setting fire to the office. The 6 April Youth Movement in Damietta rejected Dawouds accusation.

Violence erupted again on Sunday outside St. Marks Coptic Cathedral in Cairos Abbasiya district, during a funeral procession for the four Christians killed in Al-Khosous. Police fired teargas to disperse the crowds and stop the violence. Two people were killed and almost 90 injured in the melee, state news agency MENA reported.
Ministry of Health stated on 7/4/2013 that 24 persons were injured due to violence that took place in Cairo, Fayoum and Gharbia governorates, confirming that there are no deaths.
Ministry of Health stated on 7/4/2013 that 24 persons were injured due to violence that took place in Cairo, Fayoum and Gharbia governorates, confirming that there are no deaths.
Ministry of Health stated on 7/4/2013 that 24 persons were injured due to violence that took place in Cairo, Fayoum and Gharbia governorates, confirming that there are no deaths.

A group of journalists along with sympathisers staged a protest in front of Al-Tahrir newspapers office today for not being hired along with 30 of their colleagues. Protesters chanted slogans against Ibrahim Eissa and the newspapers administration. Mona Selim, one of the protesters, said that only 30 journalists were hired instead of 50 and that the standards for hiring were not clear.

Strike:A strike by railway drivers reached its second day on Monday, as drivers and authorities traded accusations on the responsibility for the strike.All main lines in northern and Upper Egypt are on hold, the suburban trains from Ain Shams to Suez, from Cairo to Manfalout and from Fayoum to Al-Wasata were functional on Monday.

Health, Population Ministry announces one killed, 14 injured in clashes outside Mary Gerges Church in Al-Khusus, Al-Qalyubiyah governorate, north of Cairo. State of cautious calm reported in Al-Khusus, with heavy security forces deployed in city.
Protesters this afternoon cut off Ramsis Street near Abassiyas Saint Marks Coptic Orthodox Cathedral amid cautious calm and heavy security, reported the state news agency.

Clashes erupted at Mansoura University after students were attacked during a sit-in calling for the dismissal of the university president, Al-Sayed Abdel Khaleq, and new investigations into the case of the dead student who was run over by a professor driving a car last Monday. Protesters were attacked with rocks and rubber bullets in attempts to breach the crowd that was blocking access to the administration building. Some claimed the attackers were students who were used by the university administration to disperse the sit-in.

Hundreds of protesters rallied in downtown Cairo to the Saint Mark Coptic Orthodox Cathedral on Tuesday to protest the sectarian clashes that happened over the week, chanting for unity. The demonstrations purpose is to protest this recent wave of violence, demand the sacking of the interior minister and call for the punishment of those responsible for the incident.

Dozens of lawyers protested outside the General Lawyers Syndicate on Tuesday, angered by the Ministry of Interiors use of force against lawyers and protesters. Police forces allegedly chased protesters into the syndicate headquarters. The protest condemned policemens repeated attacks on lawyers inside police stations.
Tens of activists organized a demonstration by the Journalists Syndicate on Wednesday in solidarity with train staff who began a strike on Sunday.
Strike:Around 40 port guards also went on strike in the Nuweiba port, protesting a decision to move them to a different port.
Dozens of Salafis protested on Tuesday in the Al-Hadra district of Alexandria against the Shia doctrine.

Alexandria police chief, security leadership negotiate with protestors in Burj al-Arab airport to convince them to end protest. Officers who tried to return airport functions back to normal were earlier expelled by protestors.

Scores of school children organize march in northern Cairo under banner ""For Love of Egypt,"" demand all forces, political parties to work together for Egypts interests, end to violent demonstrations that harm Egypt.

Scores of supply department inspectors in Al-Buhayrah Governorate continue to protest for third day, demanding dismissal of Supply, Internal Trade Ministrys undersecretary, department heads following death of two inspectors. Hundreds protested outside supply department headquarters in Damanhur.
Demonstrators on Friday staged protests at Kasr ElDobara Church in Cairo and St. Mary Church in Imbaba in solidarity with Copts and in support of national unity.

Demonstrators on Friday staged protests at Kasr ElDobara Church in Cairo and St. Mary Church in Imbaba in solidarity with Copts and in support of national unity. In Imbaba, members of the April 6 Youth movement organised a march at St. Mary Church which was torched by Salafi protesters in 2011.

Clashes broke out on Friday afternoon between supporters and opponents of the Muslim Brotherhood in Alexandrias Victor Emmanuel Square as both parties exchanged stones. As anti-brotherhood demonstrators arrived in Victor Emmanuel Square, they were met by Muslim Brotherhood supporters hurling stones and empty bottles at them .
In Cairo, protesters clashed with police in front of the presidential palace after police responded to rock-throwing by using teargas.
Hundreds of protesters on Friday marched from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque in Alexandria to the cities Northern military area to demand army intervention against President Mohamed Mursis rule.

Arrests: Security forces allegedly broke into the apartment of five political activists who were in Alexandria to attend Hassan Mustafas trial, arresting two men, Mohamed Al-Belbeesy and Mohamed Al-Torky.

Students at the German University in Cairo (GUC) gathered at the university campus on Sunday to protest against the administration following its decision to increase tuition fees. The students blocked the entrance to the financial affairs office.

Clashes broke out between students and thugs on Ain Shams University campus in Cairo Sunday following a march held by students to the university headquarters in the afternoon. Students are lobbying for tighter on-campus security as well as an end to thuggery after having been attacked by unknown assailants several times. The assailants obstructed the student march, pelting it with rocks and glass.

Dozens of low-ranking policeman at the Borg Al-Arab International Airport staged protests against suspending ten of their colleagues and issuing a decision to transfer them to the Marsa Matrouh Airport on Sunday. The protesters also demanded the return of police officers to their work after the police officers had handed over a mass resignation to the interior minister over allegedly being insulted in a previous confrontation with the low-ranking security staff.

Approximately 2,000 workers in the port town Damietta marched from the Chamber of Commerce building to the office of the governor to express their anger against rising prices. Abu Samra said that 6 April marched in solidarity with the carpenters and upholsterers, adding that ""the economic situation in Egypt has caused many problems for these people"".

The stagecoach driver strike taking place in front of the Karnak temple in Luxor has officially ended after officers heard the demands of those striking and promised to find ways to address their problems, announced Luxors Tourist Police. The strike started early on Sunday morning when drivers blocked the roads leading to the temple, protesting what they described as unfair practices by tourist companies favouring some drivers over others.

April 6 Youth Movement has condemned the security forces for breaking up its sit-in outside the Shura Council (Egypts upper house of parliament) early on Monday morning. The youth group began the sit-in on Sunday to call for the release of fellow members detained at an earlier protest. Security forces acted after the group refused to move away from the vicinity of the cabinet building,

Egypts Interior Ministry says gunmen have opened fire on a security convoy in central Sinai, killing a police lieutenant and seriously injuring another policeman before fleeing. The ministry said in a statement on its official webpage that a patrol in the Nekhel area in the center of the desert peninsula was attacked by an unknown number of gunmen Tuesday.
Clashes broke out again at Ain Shams University on Tuesday, drawing civilian and military police forces to campus to stop the fighting.

Protesters gathered outside the Saudi embassy in Giza on Wednesday to mark one year since the arrest of Egyptian lawyer Ahmed Al-Gizawy by Saudi security forces. Al-Gizawy was sentenced to five years in prison and 300 lashes by the General Court of Jeddah in Saudi Arabia in January. He was accused of drug trafficking.

The protest followed a march that began at Cairo University around noon. The march was organised by political movements who announced solidarity with the imprisoned lawyer. They included the Kefaya movement, 6 April Youth Movement (democratic front), Ikhwan Kazeboon movement and the Revolutionary Front for Peaceful Change.
Also, anti-Islamist protests were launched in some other governorates including Alexandria, Sharqiya and Daqahliya, where similar skirmishes took place.
Hundreds of the Muslim Brotherhood members and supporters had gathered at Asr al-Islam Mosque in Al-exandrias Sidi Gaber to take part in mass demonstrations the brotherhood had called for earlier.

Supporters and opponents of the Muslim Brotherhood clashed at the High Judicial Council in Cairos Ramses Street. The two parties exchanged stones near Abdel Moneim Riad Square and below October 6 Bridge.

Supporters of the Muslim Brotherhood on Friday clashed with opponents of the group in front of the brotherhoods administrative headquarters in Alexandrias Somouha, Aswat Masriya correspondent reported. Scores were wounded in the clashes and a Middle East News Agency reporter was injured by birdshots.

Members of the 6 April Democratic Front were gathering outside a court in the Fifth Settlement to show solidarity with, Abdelrahman Mohsen, who was arrested early on Friday morning along with four other men, following dawn raids by police.

Journalists covering the clashes were themselves attacked by demonstrators and at least five were injured. Both Muslim Brotherhood supporters and members of the anti-Morsi ""Black Bloc"" counter-demonstration attacked journalists.

Similar events occurred in Alexandria, where at least six journalists were attacked. In most cases, they were attacked while filming. Equipment and recordings were destroyed, leaving no doubt about the targeted na-ture of the attacks.
Also, anti-Islamist protests were launched in some other governorates including Alexandria, Sharqiya and Daqahliya, where similar skirmishes took place.

Amid a heavy security presence, around 10 protesters gathered Saturday in front of the Qatari Embassy located in Gizas Dokki district to protest what they described as the Gulf countries ""meddling"" in Egyptian affairs.The protesters later burned both the Qatari and Israeli flags.

Hundreds of residents of the city of Minya Al-Qamh in Egypts Sharqiya Governorate blocked the Cairo-Zagazig highway as well as the cities railway line Sunday morning to protest a perceived security vacuum, Ahrams Arabic news website reported. Gunshots were heard during the protest. Angry protesters also set tires ablaze and placed wooden slats on railway tracks, which in turn brought traffic and train movement to a complete halt.

Dozens of State Radio and Television Union employees staged protests on Sunday outside the Maspiro building (State TV building) to demand sacking information minister Salah Abdel Maqsoud. The protesters said that the ministers position is unconstitutional, as the radio and television are independ-ent from the ministry according to the constitutions text.

Arrests: Egyptian security forces in North Sinai uncovered an Israeli spy network operating in the peninsula, apprehending its ring leader. A security source within the North Sinai Security Directorate, who chose to remain anonymous, said that Egyptian intelligence had uncovered an Israeli spying ring that consisted of Egyptians and Palestinians, with security forces arresting the ringleader.

A group of taxi drivers blocked the 6th of October Bridge on Monday protesting what they claim to be unjust consequences from the governments ""white taxi"" project. The protesters are demanding that the Ministry of Finance cancels the rest of the instalments they are required to pay and cancel the tax hikes that increased from EGP 50 to EGP 280.

Clashes took place between supporters and opponents of Hamdeen Sabahy during a seminar in the Faculty of Engineering at Banha University in Shubra on Monday.Islamist students chanted against Sabahy and asked him to leave; supporters of Sabahy responded by chanting against the Muslim Brotherhood and President Mohamed Morsis regime, which led to clashes between the two parties.

Hundreds of lawyers staged protests on Tuesday outside a Cairo court to defend the independence of judiciary against the attacks it is being subject to. The lawyers gathered in objection to a judicial authority draft law, currently being discussed by Egypts Shura Council (upper house of the parliament).

Dozens of students gathered outside the High Court building on Tuesday afternoon, calling for the release of student Mahmoud Safwat and others who were detained last weekend. The students marched from Cairo University and Helwan University to the High Court building in Downtown Cairo chanting against the Ministry of the Interior and the Muslim Brotherhood.Friends claim Safwat was arrested on Friday morning and was one of 22 people for whom Prosecutor General Talaat Abdallah issued an arrest warrant for alleged connections to the Black Bloc.

A group of students protested in front of the faculty of Mass Communication at Cairo University against Information Minister Salah Abdel Maqsoud. Students chanted against the minister, the Muslim Brotherhood and President Mohamed Morsi. They demanded the removal of the minister, calling him ""a disgrace"". The protest ended as soon as the students were informed the minister would not be attending the conference.

Dozens of students and NGO members protested on Wednesday at the ministry of education against the recent increase in incidents of violence against school students.Protesters gathered at the ministries main gate, holding several signs and chanting against the minister of education, President Mohamed Morsi, and the Muslim Brotherhood. Protesters wrote slogans expressing their demands on the walls of the ministry.The demands included dismissing the minister of education, subjecting schools to regular ministerial in-spections, and taking legal action against teachers who violate the rights of the students rather than ordinary suspensions by the ministry of education.

General Federation of Trade Unions organizes demonstration heading from Syndicate of Journalists to Supreme Court in support of judges. Protestors expressed support for judiciary, army, police against what they call attempts by Muslim Brotherhood to control institutions.

Revolutionary movements in Suez staged a protest Thursday demanding retribution for soldiers killed in Rafah last month. The protest was staged by April 6 Youth, revolutionary socialists, and Popular Current. They also demanded the government pay more attention to Sinai and its development.

Nile News correspondent in Al-Sharqiyah Governorate says Ultras supporters demonstrated outside President Morsis home in Al-Zaqaziq. Demonstrators chanted anti-government slogans. She says demonstrators clashed with police near Governorate building.

Students from the Al-Azhar University protested on Saturday in Nasr City against the university management. The students hold the university responsible for the death of an engineering student, Ahmed El-Baz, who died in the university clinic.

A Christian housewife and her three children were stabbed to death in their house in a village in Suhaj. The woman's husband accused a Christian worker in the Suhaj village of Al-Kushah of being behind the murder over disputes.

An Egyptian security official and a priest say police fired tear gas and clashed with a stone-throwing mob of Muslims who had surrounded a Coptic Church in anger over an inter-faith romance. The alleged romance ignited sectarian tension in Wasta, a rural town in Beni Suef province, about 95 kilo-meters (60 miles) south of Cairo. Clashes flared anew on Friday after weekly Muslim prayers.For more than a month, Muslims have attacked churches over the incident and forced Christians to close their shops in the town.

Scores of demonstrators on Friday demonstrated at the High Court of Justice in Cairos downtown to declare their support for the independence of the judiciary. The demonstrators marched from Tahrir Square to the court of justice to support the judges.

Hundreds of activists and demonstrators on Friday marched in Alexandria from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the Judges Club to denounce what they called the attempt to brotherhoodise the judiciary and the state. They also demanded holding those responsible for assaulting peaceful demonstrators and kidnapping activists accountable.The demonstrators chanted slogans against the Muslim Brotherhood and President Mohamed Mursi.

In Gharbiya, thousands rallied in Tantas al-Sayed al-Badawi Square to take part in a demonstration calling for supporting the judiciary, the army, the police and al-Azhar. The demonstrators chanted pro-army and anti-Brotherhood slogans and called on the army to take to the streets.

Around 100 demonstrators participated in bicycle ride from Kit-Kat to Abdeen Palace, in a display of solidarity with imprisoned activists. The bicycle ride was organised and led by the 6 April Youth Movement (Democratic Front).

Violent clashes erupted near the Presidential Palace on Friday evening between dozens of protesters and security forces. The protesters were dispersed using teargas bombs. It is still unclear what initially triggered the violence.

Egyptian police arrested 12 members of the ""Black Bloc"" after clashes outside Cairos presidential palace, the official MENA news agency said on Saturday. Protesters hurled rocks and fire bombs at the walls of the presidential palace in Heliopolis, and torched a police vehicle, a security source told MENA.

A group of Egyptian youth living in the border regions of the Sinai Peninsula recently blocked the Al-Arish - Rafah road near the Al-Rayesa checkpoint,south of the city of Al-Arish, preventing trucks carrying building materials headed for the Gaza Strip from passing. Saeedd Iatayeq, from the Al-Sawarka tribe, said the road was blocked to send a message to Hamas and the Muslim Brotherhood that no political faction could monopolise business and commerce in the region,
The National Salvation Front (NSF) Youth Movement held a protest on Saturday against Giza Governor Aly Abdel Rahman, claiming that he was appointed because he is a member of the Muslim Brotherhood.

Scores of residents of Al-Duweiqa in Cairo governorate protested outside state media building Maspero on Sunday. The residents demanded that the government assist them in obtaining the ownership of their apartments. Scores of women also gathered at Maspero to protest against the Minister of Information Salah Abdel Maqsoud. Several Egyptian women's movements called for a demonstration in protest at Abdel Maqsouds remarks to a female journalist on Thursday in a press conference.

Hundreds of students rallied demanding ""student rights"" outside the administration of Alexandria University on Sunday. Violent clashes have been reported from several universities, including Ain Shams and Alexandria. Alexandria also reported a crackdown on students protesting.

Students across Egypt took to the streets on Sunday in protest at the aggressive handling of student movements by security forces and university staff, as well as the gross neglect of students needs by universities. Violent clashes have been reported from several universities, including Ain Shams and Alexandria. In Ain Shams, the protest turned violent after security forces arrived and tried to expel the students from the area.

Members from the 6 April Youth Movement publicly called for the release of detainees in a demonstration on the front steps of the Press Syndicate.Activists chanted the names of the detainees and those who had been arrested or killed in the past.
Students at Assiut University held a protest on Monday denouncing a road accident which led to the death of four faculty members.
Police exchanged fire with the occupants of a stolen car. A bullet hit a nearby building and another struck a church wall
Protesters rallied in front of Beheiras security directory to demand revealing the detention place of activist Ahmed Douma
Protesters marched from Sayeda Zeinab Square to Tahrir Square on labour day to protest labour reform
In Alexandrias Egypt Station Square, workers formed human chains to protest against poor workplace conditions.
Hundreds of Salafist Islamists protested outside the Egyptian National Security Agencys headquarters in Cairo
The son of Freedom and Justice Party (FJP) secretary was killed after shooting two people in a fight.
Egyptian police fired tear gas to disperse opposition demonstrators hurling rocks and firebombs near Cairos Tahrir Square. Protestors marched to Supreme Court, clashed with street vendors
Residents blocked the Cairo-Alexandria road from both directions in protest against the kidnapping of a girl.
Hundreds of protesters and activists in Alexandria marched from al-Qaed Ibrahim Mosque to the city council to demand sacking governor Mohamed Atta Abbas and his deputy Hassan al-Brens.

Hilwan Workers Solidarity Committee organizes protest in Martyrs Square, demands workers rights. Protest participants include labor leaders from Iron, Steel Complex, other factories, companies, political parties
Protestors in Suhaj dispersed following threats from security forces to remove them by force.
Dozens of protesters demonstrated in front of the High Court building against the arrest of seven youth near the Fifth Settlement Court
Clashes broke out between members of the Muslim Brotherhood and protesters from the opposition, leaving four people injured
Armed men fired at a police checkpoint at the entrance to the port of Al-Arish. Police fired back and injured one man, apprehending the rest.
Workers from a cement factory in Aswan, Upper Egypt, were attacked by security personnel from the factory
One man was wounded and later died in a firefight between the security detail of Egyptian Prime Minister and alleged thugs. The security service said the incident was not political in nature
4 Islamist gunmen shot dead a man selling alcohol in Egypts Sinai peninsula
Four members of the Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby (Popular Current) and 6 April Democratic Front, including two women, were arrested during a protest by the Presidential Palace
An open-ended sit-in organised by students began on Tuesday outside the El Shorouk Academy in Cairo.
Dozens of people in Egypt attempted to capture and lynch a man who allegedly raped and killed a 7-year-old girl

column16: Al Arabiya; Egyptian Organization for Human Rights
column17: A police officer attacked a man filing a complaint in Shobra Thani police station

Arrests: Second Field Army forces arrested on Thursday [5 September] Muslim Brotherhood leader, who is accused of inciting an attack on Bir al-Abd police station in Al-Arish in North Sinai and robbing its weapons.
An American was stabbed in the neck as he came out of the US embassy in central Cairo
A small demonstration was held outside the High Court
Weapons Seizure: Armed Forces units confiscate large arms cache in South Sinai Governorate
Unknown assailants attack Ministry of Interior with Molotov cocktails and stones. Security forces fired tear gas to disperse the rioters.
April 6 Calls for Rallying to Protest Activist Detention
Islamist powers will stage a million-man demonstration at al-Azhar Mosque to express their support for Jerusalem and protest against Israeli violations and the siege of al-Aqsa Mosque.
Arrests: Authorities at Cairo International Airport detained political activist Ahmed Maher, a founding member of the ""April 6"" movement, upon his arrival from the United States of America
Members of the 6 April Democratic Front march to the Giza security directorate to demand the release of two men associated with the group.
Members of the 6 April Youth Movement gathered outside the high court in central Cairo demonstrating for the release of detained activists.

Members of the Popular Front for the Suez Canal Axis (PFSCA) gathered outside the Press Syndicate to protest the law submitted to the Shura Council by the government for developing the Suez Canal region

""Martyrs"" family members gather outside Police Academy chanting slogans demanding execution of former president, former interior minister. Mubarak supporters gather carrying banners, chanting slogans. Security forces deployed to separate two sides
Residents of the Al-Duweiqa neighbourhood demonstrated outside the state media building in Maspero
The 6 April Democratic Front began a sit-in, in front of the Presidential Palace in solidarity with two men who are in prison awaiting questioning

Around a thousand workers gathered at the main headquarters of the North Cairo Electricity Distribution Company to protest monthly pay cheques. Security forces attempted to stop the protests, arresting 15 of the workers
A Muslim mob stormed the village church of Prince Tadros el-Mashreki and assaulted a person inside. They hurled stones and broke everything inside the church, including doors and windows
One police officer died and another injured during an operation by Special Forces to arrest several outlaws in Port Said. The outlaw was also killed.
Members of local cultural/intellectual community march from Cairo Opera House to newly-appointed ministers office to protest alleged Brotherhoodisation of Egyptian culture
Petrojet workers clashed with the company security forces. Rocks were thrown and workers were hosed with water

column7: Military Forces of Egypt (2012-2013) Border Guards
column17: Masked gunmen ambushed two taxis at gunpoint outside the city of el-Arish, fleeing with five policemen and one border guard captive. None of those abducted were in uniform. (Suspects believed to be Islamist militants)
The Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby (Popular Current) is holding several marches on Thursday to commemorate Mohamed El-Gendy and Amr Saad, Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby members who were killed a few months ago
The Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby (Popular Current) is holding several marches on Thursday to commemorate Mohamed El-Gendy and Amr Saad, Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby members who were killed a few months ago

The Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby (Popular Current) is holding several marches on Thursday to commemorate Mohamed El-Gendy and Amr Saad, Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby members who were killed a few months ago
The Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby (Popular Current) is holding several marches on Thursday to commemorate Mohamed El-Gendy and Amr Saad, Al-Tayar Al-Shaaby members who were killed a few months ago
Anti-government protests occurred in Al-Mahalla
March planned under Sufi orders following Friday prayers from Sayeda Zeinab to Tahrir Square
The Al-Dostour Party announced that it would hold two marches against the newly approved tax law and Morsis economic policies.
Opposition groups marched from Mostafa Mahmoud Mosque towards Tahrir Square to raise awareness for Tamarod
In Alexandria people took to the streets to denounce the rule of President Mohamed Morsi, calling for early presidential elections.
Protesters gathered in Martyrs Square to collect signatures from drivers. The protesters also chanted against the development of the Suez Canal Project.
Marches are planned from Tahrir Square to the Ministry of Justice demanding the release of political prisoners, planned by the ""Revolutionary Ultras""
Workers at North Cairo Electricity Distribution Company (NCEDC) have held for the fifth day in row a sit-in demanding the release of 17 of their colleagues who are currently under arrest.
Tens of activists and political party members organize protest in Al-Zaqaziq governorate outside President Morsis re
Non-violent activity: Interior Ministry, in coordination with tribal leaders, activates fire arms initiative in Matruh. Police Department receives 155 unlicensed fire arms from citizens
Egyptian police closed the Rafah border crossing with Gaza in protest at the kidnapping of colleagues in the Sinai peninsula
A feud between Christians and Muslims in Alexandria leaves one dead and dozens wounded. Molotov cocktails and automatic weapons were used.
Egyptian security forces have fired tear gas at protesters hurling firebombs at them in central Cairo, hours after hundreds of opponents of Egypts President Mohammed Morsi rallied peacefully
Egyptian police closed the Rafah border crossing with Gaza in protest at the kidnapping of colleagues in the Sinai peninsula for the 2nd day
The Rafah crossing point between the Gaza Strip and Egypt has been closed for the third day
Soldiers close down Al-Awjah Crossing in solidarity with colleagues who closed Rafah Crossing following kidnapping of soldiers
Unknown assailants opened fire at a central security forces camp in Rafahs al-Ahrash but there were no casualties

Demonstrators chanted slogans outside the defense ministry, supporting Defense Minister Abdel Fattah al-Sisi and condemning President Mohamed Morsy.

Four people were killed and five were injured in clashes that broke out between deposed president Mohamed Mursis supporters and opponents in Matrouh governorate. Police and army forces intervened to break up the clashes. Another 10 people were injured after the group of armed supporters stormed the cities security headquarters.
Egypts police arrested six men who opened fire on a march staged by President Mohamed Mursis opponents in Shorouk City. 3 people injured.

61 protesters and 2 officers were killed outside the Egyptian military headquarters when supporters of ousted President Mohammed Morsi demonstrated near the Republican Guard building in Cairo. Some protesters threw stones and Molotov cocktails and a few used firearms.
